'Do you not find it strange,' Poirot questioned, 'that these strangers arrived without a weapon, gloves, or a shovel, and yet conveniently found all these items?' Giraud smirked with a sense of superiority. 'Indeed, it is odd. Without the theory that I hold, it would be inexplicable.' 'Aha!' M. Hautet exclaimed. 'An accomplice. An accomplice within the residence!' 'Or outside,' Giraud added with a sly smile. 'But someone must have let them in, right? We cannot imagine that, through pure luck, they found the door open for them to enter.' 'Agreed, M. Judge. The door was opened for them, but it could have been done from outside by someone with a key.' 'But who had a key?' Giraud shrugged. 'No one with a key would readily admit it. But several individuals could have had access. M. Jack Renauld, the son, for example. Despite his journey to South America, he might have lost or had his key stolen. Then there's the long-serving gardener. A young servant could have a lover. It's simple to make a key impression and have one copied. There are many possibilities. However, there is one person who seems most likely to possess such a key.' 'Who might that be?' 'Madame Daubreuil,' the detective dryly replied. 'Eh, eh!' M. Hautet's expression fell slightly. 'So you're aware of that, are you?' 'I'm aware of everything,' Giraud coolly stated."

I never even spoke to the woman. But you? You had a reason to kill her and your past doesn't help your case. You're a thief, remember that. But here's the thing you don't know. I have the diamonds. Watch this." In one swift motion, he stooped, raised his arm, and threw. The sound of shattering glass echoed as the object flew through the window into the fiery mass outside. "There goes your chance to prove your innocence in the Kimberley case. Now, let's talk. I have a proposition for you. I'm trapped here. Race will find what he needs in this house. If I can escape, I might have a chance. If I stay, we're both doomed, young man! There's a skylight in the next room. Give me a head start, and I'll leave you a signed confession admitting I killed Nadina." "Yes, Harry," I exclaimed. "Yes, yes, yes!" He gave me a stern look. "No, Anne, never. You don't know what you're saying." "I do. It solves everything." "I can't face Race if I do that. I'll take my chances, but I won't let this sly old fox get away. It's no use, Anne. I won't do it." Sir Eustace chuckled, accepting his defeat calmly. "You've met your match, Anne. Moral righteousness doesn't always win." Footsteps thundered up the stairs as Harry unlocked the door. Colonel Race burst into the room, relieved to see us. "You're safe, Anne. I was worried," he said, turning to Sir Eustace. "I've been chasing you for a while, Pedler, and now I've caught you." "Everyone seems to be losing their minds," Sir Eustace remarked casually. "These young ones threatened me with guns and accused me of all sorts of things. I have no idea what's going on." "Don't you? It means I've found the 'Colonel.' It means on January 8th, you were in Marlow, not Cannes. It means you planned to eliminate Nadina when she turned on you, and now we can finally pin the crime on you," Colonel Race explained. "Really? And who told you all this? The man the police are still looking for? His testimony should be valuable." "We have other evidence. Someone else knew Nadina was meeting you at the Mill House," Colonel Race added, gesturing for Arthur Minks to step forward. "I saw Nadina in Paris the night before she went to England. She told me of her plans. I warned her about you, but she didn't listen. I read a wireless message on the table and decided to go after the diamonds myself. Mr. Rayburn convinced me to switch sides in Johannesburg," Minks confessed. Sir Eustace glanced at him, causing Minks to falter. "Rats desert a sinking ship," Sir Eustace commented. "I detest rats. Vermin must be exterminated sooner or later." "There's one thing you should know, Sir Eustace," I interjected. "The tin you threw out the window didn't have the diamonds. It contained pebbles. The diamonds are safe in the giraffe's stomach. Suzanne hid them there with cotton wool to keep them quiet," I revealed. Sir Eustace stared at me before saying, "I always despised that giraffe. It must have been instinct." We couldn't head back to Johannesburg that night. The shelling was intense, and we were nearly cut off due to the rebels' advancements in the suburbs. We sought refuge at a farm about twenty miles from Johannesburg, exhausted from the recent events. The anticipation of a peaceful future with Harry, free from danger, filled me with relief. But a subtle tension lingered between us, hinting at unspoken truths.

"I sensed a light touch on my arm. Poirot stood beside me. “Shall we make a discreet exit, my friend? I believe our services are no longer required.” Once outside, Poirot paused, then surprisingly remarked, “I would like to see the neighboring room.” The door was open, and we entered. The room, a large double one, was empty. Dust was visible, and Poirot made a face as he ran his finger along a rectangular mark on a table by the window. “The cleaning leaves much to be desired,” he dryly observed. Standing by the window lost in thought, he seemed deep in contemplation. “Well?” I impatiently inquired. “Why did we come in here?” He snapped out of his reverie. “Excuse me, my friend. I wanted to check if the door was bolted on this side as well.” “It is,” I confirmed, glancing at the door connecting to the previous room. Poirot nodded. “And, in any case,” I added, “why does it matter? The case is closed. I wish you had more opportunities to shine. But even an incompetent inspector could not have failed on this case.” Poirot shook his head. “The case is not closed, my friend. It will only be closed once we uncover the thief behind the pearl theft.” “But the maid did it!” “How do you know?” “Because the pearls were found in her mattress.” “Tsk, tsk, tsk!” Poirot impatiently dismissed. “Those were not the real pearls.” “What?” “Imitations, my friend.” This revelation left me speechless. Poirot smiled calmly. “The inspector clearly knows nothing about jewels. But there will be quite a commotion soon!” “Come!” I urged, pulling at his arm. “Where to?” “We must inform the Opalsens immediately.” “I don’t think so.” “But that poor woman” “Well; that poor woman, as you call her, will have a more peaceful night believing her jewels are safe.” “But what if the thief escapes with them?” “As always, my friend, you speak without thinking. How can you be sure that the pearls Mrs. Opalsen secured so carefully tonight were not the fake ones, and that the real theft happened much earlier?” “Oh!” I exclaimed, bewildered. “Exactly,” Poirot beamed. “We start anew.” He led the way out of the room, pausing briefly before heading down the corridor to a small den where the staff from different floors gathered. Our chambermaid was holding court, sharing her recent experiences. Poirot interrupted politely. “Excuse me, but could you unlock Mr. Opalsen’s room for me?” The chambermaid obliged, and we entered Mr. Opalsen’s room, which faced his wife’s room across the corridor. Poirot asked the chambermaid if she had ever seen a card like the one he presented. She had not. Poirot then signaled for me to ring the bell for the valet. As he questioned the valet and showed him the card, it became clear that neither of them had seen such a card among Mr. Opalsen’s possessions. Poirot, still thoughtful, muttered, “And the necklace was heavily insured...”

As he performed the act, half of the spectators erupted in loud barks of "Woof, woof!" possibly a Dutch equivalent to "Hear, hear," while the other half jolted awake from their peaceful slumber. I was informed that the man had been talking non-stop for a staggering three days. It appears patience is a virtue in South Africa. I concocted numerous reasons to detain Pagett in Cape Town, but my creativity has finally reached its limit. Tomorrow, he will accompany me with the loyalty of a faithful dog ready to meet his end by his master's side.

She was a stranger to the London crowd. The images of the Marlow victim in the newspapers were so distorted that it's no surprise no one could recognize them. On the flip side, Nadina had concealed her plans to visit England from everyone. The day following the homicide, her manager received a letter supposedly from the dancer, stating she was rushing back to Russia due to urgent personal matters and he should handle her terminated contract as he saw fit. I only found out about all of this later. With Suzanne's complete agreement, I dispatched a lengthy telegram from De Aar. It arrived at a crucial moment (this, too, I discovered afterward).

"Poirot hesitated before speaking, his voice barely a whisper: “The official description of Elsa Hardt is as follows: Height 5 ft. 7, eyes blue, hair auburn, fair complexion, straight nose, no distinctive marks.” “Could it be Mrs. Robinson?” I interjected. “It's a possibility,” Poirot conceded. “Furthermore, there was a report of a dark-skinned man, possibly a foreigner, asking about the residents of No. 4 just this morning. Therefore, my friend, I suggest we abandon our sleep tonight and keep watch in the apartment below with your trusty revolver, of course!” “Count me in,” I responded eagerly."

I wanted to go to the Magnificent right away to inform Miss Marvell about what had happened, however Poirot rejected the idea, saying that the next morning would be more suitable. I reluctantly agreed. The following morning, Poirot appeared hesitant to leave the house. I started to think that maybe he was reluctant to continue with the investigation after realizing his initial mistake. When I tried to persuade him, he logically pointed out that since the details of the Yardly Chase incident were already in the morning newspapers, the Rolfs would be as informed as we were. I reluctantly conceded.

Renauld left his tattered coat and pants in the shed, avoiding bringing them inside the house. To support Madame Renauld's story, they cruelly stabbed him with an airplane dagger. That evening, Mr. Renauld tied up his wife and silenced her, then proceeded to dig a grave in the precise location where he planned to build a shelter. It was crucial for the corpse to be discovered without raising any doubts for Madame Daubreuil. Waiting a while would reduce the risk of being identified.

Not until I reached the pier, after enduring the tedious formalities demanded by bureaucratic red tape, could I finally relax. No one had been arrested, and as I basked in the glorious weather, my hunger became apparent. Suzanne and I would be spending the night at the hotel. The boat wasn't departing for Port Elizabeth and Durban until the next morning. We hailed a taxi and headed to the Mount Nelson. The day was absolutely delightful - the sun, the breeze, the blooming flowers! Compared to the dreary January days in Little Hampsly, with its muddy terrain and constant rain, I couldn't help but revel in my current surroundings.

I had informed the stewardess of my cold and insensitivity to smells. She appeared distressed, but I stood my ground. The evening dragged on, and I retired to bed, ready for any emergency. Vague thoughts crossed my mind, but I was certain that something would happen at one o’clock. The cabin was filled with silence as my fellow passengers settled in for the night. Suddenly, my door burst open, and a panicked man stumbled inside, pleading for help. With only seconds to spare, I swiftly concealed him behind my trunk and washed basin, transforming my appearance into that of a lady preparing for bed. When the door opened again, I was surprised to find a night stewardess standing there, looking for the source of the earlier noise.

I chuckled. Everyone pokes fun at that giraffe. “And giraffes. They were nomadic, you see. It wasn’t until they settled in communities, with women doing one thing and men doing another, that women became weak. And deep down, we still feel the same, I mean, and that's why women admire physical strength in men - it's what they used to have and have lost.” “Almost like ancestor worship, isn't it?” “Something along those lines.” “And you truly believe that? That women worship strength?” “I think it's quite true, to be honest. You may think you appreciate moral qualities, but when you fall in love, your primal instincts take over. But I don’t think it ends there. If we still lived in primitive conditions, it might be fine, but we don’t, so ultimately, the other qualities prevail. It’s the things that seem defeated that always triumph in the end, isn’t it? They triumph in the only way that matters. Like what the Bible says about losing your soul and finding it.” “In the end,” Colonel Race mused, “you fall in love and then you fall out of it, is that what you’re getting at?” “Not exactly, but you could put it that way if you want.” “But have you ever fallen out of love, Miss Anne?” “No, I haven’t,” I confessed openly. “Or fallen in love, for that matter?” I remained silent. The car stopped at our destination, bringing our conversation to a halt. We got out and began the gradual climb to the World’s View. Once again, I felt a slight unease in Colonel Race’s presence. He concealed his thoughts so well behind those impenetrable black eyes. He intimidated me a little. He always had. I never knew where I stood with him. We ascended in silence until we reached the spot where Rhodes lay protected by massive boulders. A peculiar, eerie place, far from human habitation, that sang a constant hymn of rugged beauty. We sat there in silence for a while. Then we descended once more, deviating slightly from the path. At times it was a tricky climb, and we encountered a steep slope or rock that was nearly vertical. Colonel Race led the way, then turned to assist me. “It would be easier to carry you,” he said suddenly, lifting me off the ground with a swift motion. I felt his strength as he placed me down and let go. A man made of iron, with muscles like tense steel. And once again, I felt a sense of fear, especially when he didn’t step aside, but stood directly in front of me, gazing into my eyes. “What are you really doing here, Anne Beddingfeld?” he asked abruptly. “I’m a wanderer exploring the world.” “Yes, that’s accurate. The newspaper correspondent is just a cover. You aren’t cut out to be a journalist. You’re seeking your own adventure in life. But there’s more to it.” What was he trying to make me reveal? I was afraid, terrified. I stared directly back at him. My eyes may not hide secrets like his, but they can wage war on the enemy’s territory. “What are you truly doing here, Colonel Race?” I asked deliberately. For a moment, I thought he wouldn’t respond. He was clearly caught off guard, though. Finally, he spoke, and his words seemed to amuse him grimly. “Chasing ambition,” he replied. “Just that, chasing ambition. You'll recall, Miss Beddingfeld, that ‘by that sin fell the angels,’ etc.” “They say,” I said slowly, “that you have ties to the Government, that you are part of the Secret Service. Is that true?” Was it my imagination, or did he pause for a fraction of a second before answering? “I assure you, Miss Beddingfeld, that I am solely here as a private individual, traveling for my own enjoyment.” Reflecting on his response later, it struck me as slightly ambiguous. Perhaps that was his intention. We returned to the car in silence. Halfway back to Bulawayo, we stopped for tea at a rather basic structure by the road. The owner was gardening and seemed irritated at being interrupted. However, he kindly agreed to see what he could offer. After a lengthy wait, he brought us some stale cakes and lukewarm tea. Then he went back to his garden. As soon as he left, we were surrounded by cats. Six of them, all meowing pitifully at once. The noise was deafening. I offered them some cake, which they devoured eagerly. I poured the remaining milk into a saucer, and they fought among themselves to lap it up. “Oh,” I exclaimed indignantly, “they’re famished! It’s cruel. Please, please, ask for more milk and another plate of cake.” Colonel Race left quietly to fulfill my request. The cats began meowing again. He returned with a large jug of milk, which the cats finished swiftly. I stood up, determination etched on my face. “I’m taking those cats with us. I can't leave them here.” “My dear, you can’t be serious. You can't carry six cats along with fifty wooden animals.” “Forget the wooden animals. These cats are living beings. I'm bringing them back with me.” “You won't do any such thing.” I glared at him resentfully, but he continued, “You may think me heartless, but one mustn’t go through life sentimentalizing over these matters. There's no use arguing - I won't let you take them. This is a primitive land, and I’m stronger than you.” I always recognize when I’m defeated. I walked back to the car with tears in my eyes. “They're probably just short of food today,” he reassured me. “That man’s wife has gone to Bulawayo for supplies. So everything will be fine. And besides, you know, there are countless starving cats in the world.” “Don’t,” I said vehemently. “I'm teaching you to confront life as it is. I'm teaching you to be tough and ruthless, like me. That’s the key to strength and success.”

"But I am not one to partake in the frantic pursuit of a needle in a haystack, as you English say. Let Mademoiselle Bella Duveen go. I am confident that I will locate her when the time is right. For now, I am willing to be patient." I gazed at him skeptically. Was he trying to deceive me? I couldn't shake the feeling that he was still in control of the situation. My feeling of superiority was slowly fading. Despite orchestrating the girl's escape and devising a clever plan to protect her from the repercussions of her impulsive actions, I couldn't shake my unease.

As the butler entered, a telegram was presented to Lord Yardly on a silver platter. After a quick apology, he opened it and his expression changed. Passing it to his wife, he then turned to Monsieur Poirot. "I believe you should be informed. Hoffberg has a potential buyer for the diamond - an American leaving for the States tomorrow. A representative will inspect the stone tonight. If this deal goes through..." Lord Yardly's voice trailed off, his wife staring blankly at the telegram in her hand.

I quickly retreated into the shadows, observing as the man conversed with Guy Pagett. Any lingering doubts I may have had were dispelled by this interaction. Pagett consulted his watch before the two exchanged a few words, after which the man made his way towards the station. It was clear that Pagett had given him instructions, but what were they exactly? Suddenly, my heart raced as the man who had been tailing me approached a policeman in the middle of the road. They engaged in a lengthy discussion, gesturing towards Cartwright's and appearing to explain something. It became clear to me - I was being set up for an arrest, likely on false charges such as pickpocketing.

"They were both dressed in dark coats with hats pulled low over their eyes." The magistrate paused, eyeing them suspiciously. "Too much facial hair," he muttered. "Are they impostors?" questioned the woman. "Indeed," confirmed the magistrate. "Please, go on with your account." She continued, "The smaller of the two grabbed me, shoving a cloth in my mouth before tying my hands and feet with rope. Meanwhile, the other intruder loomed over my husband, brandishing my small dagger from the vanity table dangerously close to his chest."

“No, I do not believe so. It appeared that they were wearing fake beards, thought the examining magistrate, but still no.” She appeared to have made a firm decision. “I am certain that neither of the two individuals was this man.” “Understood, madame. That will be all then.” With her head held high, she left, the sun glinting off the silver strands in her hair. Jack Renauld followed her. He, too, could not identify the man, in a very natural manner. Giraud simply grunted. Whether he was satisfied or disappointed, I couldn't say. He just called out to Marchaud: “Do you have the other one?” “Yes, sir.” “Bring her in then.” “The other” was Madame Daubreuil. She entered indignantly, vehemently protesting. “I object, sir! This is an outrage! What does this have to do with me?” “Madame,” Giraud said harshly, “I am investigating not one murder, but two! For all I know, you may have committed both.” “How dare you?” she exclaimed. “How dare you insult me with such a wild accusation! It's outrageous.” “Outrageous, is it? What do you have to say about this?” Bending down, he once again removed the hair and held it up. “Do you see this, madame?” He moved closer to her. “May I compare it?” With a cry, she stepped back, pale as a ghost. “It is fake, I swear. I know nothing about either crime. Anyone who says otherwise is lying! Oh, my God, what should I do?” “Calm down, madame,” Giraud said coldly. “No one has accused you yet. But it would be wise to answer my questions promptly.” “Whatever you wish, sir.” “Look at the deceased. Have you ever seen him before?” Approaching, a hint of color returning to her face, Madame Daubreuil looked down at the victim with some interest and curiosity. Then she shook her head. “I don't recognize him.” It seemed impossible to doubt her, the words flowed so naturally. Giraud dismissed her with a nod. “Are you letting her go?” I whispered. “Is that wise? Surely that black hair is hers.” “I don't need advice on how to do my job,” Giraud replied dryly. “She is under surveillance. I have no intention of arresting her yet.” Frowning, he looked down at the body. “Would you say he looks Spanish at all?” he suddenly asked. Examining the face carefully, I finally said, “No, I would definitely say he looks French.” Giraud grunted in dissatisfaction. “I agree.” He stood there for a moment, then gestured for me to move aside, and once again, on hands and knees, he resumed his search of the shed floor. He was meticulous. Nothing eluded him. He went over the floor inch by inch, turning over pots, inspecting old sacks. He seized a bundle by the door, but it turned out to be just a ragged coat and trousers, and he tossed it aside with a growl. Two pairs of old gloves caught his attention, but ultimately he shook his head and set them aside. Then he returned to the pots, methodically examining them one by one. In the end, he stood up and shook his head thoughtfully. He seemed puzzled and perplexed. I think he had forgotten I was there. But at that moment, there was a commotion outside, and the examining magistrate, accompanied by his clerk and M. Bex, entered with the doctor trailing behind. “This is extraordinary, Mr. Giraud,” M. Hautet exclaimed. “Another crime! Ah, we have not yet unraveled this case. There is a deep mystery here. But who is the victim this time?” “That is precisely what no one can tell us, M. le juge. He has not been identified.” “Where is the body?” inquired the doctor. Giraud stepped aside slightly. “Over there in the corner. He was stabbed in the heart, as you can see. And with the dagger that was stolen yesterday morning. I suspect the murder occurred shortly after the theft, but that is for you to determine. You can handle the dagger freely, there are no fingerprints on it.” The doctor knelt beside the deceased, and Giraud turned to the examining magistrate. “A rather intriguing problem, isn't it? But I will solve it.” “So no one can identify him,” pondered the magistrate. “Could he possibly be one of the assailants? Perhaps they turned on each other.” Giraud shook his head. “I would bet my life that the man is French.” But they were interrupted by the doctor, who was sitting back on his heels with a puzzled expression. “You say he was killed yesterday morning?” “I deduced that from the dagger theft,” Giraud explained. “He might, of course, have been killed later in the day.” “Later in the day? Nonsense! This man has been dead for at least forty-eight hours, if not longer.” We stared at each other in disbelief. The doctor's statement was so unexpected that we were momentarily stunned. Here was a man stabbed with a dagger that had been stolen just twenty-four hours earlier, yet Dr. Durand asserted confidently that he had been dead for at least forty-eight hours! The situation was incredibly puzzling. Still reeling from the shock of the doctor's revelation, a telegram was delivered to me. It had been sent from the hotel to the Villa. I opened it eagerly. It was from Poirot, informing me of his return on the train arriving at Merlinville at 12:28. Glancing at my watch, I realized I had just enough time to comfortably reach the station and meet him there. I felt it was crucial that he be informed immediately of the new and astonishing developments in the case. It seemed that Poirot had no trouble finding what he needed in Paris. His swift return was proof of that. Only a few hours had passed. I wondered how he would react to the thrilling news I had to share. The train was running a few minutes late, so I wandered back and forth on the platform until I decided to inquire about who had departed Merlinville on the last train on the night of the tragedy. I approached the head porter, a sharp-looking man, and easily engaged him in conversation about the topic. He vehemently believed it was a disgrace that such criminals and murderers were allowed to roam free.

In the cozy study, we found a charming couple - the man with a weathered face resembling a withered apple, and his wife exuding a sense of calm with her ample frame. Exhausted from the journey and the long drive, we had quickly retired to bed after a delicious meal of roast chicken, apple pie, and thick Devonshire cream. After a satisfying breakfast, we gathered in the small, wood-paneled room that once belonged to the late Mr. Marsh. A roll-top desk, meticulously organized with papers, adorned one wall, while a large leather armchair, clearly the favorite spot of its former owner, sat prominently in the room.

"Listen, my friend, I understand your feelings on this dreadful matter. I have not handled it well! If you were in my position, you might have handled it better! Fine! Let's move on from it and grab some lunch." By the time we arrived at Poirot's place, it was around four o’clock. A man stood up from a seat near the window. It was Lord Yardly. He appeared worn out and troubled. "I received your message and hurried here. I went to Hoffberg, but they deny any knowledge of their employee from last night or the telegram. Could it be that" Poirot interrupted him. "I apologize! I sent that telegram and recruited the man in question."

A large settee covered in chintz sat against the wall, while the window seats were also draped in the same faded chintz. Poirot, lighting a cigarette, discussed their plan. He believed the clue they sought was in the room, hidden among the documents in the desk. Despite not expecting to find the will, Poirot suspected a seemingly innocent paper held the key. After calling for Mrs. Baker, they learned about the will-signing and the mysterious workmen from Plymouth. Poirot deduced that a second will had been made, with a hiding spot created by the workmen. In Plymouth, they confirmed the details and discovered the hidden cavity behind a brick in the fireplace. With excitement, Poirot reached into the cavity.

The Villa was shrouded in darkness, everyone fast asleep. Poirot and I stood beneath Mrs. Renauld's open window, waiting. Suddenly, a cry for help echoed through the night, a light flickered in an upper room. Poirot sprang into action, climbing up a tree and through the window. Poirot's deduction of the events that transpired that night left me speechless. The murderer had been unmasked, thanks to a clever ruse and a stolen dagger. The night's events were stranger than any dream.

"But Poirot's skills surpassed mine. In mere moments, he uncovered the entire tale, his eyes gleaming with amusement. “Ah! A story filled with romance. What is the name of this captivating young woman?” I had to admit that I was unaware. “Even more romantic! The initial encounter on the Paris train, the subsequent one here. Journeys conclude with lovers’ reunions, is that not the saying?” “Stop being ridiculous, Poirot.” “Yesterday it was Mademoiselle Daubreuil, today it is Mademoiselle Cinderella! The purser conveyed his apologies for her absence in a sincerely manner as he assigned me her room, and afterwards Colonel Race shared some intriguing insights about her. Rumors of her involvement in espionage circulated in Paris, though no evidence was ever found. It appeared that Colonel Race had been deployed to investigate this matter. He disclosed details about a sophisticated criminal network, revealing it to be non-German in nature.

"Poor Maltravers! You had no idea, I gather, that he was discovered with a crowbar next to him." "So you're saying my tale influenced him - oh, that's terrible!" "Don't worry, it would have happened regardless. Now, I need to make a call to London." Poirot had an extensive discussion on the phone, returning with a pensive expression. “Discussing apartments,” she mentioned, “have you heard about our stroke of luck, Mr. Parker? We’ve finally secured an apartment! In Montagu Mansions.” “Ah,” Parker replied, “I’ve always said that there are plenty of apartments available for a price!” “Yes, but this one isn’t at a price. It’s very inexpensive. Only eighty pounds a year!” “But Montagu Mansions is near Knightsbridge, correct? A grand building. Or are you referring to a less affluent location with the same name in the slums somewhere?” “No, it’s the Knightsbridge one. That’s what makes it so extraordinary.” “Extraordinary indeed! It’s a complete miracle. But there must be a catch somewhere. A large premium, I assume?” “No premium!” “No pre oh, help me, somebody!” groaned Parker. “But we do need to purchase the furniture,” Mrs. Robinson continued. “Ah!” Parker perked up. “I knew there was a catch!” “For fifty pounds. And it’s furnished beautifully!” “I surrender,” said Parker. “The current tenants must be lunatics with a penchant for generosity.” Mrs. Robinson appeared slightly troubled. A slight frown appeared between her delicate brows. “It is odd, isn’t it? You don’t think that the place is haunted?” “I’ve never heard of a haunted apartment,” Parker stated firmly. “N-o.” Mrs. Robinson seemed far from convinced. “But there were several things about the whole situation that struck me as well, odd.” “For example” I prompted. “Ah,” said Parker, “our expert on crime is intrigued! Tell him, Mrs. Robinson. Hastings is excellent at unraveling mysteries.” I chuckled, feeling embarrassed but not entirely displeased with the role assigned to me. "Oh, not particularly odd, Captain Hastings, but when we visited the agents, Stosser and Paul - we hadn’t tried them before because they only handle the expensive Mayfair apartments - but we thought it wouldn’t hurt to see. Everything they offered us was four and five hundred a year, or huge premiums, and then, just before we were leaving, they mentioned that they had an apartment for eighty, but they doubted whether it would be worth our time going there, because it had been on their books for some time and they had sent so many people to view it that it was almost certain to be taken ‘snapped up’ as the clerk put it only people were so tiresome in not informing them, and then they continued sending, and people get irritated at being sent to a place that had, perhaps, been rented some time.” Mrs. Robinson stopped to catch her breath, then continued: “We thanked him, and said that we understood it probably wouldn’t work out, but that we’d like an order just in case. And we went there immediately in a taxi, because, after all, you never know. No. 4 was on the second floor, and just as we were waiting for the lift, Elsie Ferguson - she’s a friend of mine, Captain Hastings, and they are also looking for an apartment - came rushing down the stairs. ‘Ahead of you for once, my dear,’ she said. ‘But it’s no use. It’s already taken.’ That seemed to settle it, but well, as John said, the place was very affordable, we could offer more, and perhaps if we offered a premium. A horrible thing to do, of course, and I feel quite ashamed of telling you, but you know how it is with apartment hunting.” I assured her that I was well aware that in the battle for housing, the baser aspects of human nature often triumphed over the higher ones, and that the well-known rule of dog eat dog always applied. “So we went up and, can you believe it, the apartment wasn’t taken at all. We were shown around by the maid, and then we met the landlady, and the deal was sealed then and there. Immediate move-in and fifty pounds for the furniture. I somewhat wished Poirot had been present. Sometimes I have the feeling that he underestimates my abilities. The whole situation was rather amusing, and I presented it as a mock problem to Poirot the next morning. He seemed intrigued and questioned me closely about the rents of apartments in various locations. “A curious tale,” he said thoughtfully. “Excuse me, Hastings, I must take a brief walk.” When he returned, about an hour later, his eyes gleamed with a peculiar excitement. He placed his stick on the table, and brushed the nap of his hat with his usual delicate care before he spoke. “It is fortunate, my friend, that we have no pressing matters at the moment. We can devote ourselves entirely to this investigation.” “What investigation are you referring to?” “The remarkably low cost of your friend’s, Mrs. Robinson’s, new apartment.” “Poirot, you can’t be serious!” “I am very serious. Imagine, my friend, that the actual rent for those apartments is £350. I have just confirmed that with the landlord’s agents. And yet this specific apartment is being sublet for eighty pounds! Why?” “There must be something wrong with it. Perhaps it is haunted, as Mrs. Robinson suggested.” Poirot shook his head in a dissatisfied manner. “Then again how strange it is that her friend informs her the apartment is taken, and yet when she goes up, behold, it is not so at all!” “But surely you agree with me that the other woman must have gone to the wrong apartment. That is the only logical explanation.” “You may or may not be correct on that point, Hastings. That was an undeniable fact. An estate. Perhaps the origin of a noble bloodline. (Lost heir? Title contender?) Or maybe a charming dilapidated building. (Hidden riches?) Indeed, I was leaning towards the notion of hidden treasure. Enigmas always accompany hidden treasure. One step to the east, seven steps to the west, excavate one yard, descend twenty-two stairs. "And my marriage isn't as stable as I thought," Suzanne said sadly. "Clarence has been sending urgent messages for me to return home, but I've ignored them for weeks now." I couldn't bring myself to be too concerned about Suzanne's marital issues. She had a way of handling Clarence when necessary. Changing the topic, I brought up the matter of the missing diamonds. Suzanne's eyes widened in shock. "Let me clarify, Anne. When I started suspecting Colonel Race, I became very anxious about the diamonds."

"I chuckled. Everyone mocks that giraffe. "And giraffes. They were nomadic, you see. It wasn’t until they settled down in communities, with women doing one type of work and men another, that women became weak. And deep down, one still feels the same, one remains the same, and that's why women admire physical strength in men - it's what they used to have and have now lost." "Almost like ancestor worship, isn't it?" "Something along those lines." "And do you truly believe that, that women worship strength?" "I believe it's quite accurate, if one is honest. You think you admire moral qualities, but when you fall in love, you revert to the primitive where only the physical matters. But I don't think that's the end of it. If you lived in primitive conditions, it might be acceptable, but you don't, and in the end, the other aspects prevail. It's the things that seem to be conquered that always emerge victorious, isn't it? They win in the only way that truly matters. Like what the Bible says about losing your soul and finding it." "Ultimately," Colonel Race pondered, "you fall in love and then fall out of it, is that your point?" "Not exactly, but you can interpret it that way if you wish." "But you've never fallen out of love, Miss Anne, have you?" "No, I haven't," I confessed openly. "Or fallen in love, for that matter?" I remained silent. The car arrived at our destination and the conversation came to an end. We exited and started the gradual climb to the World's View. Colonel Race's presence made me slightly uneasy, as always. His thoughts were well concealed behind those impenetrable black eyes. He somewhat frightened me. I never knew where I stood with him. We ascended in silence until we arrived at the place where Rhodes is protected by enormous boulders. A peculiar, eerie place, far from civilization, singing a continuous hymn of rugged beauty. We sat there in silence for some time. Then we descended once more, deviating slightly from the path. Some parts required a challenging climb, and at one point we encountered a steep slope that was almost vertical. Colonel Race went first, then turned to assist me. "It's better if I carry you," he stated suddenly, lifting me off the ground with a swift motion. I felt his strength as he placed me down and let go. A man of steel, with muscles like taut wires. I felt a sense of fear, especially as he didn't step aside, but stood directly in front of me, gazing into my eyes. "What is your true purpose here, Anne Beddingfeld?" he asked abruptly. "I'm a wanderer exploring the world," I replied. "Yes, that's accurate. The newspaper correspondent role is just a pretense. You don't possess the spirit of a journalist. You're out for your own gain, grasping at life. But there's more to it." What was he trying to get me to reveal? I was afraid, terrified. I stared directly into his eyes. My eyes may not keep secrets like his, but they can bring the battle to the enemy's territory. "What are you truly doing here, Colonel Race?" I inquired deliberately. For a moment, I thought he wouldn't respond. He appeared taken aback, however. Finally, he spoke, his words seeming to amuse him grimly. "Chasing ambition," he replied. "Precisely that - chasing ambition. You'll recall, Miss Beddingfeld, that 'by that sin fell the angels,' etc." "Rumors suggest," I said slowly, "that you are linked to the Government, that you are part of the Secret Service. Is that true?" Was it my imagination, or did he hesitate for a split second before answering? "I assure you, Miss Beddingfeld, that I am here purely as a private individual traveling for my own pleasure." Upon reflecting on the response later, it struck me as somewhat ambiguous. Perhaps he intended it to be so. We resumed our journey in silence. Halfway back to Bulawayo, we stopped for tea at a rather basic structure by the roadside. The proprietor was tending to the garden and seemed irritated by the interruption. However, he graciously agreed to see what he could provide. After a seemingly endless wait, he brought us some stale cakes and lukewarm tea. He then returned to his garden. As soon as he left, we were swarmed by cats. Six of them, meowing pitifully all at once. The noise was overwhelming. I offered them some cake, which they devoured eagerly. I poured all the milk into a saucer, and they fought to lap it up. "Oh," I exclaimed indignantly, "they're famished! It's cruel. Please, please, order more milk and another plate of cake." Colonel Race left silently to fulfill my request. The cats began meowing again. He returned with a large jug of milk, which the cats drank entirely. I stood up, determination etched on my face. "I'm taking those cats with us. I won't leave them here." "My dear, don't be absurd. You can't carry six cats along with fifty wooden animals," he remarked. "Forget the wooden animals. These cats are alive. I'll bring them back with us." "You won't do any such thing." I glared at him resentfully, but he continued, "You may think me cruel, but one can't go through life sentimentalizing over these matters. It's pointless to resist. I won't let you take them. It's a primitive land, you know, and I am stronger than you." I always recognize when I'm defeated. I headed to the car with tears in my eyes. "They're likely just missing a meal today," he reassured me. "That man's wife has gone to Bulawayo for supplies. So they'll be fine. And in any case, you know, there are plenty of starving cats in the world." "Stop it," I said firmly. "I'm showing you the reality of life. I'm teaching you to be tough and ruthless, like I am. That's the key to strength and success."

"Come on now, sir, you can't underestimate the importance of details as clues, can you?" "Not at all. They all have their place. The risk is that they might be given too much significance. Most details are irrelevant; only a few are crucial. It's the mind, the little grey cells," he pointed to his head, "that one must trust. The senses can be deceiving. The truth must be found internally, not externally." "Are you suggesting, Monsieur Poirot, that you could solve a case without even leaving your seat?" "That's exactly what I mean, provided that the facts were presented to me."

I had my doubts about Mrs. Blair and Anne's obsession with buying wooden animals at every station. The journey through Bechuanaland was filled with dust and primitive charm, as the Kafir children sold their hand-carved toys. The Hex river valley and the Karoo offered breathtaking scenery that was a stark contrast to the chaos of the train stops. Suzanne and I marveled at the sights, almost missing the train at each impromptu halt. The natives appeared out of nowhere, offering their wares, and I couldn't help but feel a sense of wonder at the simplicity and beauty of their creations.

"They fail to understand that an experienced examining magistrate like me possesses a certain discernment, a certain flair. Indeed! The courtesy of the old school suits me much better. So, my dear friend, feel free to give me any orders. We both know a thing or two, don't we?" Laughing heartily and pleased with himself and us, M. Hautet bid us farewell. Regrettably, Poirot's first comment to me as we walked through the corridor was: "That famous old imbecile! So stupid it's pitiful!" As we exited the building, we encountered Giraud, looking more stylish than ever and thoroughly satisfied with himself. "Aha! M. Poirot," he exclaimed casually. "Back from England, I see?" "Indeed," replied Poirot. "The conclusion of the case is near, I believe." "I concur, M. Giraud," Poirot said in a subdued tone. His dejected demeanor seemed to please the other man. "The most insipid criminal of all! No attempt at defense. It's unbelievable!" "So unbelievable that it gives one pause, wouldn't you say?" Poirot suggested mildly. But Giraud wasn't paying attention. He twirled his cane amicably. "Well, good day, M. Poirot. I'm glad you're finally convinced of young Renauld's guilt." "Excuse me! But I am not convinced at all. Jack Renauld is innocent." Giraud stared for a moment then burst into laughter, tapping his head significantly with the brief remark: "Crazy!" Poirot straightened up. A dangerous glint appeared in his eyes. "M. Giraud, your deliberate insults towards me throughout this case require a lesson. I am willing to bet you 500 francs that I will find M. Renauld's murderer before you do. Do we have a deal?" Giraud stared helplessly and muttered again: "Crazy!" "Come on now," urged Poirot, "do we have a deal?" "I have no desire to take your money." "Rest assured, you won't!" "Oh, well then, I agree! You speak of my insulting behavior towards you. Well, once or twice, your behavior has irritated me." "I am delighted to hear that," said Poirot. "Good morning, M. Giraud. Let's go, Hastings." I remained silent as we walked down the street. My heart was heavy. Poirot had made his intentions clear. I doubted more than ever my ability to save Bella from the consequences of her actions. This unfortunate encounter with Giraud had roused Poirot and put him on alert. Suddenly, I felt a hand on my shoulder, and turned to see Gabriel Stonor. We stopped and greeted him, and he suggested walking back to our hotel together. "And why are you here, M. Stonor?" Poirot asked. "One must support one's friends," the other replied dryly. "Especially when they are wrongly accused." "So you don't believe that Jack Renauld committed the crime?" I asked eagerly. "Absolutely not. I know the boy. There have been a few things in this case that have completely baffled me, but still, despite his foolish way of handling it, I'll never believe that Jack Renauld is a murderer." My heart warmed to the secretary. His words seemed to lift a burden from my heart. "I'm sure many others share your belief," I exclaimed. "There is ridiculously little evidence against him. I would say his acquittal is certain without a doubt." But Stonor didn't seem as enthusiastic as I had hoped. "I wish I could share your confidence," he said seriously. He turned to Poirot. "What do you think, monsieur?" "I believe the situation looks grim for him," said Poirot calmly. "You think he's guilty?" Stonor asked sharply. "No. But I think proving his innocence will be challenging." "He's behaving very strangely," muttered Stonor. "Of course, I understand that there's much more to this case than meets the eye. Giraud hasn't grasped that because he's an outsider, but the whole thing has been very odd. Let's not dwell on it. If Mrs. Renauld wants to keep things quiet, I'll follow her lead. It's her decision, and I respect her judgment too much to interfere, but I can't understand Jack's attitude. You'd think he wanted people to believe he's guilty." "But that's absurd," I interjected. "For one thing, the dagger..." I paused, unsure of how much Poirot wanted me to reveal. I continued, picking my words carefully, "We know that the dagger could not have been in Jack Renauld's possession that evening. Mrs. Renauld is aware of that." "True," said Stonor. "Once she recovers, she will surely confirm all this and more. Well, I must be going." "Wait a moment." Poirot's hand stopped him from leaving. "Can you ensure that I am immediately informed if Madame Renauld regains consciousness?" "Of course. That can be arranged easily." "Your point about the dagger is valid, Poirot," I insisted as we climbed the stairs. "I couldn't speak openly in front of Stonor." "You did the right thing. We might as well keep that information to ourselves for now. As for the dagger, your argument doesn't really help Jack Renauld. You remember I was absent for an hour this morning, before we departed from London?" "Yes?" "Well, I was busy trying to locate the company Jack Renauld hired to make his souvenirs. It wasn't very difficult. Well, Hastings, they produced not two paper-knives, but three at his request." "So that?" "So, after giving one to his mother, and one to Bella Duveen, there was a third that he likely kept for himself. No, Hastings, I fear the dagger issue won't assist us in saving him from the guillotine." "It won't come to that," I protested. Poirot shook his head doubtfully. "You will save him," I stated confidently. Poirot looked at me dryly. "Are you asking for miracles from me? Say no more. Let's see what this letter contains instead." And he took out the envelope from his pocket and read, then handed the single sheet of paper to me.

I eagerly sipped from the straw until the glass was drained. The cold liquid slid smoothly down my throat, satisfying my thirst. Yes, a little army will be starting soon. We must get ahead of them. Will you write to Cook’s today, Anne?” “What about money, papa?” I hinted delicately. He turned a reproachful eye upon me. “Your point of view always depresses me, my child. We must not be sordid. No, no, in the cause of science one must not be sordid.” “I feel Cook’s might be sordid, papa.” Papa looked pained. “My dear Anne, you will pay them in ready money.” “I haven’t got any ready money.” Papa looked thoroughly exasperated. “My child, I really cannot be bothered with these vulgar money details. The bank I had something from the Manager yesterday, saying I had twenty-seven pounds.” “That’s your overdraft, I fancy.” “Ah, I have it! Write to my publishers.” I acquiesced doubtfully, Papa’s books bringing in more glory than money. I liked the idea of going to Rhodesia immensely. “Stern silent men,” I murmured to myself in an ecstasy. Then something in my parent’s appearance struck me as unusual. “You have odd boots on, papa,” I said. “Take off the brown one and put on the other black one. And don’t forget your muffler. It’s a very cold day.” In a few minutes Papa stalked off, correctly booted and well mufflered. He returned late that evening, and, to my dismay, I saw his muffler and overcoat were missing. “Dear me, Anne, you are quite right. I took them off to go into the cavern. One gets so dirty there.” I nodded feelingly, remembering an occasion when Papa had returned literally plastered from head to foot with rich Pleiocene clay. Our principal reason for settling in Little Hampsly had been the neighbourhood of Hampsly Cavern, a buried cave rich in deposits of the Aurignacian culture. We had a tiny Museum in the village, and the curator and Papa spent most of their days messing about underground and bringing to light portions of woolly rhinoceros and cave bear. Papa coughed badly all the evening, and the following morning I saw he had a temperature and sent for the doctor. Poor Papa, he never had a chance. It was double pneumonia. He died four days later. Everyone was very kind to me. Dazed as I was, I appreciated that. I felt no overwhelming grief. Papa had never loved me, I knew that well enough. If he had, I might have loved him in return. No, there had not been love between us, but we had belonged together, and I had looked after him, and had secretly admired his learning and his uncompromising devotion to science. And it hurt me that Papa should have died just when the interest of life was at its height for him. I should have felt happier if I could have buried him in a cave, with paintings of reindeer and flint implements, but the force of public opinion constrained a neat tomb (with marble slab) in our hideous local churchyard. The vicar’s consolations, though well meant, did not console me in the least. It took some time to dawn upon me that the thing I had always longed for freedom was at last mine. I was an orphan, and practically penniless, but free. At the same time I realized the extraordinary kindness of all these good people. The vicar did his best to persuade me that his wife was in urgent need of a companion help. Our tiny local library suddenly made up its mind to have an assistant librarian. Finally, the doctor called upon me, and after making various ridiculous excuses for failing to send in a proper bill, he hummed and hawed a good deal and suddenly suggested that I should marry him. I was very much astonished. The doctor was nearer forty than thirty, and a round, tubby little man. He was not at all like the hero of “The Perils of Pamela,” and even less like a stern and silent Rhodesian. I reflected a minute and then asked him why he wanted to marry me. That seemed to fluster him a good deal, and he murmured that a wife was a great help to a General Practitioner. The position seemed even more unromantic than before, and yet something in me urged towards its acceptance. Safety, that was what I was being offered. Safety and a Comfortable Home. Thinking it over now, I believe I did the little man an injustice. He was honestly in love with me, but a mistaken delicacy prevented him from pressing his suit on those lines. Anyway, my love of romance rebelled. “It’s extremely kind of you,” I said. “But it’s impossible. I could never marry a man unless I loved him madly.” “You don’t think?” “No, I don’t,” I said firmly. He sighed. “But, my dear child, what do you propose to do?” “Have adventures and see the world,” I replied, without the least hesitation. “Miss Anne, you are very much of a child still. You don’t understand” “The practical difficulties? Yes, I do, doctor. I’m not a sentimental schoolgirl I’m a hard-headed mercenary shrew! You’d know it if you married me!” “I wish you would reconsider” “I can’t.” He sighed again. “I have another proposal to make. An aunt of mine who lives in Wales is in want of a young lady to help her. How would that suit you?” “No, doctor, I’m going to London. If things happen anywhere, they happen in London. I shall keep my eyes open and you’ll see, something will turn up! You’ll hear of me next in China or Timbuctoo.” My next visitor was Mr. Flemming, Papa’s London solicitor. He came down specially from town to see me. An ardent anthropologist himself, he was a great admirer of Papa’s works. He was a tall, spare man with a thin face and grey hair. He rose to meet me as I entered the room and, taking both my hands in his, patted them affectionately. “My poor child,” he said. “My poor, poor child.” Without conscious hypocrisy, I found myself assuming the demeanour of a bereaved orphan. He hypnotized me into it.

"I see," said Poirot thoughtfully. "It may be yes, it may be. But as yet I do not know! There is something very deep underneath all this. You will see. Something very deep." Then, as we entered our hotel, he enjoined silence on me with a gesture. We lunched with an excellent appetite. I understood well enough that Poirot did not wish to discuss the tragedy where we could so easily be overheard. But, as is usual when one topic fills the mind to the exclusion of everything else, no other subject of interest seemed to present itself. For a while we ate in silence, and then Poirot observed maliciously: "Eh bien! And your indiscretions! You recount them not?" I felt myself blushing. "Oh, you mean this morning?" I endeavoured to adopt a tone of absolute nonchalance. But I was no match for Poirot. In a very few minutes he had extracted the whole story from me, his eyes twinkling as he did so. "Tiens! A story of the most romantic. What is her name, this charming young lady?" I had to confess that I did not know. "Still more romantic! The first rencontre in the train from Paris, the second here. Journeys end in lovers' meetings, is not that the saying?" "Don't be an ass, Poirot." "Yesterday it was Mademoiselle Daubreuil, today it is Mademoiselle Cinderella! Decidedly you have the heart of a Turk, Hastings! You should establish a harem!" "It's all very well to rag me. Mademoiselle Daubreuil is a very beautiful girl, and I do admire her immensely I don't mind admitting it. The other's nothing don't suppose I shall ever see her again. She was quite amusing to talk to just for a railway journey, but she's not the kind of girl I should ever get keen on." "Why?" "Well it sounds snobbish perhaps but she's not a lady, not in any sense of the word." Poirot nodded thoughtfully. There was less raillery in his voice as he asked: "You believe, then, in birth and breeding?" "I may be old-fashioned, but I certainly don't believe in marrying out of one's class. It never answers." "I agree with you, mon ami. Ninety-nine times out of a hundred, it is as you say. But there is always the hundredth time! Still, that does not arise, as you do not propose to see the lady again." His last words were almost a question, and I was aware of the sharpness with which he darted a glance at me. And before my eyes, writ large in letters of fire, I saw the words "Hôtel du Phare," and I heard again her voice saying "Come and look me up" and my own answering with empressement: "I will." Well, what of it? I had meant to go at the time. But since then, I had had time to reflect. I did not like the girl. Thinking it over in cold blood, I came definitely to the conclusion that I disliked her intensely. I had got hauled over the coals for foolishly gratifying her morbid curiosity, and I had not the least wish to see her again. I answered Poirot lightly enough. "She asked me to look her up, but of course I shan't." "Why 'of course'?" "Well I don't want to." "I see."

"Would you dare to ask me that question once more, mademoiselle?" "What are you implying?" "If the question were posed again, my response would differ. Someone is under suspicion, but they are not Chilean." "Who?" The question slipped quietly through her lips. "Jack Renauld." "What?" She exclaimed. "Jack? That's impossible. Who would even dare to suspect him?" "Giraud." "Giraud!" Her face turned pale. "I fear that man. He is ruthless. He will he will " She hesitated. But then a sense of bravery and resolve overtook her. In that moment, I recognized her as a fighter. Poirot, too, observed her closely.

We are also working closely with Scotland Yard on this matter. Inspector McNeil is overseeing the investigation, a highly skilled detective, as I understand it.”

Lord Estair confirmed that the Prime Minister was under police protection, with his chauffeur being an Irishman from County Clare named O’Murphy. The Prime Minister's car deviated from the main road and was ambushed by masked men, but managed to escape with only a slight wound. Despite the incident, the Prime Minister continued on to Charing Cross and then departed for France. However, the police later found the Prime Minister's car parked outside a suspicious restaurant in Soho, known to be frequented by German agents.

A man with a history of hunting lions in large numbers possesses an unfair advantage over his peers. It struck me that it was about time I shared a lion-related anecdote as well, albeit of a livelier nature. "Speaking of which," I interjected, "I recall a rather thrilling story I was told. A companion of mine was on a hunting expedition in East Africa. One evening, he exited his tent for a particular purpose and was taken aback by a faint growl. Upon a sudden turn, he found himself face to face with a lion ready to pounce. His firearm was left inside the tent. Acting swiftly, he dodged, causing the lion to leap over him. Irritated by the miss, the lion emitted a growl and readied itself for another leap."

" I felt a gentle pressure on my arm. It was Poirot. “Shall we slip away, my friend? I think our services are no longer needed.” Once outside, however, he hesitated, and then, much to my surprise, he remarked: “I should rather like to see the room next door.” The door was not locked, and we entered. The room, which was a large double one, was unoccupied. Dust lay about rather noticeably, and my sensitive friend gave a characteristic grimace as he ran his finger round a rectangular mark on a table near the window. “The service leaves to be desired,” he observed dryly. He was staring thoughtfully out of the window, and seemed to have fallen into a brown study. “Well?” I demanded impatiently. “What did we come in here for?” He started. “Je vous demande pardon, mon ami. I wished to see if the door was really bolted on this side also.” “Well,” I said, glancing at the door which communicated with the room we had just left, “it is bolted.” Poirot nodded. He still seemed to be thinking. “And, anyway,” I continued, “what does it matter? The case is over. I wish you’d had more chance of distinguishing yourself. But it was the kind of case that even a stiff-backed idiot like that inspector couldn’t go wrong over.” Poirot shook his head. “The case is not over, my friend. It will not be over until we find out who stole the pearls.” “But the maid did!” “Why do you say that?” “Why,” I stammered, “they were found actually in her mattress.” “Ta, ta, ta!” said Poirot impatiently. “Those were not the pearls.” "What?" "Imitation, mon ami." The statement took my breath away. Poirot was smiling placidly. “The good inspector obviously knows nothing of jewels. But presently there will be a fine hullabaloo!” "Come!" I cried, dragging at his arm. “Where?” “We must tell the Opalsens at once.” "I think not." "But that poor woman" "Eh bien; that poor woman, as you call her, will have a much better night believing the jewels to be safe." "But the thief may escape with them!" "As usual, my friend, you speak without reflection. How do you know that the pearls Mrs. Opalsen locked up so carefully tonight were not the false ones, and that the real robbery did not take place at a much earlier date?" "Oh!" I said, bewildered. "Exactly," said Poirot, beaming. "We start again." He led the way out of the room, paused a moment as though considering, and then walked down to the end of the corridor, stopping outside the small den where the chambermaids and valets of the respective floors congregated. Our particular chambermaid appeared to be holding a small court there, and to be retailing her late experiences to an appreciative audience. She stopped in the middle of a sentence. Poirot bowed with his usual politeness. "Excuse that I derange you, but I shall be obliged if you will unlock for me the door of Mr. Opalsen’s room." The woman rose willingly, and we accompanied her down the passage again. Mr. Opalsen’s room was on the other side of the corridor, its door facing that of his wife’s room. The chambermaid unlocked it with her pass-key, and we entered. As she was about to depart Poirot detained her. "One moment; have you ever seen among the effects of Mr. Opalsen a card like this?" He held out a plain white card, rather highly glazed and uncommon in appearance. The maid took it and scrutinized it carefully. "No, sir, I can’t say I have. But, anyway, the valet has most to do with the gentlemen’s rooms." "I see. Thank you." Poirot took back the card. The woman departed. Poirot appeared to reflect a little. Then he gave a short, sharp nod of the head. "Ring the bell, I pray of you, Hastings. Three times, for the valet." I obeyed, devoured with curiosity. Meanwhile Poirot had emptied the waste-paper-basket on the floor, and was swiftly going through its contents. In a few moments the valet answered the bell. To him Poirot put the same question, and handed him the card to examine. But the response was the same. The valet had never seen a card of that particular quality among Mr. Opalsen’s belongings. Poirot thanked him, and he withdrew, somewhat unwillingly, with an inquisitive glance at the overturned waste-paper-basket and the litter on the floor. He could hardly have helped overhearing Poirot’s thoughtful remark as he bundled the torn papers back again: “And the necklace was heavily insured. . . ." "Poirot," I cried, "I see" "You see nothing, my friend," he replied quickly. "As usual, nothing at all! It is incredible but there it is. Let us return to our own apartments." We did so in silence. Once there, to my intense surprise, Poirot effected a rapid change of clothing. "I go to London to-night," he explained. "It is imperative." "What?" "Absolutely. The real work, that of the brain (ah, those brave little grey cells), it is done. I go to seek the confirmation. I shall find it! Impossible to deceive Hercule Poirot!" "You’ll come a cropper one of these days," I observed, rather disgusted by his vanity. "Do not be enraged, I beg of you, mon ami. I count on you to do me a service of your friendship." "Of course," I said eagerly, rather ashamed of my moroseness. "What is it?" "The sleeve of my coat that I have taken off will you brush it? See you, a little white powder has clung to it. You without doubt observed me run my finger round the drawer of the dressing-table?" "No, I didn’t." "You should observe my actions, my friend. Thus I obtained the powder on my finger, and, being a little over-excited, I rubbed it on my sleeve; an action without method which I deplore false to all my principles." "But what was the powder?" I asked, not particularly interested in Poirot’s principles. "Not the poison of the Borgias," replied Poirot, with a twinkle. "I see your imagination mounting. I should say it was French chalk." "French chalk?" "Yes, cabinet-makers use it to make drawers run smoothly." I laughed. "You old sinner! I thought you were working up to something exciting." "Au revoir, my friend. I save myself. I fly!" The door shut behind him. With a smile, half of derision, half of affection, I picked up the coat, and stretched out my hand for the clothes-brush. The next morning, hearing nothing from Poirot, I went out for a stroll, met some old friends, and lunched with them at their hotel. In the afternoon we went for a spin. A punctured tyre delayed us, and it was past eight when I got back to the Grand Metropolitan. The first sight that met my eyes was Poirot, looking even more diminutive than usual, sandwiched between the Opalsens, beaming in a state of placid satisfaction. “Mon ami Hastings!” he cried, and sprang to meet me. "Embrace me, my friend; all has marched to a marvel!" Luckily, the embrace was merely figurative not a thing one is always sure of with Poirot. "Do you mean" I began. "Just wonderful, I call it!" said Mrs. Opalsen, smiling all over her fat face. “Didn’t I tell you, Ed, that if he couldn’t get back my pearls nobody would?” “You did, my dear, you did. And you were right.” I looked helplessly at Poirot, and he answered the glance. "My friend Hastings is, as you say in England, all at the seaside. Seat yourself, and I will recount to you all the affair that has so happily ended." "Ended?" "But yes. They are arrested." "Who are arrested?" "The chambermaid and the valet, parbleu! You did not suspect? Not with my parting hint about the French chalk?" "You said cabinet-makers used it." "Certainly they do to make drawers slide easily. Somebody wanted that drawer to slide in and out without any noise. Who could that be? Obviously, only the chambermaid. The plan was so ingenious that it did not at once leap to the eye not even to the eye of Hercule Poirot. "Listen, this was how it was done. The valet was in the empty room next door, waiting. The French maid leaves the room. Quick as a flash the chambermaid whips open the drawer, takes out the jewel-case, and, slipping back the bolt, passes it through the door. The valet opens it at his leisure with the duplicate key with which he has provided himself, extracts the necklace, and waits his time. Célestine leaves the room again, and pst! in a flash the case is passed back again and replaced in the drawer. "Madame arrives, the theft is discovered. The chambermaid demands to be searched, with a good deal of righteous indignation, and leaves the room without a stain on her character. The imitation necklace with which they have provided themselves has been concealed in the French girl’s bed that morning by the chambermaid a master stroke, ça!” “But what did you go to London for?” “You remember the card?” “Certainly. It puzzled me and puzzles me still. I thought” I hesitated delicately, glancing at Mr. Opalsen. Poirot laughed heartily. “Une blague! For the benefit of the valet. The card was one with a specially prepared surface for finger-prints. I went straight to Scotland Yard, asked for our old friend Inspector Japp, and laid the facts before him. As I had suspected, the finger-prints proved to be those of two well-known jewel thieves who have been ‘wanted’ for some time. Japp came down with me, the thieves were arrested, and the necklace was discovered in the valet’s possession. A clever pair, but they failed in method. Have I not told you, Hastings, at least thirty-six times, that without method” “At least thirty-six thousand times!” I interrupted. “But where did their ‘method’ break down?” “Mon ami, it is a good plan to take a place as chambermaid or valet but you must not shirk your work. They left an empty room undusted; and therefore, when the man put down the jewel-case on the little table near the communicating door, it left a square mark” "I remember," I cried. "Before, I was undecided. Then I knew!" There was a moment’s silence. “And I’ve got my pearls,” said Mrs. Opalsen as a sort of Greek chorus. “Well,” I said, “I’d better have some dinner.” Poirot accompanied me. "This ought to mean kudos for you,” I observed. “Pas du tout,” replied Poirot tranquilly. “Japp and the local inspector will divide the credit between them. But” he tapped his pocket “I have a cheque here, from Mr. Opalsen, and, how say you, my friend? This week-end has not gone according to plan. Shall we return here next week-end at my expense this time?” "Now that war and the problems of war are things of the past, I think I may safely venture to reveal to the world the part which my friend Poirot played in a moment of national crisis. The secret has been well guarded. Not a whisper of it reached the Press. But, now that the need for secrecy has gone by, I feel it is only just that England should know the debt it owes to my quaint little friend, whose marvellous brain so ably averted a great catastrophe. One evening after dinner I will not particularize the date; it suffices to say that it was at the time when “Peace by negotiation” was the parrot-cry of England’s enemies my friend and I were sitting in his rooms. After being invalided out of the Army I had been given a recruiting job, and it had become my custom to drop in on Poirot in the evenings after dinner and talk with him of any cases of interest that he might have on hand. I was attempting to discuss with him the sensational news of that day no less than an attempted assassination of Mr. David MacAdam, England’s Prime Minister. The account in the papers had evidently been carefully censored. No details were given, save that the Prime Minister had had a marvellous escape, the bullet just grazing his cheek. I considered that our police must have been shamefully careless for such an outrage to be possible. I could well understand that the German agents in England would be willing to risk much for such an achievement. “Fighting Mac,” as his own party had nicknamed him, had strenuously and unequivocally combated the Pacifist influence which was becoming so prevalent. He was more than England’s Prime Minister he was England; and to have removed him from his sphere of influence would have been a crushing and paralysing blow to Britain. Poirot was busy mopping a grey suit with a minute sponge. Never was there a dandy such as Hercule Poirot. Neatness and order were his passion. Now, with the odour of benzine filling the air, he was quite unable to give me his full attention. “In a little minute I am with you, my friend. I have all but finished. The spot of grease he is not good I remove him so!” He waved his sponge. I smiled as I lit another cigarette. “Anything interesting on?” I inquired, after a minute or two. “I assist a how do you call it? ‘charlady’ to find her husband. A difficult affair, needing the tact. For I have a little idea that when he is found he will not be pleased. What would you? For my part, I sympathize with him. He was a man of discrimination to lose himself.” I laughed. “At last! The spot of grease, he is gone! I am at your disposal.” “I was asking you what you thought of this attempt to assassinate MacAdam?” “Enfantillage!” replied Poirot promptly. “One can hardly take it seriously. To fire with the rifle never does it succeed. It is a device of the past.” “It was very near succeeding this time,” I reminded him. Poirot shook his head impatiently. He was about to reply when the landlady thrust her head round the door and informed him that there were two gentlemen below who wanted to see him. “They won’t give their names, sir, but they says as it’s very important.” “Let them mount,” said Poirot, carefully folding his grey trousers. In a few minutes the two visitors were ushered in, and my heart gave a leap as in the foremost I recognized no less a personage than Lord Estair, Leader of the House of Commons; whilst his companion, Mr. Bernard Dodge, was also a member of the War Cabinet, and, as I knew, a close personal friend of the Prime Minister. “Monsieur Poirot?” said Lord Estair interrogatively. My friend bowed. The great man looked at me and hesitated. “My business is private.” “You may speak freely before Captain Hastings,” said my friend, nodding to me to remain. “He has not all the gifts, no! But I answer for his discretion.” Lord Estair still hesitated, but Mr. Dodge broke in abruptly: “Oh, come on don’t let’s beat about the bush! As far as I can see, the whole of England will know the hole we’re in soon enough. Time’s everything.” “Pray be seated, messieurs,” said Poirot politely. “Will you take the big chair, milord?” Lord Estair started slightly."

"We positioned ourselves on the grassy hill as Poirot advised, gazing towards the ocean. In the distance, the sounds of swimmers could be heard faintly. The sea glistened with the lightest shade of blue, evoking memories of our arrival in Merlinville and Poirot's teasing remark about my demeanor. It felt like ages had passed, though only three days had gone by. "Focus, my dear," Poirot urged. "Organize your thoughts. Approach this methodically and systematically. That is the key to triumph."

“He scrutinized me intently for a few minutes. “Indeed. I understand perfectly. And you are wise. Stick to your story.” “That seems to be your consistent advice,” I noted, somewhat annoyed. “Ah, my friend, trust in Papa Poirot. One day, if you allow me, I will arrange a highly suitable marriage for you.” “Thank you,” I chuckled, “but the idea doesn’t excite me.” Poirot sighed and shook his head. “The English!” he muttered. “No method, absolutely none. They leave everything to chance!” He furrowed his brow and adjusted the position of the salt cellar. “You mentioned that Miss Cinderella is staying at the Hôtel d’Angleterre, didn’t you?” “No. Hôtel du Phare.” “Right, I forgot.” A brief moment of doubt crossed my mind. Had I ever disclosed any hotel information to Poirot? I glanced at him and felt reassured. He was meticulously cutting his bread into small squares, completely engrossed in his task. He must have assumed that I had informed him of the girl’s whereabouts. We had coffee outdoors, with a view of the sea. Poirot smoked one of his tiny cigarettes, then retrieved his watch from his pocket. “The train to Paris departs at 2:25,” he remarked. “I should be on my way.” “Paris?” I exclaimed. “Exactly what I said, mon ami.” “You’re going to Paris? But why?” He replied gravely. “To find the killer of Mr. Renauld.” “You believe he is in Paris?” “I am absolutely certain he is not. However, that is where I must search for him. You don’t understand, but I will explain it all in due course. Trust me, this trip to Paris is imperative. I won’t be gone long. Most likely, I’ll be back tomorrow. I don’t suggest you accompany me. Stay here and keep an eye on Giraud. Also, spend time with Mr. Renauld’s son. And if you wish, try to win over Miss Marthe. But I doubt you’ll be successful.” I didn’t quite appreciate his last comment. “That reminds me,” I said. “I meant to ask you how you knew about those two?” “My friend, I understand human nature. Put together a young boy like Renauld and a beautiful girl like Miss Marthe, and the outcome is nearly inevitable. Then, the quarrel! Money or a woman, and recalling Léonie’s description of the lad’s rage, I opted for the latter. So I made my assumption, and I was correct.” “And that’s why you warned me against getting attached to the lady? You already suspected that she loved young Renauld?” Poirot smiled. “At the very least, I noticed she had anxious eyes. That’s how I always think of Miss Daubreuil as the girl with the anxious eyes…” His tone was so serious that it made me uneasy. “What do you mean by that, Poirot?” “I believe, my friend, that we will see soon enough. But I must leave.” “You have plenty of time.” “Perhaps perhaps. But I prefer to be leisurely at the station. I don’t want to rush, to hurry, to get worked up.” “In any case,” I said, standing up, “I’ll come see you off.” “You will do no such thing. I forbid it.” He was so firm that I gaped at him in surprise. He nodded decisively. “I’m serious, mon ami. Goodbye! May I hug you? Ah, no, I forget that it’s not the English custom. A handshake, then.” I felt somewhat lost after Poirot departed. I ambled down the beach, observing the swimmers, but lacking the energy to join them. I half expected Cinderella to be frolicking amongst them in a stunning outfit, but I saw no trace of her. I wandered aimlessly along the shoreline towards the far end of the town. It struck me that, in the end, it would be the right thing to do to inquire about the girl. And it would prevent future complications. The matter could then be settled. I wouldn’t need to worry about her anymore. But, if I didn’t go at all, she might very well come looking for me at the Villa. And that would be bothersome in every way. Certainly, it would be best to pay a brief visit, during which I could make it clear that I could no longer assist her as a guide. Therefore, I left the beach and headed inland. I quickly found the Hôtel du Phare, a modest building. It was incredibly frustrating not to know the lady’s name, and to save face, I chose to enter and explore. Perhaps I’d find her in the lounge. Merlinville was a small town, you left your hotel to go to the beach, and you left the beach to return to the hotel. There were no other attractions. A Casino was under construction, but it wasn’t finished yet. I had walked the length of the beach without spotting her, so she had to be in the hotel. I went inside. Several people were seated in the tiny lounge, but she wasn’t among them. I peeked into a few other rooms, but she was nowhere to be seen. After waiting for a while, impatience got the better of me. I pulled the concierge aside and slipped five francs into his hand. “I need to see a lady who is staying here. A young English lady, petite and dark-haired. I’m not certain of her name.” The man shook his head, seemingly trying to stifle a grin. “There’s no lady here matching your description.” “Maybe she’s American,” I suggested. These fellows are so dim-witted. But the man kept shaking his head. “No, monsieur. There are only six or seven English and American ladies in total, and they are all much older than the lady you’re looking for. She’s not here, monsieur.” He was so certain that I began to doubt myself. “But the lady told me she was staying here.” “Monsieur must have been mistaken, or more likely, the lady was, since another gentleman has been here inquiring about her.” “What did he look like?” “He was a small gentleman, well-dressed, very neat, very immaculate, with a very stiff mustache, a peculiarly shaped head, and green eyes.” Poirot! So that’s why he didn’t want me to go with him to the station.”

"Pagett was positive it was Rayburn?” His conviction was unwavering. “There’s something odd going on,” he remarked. “First off, where’s Rayburn?” It’s a fact that he’s been missing since we arrived on shore. He never made it to the hotel with us. I doubt he’s scared of Pagett, though. The whole situation is frustrating. One secretary has disappeared without a trace, and the other is a mess. Later on, a serious issue arose. I took Milray’s sealed letter to my meeting with the Prime Minister, only to find a blank sheet inside. Now, I’m in a mess. Why did I let Milray involve me in this? Pagett, with his black eye, seems oddly satisfied at my misfortune. He even managed to pass me the stationery trunk. He’s treading a thin line.
