I pushed the first glass aside empty. I was sitting on one of the little high stools in front of the counter. Out of the tail of my eye, I saw my tracker come in and sit down unostentatiously at a little table near the door. I finished the second coffee soda and demanded a maple one. I can drink practically an unlimited amount of ice-cream sodas. Suddenly the man by the door got up and went out. That surprised me. If he was going to wait outside, why not wait outside from the beginning. I slipped down from my stool and went cautiously to the door. I drew back quickly into the shadow. The man was talking to Guy Pagett. If I had ever had any doubts, that would have settled it. Pagett had his watch out and was looking at it. They exchanged a few brief words, and then the secretary swung on down the street towards the station. Evidently he had given his orders. But what were they? Suddenly my heart leapt into my mouth. The man who had followed me crossed to the middle of the road and spoke to a policeman. He spoke at some length, gesticulating towards Cartwright’s and evidently explaining something. I saw the plan at once. I was to be arrested on some charge or other pocket-picking, perhaps. It would be easy enough for the gang to put through a simple little matter like that. Of what good to protest my innocence? They would have seen to every detail. Long ago they had brought a charge of robbing De Beers against Harry Rayburn, and he had not been able to disprove it, though I had little doubt but that he had been absolutely blameless. What chance had I against such a “frame up” as the “Colonel” could devise? I glanced up at the clock almost mechanically, and immediately another aspect of the case struck me. I saw the point of Guy Pagett’s looking at his watch. It was just on eleven, and at eleven the mail train left for Rhodesia bearing with it the influential friends who might otherwise come to my rescue. That was the reason of my immunity up to now. From last night till eleven this morning I had been safe, but now the net was closing in upon me. I hurriedly opened my bag and paid for my drinks, and as I did so, my heart seemed to stand still, for inside it was a man’s wallet stuffed with notes! It must have been deftly introduced into my handbag as I left the tram. Promptly I lost my head. I hurried out of Cartwright’s. The little man with the big nose and the policeman were just crossing the road. They saw me, and the little man designated me excitedly to the policeman. I took to my heels and ran. I judged him to be a slow policeman. I should get a start. But I had no plan, even then. I just ran for my life down Adderly Street. People began to stare. I felt that in another minute some one would stop me. An idea flashed into my head. “The station?” I asked, in a breathless gasp. “Just down on the right.” I sped on. It is permissible to run for a train. I turned into the station, but as I did so I heard footsteps close behind me. The little man with the big nose was a champion sprinter.

I picked it up. It smelled of moth balls. So did the corpse. The doctor didn’t. So I deduced that the doctor must have removed it from the body. It had two words and some numbers written on it. "Let’s see it," Lord Nasby reached out a careless hand. "I think not," I replied, smiling. "It’s my discovery, you see." "You're smart. Right to hold onto it. No qualms about not giving it to the police?" "I tried this morning. They didn't think it was connected to the Marlow case, so I decided to keep it. And the inspector annoyed me." "Short-sighted man. Keep working on your lead. If you find something publishable, send it my way. You have potential. But you have to prove yourself first. Understand?" I thanked him and apologized for my tactics. "Don’t worry. Cheek from a pretty girl is refreshing. By the way, you said two minutes and it’s been three, accounting for interruptions. Quite impressive for a woman! Must be your scientific background." Back on the street, I found Lord Nasby tiresome. But I was thrilled. My plan had worked better than expected. Lord Nasby was surprisingly friendly. Now, I had to "make good," as he put it. In my room, I examined the paper closely. What did the numbers mean? "Seventeen one hundred and twenty-two," I whispered. No connection. I added them up. "One and seven is eight, one is nine, two is eleven, two is thirteen." Thirteen! Ominous number! Was it a warning to stay away? Possibly. But other than a warning, it seemed useless. The figures were not a clear indication of thirteen. So I subtracted twenty-two from a hundred and seventy-one. Resulting in a hundred and fifty-nine. I tried again and got a hundred and forty-nine. These calculations were futile in solving the mystery. I focused on the words. Kilmorden Castle. Concrete information. A place. Maybe the birthplace of an aristocratic family. Or a picturesque ruin. I leaned towards the buried treasure theory. Numbers often accompany treasure. Right, left, dig. I could figure that out later. The priority was reaching Kilmorden Castle quickly. I gathered reference books and searched. Time passed, annoyance grew. But there was no mention of Kilmorden Castle. A setback. There had to be such a place. Why invent a name and write it down? Absurd! Maybe it was a grandiose suburban home with a fabricated name. But it seemed impossible to find. I pondered how to proceed. The best option was visiting the crime scene. Sleuths always do. And they always discover what the police missed. I had to go to Marlow. But how to get inside the house? I considered various options and settled on simplicity. The house was vacant, I would pose as a potential tenant. I contacted local agents, hoping for fewer options. But I was wrong. The clerk presented a few properties. It was a challenge to find faults. It seemed like a dead end. "Do you have anything else?" I asked, desperately. "There's the Mill House," the clerk mentioned. "Where the murder happened." "I wouldn’t mind," I replied confidently. "And maybe I could get a good deal given the circumstances." A clever move, I believed. "It’s a possibility. Not easy to rent now with servants and all. If you like it, make an offer. Shall I write you an order?" "Please do."

I’d much prefer to have emerald green eyes than dark blue ones with silver flecks! Still, blue is a good color for adventurers. I wrapped a navy garment loosely around me, exposing my arms and shoulders. Then I tied my hair back and gathered it in a bun over my ears again. I applied a moderate amount of powder to my face, so that the skin appeared slightly paler than usual. I rummaged until I found some ancient lip balm, and I applied plenty of it to my lips. Then I shaded under my eyes with charcoal. Lastly, I draped a blue scarf over my naked shoulder, placed a crimson flower in my hair, and held a cigar in one corner of my mouth. The overall look satisfied me greatly. “Emily the Explorer,” I murmured, gazing at my reflection. “Emily the Explorer. Episode I, ‘The Cottage in Chelsea’!” Women are foolish creatures. In the following weeks, I was quite bored. Mrs. Flemming and her acquaintances struck me as exceedingly dull. They chatted endlessly about themselves and their offspring, the challenges of finding good milk for their children, and the confrontations with the Dairy over subpar milk. Then they moved on to domestic staff, and the struggles of finding competent servants, along with the discussions with the woman at the Registry Office and the responses received. They seemed disinterested in current events and the world at large. They despised traveling, finding everything too dissimilar to England. The Riviera was acceptable, naturally, as it was a meeting place for all their friends. I listened with great effort to contain my impatience. Most of these women were wealthy. They had the opportunity to explore the vast and beautiful world, yet chose to remain in grimy, dull London, discussing milkmen and housekeepers! Reflecting back now, I realize I may have been a tad intolerant. But they were insipid, incompetent even in their chosen vocation: many of them maintained remarkably inadequate and chaotic household accounts. My situation did not progress rapidly. The residence and furnishings had been sold, and the proceeds barely covered our debts. Thus far, I had not secured employment. Not that I truly desired one! I firmly believed that if I sought adventure, it would find me. It is my belief that one always obtains what they seek. My belief was about to be confirmed. It was early in January, the 8th to be precise. I was returning from an unsuccessful meeting with a lady seeking a secretary-companion, who actually seemed to require a robust cleaning lady willing to work twelve hours a day for £25 per year. After parting ways with veiled discourtesies, I strolled down Edgware Road (the meeting was held in a residence in St. John’s Wood) and across Hyde Park to St. George’s Hospital. Entering Hyde Park Corner Tube Station, I purchased a ticket to Gloucester Road. Upon reaching the platform, I walked to the far end. Curiosity drove me to confirm the existence of points and an opening between the two tunnels just past the station in the direction of Down Street. I was foolishly delighted to be proven correct. There were few individuals on the platform, and at the very end stood only myself and a man. As I passed by, I wrinkled my nose in disdain. The scent of mothballs was unbearable to me! This man's heavy coat reeked of them. Yet most individuals began wearing winter coats before January, so the scent should have dissipated by then. The man was ahead of me, standing near the tunnel edge. Lost in thought, he paid me no attention, allowing me to observe him closely. He was a petite, lean man with a tanned face, light blue eyes, and a small dark beard. “Just returned from abroad,” I surmised. “That explains the smell of his coat. He's arrived from India. Not a military officer, or he would not sport a beard. Perhaps a tea planter.” At that moment, the man pivoted as if to retreat along the platform. His gaze shifted from me to something behind me, and his expression altered drastically. Fear, almost panic, distorted his features. Stepping backward involuntarily, as if recoiling from an unseen threat, he lost his footing and tumbled over the edge. A bright flash emanated from the tracks, accompanied by a crackling noise. I screamed. Onlookers rushed to the scene. Two station officials materialized out of thin air and took charge. I remained rooted to the spot, held by a horrific fascination. Part of me recoiled at the abrupt tragedy, while another part observed with detached interest the efforts to rescue the man from the electrified rail and return him to the platform. “Please step aside. I am a physician.” A tall man with a brown beard pushed past me and bent over the motionless body. A peculiar sense of unreality enveloped me as he examined the man. It all felt surreal. Finally, the doctor straightened up and shook his head. “Deceased. There's nothing more to be done.” The crowd drew nearer, and an annoyed porter raised his voice. “Back up, will you? What’s the point of crowding around.” Nausea washed over me, and I turned and fled blindly, racing up the stairs towards the lift. It was too ghastly. I needed to escape into the open air. The doctor who had inspected the body was just ahead of me. The lift was on the verge of ascending, another had descended, and he broke into a run. In his haste, he dropped a piece of paper. I halted, picked it up, and rushed after him. However, the lift doors shut in my face, leaving me clutching the paper. By the time the lift reached street level, the doctor had vanished. I prayed the lost item was inconsequential, and for the first time, I examined it closely. It was a blank half-sheet of notepaper scrawled with some figures and words in pencil. The handwriting was illegible: [Indistinct cursive script which appears to say something like: ". 2 2 Kilmorden Castle"] Initially, it seemed unimportant. Yet, I hesitated to discard it. Pinching my nose in annoyance at the scent of mothballs, I gingerly held the paper to my face. Detecting a strong odor, I carefully folded the paper and stowed it in my bag. I made my way home slowly, lost in thought. I informed Mrs. Flemming that I had witnessed a dreadful incident in the Tube and felt unsettled, retiring to my room to rest. The kind woman insisted on serving me tea. Once left to my own devices, I set my plan in motion. I aimed to unravel the peculiar sensation of unreality I experienced while observing the doctor examine the deceased. Initially, I lay on the floor mimicking the position of the corpse, then substituted a bolster, meticulously replicating every gesture and movement of the doctor to the best of my recollection. Upon completion, I sat back and frowned at the opposite wall. The evening papers contained a brief snippet about a fatality in the Tube, questioning whether it was suicide or accident. To me, it was clear what needed to be done, and Mr. Flemming concurred upon hearing my account. “Certainly, you will be required at the inquest. You claim no one else was in close proximity to witness what occurred?” “I sensed someone approaching from behind, but I cannot confirm, and in any case, they would not have been as near as I was.” The inquest convened. Mr. Flemming made the necessary arrangements and accompanied me. He seemed apprehensive about the ordeal I would face, unaware of my composed demeanor. The deceased was identified as L. B. Carton. His pockets contained solely a note from a house agent to view a property near Marlow on the river. The bureau clerk from the hotel confirmed the man's arrival the previous day, registering under the name L. B. Carton, Kimberley, S. Africa. He appeared to have disembarked directly from a steamer. I was the sole witness to the incident. “You believe it was accidental?” inquired the coroner. “I am certain of it. Something startled him, causing him to step backward without thought.” “But what could have caused this alarm?” “That remains a mystery. However, he was undeniably frightened. He appeared panicked.” A juryman suggested some men had an irrational fear of cats, proposing the deceased might have encountered one. I found his theory lacking brilliance, though it seemed to placate the jury eager to adjourn and inclined to declare the incident an accident rather than suicide. “I find it puzzling,” remarked the coroner, “that the initial examining doctor did not come forward. His details should have been recorded at the time. It was highly irregular not to do so.” I smiled inwardly. I harbored my own suspicions regarding the doctor. In line with my theory, I resolved to visit Scotland Yard promptly. However, the following morning brought an unexpected turn of events. The Flemmings subscribed to the Daily Budget, and the publication was reveling in its latest scoop. EXTRAORDINARY DEVELOPMENT FOLLOWING TUBE TRAGEDY. WOMAN DISCOVERED SLAIN IN ISOLATED DWELLING. I avidly perused the article. “A shocking revelation unfolded yesterday at the Mill House, Marlow. The Mill House, owned by Sir Eustace Pedler, M.P., is available for rent unfurnished. An order to view this property was found in the possession of the man initially believed to have committed suicide by throwing himself onto the live rail at Hyde Park Corner Tube Station. In an upper chamber of the Mill House, the lifeless body of a striking young woman was unearthed, strangled. She is presumed to be a foreigner, yet remains unidentified. Law enforcement allegedly possesses a lead. Sir Eustace Pedler, the proprietor of the Mill House, is spending the winter on the Riviera.” None came forth to identify the deceased lady. The inquest revealed the following particulars. Around one o'clock on January 8th, a fashionable woman with a faint foreign accent arrived at the offices of Messrs. Butler and Park, real-estate agents, in Knightsbridge. She expressed interest in leasing or purchasing a residence on the Thames within close proximity to London. Several options were presented to her, including the Mill House. She identified herself as Mrs. de Castina, listing her address as the Ritz. However, no guest bearing that name was registered, and the hotel staff failed to recognize the deceased. Mrs. James, the wife of Sir Eustace Pedler's gardener and caretaker for the Mill House, provided testimony. At approximately three o'clock that afternoon, a woman arrived to inspect the property. Presenting an order from the agents, she was given the keys by Mrs. James, as was customary. The residence was located a distance from Mrs. James's residence, and she did not typically accompany prospective tenants. Shortly afterward, a young man appeared. Described as tall, broad-shouldered, with a bronzed complexion and light gray eyes, he was clean-shaven and attired in a brown suit. He informed Mrs. James he was a friend of the woman examining the house but had paused at the post office to dispatch a telegram. She directed him to the property and dismissed the matter. Five minutes later, he returned the keys to her, explaining the house did not meet their requirements. Mrs. James never glimpsed the lady, assuming she had already entered. She did note the young man appeared perturbed. “He resembled a man who had seen a ghost. I thought he was taken ill.” The subsequent day, another couple toured the premises, discovering the body in an upstairs chamber. Mrs. James identified the deceased as the lady from the prior day. The real-estate agents also confirmed her as “Mrs. de Castina.” The police surgeon estimated the woman had expired approximately twenty-four hours earlier. The Daily Budget hastily surmised that the Tube victim had murdered the woman before taking his own life. However, given the man in the Tube was deceased by two o'clock, while the woman was alive and well at three o'clock, the only reasonable conclusion was that the two events were unrelated, and the order to view the Marlow residence retrieved from the deceased man's possession was merely a fortuitous occurrence. A verdict of “Premeditated Murder by an unidentified individual or individuals” was rendered. The police (and the Daily Budget) embarked on the quest to locate “the man in the brown suit.” Mrs. James was certain no one was present in the house when the woman entered, and the sole individual to access the residence until the ensuing afternoon was the young man in question, thus pointing to him as the perpetrator of Mrs. de Castina's demise. Strangled with a stout black cord, she had been caught unawares, unable to raise an alarm. Her black silk purse contained a well-stocked wallet, loose coins, an elegant lace handkerchief, unmarked, and the return portion of a first-class train ticket to London. Little evidence to pursue. These were the facts disseminated by the Daily Budget, rallying the public to “Uncover the Man in the Brown Suit.” On average, around five hundred correspondents wrote in daily to claim they had identified the culprit, while tall young men with sun-kissed complexions lamented the decision to don a brown suit. The Tube accident, dismissed as coincidental, faded from public memory. But was it truly a coincidence? I harbored doubts. Undoubtedly, my partiality stemmed from the Tube incident, my personal enigma, yet a connection between the two fatalities appeared apparent to me. In both instances, an Englishman residing abroad with a tanned visage was present, among other similarities. It was the contemplation of these parallels that impelled me to take what I deemed a bold step. I made my way to Scotland Yard and demanded an audience with the individual overseeing the Mill House investigation. My request was initially misunderstood, as I inadvertently entered the department for misplaced umbrellas. Nonetheless, I was eventually ushered into a small room and introduced to Detective Inspector Meadows.

I believed I was being clever as I followed him through the swaying portières. Suzanne put up a fight, but eventually agreed to carry out my plan. I arrived at my destination early the next morning and was met by a Dutchman with a car. As we drove, the sound of guns grew closer. Eventually, we arrived at a rundown building and I was ushered in to see Mr. Harry Rayburn, who seemed to recognize me. He questioned why I had fallen into the trap again, but I remained composed. Mr. Chichester-Pettigrew tried to get down to business, but I insisted on speaking with Sir Eustace Pedler. After a brief exchange, I was led to Sir Eustace, who greeted me warmly and admitted to being the 'Colonel'.

"But what about the gun found at Ealing? It couldn't have been Mrs. Havering, right?" "No, that was Roger Havering's job, but it was a mistake on their part. It actually helped me figure things out. A man who used a gun found at the scene would have gotten rid of it immediately, not carried it all the way to London. The motive was clear - they wanted to divert the police's attention away from Derbyshire and Hunter's Lodge. The gun found at Ealing wasn't the one used to shoot Mr. Pace. Roger fired a shot with it, rushed to his club for an alibi, then quickly went to Ealing to place the parcel where it was found, and returned to town. His wife, the charming Mrs. Havering, shot Mr. Pace after dinner, reloaded the gun, and put it back, then started their little act. It's unbelievable," I whispered, intrigued, "and yet..." "And yet it's true. Unfortunately, bringing them to justice is another story. Japp has all the details, but I'm afraid, Hastings, we might have to let Fate take care of them," Poirot said regretfully. "The wicked may prosper, but always at a cost, believe me!" Poirot's predictions came true. Japp couldn't gather enough evidence for a conviction, and Mr. Pace's fortune ended up with his murderers. However, they didn't escape justice, as news of their deaths in the Air Mail crash to Paris meant that Justice was served. "There have been so many thefts lately," I noted one morning, setting down the paper. "Poirot, maybe we should switch from detection to crime!" "Planning to get rich quick, are you, my friend?" Poirot teased. "Look at this latest heist - the million dollars' worth of Liberty Bonds that vanished from the Olympia while en route to New York." "If only I didn't get seasick, I would love to travel on those big liners," Poirot mused dreamily. "Yes, indeed," I agreed enthusiastically. "They must be like floating palaces; the pools, lounges, restaurants, palm courts - it's hard to believe you're at sea." "I always know when I'm at sea," Poirot said sadly. "But think about the geniuses traveling incognito on those ships! One would meet the criminal elite," he added. "So that's what excites you! You wish you could have caught the thief who took the Liberty Bonds?" I laughed. Our conversation was interrupted by the landlady. "A Miss Esmée Farquhar is here to see you, Mr. Poirot. Here's her card." Miss Farquhar, a charming young lady with big brown eyes and a perfect figure, entered the room. "Please sit down, mademoiselle. This is my friend, Captain Hastings, who helps me with my cases," Poirot said. "I have a serious problem for you, Monsieur Poirot," Miss Farquhar began. "It's about the stolen Liberty Bonds on the Olympia." Poirot's surprise was evident, prompting her to explain further. "You're probably wondering what a girl like me has to do with the London and Scottish Bank. Well, I'm engaged to Mr. Philip Ridgeway." "Ah, and Mr. Ridgeway?" "He was responsible for the bonds when they were taken. It's not his fault, but it's causing him distress. His uncle, Mr. Vavasour, believes he must have mentioned having them, which has damaged his career." "Who is Mr. Vavasour?" "He's the joint general manager of the Bank. Let me tell you the whole story. The Bank wanted to expand in America, so they sent a million dollars in Liberty Bonds with Philip, who knew the New York operations well. The bonds were handed to him by Mr. Vavasour and Mr. Shaw, sealed in his presence, and locked in his bag."

Nadina, a captivating Russian performer who had captivated the audience in Paris, gracefully acknowledged the applause with a bow. Her dark eyes narrowed slightly as her crimson lips formed a subtle smile. The French spectators cheered fervently as the curtain descended, concealing the vibrant colors of the extravagant set. Dressed in flowing blue and orange fabrics, the dancer exited the stage. A man with a beard eagerly embraced her - the Manager.

At six, my father passed away. Eight years later, my mother joined him in the grave. The only kin left was my Uncle Andrew, who acquired Crabtree Manor after returning from Australia. Despite his kindness, he had firm beliefs in women's education, opposing 'book knowledge.' Our arguments were endless, especially when I won a scholarship to Girton. His will left me a year to prove my wits, challenging me to unravel the mystery of the manor. With Poirot's help, the hunt began, uncovering hidden secrets in the old house.

Please set aside your current cases and focus solely on my affairs. I am willing to cover any expenses required. Your assistance will likely be needed for an extended duration, including a potential trip to Santiago, where I resided for many years. Your fee is entirely up to you.

We returned to Crabtree Manor during the early hours of the morning. Ignoring the puzzled expressions of the Bakers, Poirot headed straight to the study. "I may have been mistaken multiple times, but now I see clearly," he declared. Without hesitation, he unlocked the desk and removed an envelope. I watched in disbelief, wondering how a substantial will could fit inside such a small package. Methodically, he opened the envelope and spread out its contents.

"But who was he?" Poirot asked. "The man with the duplicate key, the man who ordered the lock, the man who miraculously recovered from severe bronchitis. Yes, that 'stodgy' old man, Mr. Shaw! Sometimes, my friend, criminals lurk in high places. Ah, we have arrived. Mademoiselle, success is mine! May I?" Poirot beamed as he lightly kissed the astonished girl on both cheeks. Among the many adventures shared with Poirot, one of the most thrilling and dramatic was our investigation into the mysterious deaths following the opening of King Men-her-Ra's Tomb.

But another voice intervened, composed and collected, the voice of Hercule Poirot. “I can provide the information, if you wish, M.

"During a fleeting moment, Giraud's visage was veiled by an intense, almost murderous fury. Advancing two paces towards his antagonist, he was abruptly interrupted as Marchaud swung open the salon door and inquired, "M. Stonor, the secretary, has just arrived from England. May he enter?" The newcomer who crossed the threshold exuded a commanding presence. Towering in height, with a sturdy athletic build, and a deeply tanned complexion, he effortlessly captivated the room. Even Giraud appeared pallid in comparison. It wasn't long before I discerned that Gabriel Stonor possessed a truly remarkable persona."

"Lucas!” He grabbed my arm, his grip so strong that it made me flinch. “Where did you hear that name?” he asked hoarsely. “Is it yours?” I asked sweetly. “Or do you prefer to be called 'The Man in the Brown Suit'?” He was taken aback. He let go of my arm and stepped back. “Are you a girl or a witch?” he whispered. “I'm a friend,” I said, taking a step towards him. “I offered you help once, I offer it again. Will you accept it?” His response was fierce. “No. I want nothing to do with you or any woman. Do your worst.” My temper flared up. “Maybe you don't realize how much power I have over you? A word to the Captain” “Say it,” he sneered. Then, stepping closer: “And while we're at it, my dear, do you realize you're in my power right now? I could grab you by the throat like this.” With a quick motion, he demonstrated. I felt his hands on my throat, applying just a little pressure. “Like this, and squeeze the life out of you! And then, like our friend here, but with more success, toss your dead body to the sharks. What do you say to that?” I said nothing. I laughed. And yet, I knew the danger was real. In that moment, he despised me. But I reveled in the danger, in the feeling of his hands on my throat. I wouldn't trade that moment for anything in the world. With a short laugh, he let go. “What's your name?” he asked abruptly. “Anne Beddingfeld.” “Does anything scare you, Anne Beddingfeld?” “Oh, yes,” I replied, pretending to be calm. “Wasps, sarcastic women, very young men, cockroaches, and superior shop assistants.” He chuckled. Then, he nudged Pagett's unconscious body with his foot. “What should we do with this mess? Toss it overboard?” he asked casually. “If you want,” I replied calmly. “I admire your bloodthirsty instincts, Miss Beddingfeld. But we'll leave him to recover at his own pace. He's not seriously injured.” “You shy away from a second murder, I see,” I said sweetly. “A second murder?” He looked puzzled. “The woman in Marlow,” I reminded him. An ugly expression crossed his face. He seemed to have forgotten I was there. “I might have killed her,” he said. “Sometimes I think I meant to kill her.” A surge of hatred for the dead woman washed over me. I could have killed her in that moment, if she were there. For he must have loved her once, he must have, to feel that way! I regained control and spoke normally: “I think we've said all there is to say. Good night.” “Good night and goodbye, Miss Beddingfeld.” “Until we meet again, Mr. Lucas.” He winced at the name. He came closer. “Why do you say 'until we meet again'?” “Because I have a feeling we will,” I said, unable to explain why. “I never want to see you again,” he said suddenly and forcefully. It was rude, but I only laughed softly and slipped away into the darkness. I heard him start after me, then stop, and a word drifted down the deck. I think it was "witch"!
