"Can you estimate his height? Maybe around six feet?" "I believe so." "He was completely clean-shaven, correct?" "Yes, not a trace of a moustache." "Did his chin have a shiny appearance?" I inquired suddenly. Mrs. James gazed at me in astonishment. "Come to think of it, miss, it did. How did you know?" "Interestingly, murderers often have shiny chins," I declared excitedly. Mrs. James took my word seriously. "Is that so, miss? I had no idea." "Did you notice anything distinctive about his head?" "Just a regular head, miss."

As the Revolution finally subsided, Colonel Race arrived in Cape Town. Following his suggestion, we all moved into the grand villa in Muizenberg once owned by Sir Lawrence Eardsley. Plans were made for my return to England with Suzanne, where we would marry at her London home. The trousseau was to be purchased in Paris, a task that Suzanne took great pleasure in organizing. Despite the excitement, the future appeared strangely distant. At times, a suffocating sensation gripped me, leaving me breathless. On the eve of our departure, sleep eluded me.

"But what will you? Les affaires they know no mercy." Mrs. Maltravers allowed him to guide her to a chair. Despite her red, tear-stained eyes, her exceptional beauty remained undisguised. A woman of around twenty-seven or twenty-eight, fair-skinned with striking blue eyes and a charming pout. "Is this about my husband's insurance, then? Must I deal with this so soon?" "Courage, my dear Madame. Courage! You see, your late husband had a substantial life insurance policy, and in such cases, the Company needs to verify a few details. They have authorized me to represent them. Rest assured, I will make this process as painless as possible for you. Can you tell me briefly what happened on Wednesday?" "I was getting ready for tea when my maid informed me that one of the gardeners had rushed to the house. He found..." Her voice trailed off. Poirot squeezed her hand sympathetically. "I understand. Enough! Did you see your husband earlier that afternoon?" "Not since lunch. I went down to the village for stamps, and I believe he was out in the grounds." "Shooting rooks, was he?" "Yes, he usually took his rook rifle with him, and I heard a couple of shots in the distance." "Where is this rook rifle now?" "I believe it's in the hall." She led Poirot to the weapon, which he quickly examined. "Two shots fired, I see," he remarked before handing it back. "And now, madame, if I may see..." He paused tactfully. "The maid will show you," she whispered, turning away. The parlourmaid led Poirot upstairs, leaving me with the beautiful but unfortunate woman. It was difficult to decide whether to speak or remain silent. I attempted a few general remarks, to which she responded absentmindedly, until Poirot returned to us shortly after. "Thank you for your cooperation, madame. I believe you needn't worry about this matter any longer. By the way, do you know anything about your husband's finances?" She shook her head. "I'm not very knowledgeable about business matters." "I see. So you can't shed any light on why he suddenly decided to take out a life insurance policy? He hadn't done so before, correct?" "We had only been married for a little over a year. But he took out the policy because he was convinced he wouldn't live long. He had a strong feeling he was going to die soon. He had already had one hemorrhage, and he was certain another would be fatal. I tried to reassure him, but it was in vain. Unfortunately, he was right." With tears in her eyes, she bid us a graceful farewell. As we walked down the driveway together, Poirot made a characteristic gesture. "Well, that's that! Back to London, my friend, it seems there's no mystery to solve here. And yet..." "And yet what?" "A small discrepancy, that's all! Did you notice it? No? Nevertheless, life is full of inconsistencies, and surely the man couldn't have taken his own life - there's no poison that would cause him to bleed from the mouth."

"I understand,” conceded his companion. “However, they could not have accomplished this without leaving marks in the flower-bed.” I grasped the validity of his statement. Two large oval flower-beds filled with scarlet geraniums were situated on either side of the staircase leading to the front entrance. The tree in question had its roots directly behind the bed, making it impossible to approach without stepping on it. “You see,” the inspector continued, “due to the dry conditions, no prints would be visible on the driveway or paths; but on the soft soil of the flower-bed, it would be a different story.” Poirot approached the bed and examined it closely. As Bex had mentioned, the soil was completely smooth. There was not a single indentation to be found. Poirot nodded in apparent agreement, and we moved away, but suddenly he veered off and started inspecting the other flower-bed. “M. Bex!” he called out. “Come here. There are plenty of tracks for you to see.” The inspector joined him and smiled. “My dear M. Poirot, those are undoubtedly the footprints of the gardener's large boots. In any case, it would not matter, as on this side there is no tree, and thus no way to access the upper floor.” “Indeed,” Poirot muttered, looking disappointed. “So you believe these footprints are insignificant?” “Not at all.” Then, to my surprise, Poirot declared: “I beg to differ. I have a small suspicion that these footprints are the most crucial things we have encountered so far.” M. Bex remained silent, merely shrugging his shoulders. He was too polite to express his true opinion. “Shall we continue?” he inquired instead. “Of course. I can look into the matter of the footprints later,” Poirot said cheerfully. Rather than following the driveway to the gate, M. Bex turned onto a path that branched off at a right angle. It wound up a gentle slope, curving to the right of the residence, and was flanked on both sides by a type of shrubbery. Suddenly, it opened up into a small clearing with a view of the sea. A bench had been placed there, and not far off stood a somewhat dilapidated shed. A few steps ahead, a neat row of small bushes marked the edge of the Villa grounds. M. Bex pushed through them, and we found ourselves on a vast expanse of open downs. I glanced around and spotted something that filled me with surprise. “This is a golf course,” I exclaimed. Bex nodded. “The boundaries are not finished yet,” he clarified. “It is hoped that they will be ready to open next month. Some of the workers who were busy with the construction found the body early this morning.” I gasped. A little to my left, where I had momentarily overlooked it, was a long narrow trench, and beside it, face down, lay the body of a man! For a moment, my heart skipped a beat, and I had a fleeting fear that the tragedy had been repeated. But the inspector dispelled my notion by moving forward with an annoyed exclamation: “What have my officers been doing? They were strictly instructed not to allow anyone near the area without proper authorization!” The man on the ground turned his head. “But I do have the appropriate credentials,” he remarked, rising slowly to his feet. “My dear M. Giraud,” exclaimed the inspector. “I was not aware that you had arrived. The examining magistrate has been eagerly awaiting your presence.” While he spoke, I observed the newcomer with great curiosity. The renowned detective from the Paris Sûreté was someone I knew of by reputation, and I was fascinated to see him in person. He was quite tall, around thirty years old, with auburn hair and a moustache, carrying himself in a military manner. There was a hint of haughtiness in his demeanor, indicating his awareness of his own importance. Bex introduced us, presenting Poirot as a fellow investigator. A glint of interest appeared in the detective's eye. “I recognize your name, M. Poirot,” he remarked. “You were quite prominent in the past, weren't you? However, methods have evolved significantly since then.” “Crimes, on the other hand, remain largely the same,” Poirot remarked gently. It was evident to me that Giraud was prepared to be antagonistic. He was displeased at the association with the other investigator, and I sensed that if he came across a crucial clue, he would likely keep it to himself. “The examining magistrate,” Bex began. But Giraud rudely interjected: “The examining magistrate is irrelevant! The lighting is what matters. In half an hour or so, it will be gone for practical purposes. I am well-versed in the details of the case, and the individuals at the house can manage until tomorrow, but if we are to uncover a lead on the perpetrators, this is where we will find it. Have your officers been trampling all over the place? I assumed they were more competent nowadays.” “Certainly they are. The marks you are objecting to were made by the workers who discovered the body.” The other detective grunted in frustration. “I can see the tracks where the three of them came through the hedge, but they were clever. You can just about make out the central footprints as those of M. Renauld, but those on either side have been deliberately erased. Not that there would be much to see on this hard ground anyway, but they were taking no chances.” “The external sign,” Poirot remarked. “That is what you are searching for, correct?” The detective stared. “Exactly.” A faint smile played on Poirot's lips. He seemed about to speak, but held back. He bent down to where a shovel lay. “That is what was used to dig the grave, undoubtedly,” Giraud remarked. “But you will not glean anything from it.

I jumped up. Harry was waiting on the veranda outside. "Get dressed, Anne, and come out. I need to talk to you." I quickly threw on some clothes and stepped into the crisp night air, calm and fragrant, with its smooth texture. Harry motioned for me to follow him away from the house. His face was pale, his eyes intense. "Anne, do you remember telling me once that women do things they dislike for someone they care about?" "Yes," I replied, curious about what was coming next. He pulled me close. "Anne, come with me tonight. Back to Rhodesia, back to the island. I can't handle all this nonsense anymore. I can't wait for you any longer." I pulled away for a moment. "What about my French dresses?" I teased. Harry never knew when I was joking or serious. "Forget the dresses. I don't want to dress you up. I'm more likely to want to undress you. I can't let you go. You're mine. If I let you leave, I might lose you. You're coming with me tonight, no matter what." He embraced me tightly, kissing me fiercely. "I can't be without you any longer, Anne. I can't. I hate all this money. Let Race have it. Come on. Let's go." "My toothbrush?" I hesitated. "You can buy one. I know I'm crazy, but please, come!" He stormed off, with me following quietly like the Barotsi woman I once saw at the Falls. Except, I wasn't balancing a frying pan on my head. He walked so fast that I struggled to keep up. "Harry," I finally said, meekly, "are we walking all the way to Rhodesia?" He turned abruptly, laughing loudly as he scooped me up in his arms. "I'm mad, my love, I know. But I adore you so much." "We're both insane. And, oh, Harry, you never asked, but I'm not making a sacrifice at all! I wanted to come!" And that was two years ago. We still reside on the island. In front of me, on the rugged wooden table, lies the letter Suzanne sent me. Dear Babes in the Wood Dear Lunatics in Love, I'm not surprised at all. As we chatted about Paris and dresses, I sensed that it wasn't real, that you'd one day vanish to get married in the gypsy tradition. But you're both lunatics! This idea of giving up a vast fortune is ridiculous. Colonel Race wanted to debate, but I convinced him to let time settle it. He can manage the estate for Harry perfectly. Honeymoons don't last forever, you're not here, Anne, so I can say that without you pouncing on me Love in the wild will last a long time, but eventually you'll start dreaming of mansions in Park Lane, luxurious furs, Parisian gowns, top-notch cars, and fancy baby carriages! Oh, you will! Enjoy your honeymoon, dear lunatics, and may it be a long one. And think of me occasionally, gaining weight amidst the indulgences! Your dear friend, Suzanne Blair. P.S. I'm sending you a variety of frying pans as a wedding gift, and a large terrine of pâté de foie gras to remind you of me. Another letter occasionally catches my eye. It arrived long after the first, accompanied by a large package. It seemed to be sent from somewhere in Bolivia. My dear Anne Beddingfeld, I couldn't resist writing to you, not because I enjoy writing, but because I know it will bring you great joy. Our friend Race wasn't as smart as he believed, was he? I think I'll make you my literary executor. I'm sending you my diary. There's nothing in it that would interest Race and his group, but I suspect there are bits that will amuse you. Feel free to use it as you wish. I recommend an article for the Daily Budget, "Criminals I have met." I only request to be the central figure. By now, you're probably not Anne Beddingfeld anymore, but Lady Eardsley, living it up in Park Lane. I just want to say that I hold no grudge against you. It's hard, of course, to start over at my age, but, between us, I had a little nest egg saved for such a time. It has been very helpful, and I'm building a nice little business. By the way, if you ever run into your funny friend, Arthur Minks, let him know I haven't forgotten about him, will you? That should shake him up. Overall, I think I have shown a very forgiving spirit. Even towards Pagett. I heard that he, or rather Mrs. Pagett, had a sixth child recently. Soon, England will be filled with Pagetts. I sent the child a silver mug, and, on a postcard, offered to be the godfather. I can imagine Pagett taking both the mug and postcard straight to Scotland Yard with a straight face! Bless you, my dear. One day, you'll see what a mistake you made by not marrying me. Yours always, Eustace Pedler. Harry was livid. It's the one thing we don't agree on. To him, Sir Eustace was the man who tried to kill me and is responsible for his friend's death. Sir Eustace's attempts on my life always puzzled me. They didn't fit the picture, so to speak. I'm convinced he always had kind feelings towards me. So why did he try to kill me twice? Harry says "because he's a scoundrel," and thinks that solves it. Suzanne was more insightful. We discussed it, and she attributed it to a "fear complex." Suzanne is into psychoanalysis. She explained that Sir Eustace's life was driven by a desire for safety and comfort. He had a strong sense of self-preservation. The murder of Nadina removed certain inhibitions. His actions didn't reflect his feelings for me, but were driven by fears for his own safety. I believe Suzanne is correct. As for Nadina, she was the type of woman who deserved to die. Men do questionable things to get rich, but women shouldn't pretend to be in love for hidden motives. I can forgive Sir Eustace easily, but I'll never forgive Nadina. Never, never, never! The other day, I was unpacking some tins wrapped in old Daily Budget scraps, and I stumbled upon the words, "The Man in the Brown Suit." It felt like eons ago! I had cut ties with the Daily Budget long before it cut ties with me. My Romantic Wedding got plenty of attention. My son is playing in the sun, kicking his legs. There's a "man in a brown suit" if you like. He's dressed minimally, which suits Africa best, and is as tanned as can be. He's always digging in the earth. He must take after Papa. Suzanne sent a cable when he was born: "Congratulations and love to the newest arrival on Lunatics' Island. Is his head long or short?" I wasn't going to let that slide. I sent her a one-word reply: "Flat-headed!" I've heard a tale about a young writer who started his story with an attention-grabbing sentence: "'Hell!' said the Duchess." Oddly enough, my story begins similarly. Except the lady who uttered that exclamation wasn't a Duchess! It was a day in early June. I had been dealing with some business in Paris and was on my way back to London on the morning train. The Calais express was unusually empty my compartment had just one other passenger. I was hastily checking my belongings as the train started, not paying much attention to my companion. But she caught my eye in a startling way. Rising from her seat, she opened the window and exclaimed "Hell!" before pulling her head back in.

"Yet the letter from Mr. Renauld? It clearly alludes to a hidden truth involving Santiago?" "Certainly, a concealed aspect of M. Renauld's past seems evident. However, I believe the mention of Santiago is merely a diversion, a tactic to mislead us. Perhaps it was intentionally used to divert M. Renauld's suspicions away from a closer threat. Rest assured, Hastings, the danger looming over him did not originate in Santiago, but rather much closer, within France." His words carried a weight of seriousness and certainty that left me no room for doubt.

Not forgetting the mysterious visitor from the previous night, I made a mental note to locate him on the ship before the day was out. My attention was drawn to the following individuals as they seemed significant: (1) Sir Eustace Pedler, the owner of Mill House, whose appearance on the Kilmorden Castle was quite unexpected. (2) Mr. Pagett, the secretary with a sinister demeanor, who had shown great interest in securing Cabin 17. Note: Investigate his connection to Sir Eustace's journey to Cannes. (3) Reverend Edward Chichester.

"We chatted casually for a while. “Miss Beddingfeld, it seems I crossed paths with your father before. He was quite a fascinating man, and his area of expertise is something I find particularly intriguing. I've dabbled in a similar field myself. Back when I was in Dordogne” Our conversation shifted to a more specialized tone. Colonel Race's knowledge was impressive. Yet, he unexpectedly made a couple of errors in his explanations, almost as if they were intentional slip-ups."

"And with what audacity, carrying on an affair in such a manner? No caution, no secrecy. Clearly English style!” I fumed silently in my chair, while the magistrate proceeded with his interrogation, unfazed by my reaction. "So, M. Renauld did not escort Madame Daubreuil out? Did she leave on her own?" "Yes, sir. I heard them exit the study and head towards the door. Monsieur bid her good night and closed the door behind her." "At what time did this occur?" "Around twenty-five minutes past ten, sir." "Do you know when M. Renauld retired for the night?" "I heard him go up about ten minutes after us. The stairs creak so loud, one can hear every movement." "Did you hear any disturbances during the night?" "Absolutely nothing, sir." "Which servant descended first in the morning?" "It was me, sir. Immediately I noticed the door ajar." "Were the other downstairs windows secured?" "All of them. Nothing seemed amiss or suspicious." "Very well, Françoise, you may leave." The elderly woman shuffled towards the exit. Before departing, she glanced back. "I will reveal something to you, sir. That Madame Daubreuil is a wicked one! Oh, yes, women know about other women. She is wicked, mark my words." With a knowing nod, Françoise exited the room. "Léonie Oulard," summoned the magistrate. Léonie entered, weeping and on the verge of hysteria. M. Hautet handled her delicately. Her testimony centered on the discovery of her bound and gagged mistress, with some exaggeration. Like Françoise, she heard no sounds during the night. Her sister, Denise, followed. She concurred that her employer had been noticeably different as of late. "Each day he grew more sullen. He ate less. He was always melancholic." Yet Denise had her own theory. "Certainly, it was the Mafia who pursued him! Two masked men, who else could it be? A dreadful organization!" "It is a possibility," smoothly replied the magistrate. "Now, my dear, were you the one who let Madame Daubreuil into the house last night?" "Not last night, sir, the night before." "But Françoise just stated that Madame Daubreuil was here last night?" "No, sir. A lady did visit M. Renauld last night, but it was not Madame Daubreuil." Surprised, the magistrate probed further, but the girl stood firm. She was familiar with Madame Daubreuil's appearance. This woman was dark as well, but shorter and much younger. Her statement remained unshaken. "Had you ever seen this woman before?" "Never, sir." Then, hesitantly, she added: "But I believe she was English." "English?" "Yes, sir. She inquired for M. Renauld in perfectly good French, but one can always detect the accent, isn't that so? Besides, when they emerged from the study, they conversed in English." "Did you catch any of their conversation? Were you able to understand it?" "I am fluent in English," declared Denise proudly.

Inadvertently, Mademoiselle Marthe revealed the truth about another matter, contradicting Jack Renauld in the process. His noticeable pause when questioned about seeing Marthe Daubreuil on the night of the crime raised suspicions of deceit. To confirm my doubts, I needed to speak with Mademoiselle Marthe before Jack could warn her. Just three simple words from her provided the crucial information I sought. When I inquired if she was aware of Jack Renauld's presence that night, her response was simply, "He informed me."

Dressed identically to his attire in London, he always kept a small clothes-brush in his pocket to combat the dust that clung to his dark clothing. “And my boots,” he lamented. “Look at them, Hastings. My boots, usually gleaming patent leather, now filled with sand both inside and out, a painful sight. In addition, this heat is causing my once impeccable moustaches to droop in defeat!” “But look at the Sphinx,” I suggested. “Even I can sense the enigmatic allure it emits.” Poirot gazed at it disapprovingly. “It appears quite unhappy,” he observed. “Partially buried in sand in such a disorderly manner, how could it not be?”

"That’s what made me think it must be some business of a very unusual kind that he was going to discuss with these gentlemen.” Graves finished his story. He had gone out around 8.30, meeting a friend and together they went to the Metropolitan Music Hall in Edgware Road. No one saw them leave, but the time of the murder was confirmed at 8.47. A clock on the writing-table had been knocked over by Foscatini's arm, stopping at that hour, in line with Miss Rider's phone call. The police surgeon had examined the body, now resting on the couch. I observed the face for the first time the olive skin, the long nose, the thick black mustache, and the full red lips revealing white teeth. Not a pleasant face at all. "Well," said the inspector, closing his notebook. "The case seems clear. The only challenge will be to find Signor Ascanio. I assume his address is not in the dead man's pocket-book?" As Poirot had mentioned, Foscatini was organized. Neatly written was the inscription, "Signor Paolo Ascanio, Grosvenor Hotel." The inspector used the telephone, then turned to us with a smile. "Just in time. Our fine gentleman was off to catch the boat train to the Continent. Well, gentlemen, that’s about all we can do here. It’s a grim situation, but fairly straightforward. Likely one of those Italian vendetta matters." Dismissed casually, we headed downstairs. Dr. Hawker was thrilled. "Like the start of a novel, right? Real gripping stuff. Hard to believe unless you read about it." Poirot stayed silent. Throughout the evening, he barely spoke. "What does the master detective say, eh?" asked Hawker, patting him on the back. "Nothing to get your brain working this time." "You think not?" "What could there be?" "Well, for example, there is the window." "The window? But it was locked. No one could have entered or exited that way. I made sure of it." "And why were you able to make sure?" The doctor looked puzzled. Poirot clarified, "I refer to the curtains. They were not drawn. A little peculiar, isn't it? And then there was the coffee. It was very dark coffee." "Well, what of it?" "Very dark," repeated Poirot. "In conjunction with the fact that very little of the rice soufflé was eaten, what do we have?" "Nonsense," laughed the doctor. "You're joking." "I never joke. Hastings here knows I am dead serious." "I don’t know what you are getting at, all the same," I admitted. "You don’t suspect the manservant, do you? He might have been involved and spiked the coffee. I suppose they'll check his alibi?" "Certainly, my friend; but it's Signor Ascanio’s alibi that intrigues me." "You think he has an alibi?" "That is precisely what concerns me. I'm sure we will soon find out."

Lowen was completely unaware that he would have the opportunity to access the safe. His visit was for a job interview. Unbeknownst to him, Mr. Davenheim was out posting a letter, leaving Lowen alone in the study. "He could have taken advantage of the situation," I proposed. "But how would he have the tools to break into the safe? City men don't typically carry burglary tools around. And a penknife wouldn't do the job." "What about the second point?" "You mentioned that Lowen held a grudge against Mr. Davenheim. That implies he had bested him in the past. And any transactions between them were likely for Lowen's benefit. You don't usually hold a grudge against someone you've outsmarted. If anything, the grudge would be on Mr. Davenheim's side." "But he did lie about never leaving the study, didn't he?" "True. But he may have been scared. Especially considering the discovery of the missing man's clothes in the lake. Still, honesty would have been the better choice." "And the final point?" "I agree. If Kellett's account is accurate, Lowen is definitely involved. That's what makes this case so intriguing." "So, I did grasp a crucial detail?" "Perhaps, but you've missed the two most significant points that hold the key to this mystery." "And what are they?" "First, Mr. Davenheim's recent obsession with buying jewelry. And second, his trip to Buenos Ayres last fall." "Surely you can't be serious, Poirot!" "I am indeed. Ah, by the heavens, let's hope Japp doesn't forget my little request." And with that, the detective's joke led to a telegram arriving the following day. It read: "'Husband and wife have occupied separate rooms since last winter.'" "Aha!" exclaimed Poirot. "Now everything falls into place!" As I looked at him in astonishment, he warned me, "Do you not have money in Davenheim and Salmon's bank, my friend?" "No," I replied, puzzled. "Why do you ask?" "Because I suggest you withdraw it before it's too late." "Why? What do you foresee?" "A significant collapse in a few days, perhaps sooner. Let's send a message to Japp as well. A pencil and paper, please. There we go! 'Advise you to withdraw any funds deposited with the firm in question.' That will pique his interest, the good Japp! He won't understand until tomorrow, or the day after!" Despite my doubts, the next day proved Poirot's incredible foresight. The newspapers were filled with headlines about the dramatic downfall of the Davenheim bank. The disappearance of the renowned financier now took on a whole new meaning with the exposure of the bank's financial troubles.

"Anne, it appears you've encountered your match. But remember, the path of righteousness doesn't always lead to victory." Suddenly, the sound of splintering wood filled the air as footsteps thundered up the staircase. Harry swiftly unlocked the door. Colonel Race burst into the room, a look of relief washing over his features. "You're safe, Anne. I was worried," he reassured her before turning his gaze to Sir Eustace. "I've been on your trail for a while, Pedler, and now I've finally caught up with you." Sir Eustace chuckled lightly, "It seems everyone has lost their minds. These youngsters have been waving guns at me and hurling the most absurd accusations."

It was worth while doing the thing thoroughly. Only” “Yes?” “Eh bien, afterwards he had to wear a false beard and wig, had to make up as himself again, and to sleep with a false beard is not easy it invites detection! He cannot risk continuing to share the chamber of madame his wife. You found out for me that for the last six months, or ever since his supposed return from Buenos Ayres, he and Mrs. Davenheim occupied separate rooms. Then I was sure! Everything fitted in. The gardener who fancied he saw his master going round to the side of the house was quite right. He went to the boathouse, donned his ‘tramp’ clothes, which you may be sure had been safely hidden from the eyes of his valet, dropped the others in the lake, and proceeded to carry out his plan by pawning the ring in an obvious manner, and then assaulting a policeman, getting himself safely into the haven of Bow Street, where nobody would ever dream of looking for him!” “It’s impossible,” murmured Japp. “Ask Madame,” said my friend, smiling. The next day a registered letter lay beside Poirot’s plate. He opened it, and a five-pound note fluttered out. My friend’s brow puckered. “Ah, sacré! But what shall I do with it? I have much remorse! Ce pauvre Japp! Ah, an idea! We will have a little dinner, we three! That consoles me. It was really too easy. I am ashamed. I, who would not rob a child mille tonnerres! Mon ami, what have you, that you laugh so heartily?” Poirot and I had many friends and acquaintances of an informal nature. Amongst these was to be numbered Dr. Hawker, a near neighbour of ours, and a member of the medical profession. It was the genial doctor’s habit to drop in sometimes of an evening and have a chat with Poirot, of whose genius he was an ardent admirer. The doctor himself, frank and unsuspicious to the last degree, admired the talents so far removed from his own. On one particular evening in early June, he arrived about half-past eight and settled down to a comfortable discussion on the cheery topic of the prevalence of arsenical poisoning in crimes. It must have been about a quarter of an hour later when the door of our sitting-room flew open, and a distracted female precipitated herself into the room. “Oh, doctor, you’re wanted! Such a terrible voice. It gave me a turn, it did indeed.” I recognized in our new visitor Dr. Hawker’s housekeeper, Miss Rider. The doctor was a bachelor, and lived in a gloomy old house a few streets away. The usually placid Miss Rider was now in a state bordering on incoherence. “What terrible voice? Who is it, and what’s the trouble?” “It was the telephone, doctor. I answered it and a voice spoke. ‘Help,’ it said. ‘Doctor help. They’ve killed me!’ Then it sort of tailed away. ‘Who’s speaking?’ I said. ‘Who’s speaking?’ Then I got a reply, just a whisper, it seemed, ‘Foscatine’ something like that ‘Regent’s Court.’” The doctor uttered an exclamation. “Count Foscatini. He has a flat in Regent’s Court. I must go at once. What can have happened?” “A patient of yours?” asked Poirot. “I attended him for some slight ailment a few weeks ago. An Italian, but he speaks English perfectly. Well, I must wish you good night, Monsieur Poirot, unless” He hesitated. “I perceive the thought in your mind,” said Poirot, smiling. “I shall be delighted to accompany you. Hastings, run down and get hold of a taxi.” Taxis always make themselves sought for when one is particularly pressed for time, but I captured one at last, and we were soon bowling along in the direction of Regent’s Park. Regent’s Court was a new block of flats, situated just off St. John’s Wood Road. They had only recently been built, and contained the latest service devices. There was no one in the hall. The doctor pressed the lift-bell impatiently, and when the lift arrived questioned the uniformed attendant sharply. “Flat II. Count Foscatini. There’s been an accident there, I understand.” The man stared at him. “First I’ve heard of it. Mr. Graves that’s Count Foscatini’s man went out about half an hour ago, and he said nothing.” “Is the Count alone in the flat?” “No, sir, he’s got two gentlemen dining with him.” “What are they like?” I asked eagerly. We were in the lift now, ascending rapidly to the second floor, on which Flat II was situated. “I didn’t see them myself, sir, but I understand that they were foreign gentlemen.” He pulled back the iron door, and we stepped out on the landing. No. II was opposite to us. The doctor rang the bell. There was no reply, and we could hear no sound from within. The doctor rang again and again; we could hear the bell trilling within, but no sign of life rewarded us. “This is getting serious,” muttered the doctor. He turned to the lift attendant. “Is there any pass-key to this door?” “There is one in the porter’s office downstairs.” “Get it, then, and, look here, I think you’d better send for the police.” Poirot approved with a nod of the head. The man returned shortly; with him came the manager. “Will you tell me, gentlemen, what is the meaning of all this?” “Certainly. I received a telephone message from Count Foscatini stating that he had been attacked and was dying. You can understand that we must lose no time if we are not already too late.” The manager produced the key without more ado, and we all entered the flat. We passed first into a small square lounge hall. A door on the right of it was half open. The manager indicated it with a nod. “The dining-room.” Dr. Hawker led the way. We followed close on his heels. As we entered the room I gave a gasp. The round table in the centre bore the remains of a meal; three chairs were pushed back, as though their occupants had just risen. In the corner, to the right of the fire-place, was a big writing-table, and sitting at it was a man or what had been a man. His right hand still grasped the base of the telephone, but he had fallen forward, struck down by a terrific blow on the head from behind. The weapon was not far to seek. A marble statuette stood where it had been hurriedly put down, the base of it stained with blood. The doctor’s examination did not take a minute. “Stone dead. Must have been almost instantaneous. I wonder he even managed to telephone.

I was taken aback to discover that she truly cared for me. I had assumed I was just a passing fancy, but she embraced me warmly and wept when we reunited. After composing ourselves, I sat down and recounted the entire story to her. "You always suspected Colonel Race," she mused once I had finished. "I didn't until the night you vanished. I had always liked him and thought he would be a good match for you. Oh, Anne, dear, how can you be sure that your young man is telling the truth? You believe everything he says." "I trust him completely," I retorted. "But what is it about him that draws you in? All I see is his daring good looks and his modern approach to romance." I vented my frustrations at Suzanne for a few moments. "You seem to have forgotten about romance since you got married and gained weight," I concluded. "Oh, I'm not gaining weight, Anne. The worry about you has worn me down," Suzanne replied sadly. "You look quite well-fed," I remarked coolly. "And I'm not sure I'm as content in my marriage as you think." As Suzanne lamented her marital issues, I couldn't help but feel indifferent. She would handle Clarence just fine. Shifting the conversation to the diamonds, Suzanne explained her concerns. "I was afraid to keep them in my possession," she whispered to me anxiously. "A wise decision," I agreed. "But what did Sir Eustace do with the cases?" As Suzanne answered, I considered the situation carefully. "It's inconvenient but secure. Let's not act for now," I concluded. Suzanne smiled at my reluctance to remain idle. "You dislike inactivity, don't you, Anne?" she observed. "Not particularly," I admitted. The only action I could take was to check the train timetable to find Guy Pagett's arrival time in Kimberley. His train was due at 5.40 the next day. The situation in the Rand was dire, and I needed to speak with Pagett soon. The arrival of a telegram from Johannesburg provided a brief distraction. It read: "Arrived safely. All is well. Eric is here, as is Eustace, but not Guy. Stay put for now. Andy." The message indicated that I had to wait until I could meet Pagett. Suzanne busied herself sending a comforting cable to Clarence. She grew sentimental towards him, expressing her longing for his presence. As she applied face cream, Suzanne mentioned her desire for more from Paris. "You'll tire of South Africa and adventure soon," I predicted. "I wish for a nice hat," Suzanne admitted. "Shall I join you in meeting Guy Pagett tomorrow?" I declined, opting to meet him alone. And so, the next day, I found myself at the hotel entrance struggling with a stubborn parasol, while Suzanne relaxed in her room. The train arrived slightly late, and I spotted Pagett among the passengers. Approaching him, I asked about his whereabouts on January 8th.

"Unfortunately, the Prime Minister’s vehicle inexplicably veered off the main road,” Poirot interjected. “Around a bend in the road?” “Yes, but how did you surmise that?” “Oh, it’s obvious! Please, go on.” Lord Estair continued, “Without explanation, the Prime Minister’s car departed from the main road. Meanwhile, the police vehicle, oblivious to the detour, stayed on the main route. Further along the deserted path, the Prime Minister’s car was suddenly halted by a group of masked individuals. The driver” Poirot mused, “That courageous O’Murphy!”

"However, she found solace in his lack of dismissal towards her fears. Surprisingly, I had never imagined Poirot to possess such a strong belief in superstitions. Bringing up the topic on our way back, his demeanor was serious. 'Indeed, Hastings. I have faith in these matters. Superstition holds significant power.' 'So, what's our next move?' 'Always practical, dear Hastings! Well, first things first, we will send a cable to New York for more information on the death of young Mr. Bleibner.' With that, he promptly dispatched the cable. The response was detailed and to the point, revealing that young Rupert Bleibner had been struggling for years."

"It was most irregular, but the lady is without doubt young and beautiful, n’est-ce pas? What it is to be young! O jeunesse, jeunesse!” And he sighed sentimentally. But the commissary, less romantic, and more practical, took up the tale: “But did not you reclose and lock the door when you departed.” “That’s just it,” I said slowly. “That’s what I blame myself for so terribly. My friend was upset at the sight. She nearly fainted. I got her some brandy and water, and afterwards insisted on accompanying her back to town. In the excitement, I forgot to relock the door. I only did so when I got back to the Villa.” “Then for twenty minutes at least ” said the commissary slowly. He stopped. “Exactly,” I said. “Twenty minutes,” mused the commissary. “It is deplorable,” said M. Hautet, his sternness of manner returning. “Without precedent.” Suddenly another voice spoke. “You find it deplorable, M. le juge?” asked Giraud. “Certainly I do.” “Eh bien! I find it admirable,” said the other imperturbably. This unexpected ally quite bewildered me. “Admirable, M. Giraud?” asked the magistrate, studying him cautiously out of the corner of his eye. “Precisely.” “And why?” “Because we know now that the assassin, or an accomplice of the assassin, has been near the Villa only an hour ago. It will be strange if, with that knowledge, we do not shortly lay hands upon him.” There was a note of menace in his voice. He continued: “He risked a good deal to gain possession of that dagger. Perhaps he feared that finger-prints might be discovered on it.” Poirot turned to Bex. “You said there were none?” Giraud shrugged his shoulders. “Perhaps he could not be sure.” Poirot looked at him. “You are wrong, M. Giraud. The assassin wore gloves. So he must have been sure.” “I do not say it was the assassin himself. It may have been an accomplice who was not aware of that fact.” “Ils sont mal renseignés, les accomplices!” muttered Poirot, but he said no more. The magistrate’s clerk was gathering up the papers on the table. M. Hautet addressed us: “Our work here is finished. Perhaps, M. Renauld, you will listen whilst your evidence is read over to you. I have purposely kept all the proceedings as informal as possible. I have been called original in my methods, but I maintain that there is much to be said for originality. The case is now in the clever hands of the renowned M. Giraud. He will without doubt distinguish himself. Indeed, I wonder that he has not already laid his hands upon the murderers! Madame, again let me assure you of my heart-felt sympathy. Messieurs, I wish you all good day.” And, accompanied by his clerk and the commissary, he took his departure. Poirot tugged out that large turnip of a watch of his, and observed the time. “Let us return to the hotel for lunch, my friend,” he said. “And you shall recount to me in full the indiscretions of this morning. No one is observing us. We need make no adieux.” We went quietly out of the room. The examining magistrate had just driven off in his car. I was going down the steps when Poirot’s voice arrested me: “One little moment, my friend.” Dexterously, he whipped out his yard measure, and proceeded, quite solemnly, to measure an overcoat hanging in the hall from the collar to the hem. I had not seen it hanging there before, and guessed that it belonged to either Mr. Stonor, or Jack Renauld. Then, with a little satisfied grunt, Poirot returned the measure to his pocket, and followed me out into the open air. “Why did you measure that overcoat?” I asked, with some curiosity, as we walked down the hot white road at a leisurely pace. “Parbleu! to see how long it was,” replied my friend imperturbably. I was vexed. Poirot’s incurable habit of making a mystery out of nothing never failed to irritate me. I relapsed into silence, and followed a train of thought of my own. Although I had not noticed them specially at the time, certain words Mrs. Renauld had addressed to her son now recurred to me, fraught with a new significance. “So you did not sail?” she had said, and then had added: “After all, it does not matter now.” What had she meant by that? The words were enigmatical significant. Was it possible that she knew more than we supposed? She had denied all knowledge of the mysterious mission with which her husband was to have entrusted his son. But was she really less ignorant than she pretended? Could she enlighten us if she chose, and was her silence part of a carefully thought out and preconceived plan? The more I thought about it, the more I was convinced that I was right. Mrs. Renauld knew more than she chose to tell. In her surprise at seeing her son, she had momentarily betrayed herself. I felt convinced that she knew, if not the assassins, at least the motive for the assassination. But some very powerful considerations must keep her silent. “You think profoundly, my friend,” remarked Poirot, breaking in upon my reflections. “What is it that intrigues you so?” I told him, sure of my ground, though feeling expectant that he would ridicule my suspicions. But to my surprise he nodded thoughtfully. “You are quite right, Hastings. From the beginning I have been sure that she was keeping something back. At first I suspected her, if not of inspiring, at least of conniving at the crime.” “You suspected her?” I cried. “But certainly! She benefits enormously in fact, by this new will, she is the only person to benefit. So, from the start, she was singled out for attention. You may have noticed that I took an early opportunity of examining her wrists. I wished to see whether there was any possibility that she had gagged and bound herself. Eh bien, I saw at once that there was no fake, the cords had actually been drawn so tight as to cut into the flesh. That ruled out the possibility of her having committed the crime single-handed. But it was still possible for her to have connived at it, or to have been the instigator with an accomplice. Moreover, the story, as she told it, was singularly familiar to me the masked men that she could not recognize, the mention of ‘the secret’ I had heard, or read, all these things before. Another little detail confirmed my belief that she was not speaking the truth. The wrist watch, Hastings, the wrist watch!” Again that wrist watch! Poirot was eyeing me curiously. “You see, mon ami? You comprehend?” “No,” I replied with some ill humour. “I neither see nor comprehend. You make all these confounded mysteries, and it’s useless asking you to explain. You always like keeping everything up your sleeve to the last minute.” “Do not enrage yourself, my friend,” said Poirot with a smile. “I will explain if you wish. But not a word to Giraud, c’est entendu? He treats me as an old one of no importance! We shall see! In common fairness I gave him a hint. If he does not choose to act upon it, that is his own look out.” I assured Poirot that he could rely upon my discretion. “C’est bien! Let us then employ our little grey cells. Tell me, my friend, at what time, according to you, did the tragedy take place?” “Why, at two o’clock or thereabouts,” I said, astonished. “You remember, Mrs. Renauld told us that she heard the clock strike while the men were in the room.” “Exactly, and on the strength of that, you, the examining magistrate, Bex, and every one else, accept the time without further question. But I, Hercule Poirot, say that Madame Renauld lied. The crime took place at least two hours earlier.” “But the doctors ” “They declared, after examination of the body, that death had taken place between ten and seven hours previously. Mon ami, for some reason, it was imperative that the crime should seem to have taken place later than it actually did. You have read of a smashed watch or clock recording the exact hour of a crime? So that the time should not rest on Mrs. Renauld’s testimony alone, some one moved on the hands of that wrist watch to two o’clock, and then dashed it violently to the ground. But, as is often the case, they defeated their own object. The glass was smashed, but the mechanism of the watch was uninjured. It was a most disastrous manoeuvre on their part, for it at once drew my attention to two points first, that Madame Renauld was lying: secondly, that there must be some vital reason for the postponement of the time.” “But what reason could there be?” “Ah, that is the question! There we have the whole mystery. As yet, I cannot explain it. There is only one idea that presents itself to me as having a possible connection.” “And that is?” “The last train left Merlinville at seventeen minutes past twelve.” I followed it out slowly. “So that, the crime apparently taking place some two hours later, any one leaving by that train would have an unimpeachable alibi!” “Perfect, Hastings! You have it!” I sprang up. “But we must inquire at the station. Surely they cannot have failed to notice two foreigners who left by that train! We must go there at once!” “You think so, Hastings?” “Of course. Let us go there now.” Poirot restrained my ardour with a light touch upon the arm. “Go by all means if you wish, mon ami but if you go, I should not ask for particulars of two foreigners.” I stared, and he said rather impatiently: “Là, là, you do not believe all that rigmarole, do you? The masked men and all the rest of cette histoire-là!” His words took me so much aback that I hardly knew how to respond. He went on serenely: “You heard me say to Giraud, did you not, that all the details of this crime were familiar to me? Eh bien, that presupposes one of two things, either the brain that planned the first crime also planned this one, or else an account read of a cause célèbre unconsciously remained in our assassin’s memory and prompted the details. I shall be able to pronounce definitely on that after ” he broke off. I was revolving sundry matters in my mind. “But Mr. Renauld’s letter? It distinctly mentions a secret and Santiago?” “Undoubtedly there was a secret in M. Renauld’s life there can be no doubt of that. On the other hand, the word Santiago, to my mind, is a red herring, dragged continually across the track to put us off the scent. It is possible that it was used in the same way on M. Renauld, to keep him from directing his suspicions into a quarter nearer at hand. Oh, be assured, Hastings, the danger that threatened him was not in Santiago, it was near at hand, in France.” He spoke so gravely, and with such assurance, that I could not fail to be convinced. But I essayed one final objection: “And the match and cigarette end found near the body? What of them.” A light of pure enjoyment lit up Poirot’s face. “Planted! Deliberately planted there for Giraud or one of his tribe to find! Ah, he is smart, Giraud, he can do his tricks! So can a good retriever dog. He comes in so pleased with himself. For hours he has crawled on his stomach. ‘See what I have found,’ he says. And then again to me: ‘What do you see here?’ Me, I answer, with profound and deep truth, ‘Nothing.’ And Giraud, the great Giraud, he laughs, he thinks to himself, ‘Oh, that he is imbecile, this old one!’ But we shall see.…” But my mind had reverted to the main facts. “Then all this story of the masked men ?” “Is false.” “What really happened?” Poirot shrugged his shoulders. “One person could tell us Madame Renauld. But she will not speak. Threats and entreaties would not move her. A remarkable woman that, Hastings. I recognized as soon as I saw her that I had to deal with a woman of unusual character. At first, as I told you, I was inclined to suspect her of being concerned in the crime. Afterwards I altered my opinion.” “What made you do that?” “Her spontaneous and genuine grief at the sight of her husband’s body. I could swear that the agony in that cry of hers was genuine.” “Yes,” I said thoughtfully, “one cannot mistake these things.” “I beg your pardon, my friend one can always be mistaken. Regard a great actress, does not her acting of grief carry you away and impress you with its reality? No, however strong my own impression and belief, I needed other evidence before I allowed myself to be satisfied. The great criminal can be a great actor. I base my certainty in this case, not upon my own impression, but upon the undeniable fact that Mrs. Renauld actually fainted. I turned up her eyelids and felt her pulse. There was no deception the swoon was genuine. Therefore I was satisfied that her anguish was real and not assumed. Besides, a small additional point not without interest, it was unnecessary for Mrs. Renauld to exhibit unrestrained grief. She had had one paroxysm on learning of her husband’s death, and there would be no need for her to simulate another such a violent one on beholding his body. No, Mrs. Renauld was not her husband’s murderess. But why has she lied? She lied about the wrist watch, she lied about the masked men she lied about a third thing. Tell me, Hastings, what is your explanation of the open door?” “Well,” I said, rather embarrassed, “I suppose it was an oversight. They forgot to shut it.” Poirot shook his head, and sighed. “That is the explanation of Giraud. It does not satisfy me. There is a meaning behind that open door which for a moment I cannot fathom.” “I have an idea,” I cried suddenly. “A la bonne heure! Let us hear it.” “Listen. We are agreed that Mrs. Renauld’s story is a fabrication. Is it not possible, then, that Mr. Renauld left the house to keep an appointment possibly with the murderer leaving the front door open for his return. But he did not return, and the next morning he is found, stabbed in the back.” “An admirable theory, Hastings, but for two facts which you have characteristically overlooked. In the first place, who gagged and bound Madame Renauld? And why on earth should they return to the house to do so? In the second place, no man on earth would go out to keep an appointment wearing his underclothes and an overcoat. There are circumstances in which a man might wear pajamas and an overcoat but the other, never!” “True,” I said, rather crest-fallen. “No,” continued Poirot, “we must look elsewhere for a solution of the open door mystery.

"I regret to inform you, Monsieur, that Poirot is indisposed with influenza," I informed him. His countenance darkened. "Good Lord, this is a devastating blow to me." "Is the matter you wish to discuss with him of grave importance?" "Absolutely! My uncle, my closest friend, was brutally murdered last night." "Here in London?" "No, in Derbyshire. Upon receiving a telegram from my wife this morning, I hastened to seek Monsieur Poirot's assistance with the case." "Allow me a moment," I interjected, struck by a sudden thought. I hurried upstairs to brief Poirot on the situation in a few concise words. He cut me off. "Understood. You wish to investigate yourself, is that correct? Well, why not? You are familiar with my methods. I only ask that you provide me with detailed daily reports and strictly follow any instructions I may send." I readily agreed. An hour later, I found myself seated across from Mr. Havering in a first-class carriage on the Midland Railway, swiftly departing from London. "To start, Captain Hastings, Hunter's Lodge, the scene of the tragedy, is a small shooting-box nestled in the Derbyshire moors. Our main residence is near Newmarket, and we usually rent a flat in town. Hunter's Lodge is managed by a capable housekeeper, with our own Newmarket servants joining us during the shooting season. My uncle, Mr. Harrington Pace, has resided with us for three years. While he and my father and brother did not see eye to eye, my uncle and I got along well. He was demanding but not difficult, and we lived harmoniously. Two days ago, my uncle suggested we visit Derbyshire for a brief respite. I had to return to London yesterday, leaving my wife and uncle behind. This morning, I received a telegram." He passed it to me: "Come at once uncle Harrington murdered last night bring good detective if you can but do come Zoe." "You are not yet aware of the details?" "No, but I expect the evening papers to have information. The authorities are likely involved." When we reached Elmer's Dale station around three o'clock, we proceeded to a small grey stone building amidst the rugged moors. "A desolate place," I remarked, feeling a chill. Havering nodded. "I intend to rid myself of it. I could never reside here again." As we approached the gate, a familiar figure emerged to greet us. "Japp!" I exclaimed. The Scotland Yard inspector greeted me amiably before turning to Mr. Havering. "Mr. Havering, correct? I've been sent from London to take charge of this case. Might I have a word with you, sir?" "My wife" "I've spoken with your wife and the housekeeper. I won't detain you long, but I would appreciate your insights. Captain Hastings here knows me, and he will inform the household of your arrival. By the way, where is the little man, Captain Hastings?" "He's unwell with influenza." "Is that so? A case of the cart without the horse, you being here without him, isn't it?" With that, Japp ushered me into the house. After a brief wait, a middle-aged woman in black opened the door. "Mr. Havering will join us shortly," I explained. "I have come from London with him to investigate the case. Could you give me a brief account of last night's events?" "Please come inside, sir," she replied, leading me into the dimly-lit hall. "It was after dinner when the man arrived, sir. He inquired to see Mr. Pace, and, as he spoke similarly to Mr. Pace, I assumed he was an American acquaintance and directed him to the gun-room. Shortly after, I informed Mr. Pace, who went to meet him. The man did not provide a name, which, in hindsight, struck me as odd. Mr. Pace appeared puzzled but proceeded to the gun-room. I returned to the kitchen but soon heard raised voices, as though an argument ensued. I rushed to the hall, coinciding with Mrs. Havering's arrival. A gunshot followed, and an eerie silence descended. We both hurried to the gun-room door, finding it locked. We circled the house to reach the window, which was ajar. Inside, we discovered Mr. Pace, shot and bleeding." "Where did the man go?" "He must have escaped through the window before we arrived." "And then?" "Mrs. Havering dispatched me to summon the police, a five-mile journey by foot. They arrived, and a London police officer came this morning." "Can you describe the man who visited Mr. Pace?" After pondering, she replied, "He had a black beard, appeared middle-aged, and wore a light overcoat. Aside from his American accent, I did not notice much else." "I understand. Might I speak with Mrs. Havering?" "She is upstairs, sir. Shall I inform her?" "Please do. Let her know that Mr. Havering is outside with Inspector Japp, and that I, the gentleman accompanying him from London, wish to speak with her promptly." "Very well, sir." Impatient to uncover the truth, I eagerly awaited Mrs. Havering's arrival. A short while later, a striking young woman descended the stairs. Clad in a vibrant jumper and a leather hat, she exuded vitality despite the tragic circumstances. After our introductions, she expressed her readiness to answer any questions. "What time did the man arrive?" I inquired. "Just before nine o'clock. We had finished dinner and were enjoying coffee and cigarettes." "Your husband had already departed for London?" "Indeed. He left for the 6.15 train." "Did he travel to the station by car or on foot?" "Our car was not present. A vehicle from Elmer's Dale garage fetched him for the train." "Was Mr. Pace behaving normally?" "Completely. He showed no signs of distress." "Can you provide any description of the visitor?" "I'm afraid I cannot. Mrs. Middleton escorted him to the gun-room, and I did not see him." "How did Mr. Pace react?" "He appeared irritated but went to meet the man. Shortly after, we heard raised voices. Upon reaching the gun-room, we found it locked. By the time we reached the window, the assailant had fled. My uncle had been shot in the head. I ensured the room remained undisturbed." Impressed by her attention to detail, I commended her actions. "Regarding the weapon?" "I can hazard a guess, Captain Hastings. Two revolvers belonging to my husband were displayed on the wall. One is missing. I notified the police, who confiscated the remaining one. They will examine the bullet to confirm." "May I visit the gun-room?" "Certainly. The police have concluded their investigation. However, the body has been removed." She accompanied me to the crime scene. As Havering entered the hall, his wife rushed to him. Left alone, I conducted a thorough search but found no substantial leads apart from a bloodstain on the carpet. Disappointed, I took a few photographs and examined the area outside the window, but the trampled ground yielded nothing of significance. My exploration of Hunter's Lodge concluded, and I made my way back to Elmer's Dale to meet with Japp. At the Matlock Arms, Japp and I proceeded to view the body of Harrington Pace, a lean, clean-shaven man with typical American features. Shot at close range in the back of the head, it was evident he had been taken by surprise. As we departed, Japp shared his suspicions about Havering's past transgressions. We discussed the case further, analyzing the revolver found near the crime scene. With additional details to report, I penned a thorough account to Poirot before receiving a wire advising Middleton's arrest. Unfortunately, she had vanished, leaving behind only mundane belongings.

“You knew Jack Renauld would be coming that night, or whether you just waited about on the chance of seeing him, but you did wait about. Maybe you were just miserable, and walked aimlessly but at any rate just before twelve you were still near there, and you saw a man on the golf links. I saw the peculiar pattern of the overcoat on the dead body of Mr. Renauld, and the amazing likeness that had startled me into believing for one instant that the dead man had risen from the dead when his son burst into our conclave in the salon. “I fancy his back was to you but you recognized him, or thought you recognized him. The gait and the carriage were familiar to you, and the pattern of his overcoat. You told me in the train on the way from Paris that you had Italian blood in your veins, and that you had nearly got into trouble once with it. You used a threat in one of your letters to Jack Renauld. When you saw him there, your anger and jealousy drove you mad and you struck! I don’t believe for a minute that you meant to kill him. But you did kill him, Cinderella.” She had flung up her hands to cover her face, and in a choked voice she said: “You’re right… you’re right… I can see it all as you tell it.” Then she turned on me almost savagely. “And you love me? Knowing what you do, how can you love me?” “I don’t know,” I said a little wearily. “I think love is like that a thing one cannot help. I have tried, I know ever since the first day I met you. And love has been too strong for me.” And then suddenly, when I least expected it, she broke down again, casting herself down on the floor and sobbing wildly. “Oh, I can’t!” she cried. “I don’t know what to do. I don’t know which way to turn. Oh, pity me, pity me, some one, and tell me what to do!” Again I knelt by her, soothing her as best I could. “Don’t be afraid of me, Bella. For God’s sake don’t be afraid of me. I love you, that’s true but I don’t want anything in return. Only let me help you. Love him still if you have to, but let me help you as he can’t.” It was as though she had been turned to stone by my words. She raised her head from her hands and stared at me. “You think that?” she whispered. “You think that I love Jack Renauld?” Then, half laughing, half crying, she flung her arms passionately round my neck, and pressed her sweet wet face to mine. “Not as I love you,” she whispered. “Never as I love you!” Her lips brushed my cheek, and then, seeking my mouth, kissed me again and again with a sweetness and fire beyond belief. The wildness of it and the wonder, I shall not forget no, not as long as I live! It was a sound in the doorway that made us look up. Poirot was standing there looking at us. I did not hesitate. With a bound I reached him and pinioned his arms to his sides. “Quick,” I said to the girl.

I received instructions and approval by cable at Bulawayo. I was on the staff of the Daily Budget and had a private word of congratulation from Lord Nasby himself. I was accredited to hunt down the murderer, and I knew that the murderer was not Harry Rayburn. But let the world think that it was him for now. We arrived in Bulawayo early on Saturday morning. The place was disappointing and I hated the hotel. Sir Eustace was thoroughly sulky. Our wooden animals annoyed him, especially the big giraffe. It was a colossal giraffe with an impossible neck, a mild eye, and a dejected tail. It had character and charm. A controversy arose as to whom it belonged me or Suzanne. We had each contributed to its purchase. Suzanne advanced the claims of seniority and the married state, while I stuck to the position that I had been the first to behold its beauty. In the meantime, it occupied a good deal of our three-dimensional space. Two porters were laden with a bunch of animals, and one dropped a ravishing group of ostriches and broke their heads off. Suzanne and I carried what we could, Colonel Race helped, and I pressed the big giraffe into Sir Eustace’s arms. Miss Pettigrew did not escape; a large hippopotamus and two black warriors fell to her share. I had a feeling Miss Pettigrew didn’t like me. Perhaps she fancied I was a bold hussy. She avoided me as much as she could. Her face seemed vaguely familiar to me, though I couldn’t place it. We reposed ourselves most of the morning, and in the afternoon we drove out to the Matoppos to see Rhodes’s grave. At the last moment, Sir Eustace backed out. He cursed the porters, the waiters at breakfast, and the whole hotel management. He would have liked to curse Miss Pettigrew, but I don’t think even he would have dared to. She’s just like the efficient secretary in a book. I rescued our giraffe just in time. I feel Sir Eustace would have liked to dash him to the ground. After Sir Eustace backed out, Miss Pettigrew said she would stay at home in case he might want her. And at the last minute, Suzanne sent a message to say she had a headache. So Colonel Race and I drove off alone. He is a strange man. One doesn’t notice it so much in a crowd. But when one is alone with him, the sense of his personality seems really almost overpowering. He becomes more taciturn, and yet his silence seems to say more than speech might do. That day, we drove to the Matoppos through the soft yellow-brown scrub. Everything seemed strangely silent except our car, which I should think was the first Ford ever made by man. The upholstery was torn, and all was not as it should be in its interior. The country changed, and great boulders appeared, piled into fantastic shapes. I felt suddenly that I had gotten into a primitive era. Neanderthal men seemed quite real. I turned to Colonel Race and said dreamily, “There must have been giants once.” “Perhaps you’re nearer the mark than you know,” Colonel Race said gravely. “Simple, primitive, big that is Africa.” I nodded appreciatively. “You love it, don’t you?” I asked. “Yes. But to live in it long well, it makes one what you would call cruel. One comes to hold life and death very lightly.” “But not cruel to weak things?” “Opinions differ as to what are and are not ‘weak things,’ Miss Anne.” I felt that I knew very little really of this man at my side. “I meant children and dogs, I think.” “I’ve never been cruel to children or dogs. So you don’t class women as ‘weak things’?” “No, I don’t think I do though they are, I suppose. That is, they are nowadays. But Papa always said that in the beginning, men and women roamed the world together, equal in strength like lions and tigers.” “And giraffes?” Colonel Race said slyly.
