No, not the type you're imagining, dining at the Savoy adorned with jewels, and with their photo in every paper declaring how much they adore Madame So and So's face cream. I've been performing on stage since I was a child of six tumbling.” “I apologize,” I said, confused. “Haven't you seen child acrobats?” “Oh, I see.” “I'm American born, but I've spent most of my life in England. We have a new show now ” “We?” “My sister and I. A combination of song and dance, along with a bit of banter, and a touch of the old business mixed in. It's quite an innovative concept, and it impresses the audience every time. There's money to be made in it.” My new acquaintance leaned forward, and spoke rapidly, using many terms that were completely unintelligible to me. Yet, I discovered myself becoming increasingly intrigued by her. She appeared to be a peculiar blend of child and woman. Although completely worldly-wise, and capable, as she put it, of taking care of herself, there was still something remarkably genuine in her straightforward approach towards life, and her wholehearted determination to 'make good.' This peek into an unfamiliar world was not without its allure, and I relished seeing her lively little face light up as she spoke. We passed through Amiens. The name stirred up numerous memories. My companion seemed to have an intuitive understanding of what was on my mind. “Thinking of the War?” I nodded. “You experienced it, I presume?” “Pretty extensively. I was injured once, and after the Somme they discharged me completely. I had a half-baked Army job for a while. I'm now a sort of private secretary to an M. P.” “My! That's clever!” “No, it's not. There's actually very little to do. Usually a couple of hours each day suffices. It's also quite boring work. In fact, I don't know what I would do if I didn't have something to fall back on.” “Don't tell me you collect bugs!” “No. I share a flat with a very fascinating man. He's a Belgian, a former detective. He's established himself as a private detective in London, and he's doing remarkably well. He's truly a remarkable individual. Time and again he has been proven right where the official police have failed.” My companion listened with widening eyes. “Isn't that fascinating, now? I just adore crime. I watch all the mysteries on the movies. And when there's a murder, I devour the newspapers.” “Do you recall the Styles Case?” I inquired. “Let me think, was that the elderly lady who was poisoned? Somewhere down in Essex?” I nodded. “That was Poirot's first major case. Undoubtedly, if not for him, the murderer would have gotten away unpunished. It was a remarkable piece of detective work.” Getting more engrossed in my topic, I recounted the details of the incident, leading up to the triumphant and unexpected resolution. The girl listened spellbound. In fact, we were so absorbed that the train pulled into Calais station before we realized it. “My goodness gracious me!” exclaimed my companion. “Where's my powder-puff?” She proceeded to apply makeup liberally on her face, and then used a lip salve on her lips, examining the effect in a small mirror, displaying no hint of self-consciousness. “I say,” I hesitated. “I know it may seem presumptuous, but why go through all that trouble?” The girl paused in her actions, and stared at me with overt surprise. “It's not as if you aren't so pretty that you can do without it,” I said haltingly. “My dear boy! I have to do it. All the girls do. Do you think I want to appear like a frumpy country bumpkin?” She took a final look in the mirror, smiled in approval, and stowed it and her vanity box away in her bag. “That's better. Keeping up appearances can be a bit of a chore, I admit, but if a girl respects herself, it's her responsibility not to let herself go.” To this fundamentally moral sentiment, I had no response. A differing perspective makes a significant impact. I enlisted a couple of porters, and we disembarked on the platform. My companion extended her hand. “Goodbye, and I'll watch my language better in the future.” “Oh, but surely you'll allow me to accompany you on the boat?” “I may not be on the boat. I have to verify if my sister managed to board after all. But thank you nonetheless.” “Oh, but we're bound to meet again, right? I ” I hesitated. “I want to meet your sister.” We both chuckled. “That's very kind of you. I'll convey your message to her. But I doubt we'll cross paths again. You've been very kind to me on this journey, particularly after my impudence.”

As I made my way to Villa Geneviève, my mood soured by the unsatisfactory turn of events, I opted for the solitude of the small bench near the shed. Lost in my thoughts, I was suddenly startled by the sound of approaching voices. It was not until the voices drew closer that I realized they were not from the garden I sat in, but from the neighboring Villa Marguerite. Amongst the voices, I distinguished the melodious tone of Marthe, the beautiful girl I knew all too well.

He grasped my arm tightly. "I've made a fool of myself, my dear friend! I could hear the love and sorrow in her voice, my little theory was completely off. Well, I must rethink everything!" The doctor and M. Hautet carried the unconscious woman inside. The police inspector watched them, sighing. "Poor woman," he muttered. "The trauma was too overwhelming for her. There's nothing we can do now. Shall we go to the crime scene, M. Poirot?" "Yes, let's, M. Bex." We made our way through the house and exited through the front entrance.

"Indeed, she certainly has a past! Though not as young as before, I have observed men turning their heads as she passes by. Recently, she seems to have more money to spare, a fact well-known in town. The days of penny-pinching are over." With an air of absolute conviction, Françoise shook her head. M. Hautet pondered, stroking his beard. "And what of Madame Renauld's reaction to this companionship?" he inquired. Françoise simply shrugged. "She has always been pleasant and polite. It's as if she is completely unaware."

Mrs. Davenheim is described as a pleasant but not very bright woman, and it is mentioned that Mr. Davenheim had many financial rivals who may bear ill will towards him. A gardener saw a figure near the rose-garden, and there is speculation about suicide or foul play. Poirot examines a photograph of the missing man and finds the case to be quite obscure. Japp later reveals that Mr. Davenheim's clothes were found near the lake, and Lowen, a suspect, was seen near the study around the time of the disappearance. A pawned ring belonging to Mr. Davenheim further complicates the case. The narrative ends with the introduction of Billy Kellett, who provides a strange account of his activities on the day of the disappearance.

"As we drove back from the Matoppos that day, I made a decision. And now, I can confidently say that I have followed through. The man you care for is no longer under any shadow of doubt." "So that was your intention all along?" "Yes, it was." I felt a wave of guilt for ever suspecting otherwise. He continued, his voice filled with reflection: "In my youth, I loved a woman who left me heartbroken. I dedicated myself to my profession after that. But when I met you, Anne, everything changed."

"I demanded, 'How could you?' Our eyes met, filled with animosity as if we were sworn enemies. It was the first time I truly observed his features: the dark, closely cropped hair, the angular jawline, the scar on his tan cheek, and the piercing light grey eyes that held a hint of daring mockery. There was an undeniable danger about him. 'You haven't even thanked me for saving your life,' I remarked, feigning sweetness. When my words struck a nerve, I relished in his visible reaction. I knew deep down that he despised being reminded of his debt to me, but I didn't care. 'I wish you hadn't,' he erupted. 'I'd rather be dead.' 'You can't deny the obligation. I saved you, and I'm waiting for your gratitude,' I countered. If looks could kill, I would have been dead on the spot. He pushed past me roughly and, before leaving, declared, 'I won't thank you now or ever. But I will repay the debt one day.' With clenched fists and a racing heart, I was left in his wake. The night passed without further incident. The next morning, I had a late breakfast in bed and ventured onto the deck. Mrs. Blair greeted me, 'Good morning, Gipsy girl. Sit with me. You look like you didn't sleep well.' 'Why do you call me that?' I inquired, taking a seat. 'Does it bother you? It suits you somehow. Ever since we met, I've thought of you that way. It's the gipsy spirit in you that sets you apart. I decided that you and Colonel Race were the only ones worth talking to on this ship.' 'That's amusing,' I replied. 'I had the same thought about you, although your charm makes it more understandable. You're quite the refined lady.' 'Well said,' Mrs. Blair acknowledged. 'Now, tell me about yourself, Gipsy girl. Why are you headed to South Africa?' I shared some details about my father's work. 'So you're Charles Beddingfeld's daughter? I knew you weren't just a typical girl from the countryside! Off to dig up more artifacts in Broken Hill, are you?' 'Possibly,' I answered cautiously. 'I have other plans as well.' 'You're such a mysterious creature,' Mrs. Blair mused. 'But you do look exhausted this morning. Couldn't you sleep? I can never rest on a boat. They say ten hours is plenty for a fool! I could use twenty!' As she yawned, resembling a sleepy kitten, she recounted an amusing encounter with a steward in the middle of the night. 'He woke me up to return a roll of films I dropped yesterday. He did it so dramatically, sticking his arm through the ventilator and nearly dropping them on me. I thought it was a bomb!' 'Look, here comes Colonel Race,' I pointed out as the tall, soldierly man approached. 'He's not specifically my Colonel. Actually, he quite admires you, Gipsy girl. So don't escape,' Mrs. Blair teased. 'I need to tie something around my head. It's more comfortable than a hat,' I excused myself, slipping away swiftly."

“When I saw the lifeless body, resembling Jack, and dressed in his elegant overcoat, I instantly knew the truth. The same paper-knife that Jack had gifted Bella was there, with her fingerprints likely still on it. The sheer horror of that moment engulfed me, leaving me with one clear thought - I had to obtain that dagger and flee before it was discovered missing. So, I faked a fainting spell, seized the weapon while you fetched water, and concealed it in my dress. I had claimed to be lodging at the Hôtel du Phare, but in reality, I made a swift return to Calais and then sailed to England without delay. During our Channel crossing, I disposed of the dagger in the sea, finally feeling a sense of relief. Bella was at our London residence, her appearance a far cry from her usual self. After confessing my actions to her, she responded with unsettling laughter. Sensing the urgency to keep her mind occupied, we secured a new engagement promptly. Upon spotting you and your companion observing us that night, panic consumed me. Your pursuit hinted at suspicions, leading me to tail you in search of answers. To my dismay, I realized that you suspected me, not Bella, assuming I was her due to the stolen dagger. I longed for you to understand the fear and desperation I experienced at that moment. I was torn between saving myself and protecting Bella, my twin. The fear of your potential betrayal drove me to continue deceiving you, a choice that still weighs heavily on me. I should have trusted you from the start. As soon as the news broke of Jack Renauld's arrest, Bella wasted no time in fleeing. I am weary now, unable to continue writing. She initially signed the letter as Cinderella but opted for "Dulcie Duveen" instead. Poirot was present when I read it, his knowledge of the truth evident. The letter slipped from my grasp, prompting me to pass it to him for review. After reading it, Poirot asked what troubled me. His caring demeanor marked a change from his usual tone. Expressing my concerns was easier in this instance. The absence of a declaration of affection from her troubled me. Poirot reassured me that her feelings were evident in every line of the letter. Where to find her remained a mystery, the French stamp on the letter offering no clues. Poirot, however, promised to locate her with ease. Congratulations, M. Jack,” said Poirot, warmly greeting the young man upon his release. Jack's relief was palpable, although his weariness hinted at a looming breakdown. His sacrifice had been futile, a fact he acknowledged with sorrow. The impending legal proceedings weighed heavily on Jack's conscience as he grappled with his father’s murder and the aftermath of his actions. Poirot offered reassurance, hinting at the leniency of the French courts towards cases like his. But Jack's guilt and remorse persisted, overshadowing any potential legal consequences.

“You know?” “Certainly I know. The subject of the quarrel was Mademoiselle Marthe Daubreuil.” Renauld sprang round, startled. The magistrate leaned forward. “Is this so, monsieur.” Jack Renauld bowed his head. “Yes,” he admitted. “I love Mademoiselle Daubreuil, and I wish to marry her. When I informed my father of the fact, he flew at once into a violent rage. Naturally I could not stand hearing the girl I loved insulted, and I, too, lost my temper.” M. Hautet looked across at Mrs. Renauld. “You were aware of this attachment, madame.” “I feared it,” she replied simply. “Mother,” cried the boy. “You too! Marthe is as good as she is beautiful. What can you have against her?”

He was a young man with a determined look in his eyes. We locked gazes, and he didn't back down. "Okay," I muttered weakly. "Just keep quiet about me coming along." I hesitated, feeling a sense of foreboding about the situation. It seemed like a good idea to have him by my side, but I couldn't shake the feeling that trouble was on the horizon. Just when I thought things were finally settling down! As he turned to leave, I called out to stop him.

"Come, my friend.” He entered the crude wooden contraption and I cautiously followed. “Are we going to gain entry to the flat?” I questioned uncertainly. Poirot’s response was not very reassuring: “Not exactly today,” he stated. Tugging on the rope, we descended slowly until we arrived at the second level. Poirot exclaimed in satisfaction when he noticed that the wooden door leading to the scullery was unlocked. “Do you see? They never secure these doors during the day. Yet anyone could climb or descend as we have. At night, yes, but not always then, and it’s against that which we are going to prepare for.” He extracted some tools from his pocket as he spoke, and immediately began working skillfully, aiming to adjust the bolt so that it could be pulled back from the lift. The process took only about three minutes. Poirot then returned the tools to his pocket, and we ascended once more to our own realm. On Monday, Poirot was absent all day, but upon his return in the evening, he sank into his chair with a contented sigh. “Hastings, shall I recount to you a little tale? A story to your liking and which will bring to mind your preferred cinema?” “Go on,” I chuckled. “I assume it’s a true story, not one of your imaginative creations.” “It is quite true. Inspector Japp of Scotland Yard can attest to its accuracy, as it was through his assistance that I learned of it. Listen, Hastings. A little over six months ago, some crucial Naval plans were stolen from an American Government department. They revealed the location of some of the most vital Harbor defenses, and would hold great value to any foreign Government, such as Japan. Suspicion fell upon a young man named Luigi Valdarno, an Italian by birth, who worked in a minor role in the Department and who was missing at the same time as the documents. Whether Luigi Valdarno was the culprit or not, he was discovered two days later on the East Side in New York, shot dead. The papers were not found on him. Now, for some time, Luigi Valdarno had been seen with a Miss Elsa Hardt, a young concert singer who had recently emerged and resided with a brother in an apartment in Washington. Little was known about the background of Miss Elsa Hardt, and she vanished abruptly around the time of Valdarno’s demise. There are suspicions that she was actually a skilled international spy who had engaged in much illicit activity under various aliases. While the American Secret Service tried to track her down, they also kept watch on certain insignificant Japanese men living in Washington. They were confident that, once Elsa Hardt had sufficiently covered her tracks, she would approach the men in question. One of them left for England suddenly a fortnight ago. So, it seems likely that Elsa Hardt is in England.” Poirot paused, then whispered: “The official description of Elsa Hardt is: Height 5 ft. 7, eyes blue, hair auburn, fair complexion, nose straight, no special distinguishing marks.” “Mrs. Robinson!” I exclaimed. “Well, there is a possibility, at least,” Poirot corrected.

"I'm about to share a different side of the story," I declared confidently. Harry's attention was unwavering as I detailed the same sequence of events chronicled in this book. The most shocking revelation for him was the revelation that the diamonds had been in Suzanne's possession all this time, a fact that had completely eluded him. After hearing his version of events, I finally understood the purpose behind Carton's clever scheme, or rather Nadina's, as I was convinced it was her ingenious plan all along. It became clear that no surprise attacks against her or her husband would lead to the recovery of the diamonds.

"Why did you take the dagger?” I inquired curiously. She responded with the innocence of a child: “I was worried about fingerprints being left on it.” “But didn’t you wear gloves?” She shook her head in confusion, then whispered hesitantly: “Are you planning to turn me over to the authorities?” “Never in a million years.” Her gaze met mine, filled with uncertainty, and she timidly asked: “Why?” It was an unexpected moment for a confession of affection, and I had never envisioned love finding its way to me in such circumstances. Yet, I replied sincerely and without hesitation: “Because, my dear Cinderella, I love you.”

"Baker was sent to the neighboring town to get two printed will-forms by Mr. Marsh. They signed one, but he made a mistake and had them sign again later that day. After signing the second time, Mr. Marsh went out to pay tradesmen's books. There were workmen from a Plymouth firm who had been in the house two years ago for repairs, but they couldn't remember the details. Poirot suspected a second will and a hiding place, so they decided to go to Plymouth to investigate further."

I overheard an interesting conversation between Sir Eustace and another man about cabin allocations. Sir Eustace was adamant about not sharing his cabin, which led to a heated dispute with other passengers. In the end, the purser confirmed that Cabin 17 was mine, and the others had to choose between Nos. 13 and 28. I settled in, only to be greeted by a terrible smell in the cabin - asafœtida. It seemed someone was desperate to get me out of there, but why? The mystery of Cabin 17 continued to intrigue me.

"And no one will ever find her, mon ami, because she does not exist! ‘There’s no such person,’ as your so great Shakespeare says." "It was Dickens," I murmured, unable to suppress a smile. "But what do you mean, Poirot?" "I mean that Zoe Havering was an actress before her marriage, that you and Japp only saw the housekeeper in a dark hall, a dim middle-aged figure in black with a faint subdued voice, and finally that neither you nor Japp, nor the local police whom the housekeeper fetched, ever saw Mrs. Middleton and her mistress at one and the same time. It was child’s play for that clever and daring woman."

"Your lack of manners is truly appalling," I remarked icily. "I'm afraid I must bid you farewell." He made a move towards the exit, stumbling along the way. Reacting quickly, I guided him to the sofa with a firm hand. "Stop being foolish," I scolded bluntly. "You wouldn't want to leave a trail of blood throughout the entire ship, would you?" He appeared to grasp the logic behind my words, sitting still as I tended to his wound as well as I could. "There," I declared, giving my handiwork a satisfied pat. "That will have to suffice for now."

Anne Beddingfeld was tired of the monotony of her life. Her father, Professor Beddingfeld, was completely engrossed in studying Primitive Man, leaving Anne to handle the practicalities of everyday life. She despised anything related to Palaeolithic Man, despite her involvement in typing and revising her father's work on Neanderthal Man. The absence of her mother since childhood added to the sense of sameness in her life. But Anne always longed for some excitement, a break from the mundane routine that consumed her days.

"And once again, there was nothing to be found. No balcony in sight." "Even if there was," the inspector remarked impatiently, "I fail to see how that would be of any use to us, given that the maid claims she never left the room." "Of course," Poirot responded calmly, unfazed. "If Mademoiselle is certain she did not exit the room." Before he could continue, the chambermaid and the police searcher reappeared. "Nothing," the searcher stated bluntly. "Well, I should hope not," the chambermaid declared indignantly. "And that French woman should be ashamed for tarnishing an innocent girl's reputation!" "There, there, my dear; it's all right," the inspector reassured, as he opened the door. "No one suspects you."

"Obviously,” Giraud began, “I quickly uncovered the true nature of that Chilian deception. Two individuals were involved, but they were not enigmatic foreigners! It was all a smokescreen.” “Impressive work so far, my dear Giraud,” Poirot murmured. “Especially after their clever ploy with the match and cigarette butt.” Giraud glared, then continued: “Someone must have been implicated in the crime to have dug the grave. No one actually gains from the crime, but someone believed they would. I learned of Jack Renauld’s dispute with his father, and the threats he made. The motive was clear.”

Pagett abruptly left the table midway through dinner, leaving me slightly irritated since I had intended to bid him farewell. However, I assumed Sir Eustace could serve the same purpose. After finishing my meal, I approached Sir Eustace. "Farewell, Sir Eustace," I declared. "I depart for Durban tonight." Sir Eustace let out a weary sigh. "Yes, I heard about your plans. Would you prefer some company on your journey?" "I would appreciate it." "Lovely girl. Are you absolutely certain you wouldn't rather join me in searching for lions in Rhodesia?" "Absolutely." "The man must be quite dashing," Sir Eustace remarked with a hint of sadness.

Rayburn was leaning over him. "Did you hit him again?" I asked breathlessly. "There was no need," he replied grimly. "I found him collapsed by the door. Or else he couldn't get it open and is shamming. We'll soon see about that. And we'll see who he is too." With a racing heart, I approached. I had immediately realized that my attacker was a larger man than Chichester. In any case, Chichester was a flabby individual who might resort to a knife, but would have little physical strength. Rayburn lit a match. We both gasped. The man was Guy Pagett. Rayburn seemed completely stunned by the revelation. "Pagett," he mumbled. "My God, Pagett." I felt a slight sense of superiority. "You seem surprised." "I am," he said heavily. "I never suspected." He suddenly turned towards me. "And you? You're not? You recognized him, I suppose, when he attacked you?" "No, I didn't. Nevertheless, I'm not so shocked." He looked at me suspiciously. "Where do you fit in, I wonder? And how much do you know?" I smiled. "A lot, Mr. er Lucas!" He grabbed my arm, the force of his grip causing me to flinch. "Where did you hear that name?" he asked hoarsely. "Isn't it yours?" I asked sweetly. "Or do you prefer to be called 'The Man in the Brown Suit'?" That caught him off guard. He let go of my arm and stepped back. "Are you a girl or a witch?" he whispered. "I'm a friend." I took a step closer. "I offered you my help once, I offer it again. Will you take it?" His fierce response surprised me. "No. I want nothing to do with you or any woman. Do your worst." Just like before, my own temper began to rise. "Perhaps," I retorted, "you don't realize how much power I have over you? A word from me to the Captain." "Say it," he sneered. Then, stepping forward quickly: "And while we're coming to terms, my dear, do you realize that you're at my mercy right now? I could grab you by the throat like this." With a swift movement, he demonstrated. I felt his hands around my throat, applying slight pressure. "Like this and squeeze the life out of you! And then, like our unconscious friend here, but with more success, toss your lifeless body to the sharks. What do you think of that?" I said nothing. I laughed. And yet, I knew the danger was real. At that moment, he despised me. But I knew that I craved the danger, relished the feeling of his hands on my throat. I wouldn't have traded that moment for anything else in the world. With a short laugh, he let go. "What's your name?" he asked suddenly. "Anne Beddingfeld." "Does nothing scare you, Anne Beddingfeld?" "Oh, yes," I replied, feigning composure I didn't possess. "Wasps, sarcastic women, very young men, cockroaches, and snooty shop assistants." He chuckled, as he nudged the unconscious Pagett with his foot.

"No, Anne, you're making a grave mistake. You can't go through with this." "I can. It's the only way out." "I couldn't face Race after this. I'll take my chances, but I won't let that sly old fox escape. It's useless, Anne. I won't do it." Sir Eustace chuckled, accepting defeat calmly. "Well, well," he said. "It seems you've met your match, Anne. But I can assure you that morality doesn't always win." A loud crash interrupted them, followed by footsteps ascending the stairs. Harry unlocked the door, allowing Colonel Race to enter first. Relief washed over his face as he saw Anne unharmed. "Anne, you're safe. I was worried," he said before turning to Sir Eustace. "I've been tailing you for a while, Pedler, and finally, I've caught you." "It appears everyone has lost their minds," Sir Eustace remarked casually. "These youngsters have been threatening me with guns and accusing me of absurdities. I'm clueless about it all." "Is that so? Because I've found the 'Colonel.' I know you weren't in Cannes on January 8th, but in Marlow. I know your plans for Nadina and now we'll prove you're guilty," Colonel Race declared. Sir Eustace raised an eyebrow in surprise as Colonel Race gestured towards Arthur Minks, alias Rev. Edward Chichester, who stepped forward to testify against him. Minks recounted his encounter with Nadina in Paris and how he became entangled in Sir Eustace's web of deceit. As the truth unfolded, Sir Eustace simply smirked, dismissing the accusations. "One thing, Sir Eustace," I interjected. "The tin you threw out the window didn't have the diamonds. They're hidden in the giraffe statue's stomach, safe and sound." Sir Eustace eyed me for a moment before responding, "I always despised that giraffe. It must have been my intuition." The night was spent at a farm, far from the chaos of Johannesburg. I was exhausted, the recent events taking a toll on me. Despite the relief of being reunited with Harry, a sense of unease lingered between us. The next morning, I sat on the stoop lost in thought until Colonel Race approached me, breaking the silence. "Good morning, Anne," he greeted me. "Oh, it's you," I responded, a tinge of embarrassment coloring my cheeks. As we sat together, I couldn't shake the mixture of fear and fascination he always evoked in me. "Any news?" I inquired. "Smuts will be in Johannesburg tomorrow. This rebellion won't last much longer," he replied. "I wish only the instigators suffered, not the innocent caught in the crossfire," I mused. "I have some other news for you," he continued. "Pedler has escaped." Despite the gravity of the situation, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of fondness for Sir Eustace, a sentiment I couldn't shake off.

I trembled at the sight of Rayburn, the man with the scar who had just saved me from a dangerous attacker on the ship. As he turned to me with concern, I couldn't help but feel a strange sense of relief that he was there to protect me. His presence was both comforting and intimidating, a stark contrast to the chaos that had just unfolded. My heart raced as I watched him deal with the fallen enemy, his actions swift and decisive. In that moment, I knew that I was in the presence of someone who would stop at nothing to keep me safe. And as we stood there on the deck, surrounded by darkness and uncertainty, I felt a sense of gratitude towards Rayburn, the unlikely hero who had come to my rescue.

"I apologize for the inconvenience, madam. To make this process easier for you, I will ask questions and you may simply respond. When did you retire for the night yesterday?” “Around 9:30 pm, sir. I was quite fatigued.” “And your spouse?” “I believe he followed suit an hour later.” “Was he agitated or unsettled in any way?” “No, not noticeably.” “What transpired next?” “I was awoken by a hand covering my mouth. Despite my efforts to scream, it was futile. Two masked intruders were present.” “Can you provide a description of the suspects, madam?” “One was tall with a lengthy black beard, while the other was shorter and stout, with a reddish beard.”

"You understand the nature of women. She's enthusiastic about the film stunt." "I see," replied Poirot. After a moment of contemplation, he quickly stood up. "Are you heading back to Yardly Chase immediately? Good! Don't inform anyone except for expecting us there this evening. We will be there shortly after five." "Okay, but I'm not sure" "It doesn't matter," said Poirot kindly. "You want me to keep your diamond safe, right?" "Yes, but" "Then just follow my instructions." A confused nobleman exited the room. We reached Yardly Chase at five-thirty, and were led by the dignified butler to the antique panelled hall with its crackling fire.

"Well,” I asked eagerly, “what are your thoughts on this, Mrs. Blair?” “I find it absolutely enthralling! First things first, please stop with the Mrs. Blair. Suzanne is much more preferable. Agreed?” “I would be delighted, Suzanne.” “Excellent. Now, let’s focus on the task at hand. You mentioned that in Sir Eustace’s secretary, not the somber Pagett, but the other one, you recognized the man who was stabbed and sought refuge in your cabin?” I confirmed. “This connects Sir Eustace to the web in two ways. The woman was killed in his residence, and his secretary was attacked at one o’clock.

"They are merely new acquaintances, I believe. But surely, Poirot, you don’t suspect for a moment” Poirot gestured with his hand. “Hold on, my friend. Have I made any assumptions? All I am saying is it's an intriguing tale. And there is no clue to unravel it; except maybe the lady’s name, eh, Hastings?” “Her name is Stella,” I said firmly, “but I fail to see” Poirot cut me off with a hearty laugh. Something appeared to be greatly amusing him. “And Stella means a star, correct? Brilliant!” “What in the world” “And stars provide illumination! There you have it! Relax, Hastings. Spare me the wounded pride. Come, let us head to Montagu Mansions and conduct a few investigations."

"But how did he manage to manipulate Sir Eustace? It seems like he had some leverage over him." "Or over Pagett," I proposed involuntarily. "You don't seem to have a fondness for Pagett, Anne. Sir Eustace insists that he's a highly capable and diligent young man. And, truthfully, he may be supporting him for all we know. Now, let's continue with my theories. Rayburn is the mysterious 'Man in the Brown Suit.' He had seen the paper he dropped. Therefore, deceived by the dot just as you were, he tries to reach Cabin 17 at one o'clock on the 22nd, after attempting to secure the cabin through Pagett. On his way there, someone fatally stabs him." "Who?" I interrupted. "Chichester. Yes, it all makes sense. Send a message to Lord Nasby that you have discovered 'The Man in the Brown Suit,' and your future is secured, Anne!" "There are a few details you've neglected." "What details? Rayburn has a scar, I am aware, but scars can be easily fabricated. He matches the correct height and build. What was the description of a skull that you provided to them at Scotland Yard?" I shuddered. Suzanne was an educated woman, but I hoped she wasn't familiar with the technical terms of anthropology. "Dolichocephalic," I casually replied. Suzanne appeared uncertain. "Is that correct?" "Yes. Long-headed, you know. A skull where the width is less than 75 percent of its length," I explained smoothly. There was a moment of silence. Just as I began to relax, Suzanne suddenly asked, "What's the opposite?" "What do you mean, the opposite?" "There must be an opposite. What do you call skulls where the breadth is more than 75 percent of their length?" "Brachycephalic," I reluctantly murmured. "That's right. I thought that's what you said." "Did I? It was a slip of the tongue. I meant dolichocephalic," I confidently stated. Suzanne gazed at me intently. Then she chuckled. "You're quite the adept liar, Gipsy girl. But it would be easier if you just tell me everything now." "There's really nothing to say," I responded unwillingly. "Isn't there?" Suzanne said softly. "I suppose I'll have to confess," I said slowly. "I'm not ashamed of it. You can't be ashamed of something that just happens to you. That's what he did. He was disgustingly rude and unappreciative, but I think I understand. It's like a mistreated or chained-up dog; it'll bite anyone. That's what he was like - bitter and snarling. I don't know why I care, but I do. I care deeply. Just seeing him has completely upended my life. I love him. I desire him. I'll traverse all of Africa barefoot until I find him, and I'll make him love me. I'd sacrifice everything for him. I'd toil for him, serve him, steal for him, even beg or borrow for him! There, now you know!" Suzanne stared at me for a long moment. "You're not very English, Gipsy girl," she finally remarked. "There's not a trace of sentimentality in you. I've never encountered anyone who is simultaneously so pragmatic and so passionate. I'll never love anyone like that, thankfully for me, yet I envy you, Gipsy girl. It's a gift to be capable of caring. Most people cannot. But it's fortunate for your little doctor that you didn't marry him. He doesn't sound like the type who would appreciate having high explosives in the house! So, there won't be any message sent to Lord Nasby?" I shook my head.

We were all taken aback by this unexpected outburst. Jack Renauld, exhausted from all that had transpired, stumbled and almost fell. Poirot and I rushed to his side. We brought the boy to the Villa, where he collapsed into a chair in a daze. Poirot checked his temperature. "He has a fever. The stress is catching up to him. And now this added shock. With rest and peace, he could recover by the next day, but any excitement could lead to brain fever. Someone should stay with him through the night. With nothing more we could do, we left him in the care of Marthe and her mother, and headed to town. It was late, and we were hungry. Signor Ascanio was arrested and charged with the murder of Count Foscatini. When arrested, he denied knowing the Count, and declared he had never been near Regent’s Court either on the evening of the crime or on the previous morning. The younger man had disappeared entirely. Signor Ascanio had arrived alone at the Grosvenor Hotel from the Continent two days before the murder. All efforts to trace the second man failed. Ascanio, however, was not sent for trial. No less a personage than the Italian Ambassador himself came forward and testified at the police-court proceedings that Ascanio had been with him at the Embassy from eight till nine that evening. The prisoner was discharged. Naturally, a lot of people thought that the crime was a political one, and was being deliberately hushed up. Poirot had taken a keen interest in all these points. Nevertheless, I was somewhat surprised when he suddenly informed me one morning that he was expecting a visitor at eleven o’clock, and that that visitor was none other than Ascanio himself. “He wishes to consult you?” “Du tout, Hastings. I wish to consult him.” “What about?” “The Regent’s Court murder.” “You are going to prove that he did it?” “A man cannot be tried twice for murder, Hastings. Endeavour to have the common sense. Ah, that is our friend’s ring.” A few minutes later Signor Ascanio was ushered in a small, thin man with a secretive and furtive glance in his eyes. He remained standing, darting suspicious glances from one to the other of us. “Monsieur Poirot?” My little friend tapped himself gently on the chest. “Be seated, signor. You received my note. I am determined to get to the bottom of this mystery. In some small measure you can aid me. Let us commence. You in company with a friend visited the late Count Foscatini on the morning of Tuesday the 9th” The Italian made an angry gesture. “I did nothing of the sort. I do not ask to know whose indiscretions brought you to England. I know this much, you came for the especial purpose of seeing Count Foscatini.” “He was not a count,” growled the Italian. “I have already noted the fact that his name does not appear in the Almanach de Gotha. Never mind, the title of count is often useful in the profession of blackmailing.” “I suppose I might as well be frank. You seem to know a good deal.” “I have employed my grey cells to some advantage. Come, Signor Ascanio, you visited the dead man on the Tuesday morning that is so, is it not?” “Yes; but I never went there on the following evening. There was no need. I will tell you all. Certain information concerning a man of great position in Italy had come into this scoundrel’s possession. He demanded a big sum of money in return for the papers. I came over to England to arrange the matter. I called upon him by appointment that morning. One of the young secretaries of the Embassy was with me. The Count was more reasonable than I had hoped, although even then the sum of money I paid him was a huge one.” “Pardon, how was it paid?” “In Italian notes of comparatively small denomination. Poirot had received a brisk and business-like note from the lady asking for an appointment, and he had replied asking her to call upon him at eleven o’clock the following day. She arrived punctually a tall, handsome young woman, plainly but neatly dressed, with an assured and business-like manner. Clearly a young woman who meant to get on in the world. I am not a great admirer of the so-called New Woman myself, and, in spite of her good looks, I was not particularly prepossessed in her favour. “My business is of a somewhat unusual nature, Monsieur Poirot,” she began, after she had accepted a chair. “I had better begin at the beginning and tell you the whole story.” “If you please, mademoiselle.” “I am an orphan. My father was one of two brothers, sons of a small yeoman farmer in Devonshire. The farm was a poor one, and the elder brother, Andrew, emigrated to Australia, where he did very well indeed, and by means of successful speculation in land became a very rich man. The younger brother, Roger (my father), had no leanings towards the agricultural life. He managed to educate himself a little, and obtained a post as a clerk with a small firm. He married slightly above him; my mother was the daughter of a poor artist. My father died when I was six years old. When I was fourteen, my mother followed him to the grave. My only living relation then was my Uncle Andrew, who had recently returned from Australia and bought a small place, Crabtree Manor, in his native county. He was exceedingly kind to his brother’s orphan child, took me to live with him, and treated me in every way as though I was his own daughter. “Crabtree Manor, in spite of its name, is really only an old farmhouse. Farming was in my uncle’s blood, and he was intensely interested in various modern farming experiments. Although kindness itself to me, he had certain peculiar and deeply-rooted ideas as to the up-bringing of women. Himself a man of little or no education, though possessing remarkable shrewdness, he placed little value on what he called ‘book knowledge.’ He was especially opposed to the education of women. In his opinion, girls should learn practical housework and dairy-work, be useful about the home, and have as little to do with book learning as possible. He proposed to bring me up on these lines, to my bitter disappointment and annoyance. I rebelled frankly. I knew that I possessed a good brain, and had absolutely no talent for domestic duties. My uncle and I had many bitter arguments on the subject, for, though much attached to each other, we were both self-willed. I was lucky enough to win a scholarship, and up to a certain point was successful in getting my own way. The crisis arose when I resolved to go to Girton. I had a little money of my own, left me by my mother, and I was quite determined to make the best use of the gifts God had given me. I had one long, final argument with my uncle. He put the facts plainly before me. He had no other relations, and he had intended me to be his sole heiress. As I have told you, he was a very rich man. If I persisted in these ‘new-fangled notions’ of mine, however, I need look for nothing from him. I remained polite, but firm. I should always be deeply attached to him, I told him, but I must lead my own life. We parted on that note. ‘You fancy your brains, my girl,’ were his last words. ‘I’ve no book learning, but, for all that, I’ll pit mine against yours any day. We’ll see what we shall see.’ “That was nine years ago. I have stayed with him for a week-end occasionally, and our relations were perfectly amicable, though his views remained unaltered. He never referred to my having matriculated, nor to my B.Sc. For the last three years his health had been failing, and a month ago he died. “I am now coming to the point of my visit. My uncle left a most extraordinary will. By its terms, Crabtree Manor and its contents are to be at my disposal for a year from his death ‘during which time my clever niece may prove her wits,’ the actual words run. At the end of that period, ‘my wits having proved better than hers,’ the house and all my uncle’s large fortune pass to various charitable institutions.” “That is a little hard on you, mademoiselle, seeing that you were Mr. Marsh’s only blood relation.” “I do not look on it in that way. Uncle Andrew warned me fairly, and I chose my own path. Since I would not fall in with his wishes, he was at perfect liberty to leave his money to whom he pleased.” “Was the will drawn up by a lawyer?” “No; it was written on a printed will-form and witnessed by the man and his wife who live in the house and do for my uncle.” “There might be a possibility of upsetting such a will?” “I would not even attempt to do such a thing.” “You regard it, then, as a sporting challenge on the part of your uncle?” “That is exactly how I look upon it.” “It bears that interpretation, certainly,” said Poirot thoughtfully. “Somewhere in this rambling old manor-house your uncle has concealed either a sum of money in notes or possibly a second will, and has given you a year in which to exercise your ingenuity to find it.” “Exactly, Monsieur Poirot; and I am paying you the compliment of assuming that your ingenuity will be greater than mine.” “Eh, eh! but that is very charming of you. My grey cells are at your disposal. You have made no search yourself?” “Only a cursory one; but I have too much respect for my uncle’s undoubted abilities to fancy that the task will be an easy one.” “Have you the will or a copy of it with you?” Miss Marsh handed a document across the table. Poirot ran through it, nodding to himself. “Made three years ago. Dated March 25; and the time is given also 11 a.m. that is very suggestive. It narrows the field of search. Assuredly it is another will we have to seek for.

I avoided Carton carefully on board the boat, keeping to my own cabin as far as possible under the pretence of illness. “I had no difficulty in trailing him when we got to London. He went straight to an hotel and did not go out until the following day. He left the hotel shortly before one o’clock. I was behind him. He went straight to a house-agent in Knightsbridge. There he asked for particulars of houses to let on the river. “I was at the next table also inquiring about houses. Then suddenly in walked Anita Grünberg, Nadina whatever you like to call her. Superb, insolent, and almost as beautiful as ever. God! how I hated her. There she was, the woman who had ruined my life and who had also ruined a better life than mine. At that minute I could have put my hands round her neck and squeezed the life out of her inch by inch! Just for a minute or two I saw red. I hardly took in what the agent was saying. It was her voice that I heard next, high and clear, with an exaggerated foreign accent: ‘The Mill House, Marlow. The property of Sir Eustace Pedler. That sounds as though it might suit me. At any rate, I will go and see it.’ “The man wrote her an order, and she walked out again in her regal insolent manner. Not by word or a sign had she recognized Carton, yet I was sure that their meeting there was a preconceived plan. Then I started to jump to conclusions. Not knowing that Sir Eustace was at Cannes, I thought that this house-hunting business was a mere pretext for meeting him in the Mill House. I knew that he had been in South Africa at the time of the robbery, and never having seen him I immediately leaped to the conclusion that he himself was the mysterious ‘Colonel’ of whom I had heard so much. “I followed my two suspects along Knightsbridge. Nadina went into the Hyde Park Hotel. I quickened my pace and went in also. She walked straight into the restaurant, and I decided that I would not risk her recognizing me at the moment, but would continue to follow Carton. I was in great hopes that he was going to get the diamonds, and that by suddenly appearing and making myself known to him when he least expected it I might startle the truth out of him. I followed him down into the Tube station at Hyde Park Corner. He was standing by himself at the end of the platform. There was some girl standing near, but no one else. I decided that I would accost him then and there. You know what happened. In the sudden shock of seeing a man whom he imagined far away in South Africa, he lost his head and stepped back upon the line. He was always a coward. Under the pretext of being a doctor, I managed to search his pockets. There was a wallet with some notes in it and one or two unimportant letters, there was a roll of films which I must have dropped somewhere later and there was a piece of paper with an appointment made on it for the 22nd on the Kilmorden Castle. In my haste to get away before any one detained me, I dropped that also, but fortunately I remembered the figures. “I hurried to the nearest cloak-room and hastily removed my make-up. I did not want to be laid by the heels for picking a dead man’s pocket. Then I retraced my steps to the Hyde Park Hotel. Nadina was still having lunch. I needn’t describe in detail how I followed her down to Marlow. She went into the house, and I spoke to the woman at the lodge, pretending that I was with her. Then I, too, went in.” He stopped. There was a tense silence. “You will believe me, Anne, won’t you? I swear before God that what I am going to say is true. I went into the house after her with something very like murder in my heart and she was dead! I found her in that first-floor room God! It was horrible. Dead and I was not more than three minutes behind her. And there was no sign of any one else in the house! Of course I realized at once the terrible position I was in. By one master-stroke the blackmailed had rid himself of the blackmailer, and at the same time had provided a victim to whom the crime would be ascribed. The hand of the ‘Colonel’ was very plain. For the second time I was to be his victim. Fool that I had been to walk into the trap so easily. “I hardly know what I did next. I managed to go out of the place looking fairly normal, but I knew that it could not be long before the crime was discovered and a description of my appearance telegraphed all over the country. “I lay low for some days, not daring to make a move. In the end chance came to my aid. I overheard a conversation between two middle-aged gentlemen in the street, one of whom proved to be Sir Eustace Pedler. I at once conceived the idea of attaching myself to him as his secretary. The fragment of conversation I had overheard gave me my clue. I was now no longer so sure that Sir Eustace Pedler was the ‘Colonel.’ His house might have been appointed as a rendezvous by accident, or for some obscure motive that I had not fathomed.” “Do you know,” I interrupted, “that Guy Pagett was in Marlow at the date of the murder?” “That settles it then. I thought he was at Cannes with Sir Eustace.” “He was supposed to be in Florence but he certainly never went there. I’m pretty certain he was really in Marlow, but of course I can’t prove it.” “And to think I never suspected Pagett for a minute until the night he tried to throw you overboard. The man’s a marvellous actor.” “Yes, isn’t he?” “That explains why the Mill House was chosen. Pagett could probably get in and out of it unobserved.”

Jack Renauld, in prison, with the shadow of the guillotine looming over him! I saw the part I was playing in a more sinister light. I could save Bella, yes, but in doing so I ran the risk of sending an innocent man to his death. I pushed the thought from me with horror. It could not be. He would be acquitted. Certainly he would be acquitted! But the cold fear came back. Suppose he were not? What then? Could I have it on my conscience horrible thought! Would it come to that in the end? A decision. Bella or Jack Renauld? The promptings of my heart were to save the girl I loved at any cost to myself. But, if the cost were to another, the problem was altered. What would the girl herself say? I remembered that no word of Jack Renauld’s arrest had passed my lips. As yet she was in total ignorance of the fact that her former lover was in prison charged with a hideous crime which he had not committed. When she knew, how would she act? Would she permit her life to be saved at the expense of his? Certainly she must do nothing rash. Jack Renauld might, and probably would, be acquitted without any intervention on her part. If so, good. But if he was not.… That was the terrible, the unanswerable problem. I fancied that she ran no risk of the extreme penalty. The circumstances of the crime were quite different in her case. She could plead jealousy and extreme provocation, and her youth and beauty would go for much. The fact that by a tragic mistake it was old Mr. Renauld, and not his son, who paid the penalty would not alter the motive of the crime. But in any case, however lenient the sentence of the Court, it must mean a long term of imprisonment. No, Bella must be protected. And, at the same time, Jack Renauld must be saved. How this was to be accomplished I did not see clearly. But I pinned my faith to Poirot. He knew. Come what might, he would manage to save an innocent man. He must find some pretext other than the real one. It might be difficult, but he would manage it somehow. And with Bella unsuspected, and Jack Renauld acquitted, all would end satisfactorily. So I told myself repeatedly, but at the bottom of my heart there still remained a cold fear. We crossed from England by the evening boat, and the following morning saw us in Saint-Omer, whither Jack Renauld had been taken. Poirot lost no time in visiting M. Hautet. As he did not seem disposed to make any objections to my accompanying him, I bore him company. After various formalities and preliminaries, we were conducted to the examining magistrate’s room. He greeted us cordially. “I was told that you had returned to England, M. Poirot. I am glad to find that such is not the case.” “It is true that I went there, M. le juge, but it was only for a flying visit. A side issue, but one that I fancied might repay investigation.” “And it did eh?” Poirot shrugged his shoulders. M. Hautet nodded, sighing. “We must resign ourselves, I fear. That animal Giraud, his manners are abominable, but he is undoubtedly clever! Not much chance of that one making a mistake.” “You think not, M. le juge?” It was the examining magistrate’s turn to shrug his shoulders. “Eh bien, speaking frankly in confidence, c’est entendu can you come to any other conclusion?” “Frankly, M. le juge, there seem to me to be many points that are obscure.” “Such as ?” But Poirot was not to be drawn. “I have not yet tabulated them,” he remarked. “It was a general reflection that I was making. I liked the young man, and should be sorry to believe him guilty of such a hideous crime. By the way, what has he to say for himself on the matter?” The magistrate frowned. “I cannot understand him. He seems incapable of putting up any sort of defence. It has been most difficult to get him to answer questions. He contents himself with a general denial, and beyond that takes refuge in a most obstinate silence. I am interrogating him again tomorrow; perhaps you would like to be present?” We accepted the invitation with empressement. “A distressing case,” said the magistrate with a sigh. “My sympathy for Madame Renauld is profound.” “How is Madame Renauld?” “She has not yet recovered consciousness. It is merciful in a way, poor woman, she is being spared much. The doctors say that there is no danger, but that when she comes to herself she must be kept as quiet as possible. It was, I understand, quite as much the shock as the fall which caused her present state. It would be terrible if her brain became unhinged; but I should not wonder at all no, really, not at all.” M. Hautet leaned back, shaking his head, with a sort of mournful enjoyment, as he envisaged the gloomy prospect. He roused himself at length, and observed with a start. “That reminds me. I have here a letter for you, M. Poirot. Let me see, where did I put it?” He proceeded to rummage amongst his papers. At last he found the missive, and handed it to Poirot. “It was sent under cover to me in order that I might forward it to you,” he explained. “But as you left no address I could not do so.” Poirot studied the letter curiously. It was addressed in a long, sloping, foreign hand, and the writing was decidedly a woman’s. Poirot did not open it. Instead he put it in his pocket and rose to his feet. “A demain then, M. le juge. Many thanks for your courtesy and amiability.” “But not at all. I am always at your service. These young detectives of the school of Giraud, they are all alike rude, sneering fellows. They do not realize that an examining magistrate of my er experience is bound to have a certain discernment, a certain flair. Enfin! the politeness of the old school is infinitely more to my taste. Therefore, my dear friend, command me in any way you will. We know a thing or two, you and I eh?” And laughing heartily, enchanted with himself and with us, M. Hautet bade us adieu. I am sorry to have to record that Poirot’s first remark to me as we traversed the corridor was: “A famous old imbecile, that one! Of a stupidity to make pity!” We were just leaving the building when we came face to face with Giraud, looking more dandified than ever, and thoroughly pleased with himself. “Aha! M. Poirot,” he cried airily. “You have returned from England then?” “As you see,” said Poirot. “The end of the case is not far off now, I fancy.” “I agree with you, M. Giraud.” Poirot spoke in a subdued tone. His crest-fallen manner seemed to delight the other. “Of all the milk and water criminals! Not an idea of defending himself. It is extraordinary!” “So extraordinary that it gives one to think, does it not?” suggested Poirot mildly. But Giraud was not even listening. He twirled his cane amicably. “Well, good day, M. Poirot. I am glad you’re satisfied of young Renauld’s guilt at last.” “Pardon! But I am not in the least satisfied. Jack Renauld is innocent.” Giraud stared for a moment then burst out laughing, tapping his head significantly with the brief remark: “Toqué!” Poirot drew himself up. A dangerous light showed in his eyes. “M. Giraud, throughout the case your manner to me has been deliberately insulting! You need teaching a lesson. I am prepared to wager you 500 francs that I find the murderer of M. Renauld before you do. Is it agreed?” Giraud stared helplessly at him, and murmured again: “Toqué!” “Come now,” urged Poirot, “is it agreed?” “I have no wish to take your money from you.” “Make your mind easy you will not!” “Oh, well then, I agree! You speak of my manner to you being insulting. Eh bien, once or twice, your manner has annoyed me.” “I am enchanted to hear it,” said Poirot. “Good morning, M. Giraud. Come, Hastings.” I said no word as we walked along the street. My heart was heavy. Poirot had displayed his intentions only too plainly. I doubted more than ever my powers of saving Bella from the consequences of her act. This unlucky encounter with Giraud had roused Poirot and put him on his mettle. Suddenly I felt a hand laid on my shoulder, and turned to face Gabriel Stonor. We stopped and greeted him, and he proposed strolling with us back to our hotel. “And what are you doing here, M. Stonor?” inquired Poirot. “One must stand by one’s friends,” replied the other dryly. “Especially when they are unjustly accused.” “Then you do not believe that Jack Renauld committed the crime?” I asked eagerly. “Certainly I don’t. I know the lad. I admit that there have been one or two things in this business that have staggered me completely, but none the less, in spite of his fool way of taking it, I’ll never believe that Jack Renauld is a murderer.” My heart warmed to the secretary. His words seemed to lift a secret weight from my heart. “I have no doubt that many people feel as you do,” I exclaimed. “There is really absurdly little evidence against him. I should say that there was no doubt of his acquittal no doubt whatever.” But Stonor hardly responded as I could have wished. “I’d give a lot to think as you do,” he said gravely. He turned to Poirot. “What’s your opinion, monsieur?” “I think that things look very black against him,” said Poirot quietly. “You believe him guilty?” said Stonor sharply. “No. But I think he will find it hard to prove his innocence.” “He’s behaving so damned queerly,” muttered Stonor. “Of course I realize that there’s a lot more in this affair than meets the eye. Giraud’s not wise to that because he’s an outsider, but the whole thing has been damned odd. As to that, least said soonest mended. If Mrs. Renauld wants to hush anything up, I’ll take my cue from her. It’s her show, and I’ve too much respect for her judgment to shove my oar in, but I can’t get behind this attitude of Jack’s. Any one would think he wanted to be thought guilty.” “But it’s absurd,” I cried, bursting in. “For one thing, the dagger ” I paused, uncertain as to how much Poirot would wish me to reveal. I continued, choosing my words carefully, “We know that the dagger could not have been in Jack Renauld’s possession that evening. Mrs. Renauld knows that.” “True,” said Stonor. “When she recovers, she will doubtless say all this and more. Well, I must be leaving you.” “One moment.” Poirot’s hand arrested his departure. “Can you arrange for word to be sent to me at once should Madame Renauld recover consciousness?” “Certainly. That’s easily done.” “That point about the dagger is good, Poirot,” I urged as we went upstairs. “I couldn’t speak very plainly before Stonor.” “That was quite right of you. We might as well keep the knowledge to ourselves as long as we can. As to the dagger, your point hardly helps Jack Renauld. You remember that I was absent for an hour this morning, before we started from London?” “Yes?” “Well, I was employed in trying to find the firm Jack Renauld employed to convert his souvenirs. It was not very difficult. Eh bien, Hastings, they made to his order not two paper-knives, but three.” “So that ?” “So that, after giving one to his mother, and one to Bella Duveen, there was a third which he doubtless retained for his own use. No, Hastings, I fear the dagger question will not help us to save him from the guillotine.” “It won’t come to that,” I cried, stung. Poirot shook his head uncertainly. “You will save him,” I cried positively. Poirot glanced at me dryly. “Have you not rendered it impossible, mon ami?” “Some other way,” I muttered. “Ah! Sapristi! But it is miracles you ask from me. No say no more. Let us instead see what is in this letter.” And he drew out the envelope from his breast pocket. His face contracted as he read, then he handed the one flimsy sheet to me. “There are other women in the world who suffer, Hastings.” The writing was blurred and the note had evidently been written in great agitation: “Dear M. Poirot: “If you get this, I beg of you to come to my aid. I have no one to turn to, and at all costs Jack must be saved. I implore of you on my knees to help us. “MARTHE DAUBREUIL.” I handed it back, moved. “You will go?” “At once. We will command an auto.” Half an hour later saw us at the Villa Marguerite. Marthe was at the door to meet us, and led Poirot in, clinging with both hands to one of his. “Ah, you have come it is good of you. I have been in despair, not knowing what to do. They will not let me go to see him in prison even. I suffer horribly, I am nearly mad. Is it true what they say, that he does not deny the crime? But that is madness. It is impossible that he should have done it! Never for one minute will I believe it.” “Neither do I believe it, mademoiselle,” said Poirot gently. “But then why does he not speak? I do not understand.” “Perhaps because he is screening some one,” suggested Poirot, watching her. Marthe frowned. “Screening some one? Do you mean his mother? Ah, from the beginning I have suspected her. Who inherits all that vast fortune? She does. It is easy to wear widow’s weeds and play the hypocrite. And they say that when he was arrested she fell down like that.” She made a dramatic gesture. “And without doubt, M. Stonor, the secretary, he helped her. They are thick as thieves, those two. It is true she is older than he, but what do men care if a woman is rich!” There was a hint of bitterness in her tone. “Stonor was in England,” I put in. “He says so but who knows?” “Mademoiselle,” said Poirot quietly, “if we are to work together, you and I, we must have things clear. "Without doubt you have been employing your time to a marvel? You have the names of the assassins for us, have you not? And also the precise spot where they find themselves now?" Unmoved by this irony, Giraud replied: "I know at least where they have come from." "Comment?" Giraud took two small objects from his pocket and laid them down on the table. We crowded around. The objects were very simple ones: the stub of a cigarette, and an unlighted match. The detective wheeled round on Poirot. "What do you see there?" he asked. There was something almost brutal in his tone. It made my cheeks flush. But Poirot remained unmoved. He shrugged his shoulders. "A cigarette end, and a match." "And what does that tell you?" Poirot spread out his hands. "It tells me nothing." "Ah!" said Giraud, in a satisfied voice. "You haven't made a study of these things. That's not an ordinary match not in this country at least. It's common enough in South America. Luckily it's unlighted. I mightn't have recognized it otherwise. Evidently one of the men threw away his cigarette end, and lit another, spilling one match out of the box as he did so." "And the other match?" asked Poirot. "Which match?" "The one he did light his cigarette with. You have found that also?" "No." "Perhaps you didn't search very thoroughly." "Not search thoroughly " For a moment it seemed as though the detective were going to break out angrily, but with an effort he controlled himself. "I see you love a joke, M. Poirot. But in any case, match or no match, the cigarette end would be sufficient. It is a South American cigarette with liquorice pectoral paper." Poirot bowed. The commissary spoke: "The cigarette end and match might have belonged to M. Renauld. Remember, it is only two years since he returned from South America." "No," replied the other confidently. "I have already searched among the effects of M. Renauld. The cigarettes he smoked and the matches he used are quite different." "You do not think it odd," asked Poirot, "that these strangers should come unprovided with a weapon, with gloves, with a spade, and that they should so conveniently find all these things?" Giraud smiled in a rather superior manner. "Undoubtedly it is strange. Indeed, without the theory that I hold, it would be inexplicable." "Aha!" said M. Hautet. "An accomplice. An accomplice within the house!" "Or outside it," said Giraud with a peculiar smile. "But some one must have admitted them? We cannot allow that, by an unparalleled piece of good fortune, they found the door ajar for them to walk in?" "D'accord, M. le juge. The door was opened for them, but it could just as easily be opened from outside by some one who possessed a key." "But who did possess a key?" Giraud shrugged his shoulders. "As for that, no one who possesses one is going to admit the fact if they can help it. But several people might have had one. M. Jack Renauld, the son, for instance. It is true that he is on his way to South America, but he might have lost the key or had it stolen from him. Then there is the gardener he has been here many years. One of the younger servants may have a lover. It is easy to take an impression of a key and have one cut. There are many possibilities. Then there is another person who, I should judge, is exceedingly likely to have such a thing in her keeping." "Who is that?" "Madame Daubreuil," said the detective dryly. "Eh, eh!" said the magistrate, his face falling a little, "so you have heard about that, have you?" "I hear everything," said Giraud imperturbably. "There is one thing I could swear you have not heard," said M. Hautet, delighted to be able to show superior knowledge, and without more ado, he retailed the story of the mysterious visitor the night before. He also touched on the check made out to "Duveen," and finally handed Giraud the letter signed "Bella." Giraud listened in silence, studied the letter attentively, and then handed it back. "All very interesting, M. le juge. But my theory remains unaffected." "And your theory is?" "For the moment I prefer not to say. Remember, I am only just beginning my investigations." "Tell me one thing, M. Giraud," said Poirot suddenly. "Your theory allows for the door being opened. It does not explain why it was left open. When they departed, would it not have been natural for them to close it behind them. If a sergent de ville had chanced to come up to the house, as is sometimes done to see that all is well, they might have been discovered and overtaken almost at once." "Bah! They forgot it. A mistake, I grant you." Then, to my surprise, Poirot uttered almost the same words as he had uttered to Bex the previous evening: "I do not agree with you. The door being left open was the result of either design or necessity, and any theory that does not admit that fact is bound to prove vain." We all regarded the little man with a good deal of astonishment.

Neatly written in small, precise handwriting was the inscription, “Signor Paolo Ascanio, Grosvenor Hotel.” The inspector busied himself with the telephone, then turned to us with a grin. “Just in time. Our fine gentleman was off to catch the boat train to the Continong. Well, gentlemen, that’s about all we can do here. It’s a bad business, but straightforward enough. Signor Ascanio was arrested and charged with the murder of Count Foscatini. When arrested, he denied knowing the Count, and declared he had never been near Regent’s Court either on the evening of the crime or on the previous morning. The younger man had disappeared entirely. Signor Ascanio had arrived alone at the Grosvenor Hotel from the Continent two days before the murder. All efforts to trace the second man failed. Ascanio, however, was not sent for trial. No less a personage than the Italian Ambassador himself came forward and testified at the police-court proceedings that Ascanio had been with him at the Embassy from eight till nine that evening. The prisoner was discharged. Naturally, a lot of people thought that the crime was a political one, and was being deliberately hushed up. Poirot had taken a keen interest in all these points. Nevertheless, I was somewhat surprised when he suddenly informed me one morning that he was expecting a visitor at eleven o’clock, and that that visitor was none other than Ascanio himself. “He wishes to consult you?” “Du tout, Hastings. I wish to consult him.” “What about?” “The Regent’s Court murder.” “You are going to prove that he did it?” “A man cannot be tried twice for murder, Hastings. Endeavour to have the common sense. Ah, that is our friend’s ring.” A few minutes later Signor Ascanio was ushered in a small, thin man with a secretive and furtive glance in his eyes. He remained standing, darting suspicious glances from one to the other of us. “Monsieur Poirot?” My little friend tapped himself gently on the chest. “Be seated, signor. You received my note. I am determined to get to the bottom of this mystery. In some small measure you can aid me. Let us commence. You in company with a friend visited the late Count Foscatini on the morning of Tuesday the 9th” The Italian made an angry gesture. “I did nothing of the sort. I have sworn in court” “Précisément and I have a little idea that you have sworn falsely.” “You threaten me? Bah! I have nothing to fear from you. I have been acquitted.” “Exactly; and as I am not an imbecile, it is not with the gallows I threaten you but with publicity. Publicity! I see that you do not like the word. I had an idea that you would not. My little ideas, you know, they are very valuable to me. Come, signor, your only chance is to be frank with me. I do not ask to know whose indiscretions brought you to England. I know this much, you came for the especial purpose of seeing Count Foscatini.” “He was not a count,” growled the Italian. “I have already noted the fact that his name does not appear in the Almanach de Gotha. You seem to know a good deal.” “I have employed my grey cells to some advantage. He pondered, shaking his head. “I am at a loss. My mind eludes me.” “Why, instead of abducting him, not simply incapacitate him with a blow to the head?” I pondered. “Excuse me, mon ami, but I did not quite suggest that. Undoubtedly, it is much more their responsibility to abduct him.” “But why?” “Because uncertainty breeds panic. That is one reason. If the Prime Minister were deceased, it would be a grave disaster, but it would be dealt with. However, now there is indecision. Will the Prime Minister resurface, or not? Is he alive or dead? No one knows, and until they do, nothing concrete can be accomplished. And, as I mentioned, uncertainty fosters panic, which is the goal of les Boches. Moreover, if the abductors are holding him in secret, they have the advantage of being able to negotiate with both sides. The German Government is not known for its generosity, but they may be persuaded to provide substantial payments in such a case. Thirdly, they avoid the risk of execution. Indeed, kidnapping is clearly their responsibility.” “Then, if that is the case, why did they attempt to shoot him first?” Poirot expressed frustration. “Ah, that is what baffles me! It is nonsensically foolish! They had everything arranged (and very well arranged!) for the abduction, yet they jeopardize the entire plan with a melodramatic assault, reminiscent of a movie, and equally unrealistic. It is almost unbelievable, with a group of masked individuals not far from London!” “Perhaps they were two entirely separate attempts occurring without regard to one another,” I suggested. “Ah, no, that would be too coincidental! Then, who is the traitor? There must have been a traitor in the initial incident, at any rate. But was it Daniels or O’Murphy? It must have been one of them, or why did the car veer off the main road? We cannot assume that the Prime Minister was complicit in his own demise! Did O’Murphy take that detour of his own volition, or was it at Daniels’ behest?” “Surely it must have been O’Murphy’s doing.” “Yes, because if it had been Daniels’, the Prime Minister would have heard the command and inquired about the rationale. But there are far too many unanswered questions in this case, and they contradict each other. If O’Murphy is honest, why did he deviate from the main road? But if he was deceitful, why did he restart the vehicle after only two shots were fired, potentially saving the Prime Minister’s life? And, if he was truthful, why did he immediately drive to a known haunt of German spies upon leaving Charing Cross?” “It appears suspicious,” I remarked. “Let us analyze the situation methodically. What evidence is there for and against these two men? Let us start with O’Murphy. Against: his actions in leaving the main road were dubious; he hails from County Clare; he has vanished in a suggestive manner. In favor: his quick response in resuming driving saved the Premier’s life; he is a Scotland Yard officer, and evidently, based on his assigned role, a trusted detective. Now, regarding Daniels. There is little against him, except that his background is unknown, and he speaks numerous languages for an Englishman! (Forgive me, mon ami, but your linguistic skills are lacking!) As for him, we have the fact that he was discovered bound, gagged, and chloroformed, which suggests he was not involved.” “He could have bound and gagged himself to divert suspicion.” Poirot shook his head. “The French authorities would not overlook such a detail. Furthermore, once he had achieved his goal, and the Prime Minister had been safely abducted, there would be no reason for him to stay behind. His accomplices could have gagged and chloroformed him, of course, but I fail to see their motive. He is of little value to them now, since he is bound to be under close scrutiny until the Prime Minister’s situation is clarified.” “Maybe he intended to mislead the police?” “Then why didn’t he? He claims that something was placed over his nose and mouth, and he recalls nothing beyond that. There is no diversion there. It sounds remarkably truthful.” “Well,” I said, checking the time, “I suppose we should head to the station. You might uncover more clues in France.” “Possibly, mon ami, but I am skeptical. I find it hard to believe that the Prime Minister remains undiscovered in that confined area, where concealing him must be arduous.
