"Let me see it." Lord Nasby reached out carelessly. "I think not," I replied, smiling. "It's mine, you see." "You're clever. Right to keep it. No qualms about not giving it to the police?" "I tried this morning. They didn't think it was related to the Marlow case, so I kept it. Plus, the inspector annoyed me." "Short-sighted man. Keep working on this lead. If you find something that's worth publishing, send it to me for a chance. There's always space for talent on the Daily Budget. But you have to prove yourself first. Understand?" I thanked him and apologized for my tactics. "No need. I like cheek from a pretty girl. By the way, you said two minutes and it's been three, with interruptions. That's quite impressive for a woman! Must be your scientific background." I left the building, feeling exhausted. Lord Nasby was becoming tiresome. But I was pleased with how well my plan had worked. Lord Nasby was surprisingly friendly. Now, all that was left was to "make good," as he put it. Once in my room, I examined the paper closely. It held the key to the mystery. What did the numbers signify? Five numbers, with a dot after the first two. "Seventeen one twenty-two," I whispered. That didn't lead to anything. So I added them up. "One and seven make eight, plus one is nine, plus two is eleven, plus two is thirteen." Thirteen! A significant number. Was it a warning to stay away? Possibly. But it seemed useless, except as a warning. I doubted that a conspirator would use that method to convey the number thirteen in real life. If they meant thirteen, they would write it as "13." I subtracted twenty-two from a hundred and seventy-one. The answer was a hundred and fifty-nine. I tried again and got a hundred and forty-nine. These exercises were good practice, but didn't solve the mystery. I left the math behind and focused on the words. Kilmorden Castle. A specific location. Maybe the home of an aristocratic family. Or a picturesque ruin. I leaned towards the buried treasure theory. Numbers often point to treasure. One step right, seven steps left, dig one foot, descend twenty-two steps. I could figure that out later. The priority was to reach Kilmorden Castle quickly. I gathered reference books and searched diligently, but found no mention of Kilmorden Castle. A setback. There had to be such a place. Why invent a name and write it down? Absurd! Maybe it was a grandiose house with a fabricated name. But that would be difficult to find. I sat back and pondered my next move. Then it hit me. I had to visit the crime scene. The best sleuths always do. And they always find something the police missed, no matter how much time has passed. My plan was clear. I had to go to Marlow. But how to gain access to the house? After discarding risky approaches, I settled on a simple one. The house was for rent, so I would pose as a potential tenant. I focused on local agents with fewer listings. Unfortunately, I didn't find any suitable properties. The clerk mentioned Sir Eustace Pedler's place, The Mill House. "Where the murder happened," he added. "But maybe you wouldn't want..." "Oh, I think I wouldn't mind," I said confidently. I felt my credibility was established. "And perhaps I could get a good deal in these circumstances." A brilliant move, I thought. "It's a possibility. It won't be easy to rent now, with servants and all. If you like it, make an offer. Shall I write you a note?" "Please do."

"Isn’t it true that women worship strength, almost like ancestor worship?” “It’s quite true if we’re honest. You may think you admire moral qualities, but when you fall in love, it’s the physical that matters. Living in primitive conditions would make it acceptable, but that’s not the case. In the end, the other side triumphs. The things that seem defeated always prevail in the end, don’t they? They win in the most important way. It’s like what the Bible says about losing your soul and then discovering it."

With a quick gesture, the woman grabbed a large black velvet cat that was hiding the telephone. "The documents are hidden in the lining of this," she revealed. "Impressive," Poirot whispered admiringly as he stepped away from the door. "Good evening, madame. I will keep your New York friend occupied while you escape." "Idiot!" shouted the Italian man, raising his gun and firing at the woman as she fled, prompting me to tackle him to the ground.

“Let us enter, sir.” “Do you have our associates unharmed?” “Yes, they are safe. However, they were not in possession of the items.” “I understand. So you have come to conduct a search. I am preparing to leave with Hastings, but before I go, I would like to share some insights on the history and behaviors of the household cat.” “Goodness gracious, have you lost your mind?” “The cat,” Poirot announced, “was revered by the ancient Egyptians. Even today, it is believed to be a sign of good fortune if a black cat crosses your path. Tonight, this cat has crossed your path, Japp. To discuss the inner workings of any creature or individual is, I realize, considered impolite in England.

Poirot hesitated before turning to M. Hautet. "Let's head there now," he said quietly. As we made our way to the scene, I could sense Poirot's determination to uncover the truth behind the murder. However, when he finally spoke, it was with an odd awkwardness that seemed out of place. "His overcoat was quite long," Poirot remarked, his voice strained. M. Hautet greeted us in the hall, and we followed Françoise upstairs. Poirot's erratic movement caught my attention, but he explained in a whisper, "We must be cautious, the servants are listening."

Rayburn was taken aback by the sight of Guy Pagett. "Pagett," he mumbled in disbelief. Rayburn seemed shocked by the revelation, but I couldn't help feeling a bit smug. "You look like you've seen a ghost," I remarked. Rayburn's eyes narrowed. "What's your role in all this? How much have you figured out?" I flashed a knowing smile. "Let's just say I know more than you think, Rayburn." His grip on my arm tightened, his voice trembling as he demanded, "Where did you hear that name?"

On my instructions, Mrs. Renauld rejected her son and announced her plan to draft a will the following day that would prevent him from inheriting any of his father's wealth. It was a drastic measure, but a necessary one, and Madame Renauld was willing to take the chance, although she neglected to mention her change of location. I assumed she assumed I was aware. Everything unfolded as predicted. Marthe Daubreuil attempted one final effort to claim the Renauld fortune and was unsuccessful! "What truly astounds me," I remarked, "is how she managed to enter the premises without detection. It's truly miraculous.

“Pagett is a conniving fellow,” said Sir Eustace, after the secretary had departed. “I’d be willing to bet that he’ll choose some slab-faced creature on purpose to annoy me. She must have nice feet too, I forgot to mention that.” Suzanne clutched my hand excitedly and nearly dragged me to her room. “Now, Suzanne,” I said, “we must quickly make plans. Pagett is staying behind, did you hear that?” “Yes. I suppose that means I won’t be allowed to go to Rhodesia, which is quite annoying because I want to go. How tiresome.” “Cheer up,” I said. “You’re going for sure. I don’t see how you could back out without it seeming suspicious. And, besides, Pagett might be suddenly summoned by Sir Eustace, making it harder for you to attach yourself to him for the journey up.” “It would hardly be respectable,” said Suzanne, dimpling. “I’d have to pretend a fatal passion for him as an excuse.” “On the other hand, if you were there when he arrived, it would all be perfectly natural. Besides, we mustn’t completely forget about the other two.” “Oh, Anne, you can’t seriously suspect Colonel Race or Sir Eustace?” “I suspect everyone,” I said darkly. “And if you’ve read any detective stories, Suzanne, you would know it’s always the most unlikely person who’s the villain. Lots of criminals have been cheerful fat men like Sir Eustace.” “Colonel Race isn’t particularly fat or particularly cheerful either.” “Sometimes they’re lean and saturnine,” I retorted. “I don’t say I seriously suspect either of them, but, after all, the woman was murdered in Sir Eustace’s house.” “Yes, yes, we needn’t go over all that again. I’ll keep an eye on him for you, Anne, and if he gets any fatter and any more cheerful, I’ll send you a telegram at once. ‘Sir E. swelling. Highly suspicious. Come at once.’” “Really, Suzanne,” I cried, “you seem to think all this is a game!” “I know I do,” said Suzanne, unabashed. “It feels like that. It’s your fault, Anne. I’ve been imbued with your ‘Let’s have an adventure’ spirit. It doesn’t seem real at all. If Clarence knew that I was running about Africa tracking dangerous criminals, he’d have a fit.” “Why don’t you cable him about it?” I asked sarcastically. Suzanne’s sense of humor always deserts her when it comes to sending cables. She considered my suggestion seriously. “I might. It would have to be a very long one.” Her eyes sparkled at the thought. “But I think it’s better not. Husbands always want to interfere with perfectly harmless amusements.” “Well,” I said, summing up the situation, “you will keep an eye on Sir Eustace and Colonel Race.”

I fulfilled my assignment successfully, making sure to collect payment upfront. I meticulously planned every detail, knowing this would be my final job before leaving the business. As for your reference to burning bridges, I must admit I am at a loss. I am not a revolutionary leader, but rather a distinguished English tourist who stumbled upon a secret in a local antique store and was subsequently abducted. Soon enough, I will likely be discovered bound and in a desperate state of fear and hunger, once the timing is right.

"I suggest you adjust your attitude, young lady." I remained silent, letting out a small yawn that hinted at my boredom. "What the heck," he started forcefully. But I cut him off. "Yelling won't get you anywhere with me. Let's not waste time. I have no interest in speaking with subordinates. Take me directly to Sir Eustace Pedler to save us both time and trouble." "To?" He seemed bewildered. "Yes," I confirmed. "Sir Eustace Pedler." "I I beg your pardon," He hurried out of the room like a startled hare. I took the opportunity to touch up my makeup in my purse.

He paused for a moment, deep in thought, before rising abruptly. “You’re heading back to Yardly Chase right away? Very well! Don’t breathe a word to anyone except to expect us there this evening. We’ll be there just after five.” “Okay, but I don’t understand” “It doesn’t matter,” said Poirot kindly. “You want me to keep your diamond safe, right?” “Yes, but” “Then do as I say.” A confused nobleman left the room. We arrived at Yardly Chase at half-past five, following the butler to the grand hall with a roaring fire. Lady Yardly and her children were there, the mother’s head bent over her two kids. Lord Yardly stood nearby, smiling. “Monsieur Poirot and Captain Hastings,” announced the butler. Lady Yardly looked surprised, her husband turned to Poirot for guidance. “I apologize! I’m still investigating Miss Marvell’s case. She’s coming on Friday, isn’t she? I wanted to check everything first. Lady Yardly, do you remember the postmarks on the letters you received?” Lady Yardly shook her head. “I’m sorry, I don’t. I never thought they were serious.” “Will you be staying the night?” Lord Yardly asked. “Oh, my lord, I don’t want to inconvenience you. Our bags are at the inn.” “No trouble at all. We’ll have them sent for. Please stay.” Poirot agreed, sitting with Lady Yardly and playing with the children. As they played, Lady Yardly expressed her love for her children. “You’re a good mother,” said Poirot, bowing. A dressing-gong rang, and we prepared to go to our rooms. Just then, a telegram arrived for Lord Yardly, causing a stir. Lady Yardly expressed her reluctance for him to sell the family diamond. She left to get ready. Later, we gathered in the drawing-room, awaiting Lady Yardly’s appearance. When she entered, the lights suddenly went out, a door slammed, and a woman’s scream pierced the silence. Lord Yardly panicked, rushing towards the noise. We found Lady Yardly on the floor, unconscious, her necklace missing. “The Chinaman,” she whispered. “The Chinaman by the side door.” Lord Yardly dashed towards the mentioned door, finding the stolen necklace just outside. The missing diamond, the Star of the East, was gone. “This confirms it,” I said. “These were not ordinary thieves. They only wanted one stone.” “But how did they get in?” “Through this door.” “But it’s always locked.” I opened it easily, revealing a torn piece of silk, likely from a Chinaman’s robe. We searched in vain, the thief had escaped. The police were called, and Lady Yardly recovered enough to tell her story. The diamond of Miss Marvell had also been stolen that morning, confirming my fears. Poirot, realizing his mistake, decided to return the stolen diamond and solve the case. Lord Yardly was shocked but grateful, as Poirot revealed the truth behind the theft. The ingenious scheme had fooled everyone, but Poirot’s sharp mind had uncovered the deception.

I have always been inclined to view work as something that should be taken on with a light and airy touch, if at all! Guy Pagett, on the other hand, is a man of seriousness and dedication. His lack of frivolity makes him a challenging companion. When I suggested he go to Florence, he eagerly accepted, despite the unusual timing. His devotion to guidebooks and galleries made it a worthwhile investment for me. However, our peace was shattered when he informed me of a murder in my house, involving a foreign woman. This unexpected turn of events has led me to reconsider my plans and embark on a new journey.

Poirot calmly analyzed the situation as Japp burst in with a sense of urgency. There was a burglary, jewels and money involved, and the culprit seemed to have made a clever escape plan. Poirot, with his keen eye for detail, explained his theory while enjoying his breakfast. Japp pressed for answers on the whereabouts of the criminal. Poirot, unfazed, hinted at a hiding place that showcased the brilliance of the criminal mind. The conversation turned to the best escape strategy, with Poirot's companions offering their opinions.

He, too, had inquired at the station. “And without doubt we are not original in the idea, Hastings. The excellent Giraud, he also has probably made his inquiries.” “You don’t think ” I said, and then stopped. “Ah, no, it would be too horrible!” Poirot looked inquiringly at me, but I said no more. It had just occurred to me that though there were seven women directly or indirectly connected with the case Mrs. Renauld, Madame Daubreuil and her daughter, the mysterious visitor, and the three servants there was, with the exception of old Auguste who could hardly count, only one man Jack Renauld. And a man must have dug a grave.… I had no time to develop further the appalling idea that had occurred to me, for Jack Renauld was ushered into the room. Poirot greeted him in a business-like manner. “Take a seat, monsieur. I regret infinitely to derange you, but you will perhaps understand that the atmosphere of the Villa is not too congenial to me. M. Giraud and I do not see eye to eye about everything. His politeness to me has not been striking and you will comprehend that I do not intend any little discoveries I may make to benefit him in any way.” “Exactly, M. Poirot,” said the lad. “That fellow Giraud is an ill-conditioned brute, and I’d be delighted to see some one score at his expense.” “Then I may ask a little favour of you?” “Certainly.” “I will ask you to go to the railway station and take a train to the next station along the line, Abbalac. Ask there at the cloak-room whether two foreigners deposited a valise there on the night of the murder. It is a small station, and they are almost certain to remember. Will you do this?” “Of course I will,” said the boy, mystified, though ready for the task. “I and my friend, you comprehend, have business elsewhere,” explained Poirot. “There is a train in a quarter of an hour, and I will ask you not to return to the Villa, as I have no wish for Giraud to get an inkling of your errand.” “Very well, I will go straight to the station.” He rose to his feet. Poirot’s voice stopped him. “One moment, M. Renauld, there is one little matter that puzzles me. Why did you not mention to M. Hautet this morning that you were in Merlinville on the night of the crime?” Jack Renauld’s face went crimson. With an effort he controlled himself. “You have made a mistake. I was in Cherbourg, as I told the examining magistrate this morning.” Poirot looked at him, his eyes narrowed, cat-like, until they only showed a gleam of green. “Then it is a singular mistake that I have made there for it is shared by the station staff. They say you arrived by the 11:40 train.” For a moment Jack Renauld hesitated, then he made up his mind. “And if I did? I suppose you do not mean to accuse me of participating in my father’s murder?” He asked the question haughtily, his head thrown back. “I should like an explanation of the reason that brought you here.” “That is simple enough. I came to see my fiancée, Mademoiselle Daubreuil. I was on the eve of a long voyage, uncertain as to when I should return. I wished to see her before I went, to assure her of my unchanging devotion.” “And you did see her?” Poirot’s eyes never left the other’s face. There was an appreciable pause before Renauld replied. Then he said: “Yes.” “And afterwards?” “I found I had missed the last train. I walked to St. Beauvais where I knocked up a garage and got a car to take me back to Cherbourg.” “St. Beauvais? That is fifteen kilometres. A long walk, M. Renauld.” “I I felt like walking.” Poirot bowed his head as a sign that he accepted the explanation. Jack Renauld took up his hat and cane and departed. In a trice Poirot jumped to his feet. “Quick, Hastings. We will go after him.” Keeping a discreet distance behind our quarry, we followed him through the streets of Merlinville. But when Poirot saw that he took the turning to the station, he checked himself. “All is well. He has taken the bait. He will go to Abbalac, and will inquire for the mythical valise left by the mythical foreigners. Yes, mon ami, all that was a little invention of my own.” “You wanted him out of the way!” I exclaimed. “Your penetration is amazing, Hastings! Now, if you please, we will go up to the Villa Geneviève.” “By the way, Poirot,” I said, as we walked along the hot white road, “I’ve got a bone to pick with you. I dare say you meant well, but really it was no business of yours to go mouching round to the Hôtel du Phare without letting me know.” Poirot shot a quick sidelong glance at me. “And how did you know I had been there?” he inquired. Much to my annoyance I felt the colour rising in my cheeks. “I happened to look in in passing,” I explained with as much dignity as I could muster. I rather feared Poirot’s banter, but to my relief, and somewhat to my surprise, he only shook his head with a rather unusual gravity. “If I have offended your susceptibilities in any way, I demand pardon of you. You will understand better soon. But, believe me, I have striven to concentrate all my energies on the case.” “Oh, it’s all right,” I said, mollified by the apology. “I know it’s only that you have my interests at heart. But I can take care of myself all right.” Poirot seemed to be about to say something further, but checked himself. Arrived at the Villa, Poirot led the way up to the shed where the second body had been discovered. He did not, however, go in, but paused by the bench which I have mentioned before as being set some few yards away from it. After contemplating it for a moment or two, he paced carefully from it to the hedge which marked the boundary between the Villa Geneviève and the Villa Marguerite. Then he paced back again, nodding his head as he did so. Returning again to the hedge, he parted the bushes with his hands. “With good fortune,” he remarked to me over his shoulder, “Mademoiselle Marthe may find herself in the garden. I desire to speak to her and would prefer not to call formally at the Villa Marguerite. Ah, all is well, there she is. Pst, mademoiselle! Pst! Un moment, s’il vous plaît.” I joined him at the moment that Marthe Daubreuil, looking slightly startled, came running up to the hedge at his call. “A little word with you, mademoiselle, if it is permitted?” “Certainly, Monsieur Poirot.” Despite her acquiescence, her eyes looked troubled and afraid. “Mademoiselle, do you remember running after me on the road the day that I came to your house with the examining magistrate? You asked me if any one were suspected of the crime.” “And you told me two Chilians.” Her voice sounded rather breathless, and her left hand stole to her breast. “Will you ask me the same question again, mademoiselle?” “What do you mean?” “This. If you were to ask me that question again, I should give you a different answer. Some one is suspected but not a Chilian.” “Who?” The word came faintly between her parted lips. “M. Jack Renauld.” “What?” It was a cry. “Jack? Impossible. Who dares to suspect him?” “Giraud.” “Giraud!” The girl’s face was ashy. “I am afraid of that man. He is cruel. He will he will ” She broke off. There was courage gathering in her face, and determination. I realized in that moment that she was a fighter. Poirot, too, watched her intently. “You know, of course, that he was here on the night of the murder?” he asked. “Yes,” she replied mechanically. “He told me.” “It was unwise to have tried to conceal the fact,” ventured Poirot. “Yes, yes,” she replied impatiently. “But we cannot waste time on regrets. We must find something to save him. He is innocent, of course, but that will not help him with a man like Giraud who has his reputation to think of. He must arrest some one, and that some one will be Jack.” “The facts will tell against him,” said Poirot. “You realize that?” She faced him squarely, and used the words I had heard her say in her mother’s drawing-room. “I am not a child, monsieur. I can be brave and look facts in the face. He is innocent, and we must save him.” She spoke with a kind of desperate energy, then was silent, frowning as she thought. “Mademoiselle,” said Poirot observing her keenly, “is there not something that you are keeping back that you could tell us?” She nodded perplexedly. “Yes, there is something, but I hardly know whether you will believe it it seems so absurd.” “At any rate, tell us, mademoiselle.” “It is this. M. Giraud sent for me, as an afterthought, to see if I could identify the man in there.” She signed with her head towards the shed. “I could not. At least I could not at the moment. But since I have been thinking ” “Well?” “It seems so queer, and yet I am almost sure. I will tell you. On the morning of the day M. Renauld was murdered, I was walking in the garden here, when I heard a sound of men’s voices quarrelling. I pushed aside the bushes and looked through. One of the men was M. Renauld and the other was a tramp, a dreadful looking creature in filthy rags. He was alternately whining and threatening. I gathered he was asking for money, but at that moment maman called me from the house, and I had to go. That is all, only I am almost sure that the tramp and the dead man in the shed are one and the same.” Poirot uttered an exclamation. “But why did you not say so at the time, mademoiselle?” “Because at first it only struck me that the face was vaguely familiar in some way. The man was differently dressed, and apparently belonged to a superior station in life. But tell me, Monsieur Poirot, is it not possible that this tramp might have attacked and killed M. Renauld, and taken his clothes and money?” “It is an idea, mademoiselle,” said Poirot slowly. “It leaves a lot unexplained, but it is certainly an idea. I will think of it.” A voice called from the house. “Maman,” whispered Marthe, “I must go.” And she slipped away through the trees. “Come,” said Poirot, and taking my arm, turned in the direction of the Villa. “What do you really think?” I asked, in some curiosity. “Was that story true, or did the girl make it up in order to divert suspicion from her lover?” “It is a curious tale,” said Poirot, “but I believe it to be the absolute truth. Unwittingly, Mademoiselle Marthe told us the truth on another point and incidentally gave Jack Renauld the lie. Did you notice his hesitation when I asked him if he saw Marthe Daubreuil on the night of the crime? He paused and then said ‘Yes.’ I suspected that he was lying. It was necessary for me to see Mademoiselle Marthe before he could put her on her guard. Three little words gave me the information I wanted. When I asked her if she knew that Jack Renauld was here that night, she answered ‘He told me.’ Now, Hastings, what was Jack Renauld doing here on that eventful evening, and if he did not see Mademoiselle Marthe whom did he see?” “Surely, Poirot,” I cried, aghast, “you cannot believe that a boy like that would murder his own father.” “Mon ami,” said Poirot, “you continue to be of a sentimentality unbelievable! I have seen mothers who murdered their little children for the sake of the insurance money! After that, one can believe anything.” “And the motive?” “Money of course. Remember that Jack Renauld thought that he would come in to half his father’s fortune at the latter’s death.” “But the tramp. Where does he come in?” Poirot shrugged his shoulders. “Giraud would say that he was an accomplice an apache who helped young Renauld to commit the crime, and who was conveniently put out of the way afterwards.” “But the hair round the dagger? The woman’s hair?” “Ah,” said Poirot, smiling broadly. “That is the cream of Giraud’s little jest. According to him, it is not a woman’s hair at all. Remember that the youths of today wear their hair brushed straight back from the forehead with pomade or hairwash to make it lie flat. Consequently some of the hairs are of considerable length.” “And you believe that too?” “No,” said Poirot with a curious smile. “For I know it to be the hair of a woman and more, which woman!” “Madame Daubreuil,” I announced positively. “Perhaps,” said Poirot, regarding me quizzically. But I refused to allow myself to get annoyed. “What are we going to do now?” I asked, as we entered the hall of the Villa Geneviève. “I wish to make a search amongst the effects of M. Jack Renauld. That is why I had to get him out of the way for a few hours.” “But will not Giraud have searched already?” I asked doubtfully. “Of course. He builds a case, as a beaver builds a dam, with a fatiguing industry. But he will not have looked for the things that I am seeking in all probability he would not have seen their importance if they stared him in the face. Let us begin.” Neatly and methodically, Poirot opened each drawer in turn, examined the contents, and returned them exactly to their places. It was a singularly dull and uninteresting proceeding. Poirot waded on through collars, pajamas and socks. A purring noise outside drew me to the window. Instantly I became galvanized into life. “Poirot!” I cried. “A car has just driven up. Giraud is in it, and Jack Renauld, and two gendarmes.” “Sacré tonnerre!” growled Poirot. “That animal of a Giraud, could he not wait? I shall not be able to replace the things in this last drawer with the proper method. Let us be quick.” Unceremoniously he tumbled out the things on the floor, mostly ties and handkerchiefs. Suddenly with a cry of triumph Poirot pounced on something, a small square cardboard, evidently a photograph. Thrusting it into his pocket, he returned the things pell-mell to the drawer, and seizing me by the arm dragged me out of the room and down the stairs. In the hall stood Giraud, contemplating his prisoner. “Good afternoon, M. Giraud,” said Poirot. “What have we here?” Giraud nodded his head towards Jack. “He was trying to make a getaway, but I was too sharp for him. He is under arrest for the murder of his father, M. Paul Renauld.” Poirot wheeled to confront the boy who leaned limply against the door, his face ashy pale. “What do you say to that, jeune homme?” Jack Renauld stared at him stonily. “Nothing,” he said. I was dumbfounded. Up to the last, I had not been able bring myself to believe Jack Renauld guilty. I had expected a ringing proclamation of his innocence when Poirot challenged him. But now, watching him as he stood, white and limp against the wall, and hearing the damning admission fall from his lips, I doubted no longer. But Poirot had turned to Giraud.

When Poirot advised Japp to arrest the housekeeper, it was too late. Mrs. Middleton had vanished, leaving behind only ordinary clothes.
