Arriving at the scene of the crime, I wasted no time in inspecting the room where the tragedy had occurred. The room was plain, with white walls and a bare floor stained around the edges. Despite my thorough search, I found nothing of interest except for a peculiar discovery hidden in a cupboard under one of the windows. A roll of Kodak films, smelling strongly of moth balls, was nestled in the corner. This unexpected find provided a crucial clue to the murder mystery, leading me to believe that the films had been dropped by the mysterious "doctor" during a struggle with the woman. Determined to unravel the truth, I left the house with the films in hand, eager to have them developed and delve deeper into the investigation.

"I felt a gentle pressure on my arm. It was Poirot. 'Shall we slip away, my friend? I think our services are no longer needed.' Once outside, however, he hesitated, and then, much to my surprise, he remarked: 'I should rather like to see the room next door.' The door was not locked, and we entered. The room, which was a large double one, was unoccupied. Dust lay about rather noticeably, and my sensitive friend gave a characteristic grimace as he ran his finger round a rectangular mark on a table near the window. 'The service leaves to be desired,' he observed dryly. He was staring thoughtfully out of the window, and seemed to have fallen into a brown study. 'Well?' I demanded impatiently. 'What did we come in here for?' He started. 'Je vous demande pardon, mon ami. I wished to see if the door was really bolted on this side also.' 'Well,' I said, glancing at the door which communicated with the room we had just left, 'it is bolted.' Poirot nodded. He still seemed to be thinking. 'And, anyway,' I continued, 'what does it matter? The case is over. I wish you'd had more chance of distinguishing yourself. But it was the kind of case that even a stiff-backed idiot like that inspector couldn't go wrong over.' Poirot shook his head. 'The case is not over, my friend. It will not be over until we find out who stole the pearls.' 'But the maid did!' 'Why do you say that?' 'Why,' I stammered, 'they were found actually in her mattress.' 'Ta, ta, ta!' said Poirot impatiently. 'Those were not the pearls.' 'What?' 'Imitation, mon ami.' The statement took my breath away. Poirot was smiling placidly. 'The good inspector obviously knows nothing of jewels. But presently there will be a fine hullabaloo!' 'Come!' I cried, dragging at his arm. 'Where?' 'We must tell the Opalsens at once.' 'I think not.' 'But that poor woman' 'Eh bien; that poor woman, as you call her, will have a much better night believing the jewels to be safe.' 'But the thief may escape with them!' 'As usual, my friend, you speak without reflection. How do you know that the pearls Mrs. Opalsen locked up so carefully to-night were not the false ones, and that the real robbery did not take place at a much earlier date?' 'Oh!' I said, bewildered. 'Exactly,' said Poirot, beaming. 'We start again.' He led the way out of the room, paused a moment as though considering, and then walked down to the end of the corridor, stopping outside the small den where the chambermaids and valets of the respective floors congregated. Our particular chambermaid appeared to be holding a small court there, and to be retailing her late experiences to an appreciative audience. She stopped in the middle of a sentence. Poirot bowed with his usual politeness. 'Excuse that I derange you, but I shall be obliged if you will unlock for me the door of Mr. Opalsen's room.' The woman rose willingly, and we accompanied her down the passage again. Mr. Opalsen's room was on the other side of the corridor, its door facing that of his wife's room. The chambermaid unlocked it with her pass-key, and we entered. As she was about to depart Poirot detained her. 'One moment; have you ever seen among the effects of Mr. Opalsen a card like this?' He held out a plain white card, rather highly glazed and uncommon in appearance. The maid took it and scrutinized it carefully. 'No, sir, I can't say I have. But, anyway, the valet has most to do with the gentlemen's rooms.' 'I see. Thank you.' Poirot took back the card. The woman departed. Poirot appeared to reflect a little. Then he gave a short, sharp nod of the head. 'Ring the bell, I pray of you, Hastings. Three times, for the valet.' I obeyed, devoured with curiosity. Meanwhile Poirot had emptied the waste-paper-basket on the floor, and was swiftly going through its contents. In a few moments the valet answered the bell. To him Poirot put the same question, and handed him the card to examine. But the response was the same. The valet had never seen a card of that particular quality among Mr. Opalsen's belongings. Poirot thanked him, and he withdrew, somewhat unwillingly, with an inquisitive glance at the overturned waste-paper-basket and the litter on the floor. He could hardly have helped overhearing Poirot's thoughtful remark as he bundled the torn papers back again: 'And the necklace was heavily insured. . . .' 'Poirot,' I cried, 'I see' 'You see nothing, my friend,' he replied quickly. 'As usual, nothing at all! It is incredible but there it is. Let us return to our own apartments.' We did so in silence. Once there, to my intense surprise, Poirot effected a rapid change of clothing. 'I go to London to-night,' he explained. 'It is imperative.' 'What?' 'Absolutely. The real work, that of the brain (ah, those brave little grey cells), it is done. I go to seek the confirmation. I shall find it! Impossible to deceive Hercule Poirot!' 'You'll come a cropper one of these days,' I observed, rather disgusted by his vanity. 'Do not be enraged, I beg of you, mon ami. I count on you to do me a service of your friendship.' 'Of course,' I said eagerly, rather ashamed of my moroseness. 'What is it?' 'The sleeve of my coat that I have taken off will you brush it? See you, a little white powder has clung to it. You without doubt observed me run my finger round the drawer of the dressing-table?' 'No, I didn't.' 'You should observe my actions, my friend. Thus I obtained the powder on my finger, and, being a little over-excited, I rubbed it on my sleeve; an action without method which I deplore false to all my principles.' 'But what was the powder?' I asked, not particularly interested in Poirot's principles. 'Not the poison of the Borgias,' replied Poirot, with a twinkle. 'I see your imagination mounting. I should say it was French chalk.' 'French chalk?' 'Yes, cabinet-makers use it to make drawers run smoothly.' I laughed. 'You old sinner! I thought you were working up to something exciting.' 'Au revoir, my friend. I save myself. I fly!' The door shut behind him. With a smile, half of derision, half of affection, I picked up the coat, and stretched out my hand for the clothes-brush. The next morning, hearing nothing from Poirot, I went out for a stroll, met some old friends, and lunched with them at their hotel. In the afternoon we went for a spin. A punctured tyre delayed us, and it was past eight when I got back to the Grand Metropolitan. The first sight that met my eyes was Poirot, looking even more diminutive than usual, sandwiched between the Opalsens, beaming in a state of placid satisfaction. 'Mon ami Hastings!' he cried, and sprang to meet me. 'Embrace me, my friend; all has marched to a marvel!' Luckily, the embrace was merely figurative not a thing one is always sure of with Poirot. 'Do you mean' I began. 'Just wonderful, I call it!' said Mrs. Opalsen, smiling all over her fat face. 'Didn't I tell you, Ed, that if he couldn't get back my pearls nobody would?' 'You did, my dear, you did. And you were right.' I looked helplessly at Poirot, and he answered the glance. 'My friend Hastings is, as you say in England, all at the seaside. Seat yourself, and I will recount to you all the affair that has so happily ended.' 'Ended?' 'But yes. They are arrested.' 'Who are arrested?' 'The chambermaid and the valet, parbleu! You did not suspect? Not with my parting hint about the French chalk?' 'You said cabinet-makers used it.' 'Certainly they do to make drawers slide easily. Somebody wanted that drawer to slide in and out without any noise. Who could that be? Obviously, only the chambermaid. The plan was so ingenious that it did not at once leap to the eye not even to the eye of Hercule Poirot. 'Listen, this was how it was done. The valet was in the empty room next door, waiting. The French maid leaves the room. Quick as a flash the chambermaid whips open the drawer, takes out the jewel-case, and, slipping back the bolt, passes it through the door. The valet opens it at his leisure with the duplicate key with which he has provided himself, extracts the necklace, and waits his time. Célestine leaves the room again, and pst! in a flash the case is passed back again and replaced in the drawer. 'Madame arrives, the theft is discovered. The chambermaid demands to be searched, with a good deal of righteous indignation, and leaves the room without a stain on her character. The imitation necklace with which they have provided themselves has been concealed in the French girl's bed that morning by the chambermaid a master stroke, ça!' 'But what did you go to London for?' 'You remember the card?' 'Certainly. It puzzled me and puzzles me still. I thought' I hesitated delicately, glancing at Mr. Opalsen. Poirot laughed heartily. 'Une blague! For the benefit of the valet. The card was one with a specially prepared surface for finger-prints. I went straight to Scotland Yard, asked for our old friend Inspector Japp, and laid the facts before him. As I had suspected, the finger-prints proved to be those of two well-known jewel thieves who have been 'wanted' for some time. Japp came down with me, the thieves were arrested, and the necklace was discovered in the valet's possession. A clever pair, but they failed in method. Have I not told you, Hastings, at least thirty-six times, that without method' 'At least thirty-six thousand times!' I interrupted. 'But where did their 'method' break down?' 'Mon ami, it is a good plan to take a place as chambermaid or valet but you must not shirk your work. They left an empty room undusted; and therefore, when the man put down the jewel-case on the little table near the communicating door, it left a square mark' 'I remember,' I cried. 'Before, I was undecided. Then I knew!' There was a moment's silence. 'And I've got my pearls,' said Mrs. Opalsen as a sort of Greek chorus. 'Well,' I said, 'I'd better have some dinner.' Poirot accompanied me. 'This ought to mean kudos for you,' I observed. 'Pas du tout,' replied Poirot tranquilly. 'Japp and the local inspector will divide the credit between them. But' he tapped his pocket 'I have a cheque here, from Mr. Opalsen, and, how say you, my friend? This week-end has not gone according to plan. Shall we return here next week-end at my expense this time?' Now that war and the problems of war are things of the past, I think I may safely venture to reveal to the world the part which my friend Poirot played in a moment of national crisis. The secret has been well guarded. Not a whisper of it reached the Press. But, now that the need for secrecy has gone by, I feel it is only just that England should know the debt it owes to my quaint little friend, whose marvellous brain so ably averted a great catastrophe. One evening after dinner I will not particularize the date; it suffices to say that it was at the time when 'Peace by negotiation' was the parrot-cry of England's enemies my friend and I were sitting in his rooms. After being invalided out of the Army I had been given a recruiting job, and it had become my custom to drop in on Poirot in the evenings after dinner and talk with him of any cases of interest that he might have on hand. I was attempting to discuss with him the sensational news of that day no less than an attempted assassination of Mr. David MacAdam, England's Prime Minister. The account in the papers had evidently been carefully censored. No details were given, save that the Prime Minister had had a marvellous escape, the bullet just grazing his cheek. I considered that our police must have been shamefully careless for such an outrage to be possible. I could well understand that the German agents in England would be willing to risk much for such an achievement. 'Fighting Mac,' as his own party had nicknamed him, had strenuously and unequivocally combated the Pacifist influence which was becoming so prevalent. He was more than England's Prime Minister he was England; and to have removed him from his sphere of influence would have been a crushing and paralysing blow to Britain. Poirot was busy mopping a grey suit with a minute sponge. Never was there a dandy such as Hercule Poirot. Neatness and order were his passion. Now, with the odour of benzine filling the air, he was quite unable to give me his full attention. 'In a little minute I am with you, my friend. I have all but finished. The spot of grease he is not good I remove him so!' He waved his sponge. I smiled as I lit another cigarette. 'Anything interesting on?' I inquired, after a minute or two. 'I assist a how do you call it? 'charlady' to find her husband. A difficult affair, needing the tact. For I have a little idea that when he is found he will not be pleased. What would you? For my part, I sympathize with him. He was a man of discrimination to lose himself.' I laughed. 'At last! The spot of grease, he is gone! I am at your disposal.' 'I was asking you what you thought of this attempt to assassinate MacAdam?' 'Enfantillage!' replied Poirot promptly. 'One can hardly take it seriously. To fire with the rifle never does it succeed. It is a device of the past.' 'It was very near succeeding this time,' I reminded him. Poirot shook his head impatiently. He was about to reply when the landlady thrust her head round the door and informed him that there were two gentlemen below who wanted to see him. 'They won't give their names, sir, but they says as it's very important.' 'Let them mount,' said Poirot, carefully folding his grey trousers. In a few minutes the two visitors were ushered in, and my heart gave a leap as in the foremost I recognized no less a personage than Lord Estair, Leader of the House of Commons; whilst his companion, Mr. Bernard Dodge, was also a member of the War Cabinet, and, as I knew, a close personal friend of the Prime Minister. 'Monsieur Poirot?' said Lord Estair interrogatively. My friend bowed. The great man looked at me and hesitated. 'My business is private.' 'You may speak freely before Captain Hastings,' said my friend, nodding to me to remain. 'He has not all the gifts, no! But I answer for his discretion.' Lord Estair still hesitated, but Mr. Dodge broke in abruptly: 'Oh, come on don't let's beat about the bush! As far as I can see, the whole of England will know the hole we're in soon enough. Time's everything.' 'Pray be seated, messieurs,' said Poirot politely. 'Will you take the big chair, milord?' Lord Estair started slightly."

Madame Beroldy was the kind of woman who could captivate any man. Her beauty and mysterious aura drew people in, including the wealthy American, Mr. Hiram P. Trapp. But behind closed doors, a dark and twisted plot was unfolding. One fateful night, the Beroldys' home was breached by masked intruders, leading to a gruesome discovery. Madame Beroldy was found bound and gagged, while her husband lay lifeless with a knife through his heart. The investigation pointed towards Madame Beroldy and her alleged lover, Georges Conneau. Despite her royal blood claims and elaborate stories, the truth eventually came to light when a confession letter from Conneau surfaced, revealing the shocking extent of their deadly plan.

I am certain of Mrs. Renauld's innocence in this case, as her fainting was genuine and her anguish real. She did not need to fake her grief, as she had already shown true emotion upon hearing of her husband's death. The open door at the crime scene puzzled Poirot, who believed that the culprit must have left through the window. This theory was supported by the lack of footprints in one of the flower beds, which had been smoothed over with a rake to erase any trace of the intruder's presence. Despite initial doubts, I began to consider the possibility that the murderer had indeed escaped through the window, opening up a new avenue of investigation.

Ah, it was executed with remarkable precision! After setting the clock to 8.47, he violently smashes it and halts time. The one oversight: he neglects to close the curtains. In a real scenario, the curtains would have been drawn once daylight waned. After swiftly informing the lift operator about the guests, he rushes to a phone booth. At almost precisely 8.47, he calls the doctor with his employer's final plea. His plan is so flawless that there is never any investigation into whether a call was made from Flat II at that exact moment. "Unless Hercule Poirot decides to meddle," I remarked sarcastically.

I despise being entangled in such matters. The day took a turn when Guy Pagett entered my bedroom this morning, holding a telegram with a solemn expression that rivaled a mourner at a funeral. Guy Pagett, my diligent secretary, is an exemplary individual in every aspect - diligent, meticulous, and hard-working. Yet, he manages to irritate me like no other. I have pondered for quite some time on how to remove him from my service. However, it is not feasible to terminate a secretary simply because he prioritizes work over leisure, enjoys rising early, and possesses no discernible vices. The one redeeming quality about him is his somber countenance.

He made a stop at a small cottage hospital to get his wound treated before continuing on to Charing Cross, where a special train was ready to take him to Dover. Captain Daniels provided a brief account of the incident to the police before the man departed for France. Upon arrival in Dover, he boarded a waiting destroyer, and in Boulogne, a counterfeit car with the Union Jack awaited him. "Is that all?" inquired the listener. "Yes," replied the man. "Although, there is one rather odd detail that I must mention."

I heard the sound of running feet in the passage. Suddenly, a man burst into my cabin, pleading for help. With quick thinking, I hid him behind my cabin trunk and wash-basin, disguising myself as a lady preparing to wash. A night stewardess interrupted, warning of a drunk man causing trouble. After bandaging the wounded man's stab wound, he refused my help coldly. I felt a sense of danger from him, especially when he refused to thank me for saving his life. The next morning, I discovered someone had searched my cabin. Determined to uncover the truth, I kept a close eye on Sir Eustace Pedler, Mr. Pagett, and the Rev. Edward Chichester. The mysterious events on the ship continued, raising suspicions about the people around me.

"One learns to value life and death with ease.” “Indeed,” I replied, recalling Harry Rayburn. He had shared that sentiment. “But one should not mistreat the vulnerable?” “There are varying opinions on what constitutes ‘vulnerability,’ Miss Anne.” His tone turned serious, catching me off guard. It dawned on me that I had little insight into the man walking beside me. “I was referring to children and animals, perhaps.” “I can assure you I’ve never been unkind to children or animals. Do you consider women as ‘vulnerable’?” I paused. “No, I don’t believe I do, although they may be, I suppose.”

"The woman was talking so quickly that I couldn't quite make out her words, but I caught Monsieur's final statement as he held the door open for her." She hesitated, and then repeated slowly and painstakingly: "'Yes yes, but for God's sake go now!'" "Yes, yes, but for God's sake go now!" echoed the judge. He sent Denise away and, after a brief pause for thought, summoned Françoise back. He asked her if she might have been mistaken about the night Madame Daubreuil visited. Françoise, however, remained stubborn. It was definitely the previous night that Madame Daubreuil had come. No doubt about it. Denise just wanted attention, that's all! So she made up this elaborate story about a mysterious lady. Showing off her knowledge of English as well! Maybe Monsieur never even said that sentence in English, and even if he did, it didn't prove anything, since Madame Daubreuil spoke English fluently and usually used that language when talking to Mr. and Mrs. Renauld. "You see, Mr. Jack, Monsieur's son, was usually here, and he spoke French very poorly." The judge didn't push the issue. Instead, he asked about the chauffeur, and discovered that just the day before, Mr. Renauld had said he wouldn't be needing the car and that Masters might as well take a break. A puzzled expression began to form between Poirot's eyes. "What's wrong?" I whispered. He shook his head impatiently and posed a question: "Excuse me, Mr. Bex, but could Mr. Renauld drive the car himself?" The police officer looked at Françoise, and the elderly woman replied immediately: "No, Monsieur didn't drive himself." Poirot's frown deepened. "I wish you would tell me what's bothering you," I said irritably. "Can't you see? In his letter, Mr. Renauld mentioned sending the car for me to Calais." "Maybe he meant a rented car," I suggested. "Probably. But why rent a car when you have your own? Why decide yesterday to suddenly send the chauffeur on vacation, with no advance notice? Could it be that he wanted him out of the way for some reason before we arrived?" Françoise had left the room. The judge was drumming his fingers thoughtfully on the table. "Mr. Bex," he said after a while, "we have conflicting testimonies here. Who should we trust, Françoise or Denise?" "Denise," the police officer said firmly. "She was the one who let the visitor in. Françoise is old and stubborn, and clearly doesn't like Madame Daubreuil. Plus, our own information suggests that Renauld was involved with another woman." "Tiens!" exclaimed Mr. Hautet. "We forgot to tell Mr. Poirot about that." He rummaged through the papers on the table and eventually handed the one he was looking for to my friend. "This letter, Mr. Poirot, was found in the pocket of the deceased's coat." Poirot took it and unfolded it.

"Once I obtained a copy of a wireless message sent to Nadina by someone aboard the Kilmorden - either Carton or Rayburn, I wasn't certain. It echoed the piece of paper you found: 'Seventeen one twenty two.' I assumed it was a meeting with Rayburn, and his urgency to board the Kilmorden confirmed my suspicions. I feigned belief in his lies and allowed him access, keeping a close eye on him in hopes of gaining more information. When I discovered Minks trying to interfere, I put a stop to it. He fell in line quickly. Not securing Cabin 17 was frustrating and not being able to identify you troubled me. Were you truly the innocent girl you appeared to be? Rayburn went to the supposed meeting that night, with Minks assigned to intercept him. Minks failed, naturally." "But why did the message say 'seventeen' instead of 'seventy-one'?" "I've figured that out. Carton must have given the operator his notes to copy onto a form, without verifying the final copy. The operator, like the rest of us, misread it as 17.1.22 instead of 1.71.22. What I can't explain is how Minks found Cabin 17. It must have been pure instinct." "And the message to General Smuts? Who tampered with that?" "My dear Anne, did you think I'd let my plans be exposed without taking precautions? With an escaped murderer as a secretary, I had no qualms swapping the documents for blanks. No one would suspect poor Pedler." "What about Colonel Race?" "Yes, that was unexpected. When Pagett revealed he was in Secret Service, I grew uneasy. I remembered his past interest in Nadina during the War and feared he was onto me. His unwavering presence concerns me. He's the type to always have a hidden agenda." A whistle sounded. Sir Eustace picked up the tube, listened briefly, then replied: "Very well, I'll see him now." "Business," he commented. "Miss Anne, let me show you to your room." He led me to a modest room, a Kafir boy brought my suitcase, and Sir Eustace, encouraging me to ask for anything I needed, left, the epitome of a gracious host. A can of hot water sat on the washstand, and I began unpacking essentials. A foreign object in my sponge-bag caught my attention. I untied it and found a small pearl-handled revolver. It had not been there when I left Kimberley. I inspected it cautiously. It seemed loaded. I hesitantly tucked it into my stocking - an uncomfortable bulge, but the safest spot. Sir Eustace didn't summon me until late afternoon. I had tea and lunch in my room, preparing for what was to come. Sir Eustace was alone, pacing with a gleam in his eye. There was a shift in his demeanor towards me. "I've news for you. Your young man is on his way. Be calm, I have more to say. This morning, you tried to deceive me. Stick to the truth - I advised you. You erred by suggesting the diamonds were with Harry Rayburn. In reality, I've had them since leaving the Falls, only discovering it recently." "You knew!" I gasped. "Pagett inadvertently revealed it. He rambled about a bet and film canisters, leading me to piece it together. I transferred the films before leaving, they're in the corner. I haven't reviewed them, but one feels different, rattles oddly, and is sealed with seccotine, requiring a tin-opener. The truth is clear now, isn't it? You and Rayburn are trapped. Pity you rejected the idea of becoming Lady Pedler." I stood speechless. Footsteps approached, the door burst open, and Harry Rayburn was brought in. Sir Eustace looked triumphant. "As planned," he murmured. "Amateurs against professionals." "What's going on?" Harry demanded. "You've played into my hands," Sir Eustace chuckled. "You were meant to come safely, Anne?" "Don't blame her. That note was under my direction, she had no choice."

As my rescuer turned towards me, a sense of urgency emanated from him. "You're injured!" His voice held a hint of danger towards whoever had caused me harm. In that instant, I recognized him - the man with the scar. But before he could react, our fallen adversary had already bolted up and fled. Rayburn cursed as he pursued the enemy, leaving me behind. Feeling left out, I reluctantly joined the pursuit, lagging behind. We raced around the deck, finally reaching the starboard side of the ship.

"You see, Anne, Sir Eustace has been cleared of all charges. His guilt is certain, despite some technicalities. There is nothing to prevent you from being together now." His voice was hesitant as he spoke, avoiding eye contact. "I am aware," I responded with relief. "And there is no obstacle to him reclaiming his true identity immediately." "Indeed, there is not." "Do you know his true name?" The question caught me off guard. "Yes, I do. It's Harry Lucas." His silence in response felt unsettling, leaving me with a sense of unease.

Poirot and I quickly discussed the situation before he hurried away. I patted him on the back, acknowledging his success. "They've revealed the hiding spot to you, haven't they? But you must send a wire to France immediately. Going in person will be too slow." Poirot gave me a puzzled look. "Some things, my friend, cannot be communicated through telegrams." Just then, Major Norman came back with a Flying Corps officer, Captain Lyall, who would be flying Poirot to France.

"Ridiculous!” “Not at all! Haven't you witnessed impersonators in music halls mimicking famous personalities with uncanny precision? It's a piece of cake to pretend to be someone in the public eye. The Prime Minister of England is a much simpler target to mimic than an average Joe like Mr. John Smith from Clapham. And as for O’Murphy’s doppelgänger, no one would have paid him any attention until after the Prime Minister had left, at which point he would have vanished. He travels from Charing Cross directly to his rendezvous with accomplices. He enters as O’Murphy, and exits as an entirely different person. O’Murphy has vanished into thin air, leaving behind a conveniently suspicious trail."

“But this is pitch black. I cannot see.” “Poirot,” I exclaimed impatiently, after the Ministers had left, “what are your thoughts?” My friend was meticulously packing a small suitcase, his hands moving swiftly and expertly. With a pensive expression, he shook his head. “I am at a loss. My mind is failing me.” “Why go through the trouble of kidnapping him when a blow to the head would suffice?” I pondered. “Forgive me, my friend, but I did not quite suggest that. It is far more advantageous for them to handle the kidnapping.” “But why?” “Because uncertainty breeds chaos. That is one reason. If the Prime Minister were to be deceased, it would be a tragedy, but a challenge that could be met. However, with his disappearance, there is paralysis. Will he return, or is he gone forever? Is he alive or dead? Nobody knows, and until they find out, nothing concrete can be accomplished. And, as I mentioned, uncertainty leads to chaos, which is precisely what the enemy desires. Furthermore, by keeping the Prime Minister hidden, the kidnappers have the upper hand to negotiate with both sides. The German Government may not be known for their generosity, but in a situation like this, they can be persuaded to pay a hefty sum. Lastly, they avoid the risk of facing the hangman’s noose. Oh, without a doubt, the responsibility of kidnapping lies with them.” “In that case, why attempt to shoot him first?” Poirot expressed his frustration. “Ah, that is the part that baffles me! It is senseless and foolish! They had everything perfectly arranged for the abduction, and yet they jeopardize the entire operation with a dramatic attack, reminiscent of a film, and just as unrealistic. It is nearly inconceivable, with a group of masked individuals, so close to London!” “Perhaps the shooting and the kidnapping were two separate incidents that occurred independently,” I suggested. “Ah, no, that would be too much of a coincidence! Furthermore, who is the traitor? There must have been a traitor involved in the initial incident. Was it Daniels or O’Murphy? It had to be one of them, otherwise, why would the car deviate from the main road? We cannot assume that the Prime Minister was complicit in his own demise! Did O’Murphy choose that path on his own, or was it at Daniels’ instruction?” “It seems likely that O’Murphy was responsible.” “Yes, because had it been Daniels, the Prime Minister would have overheard the command and questioned it. However, there are too many unanswered questions in this case, and they contradict each other. If O’Murphy is trustworthy, why divert from the main road? But if he is untrustworthy, why restart the car after just two shots were fired, potentially saving the Prime Minister’s life? And, if he is honest, why drive straight to a known spot for German spies immediately after departing from Charing Cross?” “It does not look favorable,” I remarked. “Let us approach this methodically. What evidence do we have for and against these two men? Let us begin with O’Murphy. Against: his decision to leave the main road was suspicious; he hails from County Clare; he has vanished in a suspicious manner. For: his quick action in restarting the car prevented a tragedy; he is a member of Scotland Yard and, based on his assigned role, a trusted detective. Now, as for Daniels. There is little against him, except his mysterious background and proficiency in multiple languages for an Englishman! (I beg your pardon, my friend, but your linguistic abilities are lacking!) On his behalf, he was discovered gagged, bound, and unconscious, which does not align with him being involved in the plot.” “He could have tied himself up to divert attention,” I suggested. Poirot shook his head. “The French authorities would not overlook such a detail. Besides, once he achieved his objective and the Prime Minister was safely taken, there would be no reason for him to stay behind. His accomplices could have subdued him, but I fail to comprehend their motive. He is of little use to them now, as he will undoubtedly be under close surveillance until the Prime Minister’s situation is resolved.” “Perhaps he aimed to mislead the police?” “Then why did he not do so? He simply claims to have been chloroformed and remembers nothing further. There is no indication of deception. It sounds remarkably truthful.” “Well,” I said, glancing at the clock, “I suppose we should head to the station. You may discover additional clues in France.” “Possibly, my friend, but I am skeptical. It is still incredible to me that the Prime Minister has not been located in that confined area, where concealing him would be a significant challenge. If the forces of two nations have not succeeded in finding him, how can I?” At Charing Cross, Mr. Dodge greeted us. “This is Detective Barnes from Scotland Yard and Major Norman. They are at your service. Best of luck. It’s a dire situation, but I am still hopeful. I must take my leave now.” And with that, the Minister walked away briskly. We engaged in casual conversation with Major Norman. In the midst of the group of men on the platform, I spotted a familiar face conversing with a tall, fair man. It was Detective-Inspector Japp, an old acquaintance of Poirot’s, reputed to be one of Scotland Yard’s brightest officers. He approached us and greeted my friend warmly. “I heard you were involved in this case as well. Impressive work. So far, they have managed to evade capture. But I believe they will not be able to keep him hidden for long. Our teams are scouring France thoroughly. I sense that the end is near, possibly within hours.” “That is, assuming he is still alive,” the tall detective remarked somberly. Japp’s expression turned grim. “Yes.

"It adds up, also, to M. Renauld's effort to appease her with a check. I believe I will be able to locate her easily with the aid of this." He then revealed the picture he had removed from Jack Renauld's desk. "With affection from Bella," was written in messy handwriting in the corner, but that was not what captured my attention. The quality of the image was not the best, yet it was undeniably familiar to me. A chill ran down my spine, as if a terrible disaster had struck me. It was the visage of Cinderella.

"And yet, attributing the crime to Georges Conneau, the first is just as plausible. Therefore, we must consider the possibility that Madame Renauld lied out of love for the man she cherished, Georges Conneau. Do you agree with that?" "Yes," I conceded. "It does make sense." "Good! Madame Renauld's affections lie with Georges Conneau. But who is Georges Conneau, really?" "The vagrant." "Do we have any proof that Madame Renauld loved the vagrant?" "No, but..." "Exactly. Let go of theories that lack supporting evidence. Instead, ponder on who Madame Renauld truly loved." I shook my head, puzzled. "Mais, oui, you already know. Who did Madame Renauld love so deeply that upon seeing his lifeless body, she fainted?" I gaped in disbelief. "Her husband?" I stammered. Poirot nodded. "Her husband, or Georges Conneau, as you wish to call him." I collected myself. "But it's preposterous." "How 'preposterous?' Didn't we just agree that Madame Daubreuil could blackmail Georges Conneau?" "Yes, but..." "And didn't she successfully blackmail Mr. Renauld?" "That may be true, but..." "And isn’t it a fact that we have no knowledge of Mr. Renauld's past and upbringing? That he suddenly emerges as a French Canadian exactly twenty-two years ago?" "All of that is true," I asserted more confidently, "but you appear to be overlooking a crucial point." "What is it, my friend?" "Well, we have acknowledged that Georges Conneau orchestrated the crime. This leads us to the absurd notion that he planned his own demise!" "Eh bien, mon ami," Poirot said calmly, "that is precisely what he did!" In a composed tone, Poirot commenced his explanation. "You find it odd, my friend, that a man would orchestrate his own death? So peculiar, that you find it easier to dismiss it as fantastical, and revert to a story that is in fact ten times more improbable. Yes, Mr. Renauld plotted his own death, but there is one detail that perhaps escapes you he did not intend to die." I shook my head, bewildered. "But no, it is all quite simple truly," said Poirot kindly. "For the crime Mr. Renauld envisioned, a murderer was not required, as I mentioned, but a body was. Let us reconstruct, viewing the events from a different perspective this time. "Georges Conneau flees from justice to Canada. There, under an assumed identity, he weds and eventually amasses a vast fortune in South America. However, he longs for his homeland. Two decades have passed, he is significantly altered in appearance, and has become a man of such prominence that no one would link him to a fugitive from years prior. He deems it safe to return. He establishes himself in England, with plans to spend summers in France. And fate, that enigmatic force that ensures individuals face the consequences of their actions, leads him to Merlinville. There, within all of France, is the sole individual capable of recognizing him. It is, naturally, a goldmine for Madame Daubreuil, and one she wastes no time exploiting. He is at her mercy, entirely. And she extracts a hefty price. "Then, the inevitable occurs. Jack Renauld falls in love with the captivating woman he sees almost daily, and wishes to marry her. This alarms his father. At any cost, he will prevent his son from marrying the daughter of this wicked woman. Jack Renauld is unaware of his father's past, but Madame Renauld knows it all. She is a woman of great strength, deeply devoted to her husband. They confer. Renauld sees only one escape from death. He must feign his demise, actually fleeing to a foreign land where he will start anew under a different name, and where Madame Renauld, having played the role of a grieving widow for a time, can join him. It is imperative that she controls the finances, so he revises his will. How they intended to handle the body situation initially, I am unsure perhaps using a skeleton from an art student and a fire, or something of that nature, but long before their plans come to fruition, an incident occurs that aids them. A rough vagrant, aggressive and vulgar, finds his way into the garden. A scuffle ensues, Mr. Renauld tries to remove him, and suddenly the vagrant, an epileptic, collapses in a seizure. He expires. Mr. Renauld summons his wife. Together, they drag him into the shed, where, just outside, the incident transpired, and they recognize the marvelous opportunity that has presented itself. The man bears no resemblance to Mr. Renauld, but he is middle-aged, of a typical French appearance. That suffices. "I presume they sat on the bench up there, away from the house, discussing matters. Their plan is swiftly devised. The identification hinges solely on Madame Renauld's testimony. Jack Renauld and the chauffeur (who served his master for two years) must be removed. It is unlikely that the French female servants would approach the body, and in any case, Renauld intends to take precautions to deceive anyone unlikely to discern details. Masters is sent away, a telegram dispatched to Jack, selecting Buenos Ayres to lend credence to the narrative Renauld had devised. Aware of me as a rather obscure elderly detective, he wrote his plea for assistance knowing that, upon my arrival, presenting the letter would deeply affect the examining magistrate, which it indeed did. "They dress the vagrant's body in one of Mr. Renauld's suits and leave his tattered coat and trousers by the shed's entrance, hesitant to bring them inside. Subsequently, to validate the account Madame Renauld is to provide, they drive the aeroplane dagger through his heart. That evening, Mr. Renauld will bind and silence his wife, and then, armed with a spade, will excavate a grave in that precise area where a how do you say? bunker? is to be constructed. It is crucial that the body is discovered Madame Daubreuil must harbor no suspicions. Nevertheless, if some time passes, the risks of identity being exposed will diminish significantly. Subsequently, Mr. Renauld will don the vagrant's tattered attire, and shuffle to the station, where he will depart, unnoticed, on the 12:10 train."

Poirot pondered for a moment before speaking, "The value of the diamond is significant. Greg sold it to you for far less than it is worth." He paused, deep in thought. "Hand me my almanac, Hastings," he requested. As I handed it to him, Poirot turned the pages, mumbling to himself. "Ah, the full moon is on Friday next, in three days' time. Madame, I suggest you leave the diamond with me for safekeeping until then. This romantic tale may be a deception, but we cannot be certain. Let us wait until after Friday to decide our next move."

He was a kind and fatherly man, regarding me as a naive girl facing a harsh world. Despite my efforts to prove otherwise, it seemed futile. In the end, I was left with a mere £87, 17s. 4d. to start a new life. Mr. Flemming proposed I stay with him and his wife in London, a chance I eagerly accepted. As I prepared to leave, I adjusted my appearance to fit the image of an orphan, hoping to make a good impression. Mrs. Flemming welcomed me warmly, though her husband seemed bewildered by my transformation. The day ended with plans for me to seek employment immediately. As I pondered my reflection before bed, I questioned whether my looks truly held any appeal.

He cursed the porters, he cursed the waiters at breakfast, he cursed the whole hotel management, he would doubtless have liked to curse Miss Pettigrew who hovered around with her pencil and pad, but I don’t think even Sir Eustace would have dared to curse Miss Pettigrew. She’s just like the efficient secretary in a book. I only rescued our dear giraffe just in time. I feel Sir Eustace would have liked to dash him to the ground. To return to our expedition, after Sir Eustace had backed out, Miss Pettigrew said she would remain at home in case he might want her. And at the very last minute Suzanne sent down a message to say she had a headache. So Colonel Race and I drove off alone. He is a strange man. One doesn’t notice it so much in a crowd. But, when one is alone with him, the sense of his personality seems really almost overpowering. He becomes more taciturn, and yet his silence seems to say more than speech might do. It was so that day that we drove to the Matoppos through the soft yellow brown scrub. Everything seemed strangely silent except our car which I should think was the first Ford ever made by man! The upholstery of it was torn to ribbons and, though I know nothing about engines, even I could guess that all was not as it should be in its interior. By and by the character of the country changed. Great boulders appeared, piled up into fantastic shapes. I felt suddenly that I had got into a primitive era. Just for a moment Neanderthal men seemed quite as real to me as they had to Papa. I turned to Colonel Race. “There must have been giants once,” I said dreamily. “And their children were just like children are to-day they played with handfuls of pebbles, piling them up and knocking them down, and the more cleverly they balanced them, the better pleased they were. If I were to give a name to this place I should call it ‘The Country of Giant Children.’” “Perhaps you’re nearer the mark than you know,” said Colonel Race gravely. “Simple, primitive, big that is Africa.” I nodded appreciatively. “You love it, don’t you?” I asked. “Yes. But to live in it long well, it makes one what you would call cruel. One comes to hold life and death very lightly.” “Yes,” I said, thinking of Harry Rayburn. He had been like that too. “But not cruel to weak things?” “Opinions differ as to what are and are not ‘weak things,’ Miss Anne.” There was a note of seriousness in his voice which almost startled me. I felt that I knew very little really of this man at my side. “I meant children and dogs, I think.” “I can truthfully say I’ve never been cruel to children or dogs. So you don’t class women as ‘weak things’?” I considered. “No, I don’t think I do though they are, I suppose. That is, they are nowadays. But Papa always said that in the beginning men and women roamed the world together, equal in strength like lions and tigers” “And giraffes?” interpolated Colonel Race slyly. I laughed. Every one makes fun of that giraffe. “And giraffes. They were nomadic, you see. It wasn’t till they settled down in communities, and women did one kind of thing and men another that women got weak. And of course, underneath, one is still the same one feels the same, I mean, and that is why women worship physical strength in men it’s what they once had and have lost.” “Almost ancestor worship, in fact?” “Something of the kind.” “And you really think that’s true? That women worship strength, I mean?” “I think it’s quite true if one’s honest. You think you admire moral qualities, but when you fall in love, you revert to the primitive where the physical is all that counts. But I don’t think that’s the end if you lived in primitive conditions it would be all right, but you don’t and so, in the end, the other thing wins after all. It’s the things that are apparently conquered that always do win, isn’t it? They win in the only way that counts. Like what the Bible says about losing your soul and finding it.” “In the end,” said Colonel Race thoughtfully, “you fall in love and you fall out of it, is that what you mean?” “Not exactly, but you can put it that way if you like.” “But I don’t think you’ve ever fallen out of love, Miss Anne?” “No, I haven’t,” I admitted frankly. “Or fallen in love, either?” I did not answer. The car drew up at our destination and brought the conversation to a close. We got out and began the slow ascent to the World’s View. Not for the first time, I felt a slight discomfort in Colonel Race’s company. He veiled his thoughts so well behind those impenetrable black eyes. He frightened me a little. He had always frightened me. I never knew where I stood with him. We climbed in silence till we reached the spot where Rhodes lies guarded by giant boulders. A strange eerie place, far from the haunts of men, that sings a ceaseless pæan of rugged beauty. We sat there for some time in silence. Then descended once more, but diverging slightly from the path. Sometimes it was a rough scramble and once we came to a sharp slope or rock that was almost sheer. Colonel Race went first, then turned to help me. “Better lift you,” he said suddenly, and swung me off my feet with a quick gesture. I felt the strength of him as he set me down and released his clasp. A man of iron, with muscles like taut steel. And again, I felt afraid, especially as he did not move aside, but stood directly in front of me, staring into my face. “What are you really doing here, Anne Beddingfeld?” he said abruptly. “I’m a gipsy seeing the world.” “Yes, that’s true enough. The newspaper correspondent is only a pretext. You’ve not the soul of the journalist. You’re out for your own hand snatching at life. But that’s not all.” What was he going to make me tell him? I was afraid afraid. I looked him full in the face. My eyes can’t keep secrets like his, but they can carry the war into the enemy’s country. “What are you really doing here, Colonel Race?” I asked deliberately. For a moment I thought he wasn’t going to answer. He was clearly taken aback, though. At last he spoke, and his words seemed to afford him a grim amusement. “Pursuing ambition,” he said. “Just that pursuing ambition. You will remember, Miss Beddingfeld, that ‘by that sin fell the angels,’ etc.” “They say,” I said slowly, “that you are really connected with the Government that you are in the Secret Service. Is that true?” Was it my fancy, or did he hesitate for a fraction of a second before he answered? “I can assure you, Miss Beddingfeld, that I am out here strictly as a private individual travelling for my own pleasure.” Thinking the answer over later, it struck me as slightly ambiguous. Perhaps he meant it to be so. We rejoined the car in silence. Half-way back to Bulawayo we stopped for tea at a somewhat primitive structure at the side of the road. The proprietor was digging in the garden and seemed annoyed at being disturbed. But he graciously promised to see what he could do. After an interminable wait he brought us some stale cakes and some lukewarm tea. Then he disappeared to his garden again. No sooner had he departed than we were surrounded by cats. Six of them all miaowing piteously at once. The racket was deafening. I offered them some pieces of cake. They devoured them ravenously. I poured all the milk there was into a saucer and they fought each other to get it. “Oh,” I cried indignantly, “they’re starved! It’s wicked. Please, please, order some more milk and another plate of cake.” Colonel Race departed silently to do my bidding. The cats had begun miaowing again. He returned with a big jug of milk and the cats finished it all. I got up with determination on my face. “I’m going to take those cats home with us I shan’t leave them here.” “My dear child, don’t be absurd. You can’t carry six cats as well as fifty wooden animals round with you.” “Never mind the wooden animals. These cats are alive. I shall take them back with me.” “You will do nothing of the kind.” I looked at him resentfully, but he went on: “You think me cruel but one can’t go through life sentimentalizing over these things. It’s no good standing out I shan’t allow you to take them. It’s a primitive country, you know, and I’m stronger than you.” I always know when I am beaten. I went down to the car with tears in my eyes. “They’re probably short of food just to-day,” he explained consolingly. “That man’s wife has gone into Bulawayo for stores. So it will be all right. And anyway, you know, the world’s full of starving cats.” “Don’t don’t,” I said fiercely. “I’m teaching you to realize life as it is. I’m teaching you to be hard and ruthless like I am. That’s the secret of strength and the secret of success.” “I’d sooner be dead than hard,” I said passionately. We got into the car and started off. I pulled myself together again slowly. Suddenly, to my intense astonishment, he took my hand in his. “Anne,” he said gently, “I want you. Will you marry me?” I was utterly taken aback. “Oh, no,” I stammered. “I can’t.” “Why not?” “I don’t care for you in that way. I’ve never thought of you like that.” “I see. Is that the only reason?” I had to be honest. I owed it him. “No,” I said, “it is not. You see I care for some one else.” “I see,” he said again. “And was that true at the beginning when I first saw you on the Kilmorden?” “No,” I whispered. “It was since then.” “I see,” he said for the third time, but this time there was a purposeful ring in his voice that made me turn and look at him. His face was grimmer than I had ever seen it. “What what do you mean?” I faltered. He looked at me, inscrutable, dominating. “Only that I know now what I have to do.” His words sent a shiver through me. There was a determination behind them that I did not understand and it frightened me. We neither of us said any more until we got back to the hotel. I went straight up to Suzanne. She was lying on her bed reading, and did not look in the least as though she had a headache. “Here reposes the perfect gooseberry,” she remarked. “Alias the tactful chaperone. Why, Anne dear, what’s the matter?” For I had burst into a flood of tears. I told her about the cats I felt it wasn’t fair to tell her about Colonel Race. But Suzanne is very sharp. I think she saw that there was something more behind. “You haven’t caught a chill, have you, Anne? Sounds absurd even to suggest such things in this heat, but you keep on shivering.” “It’s nothing,” I said. “Nerves or some one walking over my grave. I keep feeling something dreadful’s going to happen.” “Don’t be silly,” said Suzanne, with decision. “Let’s talk of something interesting. Anne, about those diamonds” “What about them?” “I’m not sure they’re safe with me. It was all right before, no one could think they’d be amongst my things. But now that every one knows we’re such friends, you and I, I’ll be under suspicion too.” “Nobody knows they’re in a roll of films, though,” I argued. “It’s a splendid hiding-place and I really don’t think we could better it.” She agreed doubtfully, but said we would discuss it again when we got to the Falls. Our train went at nine o’clock. Sir Eustace’s temper was still far from good, and Miss Pettigrew looked subdued. Colonel Race was completely himself. I felt that I had dreamed the whole conversation on the way back. I slept heavily that night on my hard bunk, struggling with ill-defined, menacing dreams. I awoke with a headache and went out on the observation platform of the car. It was fresh and lovely, and everywhere, as far as one could see, were the undulating wooded hills. I loved it loved it more than any place I had ever seen. I wished then that I could have a little hut somewhere in the heart of the scrub and live there always always. Just before half-past two, Colonel Race called me out from the “office” and pointed to a bouquet-shaped white mist that hovered over one portion of the bush. “The spray from the Falls,” he said. “We are nearly there.” I was still wrapped in that strange dream feeling of exaltation that had succeeded my troubled night. Very strongly implanted in me was the feeling that I had come home. Home! And yet I had never been here before or had I in dreams? We walked from the train to the hotel, a big white building closely wired against mosquitoes. There were no roads, no houses. We went out on the stoep and I uttered a gasp. There, half a mile away, facing us, were the Falls. I’ve never seen anything so grand and beautiful I never shall. “Anne, you’re fey,” said Suzanne, as we sat down to lunch. “I’ve never seen you like this before.” She stared at me curiously. “Am I?” I laughed, but I felt that my laugh was unnatural. “It’s just that I love it all.” “It’s more than that.” A little frown creased her brow one of apprehension. Yes, I was happy, but beyond that I had the curious feeling that I was waiting for something something that would happen soon. I was excited restless. After tea we strolled out, got on the trolley and were pushed by smiling blacks down the little tracks of rails to the bridge. It was a marvellous sight, the great chasm and the rushing waters below, and the veil of mist and spray in front of us that parted every now and then for one brief minute to show the cataract of water and then closed up again in its impenetrable mystery. That, to my mind, has always been the fascination of the Falls their elusive quality. You always think you’re going to see and you never do. We crossed the bridge and walked slowly on by the path that was marked out with white stone on either side and led round the brink of the gorge. Finally we arrived in a big clearing where on the left a path led downwards towards the chasm. “The palm gully,” explained Colonel Race. “Shall we go down? Or shall we leave it until to-morrow? It will take some time, and it’s a good climb up again.” “We’ll leave it until to-morrow,” said Sir Eustace with decision. He isn’t at all fond of strenuous physical exercise, I have noticed. He led the way back. As we went, we passed a fine native stalking along. Behind him came a woman who seemed to have the entire household belongings piled upon her head! The collection included a frying pan! “I never have my camera when I want it,” groaned Suzanne. “That’s an opportunity that will occur often enough, Mrs. Blair,” said Colonel Race. “So don’t lament.

His expression remained unchanged, a smirk playing on his lips. "I have my eye on those diamonds," he declared. I shook my head. "You won't be getting your hands on them," I retorted. "Oh, but I will. Let's not beat around the bush. A few bodies turning up in this part of town wouldn't raise any eyebrows. There's a guy downstairs who takes care of those messy situations. Now, let's be reasonable. Write a letter to Harry Rayburn. Tell him to come here, diamonds in tow." I stood my ground. "I refuse to comply with your demands."

"Speaking of apartments," she mentioned, "have you heard the news, Mr. Parker? We finally secured one! At Montagu Mansions." "Well," Parker responded, "I've always said there are plenty of apartments at various prices!" "Yes, but this one is different. It's incredibly cheap. Eighty pounds per year!" "But isn't Montagu Mansions right off Knightsbridge? A grand building. Or are you referring to a lesser version with the same name hidden in the slums somewhere?" "No, it's the one in Knightsbridge. That's what makes it so extraordinary." "Extraordinary indeed! It's like a miracle. But there must be a catch somewhere. Big deposit, I presume?" "No deposit!" "No dep oh, help me, somebody!" groaned Parker. "But we do need to purchase the furniture," Mrs. Robinson added. "Ah!" Parker perked up. "I knew there was a catch!" "For fifty pounds. And it's beautifully furnished!" "I surrender," said Parker. "The current occupants must be crazy with a penchant for generosity." Mrs. Robinson seemed a bit concerned. A slight frown appeared between her delicate eyebrows. "It is strange, isn't it? Do you think that perhaps the place is haunted?" "Never heard of a haunted apartment," Parker stated firmly. "N-o." Mrs. Robinson seemed far from convinced. "But there were several things about it that struck me as, well, strange." "For example," I prompted. "Ah," said Parker, "our expert in crime is intrigued! Tell him, Mrs. Robinson. Hastings is skilled at unraveling mysteries." I chuckled, embarrassed but somewhat flattered by the role assigned to me. "Oh, not truly strange, Captain Hastings, but when we went to the agents, Stosser and Paul we hadn’t tried them before because they only have the expensive Mayfair flats, but we thought at any rate it would do no harm everything they offered us was four and five hundred a year, or else huge premiums, and then, just as we were going, they mentioned that they had a flat at eighty, but that they doubted if it would be any good our going there, because it had been on their books some time and they had sent so many people to see it that it was almost sure to be taken ‘snapped up’ as the clerk put it only people were so tiresome in not letting them know, and then they went on sending, and people get annoyed at being sent to a place that had, perhaps, been let some time." Mrs. Robinson paused for some much needed breath, and then continued: "We thanked him, and said that we quite understood it would probably be no good, but that we should like an order all the same just in case. And we went there straight away in a taxi, for, after all, you never know. No. 4 was on the second floor, and just as we were waiting for the lift, Elsie Ferguson she's a friend of mine, Captain Hastings, and they are looking for a flat too came hurrying down the stairs. 'Ahead of you for once, my dear,' she said. 'But it’s no good. It’s already let.' That seemed to finish it, but well, as John said, the place was very cheap, we could afford to give more, and perhaps if we offered a premium. A horrid thing to do, of course, and I feel quite ashamed of telling you, but you know what flat-hunting is." I assured her that I was well aware that in the struggle for house-room the baser side of human nature frequently triumphed over the higher, and that the well-known rule of dog eat dog always applied. "So we went up and, would you believe it, the flat wasn’t let at all. We were shown over it by the maid, and then we saw the mistress, and the thing was settled then and there. Immediate possession and fifty pounds for the furniture. We signed the agreement next day, and we are to move in tomorrow!" Mrs. Robinson paused triumphantly. "And what about Mrs. Ferguson?" asked Parker. "Let’s have your deductions, Hastings." "'Obvious, my dear Watson,'" I quoted lightly. "She went to the wrong flat." "Oh, Captain Hastings, how clever of you!" cried Mrs. Robinson admiringly. I rather wished Poirot had been there. Sometimes I have the feeling that he rather underestimates my capabilities. The whole thing was rather amusing, and I propounded the thing as a mock problem to Poirot on the following morning. He seemed interested, and questioned me rather narrowly as to the rents of flats in various localities. "A curious story," he said thoughtfully. "Excuse me, Hastings, I must take a short stroll." When he returned, about an hour later, his eyes were gleaming with a peculiar excitement. He laid his stick on the table, and brushed the nap of his hat with his usual tender care before he spoke. "It is as well, mon ami, that we have no affairs of moment on hand. We can devote ourselves wholly to the present investigation." "What investigation are you talking about?" "The remarkable cheapness of your friend’s, Mrs. Robinson’s, new flat." "Poirot, you are not serious!" "I am most serious. Figure to yourself, my friend, that the real rent of those flats is £350. I have just ascertained that from the landlord’s agents. And yet this particular flat is being sublet at eighty pounds! Why?" "There must be something wrong with it. Perhaps it is haunted, as Mrs. Robinson suggested." Poirot shook his head in a dissatisfied manner. "Then again how curious it is that her friend tells her the flat is let, and, when she goes up, behold, it is not so at all!" "But surely you agree with me that the other woman must have gone to the wrong flat. That is the only possible solution." "You may or may not be right on that point, Hastings. The fact still remains that numerous other applicants were sent to see it, and yet, in spite of its remarkable cheapness, it was still in the market when Mrs. Robinson arrived." "That shows that there must be something wrong about it." "Mrs. Robinson did not seem to notice anything amiss. Very curious, is it not? Did she impress you as being a truthful woman, Hastings?" "She was a delightful creature!" "Évidemment! since she renders you incapable of replying to my question. Describe her to me, then." "Well, she’s tall and fair; her hair’s really a beautiful shade of auburn" "Always you have had a penchant for auburn hair!" murmured Poirot. "But continue.

"Quietly unlocking the door, he peered out cautiously and let out a loud 'Miaow' before sticking the cat's head through the opening. The Scotland Yard inspector and another man standing outside were startled by the sudden noise. 'Ah, it's just Monsieur Poirot being his usual playful self!' the inspector exclaimed as Poirot's head appeared next to the cat. 'Let us in, monsieur.' 'You have our associates safe?' 'Yes, we have them secured, but they did not have the items on them.' 'Ah, so you've come to search. Before I leave with Hastings, allow me to share some wisdom on the history and behavior of domestic cats.' 'Are you completely out of your mind?' 'The cat,' began Poirot, 'was revered by the ancient Egyptians. It is still considered lucky if a black cat crosses your path. This cat crossed yours tonight, Japp. Speaking of the insides of any living being is not polite, I know, but this cat's interior is quite unique. I'm referring to the lining.' With a sudden movement, the second man snatched the cat from Poirot's grasp. 'Oh, I forgot to introduce you,' Japp said. 'Mr. Poirot, meet Mr. Burt from the United States Secret Service.' The American quickly found what he was looking for. 'Nice to meet you,' said Mr. Burt. 'Perhaps I won't die this time,' Poirot mused optimistically, his words reflecting a hopeful outlook. As the first victim of the flu, I appreciated his positive attitude. Poirot, now recuperating in bed, sipped on a bitter herbal tea while observing a row of medicine bottles on the mantelpiece. 'Yes, soon I shall be back to my usual self, the great Hercule Poirot,' he declared. 'Imagine, mon ami, I even have a mention in Society Gossip. Here it is! 'Hercule Poirot, our beloved society detective, is temporarily out of commission due to illness.' I chuckled. 'You're becoming quite the celebrity, Poirot. You haven't missed much during your recovery.' 'That's true. I didn't regret turning down the few cases that came my way.' Our landlady interrupted, informing us of a visitor downstairs. 'Mr. Roger Havering,' I read from the card she handed me. Poirot gestured towards the bookshelf, and I retrieved 'Who's Who.' After a quick scan, Poirot identified the visitor as the second son of the fifth Baron Windsor. 'Would you like to go speak with him, Hastings?' I volunteered to hear Mr. Havering's concerns in Poirot's absence. Mr. Havering, visibly distressed, urgently requested Poirot's assistance in investigating his uncle's murder. 'I'm sorry, but Poirot is unwell with the flu,' I informed him. Disheartened, Mr. Havering explained the circumstances of the crime that had taken place in Derbyshire. An idea struck me, and I quickly consulted Poirot, who agreed to let me lead the investigation. An hour later, I found myself on a train with Mr. Havering, heading towards Hunter's Lodge in Derbyshire."

He needed to fake his death, escape to a different country with his wife, and change his identity. To make sure his wife had control of the money, he altered his will. A rough tramp intruded into their garden, leading to an unexpected opportunity for the couple. They quickly devised a plan to shift the blame onto the tramp's body, dressing it in the man's clothes and stabbing it with an aeroplane dagger. The husband would then bury the body, ensuring it was found later to divert suspicion. In the meantime, he would disguise himself as the tramp and quietly leave town. However, their carefully laid out plan faced unexpected challenges when a girl named Bella showed up at their door, threatening to unravel everything.

What cunning! He anticipated every move a detective might make, steps that I, a foolish fool, actually made. He prepares two wills, has the staff sign both, then confidently presents his will on the back of a crumpled receipt, using a pen filled with his own unique ink. Under false pretenses, he convinces the baker and his spouse to add their signatures below his, then attaches it to his desk key, smirking to himself. Should his niece uncover his deception, she will prove her worth and expensive education, earning her rightful claim to his fortune.

Papa never cared for others' opinions. He lived detached from daily life, eating without concern for payment. His celebrity brought no money, only trouble when a reporter twisted his words. I longed for romance and adventure, envying Emily's suitors. My only excitement came from daydreams and the Kinema. Yet, a discovery in Rhodesia would soon bring real adventure to my doorstep. Papa was ecstatic about the find, convinced it was the ancestral form of the Neanderthal race. We had to leave at once to explore the area for more treasures.

Baker, wiping her hands on her apron and beaming all over her face. In a few clear words Poirot set forth the purpose of his visit. “Magnificent!” he exclaimed. “May I have a look, madame?” He carefully examined the jewel before handing it back with a slight bow. “An exquisite stone, flawless. Ah, what a gem! And you carry it with you like this!” “No, Monsieur Poirot, I am very cautious. Normally, it is kept in my jewel-case, secured in the hotel safe. We are staying at the Luxurious, you know. I only brought it today for you to admire.”“You will leave it with me, won’t you? You will heed Papa Poirot’s advice?”“Well, you see, Monsieur Poirot, we are heading to Yardly Chase on Friday to visit Lord and Lady Yardly.” This triggered a distant memory. A few years back, scandal surrounded Lord and Lady Yardly during their visit to the States, particularly involving Lady Yardly and a movie star named Gregory B. Rolf.“I’ll share a secret with you, Monsieur Poirot,” Miss Marvell continued. “We are in talks with Lord Yardly about filming a play at his estate.”“At Yardly Chase?” I inquired, intrigued. “It's a renowned English landmark.”Miss Marvell confirmed and added, “He is asking for a substantial fee, so it's uncertain if the deal will go through. But Greg and I enjoy mixing business with pleasure.”“Forgive my ignorance, madame, but isn't it possible to visit Yardly Chase without the diamond?” I asked.A sharp look crossed Miss Marvell’s face, betraying her youthful appearance. “I want to wear it there.”“Indeed,” I interjected, “Yardly’s collection includes some famous jewels, including a large diamond, correct?”Miss Marvell simply responded, “That’s right.”Poirot muttered softly, “Ah, that's how it is!” Then, with his usual keen insight, he remarked, “You must be acquainted with Lady Yardly, or perhaps your husband is?”“Gregory knew her when she visited the West three years ago,” Miss Marvell revealed. She hesitated before abruptly asking, “Do you both read Society Gossip?”We admitted guiltily. “I ask because this week's issue features an article on famous jewels,” she said, taking the paper from me and reading about the Star of the East and the Star of the West.Poirot, amused, remarked, “A delightful mystery indeed.” He turned to Miss Marvell, “Are you not afraid, madame? No superstitious fears?”“I believe my diamond is superior to Lady Yardly's,” Miss Marvell asserted. “But I intend to find out.”Before Poirot could respond, Gregory Rolf entered the room, exuding charm. “I promised to pick you up, Mary,” he said. “So, what does Monsieur Poirot think of our little dilemma? Just a prank, like I believe?”Poirot, with a wry smile, advised against taking the jewel to Yardly Chase. “I've already told Mary that,” Gregory agreed. “But she's a woman, can't stand the thought of being outshone.”“What nonsense, Gregory!” Mary retorted, though she blushed. Poirot, resigned, bid them farewell. “Women's affairs! The good husband hit the nail on the head, not very tactful indeed.” I shared my suspicions with Poirot, who decided to take a stroll, leaving me to await his return.

“Do you recognize me?” Poirot grinned. “Of course. I follow the news in the papers with pictures. How could I not recognize you?” “Monsieur Poirot, I need your help with a urgent matter. I need absolute secrecy.” “You have my word,” said Poirot grandly. “It involves the Prime Minister. We are facing a serious situation.” “We’re in trouble!” interrupted Mr. Dodge. “Is the injury severe?” I inquired. “What injury?” “The gunshot wound.” “Oh, that,” scoffed Mr. Dodge. “That’s old news.” “As my colleague mentioned,” Lord Estair continued, “that incident is in the past. But unfortunately, there was a second attempt.” “There was another attempt?” “Yes, but of a different kind. Monsieur Poirot, the Prime Minister has gone missing.” “What?” “He has been kidnapped!” “Impossible!” I exclaimed, stunned. Poirot shot me a look, silently telling me to stay quiet. “Unfortunately, as impossible as it sounds, it is true,” his lordship added. Poirot turned to Mr. Dodge. “You mentioned that time was crucial. What did you mean?” The two men exchanged glances, and Lord Estair explained: “You are aware of the upcoming Allied Conference?” Poirot nodded. “For security reasons, the details of the Conference have not been disclosed. But the date is widely known in diplomatic circles. The Conference is scheduled for tomorrow evening in Versailles. Now you understand the gravity of the situation. The Prime Minister’s presence is essential. The Pacifist propaganda has been strong, and the Prime Minister's role is crucial. His absence could lead to disastrous consequences. We have no one else who can represent England.” Poirot’s expression turned serious. “So you believe the kidnapping is an attempt to prevent his attendance at the Conference?” “That is my belief. He was on his way to France at the time.” “And the Conference is still happening?” “Tomorrow night at nine o’clock.” Poirot checked his watch. “It’s a quarter to nine now.” “Twenty-four hours,” mused Mr. Dodge. “And a quarter,” corrected Poirot. “Let’s not forget the quarter, it may be important. Now, about the abduction, did it happen in England or France?” “In France. Mr. MacAdam arrived in France this morning. He was supposed to stay with the Commander-in-Chief, then head to Paris tomorrow. He was escorted across the Channel by a destroyer. In Boulogne, he was met by a car from General Headquarters and the Commander-in-Chief’s A.D.C.” “And then?” “They left Boulogne but never reached their destination.” “What happened?” “The car and the A.D.C. were found gagged and bound in a side road. The bogus car is still missing.” Poirot looked frustrated. “Unbelievable! How could it go unnoticed?” “That area is under Military Law. We expected it to be found quickly, but so far, nothing. French police and Scotland Yard are searching. It’s incredible, but true.” At that moment, a young officer entered with a sealed envelope for Lord Estair. After reading it, Lord Estair announced that the second car and the secretary had been found. They were chloroformed, bound and left in an abandoned farm. “No sign of the Prime Minister’s body?” “No.” “Then there’s hope. But why go through the trouble of keeping him alive after the failed assassination this morning?” Dodge shook his head. “The goal is to prevent him from attending the Conference at all costs.” “If there’s a chance, the Prime Minister will be there. I hope it’s not too late. Now, tell me everything from the beginning. I need to know about the shooting incident as well.”

He's like the rest of them, spouting inflammatory speeches for political gain only to backtrack later. I encountered him as he was heading to Cape Town to defend himself in a lengthy Dutch speech. The endless droning in the South African Legislative Assembly made me grateful for the brevity of the House of Commons. But trouble was brewing, with arms and explosives flowing in under the guise of vegetables. The mastermind behind it all was rumored to be in Johannesburg. Despite warnings and offers of safe passage, I refused to be whisked away to Pretoria. Instead, I received a surprising telegram confirming Anne's safety in Kimberley. Her resilience never ceases to amaze me.

They were a striking pair, the tall, dark young man and the blonde beauty standing together. Despite the dark cloud of tragedy hanging over them, they exuded happiness. The girl appeared uneasy, a fact not lost on Jack Renauld, who pulled her in closer and inquired, "What troubles you, my love? What haunts you now?" As she gazed back with the same fearful expression Poirot had mentioned, she whispered softly, almost revealing her thoughts, "I fear for your safety."

I've been in this business a long time, and I've learned to trust my instincts. You have to be one step ahead of the game, always ready for the unexpected. The key is to keep your eyes open and your mind sharp, never letting your guard down. That's how you stay alive in this world of shadows and secrets. The truth is, you never know who's watching, who's waiting to strike. That's why you have to be ready for anything, even when it comes from the most unlikely sources. It's a dangerous game we play, but it's the only one I know how to win.

I will search every corner of the city until I find him, and once I do, I will make him mine. I would do anything for him. After the show, in her dressing room filled with bouquets and luxurious garments, she received a surprise visitor - Count Sergius Paulovitch. A sense of intrigue filled the room as they conversed in English, revealing a shared history of espionage and suspicion. The Count mentioned the retirement of the elusive 'Colonel,' a criminal mastermind who had always managed to evade capture. Nadina, however, had a plan of her own. She declared her intention to travel to London incognito, leaving behind a trail of mystery and anticipation.

"He showed up today after being called by your husband." With that, he removed the letter penned by M. Renauld from his coat pocket and passed it to the woman. “Then, in triumph shall they return to the god.’ It is a curious coincidence that there is at the present time a stone corresponding closely in description with this one, and known as ‘the Star of the West,’ or ‘the Western Star.’ It is the property of the celebrated film actress, Miss Mary Marvell. A comparison of the two stones would be interesting.” She stopped. “Épatant!” murmured Poirot. “Without doubt a romance of the first water.” He turned to Mary Marvell. “And you are not afraid, madame? You have no superstitious terrors? You do not fear to introduce these two Siamese twins to each other lest a Chinaman should appear and, hey presto! whisk them both back to China?” His tone was mocking, but I fancied that an undercurrent of seriousness lay beneath it. “I don’t believe that Lady Yardly’s diamond is anything like as good a stone as mine,” said Miss Marvell. “Anyway, I’m going to see.” What more Poirot would have said I do not know, for at that moment the door flew open, and a splendid-looking man strode into the room. From his crisply curling black head, to the tips of his patent-leather boots, he was a hero fit for romance. “I said I’d call round for you, Mary,” said Gregory Rolf, “and here I am. Well, what does Monsieur Poirot say to our little problem? Just one big hoax, same as I do?” Poirot smiled up at the big actor. They made a ridiculous contrast. “Hoax or no hoax, Mr. Rolf,” he said dryly, “I have advised Madame your wife not to take the jewel with her to Yardly Chase on Friday.” “I’m with you there, sir. I’ve already said so to Mary. But there! She’s a woman through and through, and I guess she can’t bear to think of another woman outshining her in the jewel line.” “What nonsense, Gregory!” said Mary Marvell sharply. But she flushed angrily. Poirot shrugged his shoulders. “Madame, I have advised. I can do no more. C’est fini.” He bowed them both to the door. “Ah! la la,” he observed, returning. “Histoire de femmes! The good husband, he hit the nail on the head tout de même, he was not tactful! Assuredly not.” I imparted to him my vague remembrances, and he nodded vigorously. “So I thought. All the same, there is something curious underneath all this. With your permission, mon ami, I will take the air. Await my return, I beg of you. I shall not be long.” I was half asleep in my chair when the landlady tapped on the door, and put her head in. “It’s another lady to see Mr. Poirot, sir. I’ve told her he was out, but she says as how she’ll wait, seeing as she’s come up from the country.” “Oh, show her in here, Mrs. Murchison. Perhaps I can do something for her.” In another moment the lady had been ushered in. My heart gave a leap as I recognized her. Lady Yardly’s portrait had figured too often in the Society papers to allow her to remain unknown. “Do sit down, Lady Yardly,” I said, drawing forward a chair.

"Always I made sure of it myself." "And last evening?" "I secured it just like always." "You are certain of that?" "I vow it by the saints, sir." "What time was that?"
