Monsieur was still in his study." "So, if anyone unlocked the door later, it must have been M. Renauld himself?" Françoise simply shrugged.

"Apologies, Hastings, I need a brief walk." Upon his return, after roughly an hour, his eyes sparkled with an unusual excitement. He placed his cane on the table, meticulously tending to his hat's nap before speaking. "Luckily, my friend, we have no pressing matters. Let us focus entirely on this current inquiry." "And what inquiry might that be?" "The astonishing affordability of Mrs. Robinson's recent apartment." "Poirot, you can't be serious!" "Oh, but I am deadly serious."

As we were still reeling from the doctor's bombshell, a telegram arrived at the Villa. It was a message from Poirot, informing me of his imminent return on the 12:28 train to Merlinville. With a quick glance at my watch, I realized I had just enough time to reach the station and greet him. It was crucial that Poirot be briefed on the latest shocking turn of events in the investigation. Clearly, he had wasted no time in obtaining the information he sought in Paris.

Harry Rayburn sat quietly between the rough wooden walls of the small room, his presence casting a shadow over the scene. Anne, still weak and bruised, looked up at him with tears streaming down her face. She longed to hold on to this moment, to die with his hand in hers. Rayburn's eyes held a new tenderness as he offered her a cup of milk, speaking softly and reassuringly. Despite the pain and confusion, Anne found solace in his presence, feeling safe and protected for the first time since the nightmare began. She clung to him, desperate for his comfort and the hope he brought with him. Rayburn stayed by her side, a silent guardian in the darkness of the room, promising to keep her safe from harm.

“After the disastrous turn of events, wouldn’t it be best to make a swift exit?” “But what about the exquisite dinner Lord Yardly’s chef has prepared?” “Forget the dinner,” I snapped. Poirot looked scandalized. “Mon Dieu! You Brits take food too lightly.” “There’s another pressing matter that requires our attention,” I pressed on. “And what might that be?” “The second diamond,” I whispered. “Miss Marvell’s.” “Well, what about it?” “Can’t you see?” His lack of understanding frustrated me.

I must anticipate the little army that will soon be starting. We need to be proactive. Will you be contacting Cook's today, Anne?" "What about finances, father?" I delicately suggested. He gave me a reproachful look. "Your perspective always brings me down, my dear. We must not be materialistic. No, no, in the pursuit of knowledge, one must not be materialistic." "I fear that Cook's may be materialistic, father." Father looked pained. "My dear Anne, you will settle with them in cash." "I don't have any cash on hand." Father looked thoroughly exasperated. "My dear, I really cannot be bothered with these base financial details. The bank tells me I have twenty-seven pounds." "That's your overdraft, I believe." "Ah, I remember now! Write to my publishers." I reluctantly agreed, aware that Father's books brought more prestige than wealth. The thought of traveling to Rhodesia excited me greatly. "Strong, silent men," I whispered to myself in delight. But then something about my father's appearance struck me as odd. "You're wearing mismatched boots, father," I pointed out. "Take off the brown one and put on the other black one. And don't forget your scarf. It's quite cold out." In a few minutes, Father left, properly booted and well wrapped in a scarf. He returned late that evening, and, to my horror, I noticed his scarf and coat were missing. "Oh dear, Anne, you were right. I took them off to enter the cave. One gets quite dirty in there." I nodded sympathetically, recalling a time when Father had come home covered in Pleistocene clay from head to toe. Our main reason for settling in Little Hampsly had been the proximity of Hampsly Cavern, an underground cave rich in Aurignacian culture artifacts. We had a small museum in the village, and the curator and Father spent most of their days excavating underground and uncovering remains of woolly rhinoceroses and cave bears. Father had a bad cough that evening, and the next morning I noticed he had a fever, so I called for the doctor. Poor Father, he never stood a chance. It was double pneumonia. He passed away four days later. Everyone was very kind to me. In my daze, I was grateful for that. I did not feel overwhelming grief. Father had never loved me, I knew that all too well. If he had, perhaps I could have loved him in return. No, love had not existed between us, but we belonged together, and I had cared for him, secretly admiring his knowledge and unwavering dedication to science. It pained me that Father had passed away just when life's excitement was at its peak for him. I would have been happier burying him in a cave, adorned with paintings of reindeer and flint tools, but public opinion dictated a neat grave (with a marble slab) in the unattractive local churchyard. The vicar's attempts at solace, though well-intentioned, did not bring me comfort in the slightest. It took some time for me to realize that the freedom I had always longed for was now mine. I was an orphan, practically penniless, but free. At the same time, I recognized the remarkable kindness of these good people. The vicar tried his best to convince me that his wife needed urgent help as a companion. Our small local library suddenly decided to hire an assistant librarian. Finally, the doctor paid me a visit, and after making various absurd excuses for not sending a proper bill, he hesitated and then proposed marriage to me. I was quite surprised. The doctor was closer to forty than thirty, and a round, plump man. He bore no resemblance to the hero of "The Perils of Pamela," and even less to a stern, silent Rhodesian. After pondering for a moment, I asked him why he wanted to marry me. He seemed flustered, mumbling that a wife was a great asset to a General Practitioner. The situation seemed even less romantic now, yet something within me leaned towards accepting it. Safety, that was what was being offered. Safety and a Comfortable Home. Looking back now, I believe I misjudged the little man. He genuinely loved me, but a misguided sense of propriety kept him from pursuing me more forcefully. Regardless, my romantic inclinations rebelled. "Your offer is very kind," I said. "But it's not possible. I could never marry a man unless I was absolutely in love with him." "You don't think?" "No, I don't," I asserted firmly. He sighed. "But, my dear, what are your plans?" "I plan to have adventures and explore the world," I declared, without hesitation. "Miss Anne, you're still very much a child. You don't understand." "The practical challenges? Yes, I do, doctor. I'm not a sentimental schoolgirl, I'm a practical, mercenary shrew! If you married me, you'd know it!" "I wish you would reconsider." "I can't." He sighed again. "I have another suggestion. An aunt of mine in Wales is in need of a young lady to assist her. How does that sound?" "No, doctor, I'm heading to London. If anything happens anywhere, it's in London. I'll keep my eyes open, and mark my words, something will come up! You'll hear about me next in China or Timbuctoo." My next visitor was Mr. Flemming, Father's solicitor from London. He made a special trip to see me. An avid anthropologist himself, he greatly admired Father's work. He was a tall, thin man with gray hair and a gaunt face. As I entered the room, he rose to greet me, taking both my hands in his and patting them affectionately. "My poor child," he said. "My poor, poor child." Without intending to deceive, I found myself adopting the role of a grieving orphan. He somehow compelled me to do so.

I would much rather have Irish blue eyes than dark green ones with yellow specks! However, green is a suitable color for daring women. I wrapped a black garment tightly around me, leaving my arms and shoulders exposed. I then pushed my hair back and pulled it down over my ears once more. I applied a generous amount of powder to my face, making my skin appear even paler than usual. I searched until I found some old lip balm, applying a lot of it to my lips. Next, I darkened under my eyes with burnt coal. Finally, I draped a red ribbon over my exposed shoulder, placed a scarlet feather in my hair, and placed a cigarette in one corner of my mouth. I was quite pleased with the overall effect. "Anna the Adventuress," I exclaimed, nodding at my reflection. "Anna the Adventuress. Episode I, 'The House in Kensington'!" Women are foolish creatures. Over the following weeks, I was quite bored. Mrs. Flemming and her friends seemed incredibly uninteresting to me. They chatted about themselves and their children for hours, as well as the challenges of obtaining good milk for their children and how they dealt with the Dairy when the milk was subpar. Then they moved on to discussing servants and the struggles of finding good ones, along with their experiences with the woman at the Registry Office. They appeared to have no interest in reading the news or being aware of current events. They disliked traveling because everything was so different from England. The Riviera was acceptable, of course, because they could see all of their friends there. I listened, barely containing my impatience. Most of these women were wealthy. They had the entire beautiful world at their disposal, yet they chose to stay in dreary, dirty London and talk about milkmen and servants! Looking back now, I realize that I may have been somewhat intolerant. However, they were foolish, so foolish that they couldn't even keep their housekeeping accounts in order. My situation did not improve much. The house and furniture had been sold, and the proceeds barely covered our debts. I had yet to secure a job. Not that I truly desired one! I firmly believed that if I sought adventure, it would come to me. I have always believed that one gets what one desires. My theory was about to be put to the test. It was early January, the 8th to be precise. I was returning from an unsuccessful meeting with a lady who claimed to be seeking a secretary-companion, but in reality needed a strong cleaning lady who would work twelve hours a day for £25 a year. After exchanging veiled insults, I walked along Edgware Road (the meeting had taken place in a house in St. John's Wood) and through Hyde Park to St. George's Hospital. From there, I entered Hyde Park Corner Tube Station and purchased a ticket to Gloucester Road. Once on the platform, I walked to the very end. My curious nature wanted to confirm whether there were indeed points and an opening between the two tunnels just past the station in the direction of Down Street. I was foolishly pleased to discover that I was correct. There were not many people on the platform, and at the far end there was only myself and one man. As I passed him, I caught a whiff of mothballs. If there is one scent I cannot stand, it is that of mothballs! This man's heavy coat was saturated with the smell. Yet most men began wearing their winter coats before January, so by now the odor should have dissipated. The man was standing near the edge of the tunnel, lost in thought. I was able to observe him without being impolite. He was a small, thin man, with a very tanned face, light blue eyes, and a small dark beard. "Recently returned from abroad," I deduced. "That explains the smell of his coat. He must have come from India. Not an officer, or he wouldn't have a beard. Perhaps a tea planter." At that moment, the man turned as if to walk back along the platform. His gaze shifted from me to something behind me, and his expression changed. Fear contorted his face, almost in a panic. He took a step back, as if recoiling from some unseen danger, forgetting that he was standing at the very edge of the platform, and he fell over and onto the tracks. There was a bright flash from the rails and a crackling noise. I screamed. People rushed over. Two station employees appeared out of nowhere and took charge. I stood frozen in place, horrified by the sudden tragedy, yet also dispassionately fascinated by the process of lifting the man off the electrified rail and back onto the platform. "Let me through, please. I am a doctor." A tall man with a brown beard pushed past me and bent over the motionless body. As he examined the man, a strange feeling of unreality washed over me. It couldn't be real. Finally, the doctor stood up and shook his head. "Dead as a doornail. There's nothing more to be done." We all moved closer, and a disgruntled porter raised his voice. "Step back, will you? There's no sense in crowding around." A wave of nausea hit me, and I turned and ran blindly up the stairs toward the elevator. It was too awful. I needed to get outside. The doctor who had examined the man was ahead of me. The elevator was about to ascend, after having descended, and he began to run. In his haste, he dropped a piece of paper. I stopped, picked it up, and ran after him. However, the elevator doors closed in my face, leaving me with the paper in hand. By the time the second elevator reached the street level, the doctor was nowhere to be seen.

“Mon ami! Vive l’amour! It can perform miracles. It is decidedly ingenious what you have thought of there. I retired to rest that night on a note of triumph, but I awoke to realize that I was by no means out of the wood. True, I could see no flaw in the alibi I had so suddenly conceived. I had but to stick to my story, and I failed to see how Bella could be convicted in face of it. It was not as though there was any old friendship between us that could be raked up, and which might lead them to suspect that I was committing perjury. It could be proved that in actual fact I had only seen the girl on three occasions. No, I was still satisfied with my idea had not even Poirot admitted that it defeated him? But there I felt the need of treading warily. All very well for my little friend to admit himself momentarily nonplussed. I had far too much respect for his abilities to conceive of him as being content to remain in that position. I had a very humble opinion of my wits when it came to matching them against his. Poirot would not take defeat lying down. Somehow or other, he would endeavour to turn the tables on me, and that in the way, and at the moment, when I least expected it. We met at breakfast the following morning as though nothing had happened. Poirot’s good temper was imperturbable, yet I thought I detected a film of reserve in his manner which was new. After breakfast, I announced my intention of going out for a stroll. A malicious gleam shot through Poirot’s eyes. “If it is information you seek, you need not be at the pains of deranging yourself. I can tell you all you wish to know. The Dulcibella Sisters have cancelled their contract, and have left Coventry for an unknown destination.” “Is that really so, Poirot?” “You can take it from me, Hastings. I made inquiries the first thing this morning. After all, what else did you expect?” True enough, nothing else could be expected under the circumstances. Cinderella had profited by the slight start I had been able to assure her, and would certainly not lose a moment in removing herself from the reach of the pursuer. It was what I had intended and planned. Nevertheless, I was aware of being plunged into a network of fresh difficulties. I had absolutely no means of communicating with the girl, and it was vital that she should know the line of defence that had occurred to me, and which I was prepared to carry out. Of course it was possible that she might try to send word to me in some way or another, but I hardly thought it likely. She would know the risk she ran of a message being intercepted by Poirot, thus setting him on her track once more. Clearly her only course was to disappear utterly for the time being. But, in the meantime, what was Poirot doing? I studied him attentively.

I now understood. They were like Cinderella, young but fixated on morbid excitement, seeking sensation without regard for decency or good feeling. Despite being drawn to the girl's beauty, I couldn't shake my initial disapproval. Thoughts of my deceased mother surfaced. What would she think of this modern twist on girlhood? A pretty face masked with paint and powder, concealing a ghoulish mind. "Get off your high horse," the lady interjected abruptly. "Stop pretending. When you were called to this job, did you act all snooty, saying it was distasteful and you wanted no part in it?" "No, but..." "If you were here on vacation, wouldn't you be just as curious as I am? I did have some anxiety about the examining magistrate's reaction, but reassured myself that no harm would come of it. We headed first to where the body was found. A guard saluted me, recognizing me, and didn't question my companion. I explained the discovery to Cinderella, who listened attentively and asked intelligent questions. Then we made our way to the Villa. Proceeding cautiously, I led the girl through the shrubbery to the back of the house where the small shed stood. Remembering that M. Bex had left the key with Marchaud the previous evening, I assumed the detective had returned it to him. Leaving the girl hidden in the shrubbery, I entered the house. Marchaud was stationed outside the salon. "Do you need Hautet, monsieur? He's inside interrogating Françoise again." "No," I replied quickly, "I don't need him. But I would like the key to the shed if possible." "Certainly, monsieur." He handed it over. "Return it when you're done out there." "Of course." I felt a sense of satisfaction knowing that, at least in Marchaud's eyes, I was on par with Poirot. The girl was waiting, delighted to see the key in my possession. "You got it?" she asked eagerly. "Yes," I replied calmly. "What I'm doing is quite irregular, you know." "You've been wonderful. Let's go. They can't see us from the house, right?" "Wait." I stopped her. "It's going to be unpleasant and gruesome. Are you sure you want to go in?" She looked at me with an inscrutable expression, then laughed. "I'm up for it," she declared. "Let's go." Quietly, we reached the shed's door. I opened it, revealing the body. As I pulled down the sheet, a gasp escaped the girl. I turned to see horror on her face, her high spirits extinguished. She had ignored my advice and was now facing the consequences. I felt a coldness towards her. She needed to see this through. Gently, I turned the corpse over. "He was stabbed in the back," I informed her. Her voice barely audible, she asked, "With what?" I gestured towards the glass jar. "That dagger." The girl suddenly staggered and collapsed. Rushing to her aid, I realized she was faint. "Let's get out of here. It's too much for you." "Water," she whispered. "Quick. Water..." I left momentarily to fetch water and a bit of brandy. When I returned, the girl had revived. "Take me away from here, quickly!" she pleaded, trembling. Supporting her, I led her outside, closing the shed door behind us. She breathed a sigh of relief. "That's better. It was awful! Why did you let me go in?" I couldn't help but smile at her feminine reaction.

The purpose of this question completely eluded me, as I knew it to be meaningless in Poirot's eyes. Madame Daubreuil responded calmly: "Not that I am aware of." "He did not meet with Mrs. Renauld?" There will be time for that later." We reunited with Cinderella and hurried towards the Villa Geneviève. Poirot glanced back at the illuminated window and Marthe's profile as she focused on her task. Upon reaching the Villa Geneviève, Poirot positioned himself behind some bushes to the left of the driveway, allowing us a good view while remaining hidden. The Villa was engulfed in darkness, everyone likely fast asleep. We found ourselves directly beneath the open window of Mrs. Renauld's bedroom, upon which Poirot's gaze seemed fixed. "What is our plan?" I whispered. "We wait." "But-" "I do not anticipate any activity for at least an hour, perhaps two, but-" Our conversation was cut short by a prolonged, piercing cry: "Help!" A light flickered to life in a room on the second floor to the right of the house. The cry had originated from there. As we watched, a shadow appeared on the window blind, hinting at a struggle between two individuals. "Mille tonnerres!" exclaimed Poirot. "She must have changed rooms!" With determination, he rushed to the front door, pounding on it frantically. Then, without hesitation, he climbed a nearby tree with feline agility. I followed suit, and as he leaped through the open window, I saw Dulcie reaching the branch behind me. "Be careful," I warned. "Mind your grandmother!" the girl retorted. "This is nothing to me." Poirot dashed through the empty room and began pounding on the door leading to the corridor. "Locked and bolted from the outside," he growled. "It will take time to force it open." The cries for help were growing fainter. Desperation clouded Poirot's eyes. Together, we pushed against the door. Cinderella's composed voice drifted in from the window: "You are running out of time. I believe I am the only one who can help." Before I could react, she seemed to leap into the air. Alarmed, I peered out and saw her hanging from the roof, inching toward the lighted window. "Heaven help us! She will fall," I exclaimed. "Do not forget, Hastings, she is an acrobat by trade. It was a stroke of luck that she insisted on accompanying us tonight. I only pray she arrives in time. Ah!" A cry of sheer terror pierced the night as Cinderella vanished through the right-hand window; then, in her clear voice came the words: "No, you will not escape! I have a firm grip, my wrists are like steel." Simultaneously, the door to our confinement was cautiously opened by Françoise. Poirot pushed past her and sprinted down the corridor where the other maids were gathered around another door. "It is locked from the inside, monsieur." A heavy thud resonated from within. After a brief pause, the key turned, and the door creaked open. Cinderella, visibly shaken, motioned for us to enter. "Is she safe?" Poirot demanded. "Yes, I arrived just in time. She was exhausted." Mrs. Renauld was sprawled on the bed, struggling to breathe. "Nearly strangled me," she whispered hoarsely. The girl picked up an object from the floor and handed it to Poirot. It was a coiled silk rope ladder, delicate yet sturdy. "An escape plan," Poirot deduced. "Through the window, while we were trying to break down the door. But where is the other one?" The girl gestured towards a figure shrouded in dark fabric on the ground, its face obscured. "Dead?" I gasped. "I believe so," she nodded. "Their head likely struck the marble fender." "But who is it?" I inquired. "The killer of M. Renauld, Hastings. And the attempted murderer of Madame Renauld." My recollections of the subsequent events of that fateful night are a blur. Poirot seemed unresponsive to my inquiries, instead focusing on reprimanding Françoise for failing to inform him of Mrs. Renauld's room change. I grabbed his shoulder, determined to capture his attention and make myself heard. "But you must have known," I protested. "You were escorted to see her this afternoon." Poirot spared me a momentary glance. "She had been wheeled into the central room- her boudoir," he clarified. "But, monsieur," Françoise interjected, "Madame relocated almost immediately following the incident! The memories were too painful!" "Then why was I not informed," Poirot bellowed, striking the table and working himself into a rage. "Explain to me why I was kept in the dark! You are a senile old woman! If not for this brave child-" He paused, crossing the room to where the girl was tending to Mrs. Renauld, embracing her with fervor, much to my chagrin.

He is unlikely to be of any help to them now, as he will be closely monitored until the situation with the Prime Minister is resolved. It's possible that he intended to mislead the police? However, he claims that something was placed over his nose and mouth, and he recalls nothing beyond that. This does not lead the investigation astray; it sounds remarkably truthful. Let's head to the station. France may reveal more clues. Although I have my doubts. It's astonishing that the Prime Minister hasn't been found in such a confined area. If the military and police of two nations haven't located him, how can I?

I was surprised to find that she really was fond of me. I thought I had been just a new sensation, but she positively fell on my neck and wept when we met. After recovering from our emotions, I sat down on the bed and told her the whole story from A to Z. “You always did suspect Colonel Race,” she said thoughtfully. “I didn’t until the night you disappeared. I liked him so much all along and thought he would make such a nice husband for you."

I couldn't believe the affection she showed towards me, it caught me off guard. She embraced me tightly, tears streaming down her face. After collecting ourselves, I sat down and recounted everything that had happened. "You always had your suspicions about Colonel Race," she mused. "I only started to doubt him the night you vanished. I actually thought he would be a suitable match for you. But how can you be certain that this young man is being truthful? You seem to believe every word he says." "I trust him completely," I responded defensively. "But what is it about him that captivates you? I fail to see any outstanding qualities, apart from his daring appearance and unconventional ways." I spent a few moments criticizing Suzanne, expressing my frustrations. "You've become so content in your marriage that you've forgotten about romance," I concluded. "I am not content in my marriage, Anne. The worry about you has taken a toll on me," Suzanne said sadly. "You appear to be in good health," I replied coolly. "You seem to have put on some weight." "And I'm not so sure about being happily married," Suzanne added in a despondent tone. She shared her troubles with her husband, Clarence, who was demanding her immediate return. After a while, she stopped responding to his messages, and now it had been two weeks since she heard from him. I didn't take Suzanne's marital issues seriously, as I was confident she could handle Clarence when the time came. The conversation shifted to the diamonds, and Suzanne explained her concerns. She had sent the large diamonds to Cape Town, under the care of Pagett, who would be joining Sir Eustace in Johannesburg. As for the smaller ones, Suzanne assumed Sir Eustace had them with him. I suggested we wait before taking any action. Suzanne smiled, noting my dislike for inactivity. I decided to check the train schedule to see when Pagett's train would pass through Kimberley. It was a crucial moment to meet with him, given the escalating situation in the Rand. The day was brightened by a telegram from Johannesburg, informing us of their safe arrival. Nothing could be done until I spoke to Pagett. Suzanne busied herself by sending a comforting message to Clarence. She expressed her longing for him, showing a side of affection that differed from mine and Harry's. "I wish Clarence was here," she sobbed. "It's been so long since I've seen him." "Here, have some face cream," I offered. Suzanne applied it delicately, mentioning her desire for more from Paris. She dreamt of Paris and longed for a nice hat. Suzanne asked to accompany me to meet Pagett, but I preferred to go alone. As a result, I stood at the hotel entrance the next afternoon, struggling with a stubborn parasol, while Suzanne relaxed in her room with a book and some fruit. The train arrived slightly late, with everyone bustling about on the platform. I spotted Pagett easily and approached him. He seemed startled to see me, but I wasted no time in asking him about his whereabouts on a particular date.

“Just a bluff. No clue where she’s hiding.” “She sounded pretty sure.” “Probably. I’ve checked it out, we’re in the clear. And it’s the ‘Colonel’s’ call. You wouldn’t want to disobey, right?” The Dutchman muttered something in his native tongue. I assumed it was a quick denial. “Why not just get rid of her?” he snarled. “Easy enough. The boat is ready. We could take her out to sea?” “Agreed,” Chichester pondered. “That’s the way to go. She’s a liability, no doubt about it.

Descending the stairway, with Léonie's support, Mrs. Renauld appeared, her head bandaged. The French girl was in tears, begging her mistress to go back to bed. “Madame, you will harm yourself. This goes against the doctor’s orders!” Despite the pleas, Mrs. Renauld continued. “Jack, my son,” called out Jack, moving towards her. But she pushed him away. “You are not my son! I disown you!” “Mother,” Jack said, shocked. She hesitated for a moment, touched by his pain. Poirot intervened, but she quickly regained her composure. “You bear responsibility for your father's death. Leave my house. Tomorrow, I will ensure you never inherit his fortune. Make your own way in the world with the daughter of your father's enemy.” With a slow and painful effort, she made her way back upstairs, leaving us all speechless. Jack, exhausted, almost collapsed. Poirot and I rushed to help him. “He is exhausted,” Poirot told Marthe. “Where should we take him?” “To our home, Villa Marguerite. We will care for him,” Marthe replied. We brought Jack to the Villa, where he sat down, looking dazed. Poirot checked his condition. “He has a fever. The strain is taking its toll. Let's get him to bed, and we will call a doctor,” Poirot decided. A doctor was summoned and diagnosed Jack with nerve strain. Rest was prescribed, with the warning that excitement could lead to brain fever. Marthe and her mother volunteered to stay up with him. After doing all we could, we left Jack in their care and headed to town, hungry and tired. Our meal at a nearby restaurant satisfied our hunger, and we secured rooms at Hôtel des Bains for the night. Poirot surprised me by inquiring about an English lady, Miss Robinson, who had arrived. “Yes, she is in the lounge,” we were told. Poirot hinted at a marriage arrangement for me with Miss Robinson, as we entered the room. It was Cinderella who greeted us. She handed Poirot an object wrapped in paper that I recognized as the aeroplane dagger she had thrown into the sea. “Well done, my child,” Poirot praised her. He instructed her to rest, while he and I had work to do. Poirot informed her that she would see me the next day. Despite objections, Cinderella insisted on joining us on our next venture. Twenty minutes later, we set off into the dark night, heading towards Villa Geneviève. As we passed Villa Marguerite, Poirot decided to check on Jack Renauld. Madame Daubreuil welcomed us and led us to Jack's room, where he was sleeping restlessly. Madame Daubreuil assured us that he was resting, and she had given him a herbal tea. As we left, I observed Marthe Daubreuil embroidering near a window. We left the house, intrigued by the mysterious circumstances surrounding Madame Daubreuil.

“Shall we check in at our usual spot, the Hôtel des Bains?” Without hesitation, we headed over. The staff informed us that they had two available rooms with a view of the sea. Poirot then inquired about the arrival of an English lady named Miss Robinson. Turns out, she was in the small sitting room. As we walked down the corridor, I couldn't help but ask Poirot about Miss Robinson. His response? "I have found you a wife, Hastings." Shocked, I protested, but Poirot dismissed my concerns and ushered me into the room. And there she was, Cinderella herself, waiting to greet us.

"But what about the crime passionnel? Can you rule that out? If Madame Daubreuil was Renauld’s mistress, if she found that his affection was cooling, or if her jealousy was aroused in any way, might she not have struck him down in a moment of anger?” Poirot shook his head. “If I say if, you note Madame Daubreuil was Renauld’s mistress, he had not had time to tire of her. And in any case you mistake her character. She is a woman who can simulate great emotional stress. She is a magnificent actress. But, looked at dispassionately, her life disproves her appearance. Throughout, if we examine it, she had been cold-blooded and calculating in her motives and actions. It was not to link her life with that of her young lover that she connived at her husband’s murder. The rich American, for whom she probably did not care a button, was her objective. If she committed a crime, she would always do so for gain. Here there was no gain. Besides, how do you account for the digging of the grave? That was a man’s work.” “She might have had an accomplice,” I suggested, unwilling to relinquish my belief. “I pass to another objection. You have spoken of the similarity between the two crimes. Wherein does that lie, my friend?” I stared at him in astonishment. “Why, Poirot, it was you who remarked on that! The story of the masked men, the ‘secret,’ the papers!” Poirot smiled a little. “Do not be so indignant, I beg of you. I repudiate nothing. The similarity of the two stories links the two cases together inevitably. But reflect now on something very curious. It is not Madame Daubreuil who tells us this tale if it were all would indeed be plain sailing it is Madame Renauld. Is she then in league with the other?” “I can’t believe that,” I said slowly. “If it is so, she must be the most consummate actress the world has ever known.” “Ta-ta-ta,” said Poirot impatiently. “Again you have the sentiment, and not the logic! If it is necessary for a criminal to be a consummate actress, then by all means assume her to be one. But is it necessary? I do not believe Madame Renauld to be in league with Madame Daubreuil for several reasons, some of which I have already enumerated to you. The others are self-evident. Therefore, that possibility eliminated, we draw very near to the truth which is, as always, very curious and interesting.” “Poirot,” I cried, “what more do you know?” “Mon ami, you must make your own deductions. You have ‘access to the facts!’ Concentrate your grey cells. Reason not like Giraud but like Hercule Poirot.” “But are you sure?” “My friend, in many ways I have been an imbecile. But at last I see clearly.” “You know everything?” “I have discovered what M. Renauld sent for me to discover.” “And you know the murderer?” “I know one murderer.” “What do you mean?” “We talk a little at cross-purposes. There are here not one crime, but two. The first I have solved, the second eh bien, I will confess, I am not sure!” “But, Poirot, I thought you said the man in the shed had died a natural death?” “Ta-ta-ta.” Poirot made his favourite ejaculation of impatience. “Still you do not understand. One may have a crime without a murderer, but for two crimes it is essential to have two bodies.” His remark struck me as so peculiarly lacking in lucidity that I looked at him in some anxiety. But he appeared perfectly normal. Suddenly he rose and strolled to the window. “Here he is,” he observed. “Who?” “M. Jack Renauld. I sent a note up to the Villa to ask him to come here.” That changed the course of my ideas, and I asked Poirot if he knew that Jack Renauld had been in Merlinville on the night of the crime. I had hoped to catch my astute little friend napping, but as usual, he was omniscient. He, too, had inquired at the station. “And without doubt we are not original in the idea, Hastings. The excellent Giraud, he also has probably made his inquiries.” “You don’t think ” I said, and then stopped. “Ah, no, it would be too horrible!” Poirot looked inquiringly at me, but I said no more. It had just occurred to me that though there were seven women directly or indirectly connected with the case Mrs. Renauld, Madame Daubreuil and her daughter, the mysterious visitor, and the three servants there was, with the exception of old Auguste who could hardly count, only one man Jack Renauld. And a man must have dug a grave.… I had no time to develop further the appalling idea that had occurred to me, for Jack Renauld was ushered into the room. Poirot greeted him in a business-like manner. “Take a seat, monsieur. I regret infinitely to derange you, but you will perhaps understand that the atmosphere of the Villa is not too congenial to me. M. Giraud and I do not see eye to eye about everything. His politeness to me has not been striking and you will comprehend that I do not intend any little discoveries I may make to benefit him in any way.” “Exactly, M. Poirot,” said the lad. “That fellow Giraud is an ill-conditioned brute, and I’d be delighted to see some one score at his expense.” “Then I may ask a little favour of you?” “Certainly.” “I will ask you to go to the railway station and take a train to the next station along the line, Abbalac. Ask there at the cloak-room whether two foreigners deposited a valise there on the night of the murder. It is a small station, and they are almost certain to remember. Will you do this?” “Of course I will,” said the boy, mystified, though ready for the task. “I and my friend, you comprehend, have business elsewhere,” explained Poirot. “There is a train in a quarter of an hour, and I will ask you not to return to the Villa, as I have no wish for Giraud to get an inkling of your errand.” “Very well, I will go straight to the station.” He rose to his feet. Poirot’s voice stopped him. “One moment, M. Renauld, there is one little matter that puzzles me."

"Madame Daubreuil from the Villa Marguerite just down the road?" "That is what I said, monsieur. Oh, she is a pretty one, cellela!" The old woman tossed her head scornfully. "Madame Daubreuil," murmured the commissary. "Impossible." "Voilà," grumbled Françoise. "That is all you get for telling the truth." "Not at all," said the examining magistrate soothingly. "We were surprised, that is all. Madame Daubreuil then, and Monsieur Renauld, they were " he paused delicately. "Eh? It was that without doubt?" "How should I know? But what will you? Monsieur, he was milor anglais trés riche and Madame Daubreuil, she was poor, that one and trés chic for all that she lives so quietly with her daughter. Not a doubt of it, she has had her history! She is no longer young, but ma foi! I who speak to you have seen the men’s heads turn after her as she goes down the street. Besides lately, she has had more money to spend all the town knows it. The little economies, they are at an end." And Françoise shook her head with an air of unalterable certainty. M. Hautet stroked his beard reflectively. "And Madame Renauld?" he asked at length. "How did she take this friendship." Françoise shrugged her shoulders. "She was always most amiable most polite. One would say that she suspected nothing. But all the same, is it not so, the heart suffers, monsieur? Day by day, I have watched Madame grow paler and thinner. She was not the same woman who arrived here a month ago. Monsieur, too, has changed. He also has had his worries. One could see that he was on the brink of a crisis of the nerves. And who could wonder, with an affair conducted such a fashion? No reticence, no discretion. Style anglais, without doubt!" I bounded indignantly in my seat, but the examining magistrate was continuing his questions, undistracted by side issues. "You say that M. Renauld had not to let Madame Daubreuil out? Had she left, then?" "Yes, monsieur. I heard them come out of the study and go to the door. Monsieur said good night, and shut the door after her." "What time was that?" "About twenty-five minutes after ten, monsieur." "Do you know when M. Renauld went to bed?" "I heard him come up about ten minutes after we did. The stair creaks so that one hears every one who goes up and down." "And that is all? You heard no sound of disturbance during the night?" "Nothing whatever, monsieur." "Which of the servants came down the first in the morning?" "I did, monsieur. At once I saw the door swinging open." "What about the other downstairs windows, were they all fastened?" "Every one of them. There was nothing suspicious or out of place anywhere." "Good, Françoise, you can go." The old woman shuffled towards the door. On the threshold she looked back. "I will tell you one thing, monsieur. That Madame Daubreuil she is a bad one! Oh, yes, one woman knows about another. She is a bad one, remember that." And, shaking her head sagely, Françoise left the room. "Léonie Oulard," called the magistrate. Léonie appeared dissolved in tears, and inclined to be hysterical. M. Hautet dealt with her adroitly. Her evidence was mainly concerned with the discovery of her mistress gagged and bound, of which she gave rather an exaggerated account. She, like Françoise, had heard nothing during the night. Her sister, Denise, succeeded her. She agreed that her master had changed greatly of late. "Every day he became more and more morose. He ate less. He was always depressed." But Denise had her own theory. "Without doubt it was the Mafia he had on his track! Two masked men who else could it be? A terrible society that!" "It is, of course, possible," said the magistrate smoothly. "Now, my girl, was it you who admitted Madame Daubreuil to the house last night?" "Not last night, monsieur, the night before." "But Françoise has just told us that Madame Daubreuil was here last night?" "No, monsieur. A lady did come to see M. Renauld last night, but it was not Madame Daubreuil." Surprised, the magistrate insisted, but the girl held firm. She knew Madame Daubreuil perfectly by sight. This lady was dark also, but shorter, and much younger. Nothing could shake her statement. "Had you ever seen this lady before?" "Never, monsieur." And then the girl added diffidently: "But I think she was English." "English?" "Yes, monsieur. She asked for M. Renauld in quite good French, but the accent one can always tell it, n’est-ce pas? Besides when they came out of the study they were speaking in English." "Did you hear what they said? Could you understand it, I mean?" "Me, I speak the English very well," said Denise with pride. "The lady was speaking too fast for me to catch what she said, but I heard Monsieur’s last words as he opened the door for her." She paused, and then repeated carefully and laboriously: "‘Yeas yeas butt for Gaud’s saike go nauw!’" "Yes, yes, but for God’s sake go now!" repeated the magistrate. He dismissed Denise and, after a moment or two for consideration, recalled Françoise. To her he propounded the question as to whether she had not made a mistake in fixing the night of Madame Daubreuil’s visit. Françoise, however, proved unexpectedly obstinate. It was last night that Madame Daubreuil had come. Without a doubt it was she. Denise wished to make herself interesting, voilà tout! So she had cooked up this fine tale about a strange lady. Airing her knowledge of English too! Probably Monsieur had never spoken that sentence in English at all, and even if he had, it proved nothing, for Madame Daubreuil spoke English perfectly, and generally used that language when talking to M. and Madame Renauld. "You see, M. Jack, the son of Monsieur, was usually here, and he spoke the French very badly." The magistrate did not insist. Instead he inquired about the chauffeur, and learned that only yesterday, M. Renauld had declared that he was not likely to use the car, and that Masters might just as well take a holiday.

I am completely agitated. The dreadful breakfast I had was accompanied by dreadful company. Slow Dutch waitresses served me subpar fish after making me wait. The ordeal of waking up at 5 a.m. to see a doctor upon arrival at the port is exhausting. But now, a serious issue has arisen. I presented Milray’s sealed letter to the Prime Minister, only to find a blank sheet inside. Pagett, a constant source of annoyance, seems pleased by my predicament. Despite my reluctance, I had to entertain his theory about Rayburn. The situation is escalating, and I am eager to leave for Rhodesia. I have made it clear to Pagett that he will not be joining me on this journey. My reputation as an English Member of Parliament is at stake.

"In that instant of frigid rationality, I berated myself for being overly theatrical, longing for the quiet monotony of Smallington. These thoughts raced through my mind in a mere moment. Instinctively, I inched backwards, searching for the door handle. The man holding me captive smirked. "You're here now, and here you will remain," he said jokingly. Trying to appear brave, I stated, "I was brought here by the curator of the Cape Town Museum."

"Bravo!" he whispered. "May I have a look, madame?" He examined the gem closely in his own hand before handing it back with a slight bow. "A flawless and magnificent stone. Oh, my word! and you carry it around with you, like that!" "No, no, I'm usually very cautious, Monsieur Poirot. Normally, it's locked away in my jewelry box, kept in the hotel safe deposit box. We're staying at the Grand, you know. I just brought it today for you to admire." "And you'll leave it with me, won't you? You'll take advice from Papa Poirot?""Well, you see, Monsieur Poirot, the thing is, on Friday we are heading to Yardly Chase to spend a few days with Lord and Lady Yardly." Her words triggered a faint memory in my mind. Wasn't there some gossip...? A few years back, Lord and Lady Yardly had visited the States, and there were rumors that his lordship had indulged in some questionable activities with certain ladies out there. But there was something else, some rumor linking Lady Yardly's name with a Hollywood star in California... it hit me in an instant - Gregory B. Rolf."I'll share a little secret with you, Monsieur Poirot," Miss Marvell continued. "We're in talks with Lord Yardly for a potential filming project in his ancestral home.""At Yardly Chase?" I interjected, intrigued. "It's one of England's top attractions."Miss Marvell nodded. "It's full of old-world charm for sure. But he's asking for a hefty price, and we're not sure yet if the deal will go through, but Greg and I always like to mix business with pleasure.""But forgive my ignorance, madame, isn't it possible to visit Yardly Chase without bringing the diamond with you?" A sharp, calculating look appeared in Miss Marvell's eyes, contradicting her innocent facade. She suddenly seemed much older. "I want to wear it there," she stated firmly."Of course," I remarked, "there are some famous jewels in the Yardly collection, including a large diamond, right?""That's correct," replied Miss Marvell, shortly. Poirot muttered softly to himself: "Ah, that's how it is!" Then he said aloud, with his usual knack for hitting the mark (he calls it psychology): "So you must already be acquainted with Lady Yardly, or perhaps your husband is?""Gregory knew her when she visited the West three years ago," Miss Marvell revealed. She paused, then blurted out: "Do either of you read Society Gossip?"We both admitted somewhat sheepishly. "I ask because this week's issue has an article on famous jewels, and it's quite intriguing," she added. I got up, fetched the magazine from the other side of the room, and handed it to her. She found the article and began to read aloud: "...Among other notable stones is the Star of the East, a diamond belonging to the Yardly family. An ancestor of the current Lord Yardly brought it back from China, and there's a romantic tale associated with it..." "Bravo!" Poirot exclaimed. "Undoubtedly a tale of the highest caliber." He turned to Mary Marvell. "Are you not afraid, madame? No superstitions? No fears of introducing these two 'Siamese twins' to each other only to have a Chinaman appear and whisk them back to China?""I don't think Lady Yardly's diamond is anywhere near as good as mine," said Miss Marvell. "But I want to find out."

I couldn't see into the passage from where I sat, but she and Poirot were facing it. She let out a long shriek as she turned to him. "You saw him there in the passage?" she exclaimed. He was staring down at her with a puzzled expression, then shook his head. "I saw him, my husband, you must have seen him too?" "Madame, I saw nothing. You are not well, unstrung." "I am perfectly well, Oh, God!" Suddenly, without any warning, the lights flickered and went out. Out of the darkness came three loud knocks. I could hear Mrs. Maltravers moaning. And then I saw! The man I had seen on the bed upstairs stood there facing us, gleaming with a faint ghostly light. There was blood on his lips, and he held his right hand out, pointing. Suddenly a brilliant light seemed to emanate from it. It passed over Poirot and me, and fell on Mrs. Maltravers. I saw her white terrified face, and something else! "My God, Poirot!" I exclaimed. "Look at her hand, her right hand. It's all red!" Her own eyes fell on it, and she collapsed in a heap on the floor. "Blood," she cried hysterically. "Yes, it's blood. I killed him. I did it. He was showing me, and then I put my hand on the trigger and pressed. Save me from him, save me! He's come back!" Her voice faded into a gurgle. "Lights," said Poirot briskly. The lights came on as if by magic. "That's it," he continued. "You heard, Hastings? And you, Everett? Oh, by the way, this is Mr. Everett, rather a fine member of the theatrical profession. I 'phoned him this afternoon. His makeup is good, isn't it? Quite like the dead man, and with a pocket torch and the necessary phosphorescence, he made the proper impression. I shouldn't touch her right hand if I were you, Hastings. Red paint marks so. When the lights went out, I clasped her hand, you see. By the way, we mustn't miss our train. Inspector Japp is outside the window. A bad night, but he has been able to while away the time by tapping on the window every now and then." "You see," continued Poirot, as we walked briskly through the wind and rain, "there was a little discrepancy. The doctor seemed to think the deceased was a Christian Scientist, and who could have given him that impression but Mrs. Maltravers? But to us, she represented him as being in a grave state of apprehension about his own health. Again, why was she so taken aback by the reappearance of young Black? And lastly, although I know that convention decrees that a woman must make a decent pretense of mourning for her husband, I do not care for such heavily rouged eyelids! You did not observe them, Hastings? No? As I always tell you, you see nothing!" "Well, there it was. There were the two possibilities. Did Black's story suggest an ingenious method of committing suicide to Mr. Maltravers, or did his other listener, the wife, see an equally ingenious method of committing murder? I inclined to the latter view. To shoot himself in the way indicated, he would probably have had to pull the trigger with his toe or at least so I imagine. Now if Maltravers had been found with one boot off, we should almost certainly have heard of it from someone. An odd detail like that would have been remembered. "No, as I say, I inclined to the view that it was a case of murder, not suicide, but I realized that I had not a shadow of proof in support of my theory. Hence the elaborate little comedy you saw played tonight." "Even now I don't quite see all the details of the crime?" I said. "Let us start from the beginning. Here is a shrewd and scheming woman who, knowing of her husband's financial debacle and tired of the elderly mate she has only married for his money, induces him to insure his life for a large sum, and then seeks for the means to accomplish her purpose. An accident gives her that the young soldier's strange story. The next afternoon when monsieur le capitaine, as she thinks, is on the high seas, she and her husband are strolling round the grounds. 'What a curious story that was last night!' she observes. 'Could a man shoot himself in such a way? Do show me if it is possible!' The poor fool he shows her. He places the end of the rifle in his mouth. She stoops down, and puts her finger on the trigger, laughing up at him. 'And now, sir,' she says saucily, 'supposing I pull the trigger?' "And then and then, Hastings she pulls it!" So far, in the cases which I have recorded, Poirot's investigations have started from the central fact, whether murder or robbery, and have proceeded from thence by a process of logical deduction to the final triumphant unraveling. In the events I am now about to chronicle, a remarkable chain of circumstances led from the apparently trivial incidents which first attracted Poirot's attention to the sinister happenings which completed a most unusual case. I had been spending the evening with an old friend of mine, Gerald Parker. There had been, perhaps, about half a dozen people there besides my host and myself, and the talk fell, as it was bound to do sooner or later wherever Parker found himself, on the subject of house-hunting in London. Houses and flats were Parker's special hobby. Since the end of the War, he had occupied at least half a dozen different flats and maisonettes. No sooner was he settled anywhere than he would light unexpectedly upon a new find, and would forthwith depart bag and baggage. His moves were nearly always accomplished at a slight pecuniary gain, for he had a shrewd business head, but it was sheer love of the sport that actuated him, and not a desire to make money at it. We listened to Parker for some time with the respect of the novice for the expert. Then it was our turn, and a perfect babel of tongues was let loose. Finally the floor was left to Mrs. Robinson, a charming little bride who was there with her husband. I had never met them before, as Robinson was only a recent acquaintance of Parker's.

She hopped onto the train at the very last moment, gasping for breath as if she had just finished a marathon, yet Pagett claimed he saw her boarding a train to Durban the previous night! Either Pagett was intoxicated once again or the girl must have a supernatural presence. And she never offers any explanation. No one ever does. Ah, the "Secretaries I have encountered." The first, a fugitive murderer on the run. The second, a hidden drinker involved in scandalous affairs in Italy. The third, a stunning woman with the uncanny ability to be in two places simultaneously.

Poirot calmly explained the intricate plan that M. Renauld had devised, ensuring that he would appear to die without actually perishing. The body of the tramp was manipulated to serve as a decoy, while M. Renauld planned to escape to another country under an assumed identity. Madame Renauld was to play the part of the grieving widow until they could reunite in secret. The details were meticulously arranged, from altering the will to staging the body with the aeroplane dagger. The truth behind the elaborate scheme was slowly unraveling, revealing the extent of their desperation and determination to start anew.

I arrived at the Villa Medgee after a challenging search. The people arrived on the waves on short curved boards. It was too early for tea, so I headed to the bathing pavilion. When offered a surf board, I eagerly accepted. Surfing seemed simple at first glance, but I quickly learned otherwise. Despite my initial frustration, I was determined to try again. As I anticipated. Mrs. Blair and Anne have purchased forty-nine wooden animals! (Anne’s Narrative Continued) I immensely enjoyed the journey up to Rhodesia. There was something novel and thrilling to behold each day. First the breathtaking landscapes of the Hex river valley, then the desolate magnificence of the Karoo, and finally that remarkable straight stretch of track in Bechuanaland, and the utterly charming toys the locals brought to sell. Suzanne and I were nearly stranded at each stop, if you could call them that. It seemed to me that the train just halted whenever it pleased, and as soon as it did, a crowd of locals emerged from the barren landscape, displaying mealie bowls, sugar canes, fur karosses, and enchanting carved wooden animals. Suzanne immediately began collecting the latter. I followed suit most of them cost a “tiki” (threepence) and each was unique. There were giraffes, tigers, snakes, a forlorn eland, and amusing little black warriors. We had an absolute blast. Sir Eustace attempted to restrain us but to no avail. I find it miraculous that we were not abandoned at some oasis along the line. South African trains don’t sound their horns or show any signs of departure. They simply glide away, and you must hastily make your way back on board. Suzanne’s astonishment at witnessing me clamber onto the train at Cape Town can be imagined. We conducted a thorough assessment of the situation on the first night. We conversed well into the night. It became evident to me that defensive measures must be taken in addition to offensive ones. Traveling with Sir Eustace Pedler and his entourage, I felt relatively secure. Moreover, as long as I was in close proximity to Sir Eustace, I was somewhat connected to Guy Pagett and Guy Pagett was at the core of the mystery. I inquired of Suzanne whether she believed it was plausible that Pagett himself was the enigmatic “Colonel.” His subordinate status was a mark against the theory, but I had occasionally considered that, despite his autocratic demeanor, Sir Eustace was greatly influenced by his secretary. He was an amiable man, and one whom a clever secretary might be able to manipulate. The obscurity of his position might actually be advantageous to him, as he would likely prefer to remain out of the spotlight. However, Suzanne vehemently rejected these notions. She refused to entertain the idea that Guy Pagett was the mastermind. The true leader the “Colonel” was lurking in the shadows and had probably been in Africa at the time of our arrival. I acknowledged that there was merit to her perspective, but I remained unconvinced. In each incriminating instance, Pagett had been depicted as the guiding force. It was true that his demeanor seemed to lack the confidence and decisiveness one would expect from a criminal mastermind but according to Colonel Race, it was intellectual prowess alone that this mysterious leader provided, and creative brilliance is often coupled with a feeble and timid physical constitution. I received approval and detailed instructions via telegram at Bulawayo. I was now part of the Daily Budget team, and I received a private message of congratulations from Lord Nasby himself. Our train departed at nine o’clock. Sir Eustace’s mood was still far from pleasant, and Miss Pettigrew appeared subdued. Colonel Race was completely himself. I felt as though the entire conversation on the way back had been a dream. I slept heavily that night on my hard bunk, wrestling with vague, menacing dreams. I woke up with a headache and went out to the observation platform of the car. It was cool and beautiful, with undulating wooded hills as far as the eye could see. I adored it, loved it more than any other place I had ever been. I wished then that I could have a small hut somewhere in the heart of the scrub and live there forever. Just before half-past two, Colonel Race called me out from the “office” and pointed to a bouquet-shaped white mist hanging over a section of the bush. “The spray from the Falls,” he explained. “We are almost there.” I was still enveloped in that strange sense of elation that followed my troubled night. There was a strong feeling within me that I had arrived home. Home! And yet I had never been here before or had I in dreams? We walked from the train to the hotel, a large white building tightly secured against mosquitoes. There were no roads, no houses. We stepped out onto the veranda and I gasped. There, half a mile away, directly in front of us, were the Falls. I’ve never seen anything so magnificent and beautiful I never will. “Anne, you’re fey,” remarked Suzanne, as we sat down to lunch. “I’ve never seen you like this before.” She stared at me intently. “Am I?” I laughed, but it felt forced. “It’s just that I love it all.” “It’s more than that.” A slight frown appeared on her forehead, one of apprehension. Yes, I was happy, but beyond that I had the strange sensation that I was expecting something something that would occur soon. I was excited, restless. After tea, we took a stroll, boarded the trolley, and were pushed by smiling locals down the small rail tracks to the bridge. It was a marvelous sight, the vast chasm and the rushing waters below, with a veil of mist and spray in front of us that parted occasionally to reveal the cascade of water before closing up again in its impenetrable mystery. That, to me, has always been the allure of the Falls their elusive nature. You always think you’re about to see it and you never do. We crossed the bridge and leisurely walked along the path marked with white stones on each side, leading around the edge of the gorge. Finally, we reached a large clearing where a path descended towards the chasm. “The palm gully,” explained Colonel Race. “Shall we go down? Or shall we leave it until tomorrow? Sir Eustace returned to the hotel. I found the rainbow forest rather disappointing. Poirot intervened: "Mr. Stonor, the English chauffeur, Masters, how long had he been in Mr. Renauld's service?" "Over a year." "Do you know if he has ever been to South America?" "I am certain he has not. Before working for Mr. Renauld, he was employed for many years by a family in Gloucestershire whom I am acquainted with." "Can you vouch for him as being beyond suspicion?" "Absolutely." Poirot seemed disappointed. Meanwhile, the magistrate called for Marchaud. "Please inform Mrs. Renauld that I would like to speak with her for a few minutes. Ask her not to trouble herself. I will go to her upstairs." Marchaud saluted and left. After a few moments, to our surprise, Mrs. Renauld, deathly pale in mourning attire, entered the room. Mr. Hautet offered her a chair with profuse apologies, and she thanked him with a smile. Stonor held one of her hands with evident sympathy. Words seemed to escape him. Mrs. Renauld turned to Mr. Hautet. "You wanted to ask me something, Mr. Judge." "If you don't mind, madame. I understand your husband was originally from French Canada. Can you provide any insight into his youth or upbringing?" She shook her head. "My husband was always secretive about his past, sir. I know he came from the North West, but I suspect he had a difficult childhood since he never spoke of that time. Our focus was always on the present and the future." "Was there any mystery in his past?" Mrs. Renauld smiled faintly and shook her head. "I don't believe anything so dramatic, Mr. Judge." Mr. Hautet also smiled. "Indeed, we must not indulge in melodrama. There is one more thing," he hesitated. Stonor interrupted eagerly: "They have a preposterous notion, Mrs. Renauld. They actually believe that Mr. Renauld was involved with a Madame Daubreuil, who apparently lives next door." A deep blush spread across Mrs. Renauld's cheeks. She lifted her head high, then bit her lip, her expression trembling. Stonor watched her in astonishment, while Mr. Bex leaned forward and asked gently: "We regret any distress this may cause you, madame, but do you have reason to believe that Madame Daubreuil was your husband's lover?" With a sob of anguish, Mrs. Renauld buried her face in her hands. Her body shook with sobs. Finally, she raised her head and said in a broken voice: "She may have been." I had never seen Stonor look so utterly dumbfounded in all my years.

There were other reasons, too, which I would hardly acknowledge to myself, but which made it inadvisable to confide in Colonel Race. Then I thought of Mrs. Blair. She, too, had been kind to me. I did not delude myself into the belief that that really meant anything. It was probably a mere whim of the moment. All the same, I had it in my power to interest her. She was a woman who had experienced most of the ordinary sensations of life. I proposed to supply her with an extraordinary one! And I liked her; liked her ease of manner, her lack of sentimentality, her freedom from any form of affectation. My mind was made up. I decided to seek her out then and there. She would hardly be in bed yet. Then I remembered that I did not know the number of her cabin. My friend, the night stewardess, would probably know. I rang the bell. After some delay it was answered by a man. He gave me the information I wanted. Mrs. Blair’s cabin was No. 71. He apologized for the delay in answering the bell, but explained that he had all the cabins to attend to. “Where is the stewardess, then?” I asked. “They all go off duty at ten o’clock.” “No I mean the night stewardess.” “No stewardess on at night, miss.” “But but a stewardess came the other night about one o’clock.” “You must have been dreaming, miss. There’s no stewardess on duty after ten.” He withdrew and I was left to digest this morsel of information. Who was the woman who had come to my cabin on the night of the 22nd? My face grew graver as I realized the cunning and audacity of my unknown antagonists. Then, pulling myself together, I left my own cabin and sought that of Mrs. Blair. I knocked at the door. “Who’s that?” called her voice from within. “It’s me Anne Beddingfeld.” “Oh, come in, Gipsy girl.” I entered. A good deal of scattered clothing lay about, and Mrs. Blair herself was draped in one of the loveliest kimonos I had ever seen. It was all orange and gold and black and made my mouth water to look at it. “Mrs. Blair,” I said abruptly, “I want to tell you the story of my life that is, if it isn’t too late, and you won’t be bored.” “Not a bit. I always hate going to bed,” said Mrs. Blair, her face crinkling into smiles in the delightful way it had. “And I should love to hear the story of your life. You’re a most unusual creature, Gipsy girl. Nobody else would think of bursting in on me at 1 a.m. to tell me the story of their life. Especially after snubbing my natural curiosity for weeks as you have done! I’m not accustomed to being snubbed. It’s been quite a pleasing novelty. Sit down on the sofa and unburden your soul.” I told her the whole story. It took some time as I was conscientious over all the details. She gave a deep sigh when I had finished, but she did not say at all what I had expected her to say. Instead she looked at me, laughed a little and said: “Do you know, Anne, you’re a very unusual girl? Haven’t you ever had qualms?” “Qualms?” I asked, puzzled. “Yes, qualms, qualms, qualms! Starting off alone with practically no money. What will you do when you find yourself in a strange country with all your money gone?” “It’s no good bothering about that until it comes. I’ve got plenty of money still. The twenty-five pounds that Mrs. Flemming gave me is practically intact, and then I won the sweep yesterday. That’s another fifteen pounds. Why, I’ve got lots of money. Forty pounds!” “Lots of money! My God!” murmured Mrs. Blair. “I couldn’t do it, Anne, and I’ve plenty of pluck in my own way. I couldn’t start off gaily with a few pounds in my pocket and no idea as to what I was doing and where I was going.” “But that’s the fun of it,” I cried, thoroughly roused. “It gives one such a splendid feeling of adventure.” She looked at me, nodded once or twice, and then smiled. “Lucky Anne! There aren’t many people in the world who feel as you do.” “Well,” I said impatiently, “what do you think of it all, Mrs. Blair?” “I think it’s the most thrilling thing I ever heard! Now, to begin with, you will stop calling me Mrs. Blair. Suzanne will be ever so much better. Is that agreed?” “I should love it, Suzanne.” “Good girl. Now let’s get down to business. You say that in Sir Eustace’s secretary not that long-faced Pagett, the other one you recognized the man who was stabbed and came into your cabin for shelter?” I nodded. “That gives us two links connecting Sir Eustace with the tangle. And deep down, one remains the same, feels the same, I mean, and that's why women admire physical strength in men, it's what they once possessed and have lost.” “So it's almost like ancestor worship, isn’t it?” “Something along those lines.” “And do you really believe that? You may think you admire moral qualities, but when you fall in love, you revert to a primitive state where only the physical matters. But I don’t think that’s the end of it. If you lived in primitive conditions, it would be acceptable, but you don’t, and in the end, the other qualities prevail. It’s the things that seem defeated that always triumph, isn’t it? They triumph in the most important way. Like what the Bible says about losing your soul and finding it.” “In the end,” Colonel Race pondered, “you fall in love and then fall out of it, is that what you mean?” “Not quite, but you could put it that way if you prefer.” “But have you ever fallen out of love, Miss Anne?” “No, I haven’t,” I confessed honestly. “Or fallen in love, for that matter?” I remained silent. The car stopped at our destination, concluding our conversation. We exited the vehicle and began the gradual climb to the World’s View. Once again, I felt a slight unease in Colonel Race’s presence. He concealed his thoughts so well behind those impenetrable black eyes. He intimidated me a little. He always had. I never knew where I stood with him. We ascended in silence until we arrived at the place where Rhodes is surrounded by enormous boulders. A peculiar, eerie place, far from human habitation, that sings a constant song of rugged beauty. We sat there in silence for a while. Then descended once more, deviating slightly from the path. At times it was a challenging climb, and once we encountered a steep slope or rock that was nearly vertical. Colonel Race went ahead, then turned to assist me. “I should carry you,” he said suddenly, lifting me off the ground with a swift movement. I felt his strength as he placed me down and released his grip. A man of iron, with muscles like tightly drawn steel. And once again, I felt fearful, especially as he did not step aside, but stood directly in front of me, gazing into my eyes. “What are you truly doing here, Anne Beddingfeld?” he asked abruptly. “I’m a wanderer exploring the world.” “Yes, that's accurate. The newspaper correspondent is just a facade. You don’t have the soul of a journalist. You are pursuing life for your own sake. But that's not all.” What was he trying to make me reveal? I was frightened. I met his gaze directly. My eyes may not keep secrets like his, but they can wage war against the enemy. “What are you really doing here, Colonel Race?” I inquired deliberately. For a moment, I thought he wouldn’t respond. He was clearly surprised, though. Finally, he spoke, with a hint of grim amusement in his words. “Chasing ambition,” he stated. “Simply pursuing ambition. You will recall, Miss Beddingfeld, that ‘by that sin fell the angels,’ etc.” “They say,” I spoke slowly, “that you are involved with the Government, that you are part of the Secret Service. Is that true?” Was it my imagination, or did he pause for a fraction of a second before replying? “I can assure you, Miss Beddingfeld, that I am here strictly as a private individual traveling for my own pleasure.” Reflecting on his response later, it seemed somewhat ambiguous to me. Perhaps he intended it to be so. We returned to the car in silence. Halfway back to Bulawayo, we stopped for tea at a somewhat basic structure on the side of the road. The owner was digging in the garden and appeared irritated at being interrupted. However, he kindly agreed to see what he could provide. After an endless wait, he brought us some stale cakes and lukewarm tea. Then he went back to his garden. As soon as he left, we were surrounded by cats. Six of them, all meowing pitifully at once. The noise was deafening. I offered them some cake, which they devoured eagerly. I poured all the milk into a saucer, and they fought each other to lap it up. “Oh,” I exclaimed indignantly, “they're starving! It’s cruel. Please, order more milk and another plate of cake.” Colonel Race silently went to fulfill my request. The cats began meowing again. He returned with a large jug of milk, which the cats finished quickly. I stood up determinedly. “I’m taking these cats home with us. I won’t leave them here.” “My dear, don’t be ridiculous. You can't carry six cats along with fifty wooden animals.” “Forget the wooden animals. These cats are alive. I'll take them with me.” “You will do no such thing.” I glared at him, but he continued, “You may think me harsh, but one can't go through life being sentimental about these matters. There’s no use in arguing—I won’t let you take them. It’s a primitive country, you know, and I’m stronger than you.” I always recognize when I’m defeated. I went back to the car with tears in my eyes. “They’re probably short of food just for today,” he reassured me. “That man's wife has gone to Bulawayo for supplies. So everything will be fine. Besides, you know, the world is full of hungry cats.” “Please, stop,” I said firmly. “I’m teaching you to understand life as it is. I’m teaching you to be tough and ruthless like me. That’s the key to strength and success.”

Poirot and I were expecting our old friend Inspector Japp of Scotland Yard to tea. We were sitting round the tea-table awaiting his arrival. Poirot had just finished carefully straightening the cups and saucers which our landlady was in the habit of throwing, rather than placing, on the table. He had also breathed heavily on the metal teapot, and polished it with a silk handkerchief. The kettle was on the boil, and a small enamel saucepan beside it contained some thick, sweet chocolate which was more to Poirot’s palate than what he described as “your English poison.” A sharp “rat-tat” sounded below, and a few minutes afterwards Japp entered briskly. “Hope I’m not late,” he said as he greeted us. “To tell the truth, I was yarning with Miller, the man who’s in charge of the Davenheim case.” I pricked up my ears. For the last three days the papers had been full of the strange disappearance of Mr. Davenheim, senior partner of Davenheim and Salmon, the well-known bankers and financiers. On Saturday last he had walked out of his house, and had never been seen since. I looked forward to extracting some interesting details from Japp. “I should have thought,” I remarked, “that it would be almost impossible for anyone to ‘disappear’ nowadays.” Poirot moved a plate of bread and butter the eighth of an inch, and said sharply: “Be exact, my friend. What do you mean by ‘disappear’? To which class of disappearance are you referring?” “Are disappearances classified and labelled, then?” I laughed. Japp smiled also. Poirot frowned at us both. “But certainly they are! They fall into three categories: First, and most common, the voluntary disappearance. Second, the much abused ‘loss of memory’ case rare, but occasionally genuine. Third, murder, and a more or less successful disposal of the body. Do you refer to all three as impossible of execution?” “Very nearly so, I should think. You might lose your own memory, but some one would be sure to recognize you especially in the case of a well-known man like Davenheim. Then ‘bodies’ can’t be made to vanish into thin air. Sooner or later they turn up, concealed in lonely places, or in trunks. Murder will out. In the same way, the absconding clerk, or the domestic defaulter, is bound to be run down in these days of wireless telegraphy. He can be headed off from foreign countries; ports and railway stations are watched; and, as for concealment in this country, his features and appearance will be known to every one who reads a daily newspaper. He’s up against civilization.” “Mon ami,” said Poirot, “you make one error. You do not allow for the fact that a man who had decided to make away with another man or with himself in a figurative sense might be that rare machine, a man of method. He might bring intelligence, talent, a careful calculation of detail to the task; and then I do not see why he should not be successful in baffling the police force.” “But not you, I suppose?” said Japp good-humouredly, winking at me. “He couldn’t baffle you, eh, Monsieur Poirot?” Poirot endeavoured, with a marked lack of success, to look modest. “Me, also! Why not? It is true that I approach such problems with an exact science, a mathematical precision, which seems, alas, only too rare in the new generation of detectives!” Japp grinned more widely. “I don’t know,” he said. “Miller, the man who’s on this case, is a smart chap.

The deceased was identified as L. B. Carton. Nothing was discovered in his pockets except a house-agent’s order to view a house on the river near Marlow. It was under the name of L. B.
