I sank down on the sofa, suddenly realizing the thing. Somebody had put a pinch of asafœtida in my cabin. Why? So that I should vacate it? Why were they so anxious to get me out? I thought of the scene this afternoon from a rather different point of view. What was there about Cabin 17 that made so many people anxious to get hold of it? The other two cabins were better cabins, why had both men insisted on sticking to 17? 17. How the number persisted. It was on the 17th I had sailed from Southampton. It was a 17 I stopped with a sudden gasp. Quickly I unlocked my suit-case, and took my precious paper from its place of concealment in some rolled stockings. 17 1 22 I had taken that for a date, the date of departure of the Kilmorden Castle. Supposing I was wrong. When I came to think of it, would any one, writing down a date, think it necessary to put the year as well as the month? Supposing 17 meant Cabin 17? And 1? The time one o’clock. Then 22 must be the date. I looked up at my little almanac. To-morrow was the 22nd! I was violently excited. I was sure that I had hit on the right trail at last. One thing was clear, I must not move out of the cabin. The asafœtida had got to be borne. I examined my facts again. To-morrow was the 22nd, and at 1 a.m. or 1 p.m. something would happen. I plumped for 1 a.m. It was now seven o’clock. In six hours I should know. I don’t know how I got through the evening. I retired to my cabin fairly early. I had told the stewardess that I had a cold in the head and didn’t mind smells. She still seemed distressed, but I was firm. The evening seemed interminable. I duly retired to bed, but in view of emergencies I swathed myself in a thick flannel dressing-gown, and encased my feet in slippers. Thus attired I felt that I could spring up and take an active part in anything that happened. What did I expect to happen? I hardly knew. Vague fancies, most of them wildly improbable, flitted through my brain. But one thing I was firmly convinced of, at one o’clock something would happen. At various times, I heard my fellow-passengers coming to bed. Fragments of conversation, laughing good-nights, floated in through the open transom. Then, silence. Most of the lights went out. There was still one in the passage outside, and there was therefore a certain amount of light in my cabin. I heard eight bells go. The hour that followed seemed the longest I had ever known. I consulted my watch surreptitiously to be sure I had not overshot the time. If my deductions were wrong, if nothing happened at one o’clock, I should have made a fool of myself, and spent all the money I had in the world on a mare’s-nest. My heart beat painfully.

"And now, my dear, you see the consequences of youth and beauty. I have revealed confidential information for you!" The woman chuckled, then graciously expressed her gratitude. "I should return home now. My mother will be worried." With that, she hurried back along the road, resembling a modern-day Atalanta. I gazed in her direction. "My friend," Poirot remarked, his voice tinged with irony, "are we to remain rooted here all night simply because you have encountered a lovely young lady who has captivated you?" I chuckled and offered my apologies. "But she is truly stunning, Poirot. It's hard not to be taken aback by her beauty." Poirot let out a groan.

"Are you Hassan, the former servant of Sir John Willard?" "I was in service to Sir John, now I am in service to his son." He moved closer, speaking softly. "You have a reputation for knowledge in the supernatural. Advise the young master to leave. There is malevolence surrounding us." Without waiting for a response, he walked away abruptly. "Malevolence in the air," murmured Poirot. "I sense it too." Our dinner was somber. Dr. Tosswill dominated the conversation with a lecture on ancient Egyptian artifacts.

Bella's unexpected visit threw off his plans. He quickly got rid of her to proceed with his dark deeds. Binding and silencing Madame Renauld, he corrected past mistakes, leaving subtle clues behind. Mrs. Maltravers, the widow, was questioned about the events leading up to her husband's death. She revealed that he had a premonition of his death and had insured his life because of it. As they were about to leave, a tall young man approached them.

The Villa was cloaked in darkness as we approached Mrs. Renauld's bedroom window. Suddenly, a cry for help pierced the silence, followed by a shadowy struggle. Poirot sprang into action, climbing a tree to enter the room through the window. Meanwhile, Cinderella, the acrobat, swung from the roof to rescue Mrs. Renauld. In the end, Marthe Daubreuil was unmasked as the murderer of Mr. Renauld and the would-be murderer of Mrs. Renauld. The night's events left me bewildered and exhausted, with Poirot unraveling the intricate web of motives and lies.

I reached out with a trembling hand, my heart racing as I grasped it. The weight was unexpected, sending a jolt of excitement through me. Carefully, I removed the adhesive plaster sealing it shut. As I lifted the lid, a cascade of dull glassy pebbles spilled out onto the surface. "Pebbles," I muttered, my disappointment palpable. "Pebbles?" Suzanne exclaimed, her voice filled with disbelief. "Not pebbles, Anne! Diamonds!" Diamonds! The word echoed in my mind as I gazed at the glimmering heap before me. Each stone appeared unassuming, like a shard of glass. "Are you certain, Suzanne?" I inquired. "Absolutely, my dear."

I awoke from troubled dreams once more, desperate to find Harry Rayburn and warn him of some unknown danger. As I regained consciousness, memories of the nightmarish ordeal flooded back to me - the hurried escape from the hotel, the mysterious figure in the shadows, and the terrifying sensation of falling. Miraculously, I had survived the ordeal, though I was battered and weak. As I struggled to move, I realized I was confined in a cramped room with walls made of rough wood.

Poirot also convinced Mrs. Renauld to disclose her secret to Jack, revealing his father's dark past as a fugitive. Poirot ensured that the truth remained hidden from the world, sparing Jack and his family from shame. Jack later decided to start a new life in South America, accompanied by his mother. Poirot encouraged Jack to seek out his love and face the future with honesty and courage. In the end, Poirot and Hastings shared a moment of lighthearted observation in the garden.

"I am quite famished," she whispered. "Excellent. You're at the purser's table, correct? Confront him about the cabin." Flemming and her friends appeared to be incredibly mundane to me. Their conversations revolved around themselves, their children, and the struggles of procuring quality milk for their little ones. They would then transition to discussing the challenges of finding reliable servants, recounting their interactions with the staff at the Registry Office. It was rare to see them engage with current events or show any interest in the world beyond their comfort zone. They harbored a distaste for travel, finding everything abroad too unfamiliar compared to their beloved England.

It was clear that Madame Beroldy was involved in a complicated web of lies and deceit, leading to a shocking murder. Despite her initial acquittal, the truth eventually came to light. Madame Beroldy's manipulative nature and hidden motives were finally exposed, revealing a dark and twisted tale of betrayal and revenge. The case was a tangled web of secrets and lies, shrouded in mystery and intrigue. The shocking revelation of Madame Beroldy's true intentions left everyone stunned, proving that sometimes the most innocent-looking faces hide the darkest hearts.

M. Hautet bid us farewell, laughing heartily and enchanted with himself. Poirot, on the other hand, called him an old imbecile, showing his disdain. Just as we were leaving the building, we ran into Giraud, looking pleased with himself. Poirot hinted that the end of the case was near, but Giraud was dismissive. Poirot then challenged Giraud to a bet, claiming he would find the real murderer before him. Despite Giraud's initial reluctance, he finally agreed. As we walked, Poirot's determination was evident, causing me to doubt my ability to protect Bella. Suddenly, Gabriel Stonor joined us, expressing his belief in Jack Renauld's innocence. Stonor's words gave me hope in the midst of uncertainty.

“You confided in me during our train ride back from Paris about your Italian heritage and a past incident involving it. There was mention of a threatening letter sent to Jack Renauld. Upon encountering him, a surge of anger and jealousy overwhelmed you, leading to a fatal act. While you may not have intended to take his life, Cinderella, you are responsible for his death.” With hands shielding her face, she whispered, “You’re correct... I understand now, it’s all clear.” Abruptly, she fixed me with a fierce gaze.

“Good gracious, we’ve certainly surprised the poor man!” she exclaimed to an invisible crowd. “I beg your pardon for my outburst! Quite improper, I know, but my goodness, the circumstances warrant it! Can you believe I’ve misplaced my sole sibling?”“Is that so?” I responded courteously. “What a dreadful situation.”“He is disapproving!” the woman declared. “He wholeheartedly disapproves of me, and my sister, which is unjust, considering he has yet to meet her!” I started to speak, but she cut me off.“Enough said! No one cares for me! I shall retire to the orchard and devour earthworms! Oh woe is me! I am devastated!” With that, she disappeared behind a large, whimsical Italian magazine.

"Poirot agreed to join Lady Yardly and the children, quickly forming a bond with them. Lady Willard was distraught after her husband's death, worried about the possibility of an ancient curse haunting her son. She sought the help of Monsieur Poirot, who surprisingly admitted to believing in superstition. Poirot assured her that he would protect her son from harm, both physical and occult. Lady Willard mentioned the members of the expedition, including her husband's nephew, who had recently committed suicide in New York. Poirot decided to investigate further and they set off for Egypt the next day, despite Poirot's dread of the sea. Now, beneath the scorching sun of the desert, Poirot's discomfort was evident as they approached the Pyramids.

"On the contrary," Suzanne declared firmly, "let's shift our focus to something more captivating. Anne, let's discuss those diamonds." "What concerns you about them?" "I'm beginning to doubt their safety in my possession. It was fine before, no one would suspect they were among my belongings. But now that everyone is aware of our close friendship, you and I, I fear I'll be under scrutiny as well." "But no one knows they're concealed in a roll of film," I countered. "It's a clever hiding spot and I don't believe we could find a better one." She reluctantly agreed, suggesting we revisit the topic once we reached the Falls. Our departure was scheduled for nine o'clock. Sir Eustace's mood remained sour, while Miss Pettigrew appeared subdued. Colonel Race seemed unaffected. The previous conversation felt like a distant memory to me. I drifted into a deep sleep that night on my uncomfortable bunk, battling with vague, threatening dreams. I woke up with a headache and stepped out onto the observation deck of the carriage. The air was crisp and delightful, with rolling wooded hills stretching as far as the eye could see. I was enamored with the scenery, more so than any other place I had ever encountered. In that moment, I longed for a tiny hut nestled in the heart of the wilderness, a place to call my own forever. Just before half-past two, Colonel Race summoned me from the "office" and gestured towards a bouquet-shaped white mist hovering over a portion of the bush. "That's the spray from the Falls," he remarked. "We're almost there." I was still enveloped in a peculiar sense of euphoria that followed my restless night. It felt as though I had returned home, despite never having been there before - or had I, in my dreams? We disembarked from the train and made our way to the hotel, a large white structure protected by mosquito wire. There were no roads or houses in sight. As we stepped onto the stoep, I let out a gasp. Half a mile in the distance, facing us, were the majestic Falls. I had never witnessed such grandeur and beauty, and I knew I never would again. "Anne, you seem otherworldly," Suzanne remarked as we sat down for lunch. "You're different today." She studied me intently. "Am I?" I chuckled, though my laughter felt forced. "I just adore it all." "It's more than that." A look of concern crossed her face. Yes, I was content, but beyond that, I had a sense of anticipation, a feeling that something was about to transpire. I was on edge, restless. After tea, we took a leisurely stroll, boarded the trolley, and were pushed by cheerful locals along the rail tracks to the bridge. The sight was breathtaking - the immense chasm, the rapid waters below, and the veil of mist and spray that intermittently revealed the cascade before enveloping it once more in mystery. That, to me, was the allure of the Falls - their elusive nature. You always anticipate a sight, yet it remains just out of reach. We crossed the bridge and followed the path outlined with white stones, skirting the edge of the gorge.

The Villa was shrouded in darkness, the inhabitants fast asleep. As we stood below Mrs. Renauld’s open window, a cry for help pierced the night. Poirot sprang into action, rushing to the front door, then scaling a tree with feline grace to enter through the window. The scene inside was chaotic, with Mrs. Renauld barely clinging to life. The true culprit, Marthe Daubreuil, lay dead on the ground, a victim of her own twisted plot. The events of that night unfolded like a macabre dance, revealing a web of deceit and greed that only Poirot could untangle.

"The check was made out to a certain Duveen," Poirot pointed out. "I suspect it was the former," he continued, "considering the resemblance to M. Renauld's handwriting." The authenticity was quickly confirmed by cross-referencing it with a note found on the desk. The commissary, looking sheepish, muttered, "I can't believe I missed this." Poirot chuckled. "Always check under the mats! My associate Hastings knows that any irregularity bothers me. When I noticed the rug askew, I immediately thought, 'Ah! The chair leg must have nudged it.'"

" He scrutinized me intently for a few minutes. "Yes. I understand perfectly. And you are wise. Stick to your story." "That seems to be your constant advice," I said, slightly annoyed. "Ah, my friend, trust in Papa Poirot. One day, with your permission, I will arrange a suitable marriage for you." "Thank you," I replied with a laugh, "but the idea doesn't appeal to me." Poirot sighed and shook his head. "The English!" he muttered. "No method at all. They leave everything to chance!" He scowled and adjusted the position of the salt shaker. "You mentioned that Mademoiselle Cinderella is staying at the Hôtel du Phare, didn't you?" "No. Hôtel du Phare." "Right, I forgot." A moment of doubt crossed my mind. Had I ever told Poirot about the hotel? I glanced at him and felt reassured. He was meticulously cutting his bread into small squares, completely engrossed in the task. He must have assumed I had informed him of the girl's whereabouts. We had coffee outside overlooking the sea. Poirot smoked one of his tiny cigarettes, then checked his watch. "The train to Paris departs at 2:25," he noted. "I should be on my way." "Paris?" I exclaimed. "That's correct, my friend." "You're going to Paris? But why?" He responded gravely. "To find the killer of Mr. Renauld." "You think he's in Paris?" "I'm certain he isn't. However, that's where I must search for him. You may not comprehend, but I'll elucidate in due time. Trust me, this trip to Paris is essential. I won't be gone long. Most likely, I'll return tomorrow. I don't suggest you accompany me. Stay here, keep an eye on Giraud. Also, befriend Mr. Renauld's son. And if you wish, try to woo Mademoiselle Marthe. But I doubt you'll succeed." I wasn't pleased with his final comment. "That reminds me," I said. "I meant to ask you how you knew about those two?" "My friend, I understand human nature. Put together a young boy Renauld and a beautiful girl like Mademoiselle Marthe, and the outcome is almost inevitable. Then, the quarrel! It was either money or a woman, and recalling Léonie's account of the lad's anger, I opted for the latter. So I made my deduction, and I was correct." "And that's why you cautioned me against pursuing the lady? You already suspected that she loved young Renauld?" Poirot smiled. "At the very least, I noticed she had worried eyes. That is how I always think of Mademoiselle Daubreuil as the girl with the anxious eyes." His tone was so serious that it unsettled me. "What do you mean by that, Poirot?" "I believe, my friend, that we will find out soon enough. But I must depart." "You have plenty of time." "Perhaps, perhaps. But I prefer to have leisure at the station. I don't want to rush or hurry or agitate myself." "In any case," I said, getting up, "I'll come and see you off." "You will do no such thing. I forbid it." He was so authoritative that I stared at him in astonishment. He nodded emphatically. "I mean it, my friend. Goodbye! May I shake your hand? Oh no, I forgot it's not the English custom. A handshake, then." I felt somewhat lost after Poirot had left. I walked along the beach, observing the swimmers, without feeling motivated enough to join them. I half expected Cinderella to be frolicking among them in some extravagant outfit, but I saw no sign of her. I wandered aimlessly along the shore towards the far end of town. It occurred to me that it would be only proper to inquire about the girl. And it would save trouble in the long run. The issue would then be resolved. I wouldn't have to worry about her any longer. But if I didn't go at all, she might come looking for me at the Villa. And that would be inconvenient in every way. Definitely, it would be better to make a brief visit, during which I could make it clear that I could offer no further assistance to her as a guide. So I left the beach and headed inland. I quickly located the Hôtel du Phare, a very modest building. It was extremely frustrating not to know the lady's name, and to preserve my dignity, I decided to stroll inside and look around. Probably I would find her in the lounge. Merlinville was a small town, you left your hotel to go to the beach, and you left the beach to return to the hotel. There were no other attractions. There was a Casino under construction, but it was not yet finished. I had walked the length of the beach without spotting her, so she must be in the hotel. I entered. Several people were seated in the tiny lounge, but my target was not among them. I peeked into a few other rooms, but she was nowhere to be found. I waited for a while, until my impatience got the best of me. I pulled the concierge aside and slipped five francs into his hand. "I want to see a lady who is staying here. A young English lady, petite and dark. I'm not certain of her name." The man shook his head, trying to suppress a smirk. "There is no lady here matching your description." "Perhaps she's American," I suggested. These people are so dense. But the man continued to shake his head. "No, sir. There are only six or seven English and American ladies in total, and they are all much older than the lady you're seeking. You won't find her here, sir." He was so adamant that I began to doubt myself. "But the lady informed me she was staying here." "You or the lady must have made an error, as another gentleman has been here asking about her." "What did he look like?" "He was a small, well-dressed gentleman, very tidy, with a very stiff mustache, a peculiarly shaped head, and green eyes." Poirot! So that's why he didn't want me to accompany him to the station."

When I considered it, did anyone ever bother to include the year when writing a date? If 17 was code for Cabin 17, then what about 1? Perhaps one o'clock. In that case, 22 must be the date. Glancing at my pocket almanac, I saw that tomorrow was indeed the 22nd. My excitement grew. It seemed I had finally uncovered the correct path. One thing was certain - I could not leave the cabin. The stench of asafœtida had to be endured. Reviewing my clues once more, I deduced that something was set to occur on the 22nd at 1 a.m. or 1 p.m. I leaned towards 1 a.m. It was currently seven o'clock. In six hours, the truth would be revealed. The following hours were a blur.

I struck up a conversation with Mr. Chichester, hoping to glean some information. He mentioned his time in Africa, but I couldn't help but notice his lack of sunburn. As he fumbled with a piece of paper, claiming it was part of a sermon, my suspicions grew. Later, during a conversation about Italy, Mr. Pagett seemed uneasy and quickly excused himself. Sir Eustace joked about his secretary possibly committing a dark deed in Florence. Despite his respectable appearance, the idea lingered in the air. As the group dispersed, Mr. Chichester's clumsy action caught my attention once again. Colonel Race then approached me, commenting on my elusive nature at the previous night's dance. Let’s not act for now.” Suzanne gave me a smile. “You don’t like sitting idle, do you, Anne?” “Not really,” I replied truthfully. The only thing I could do was check the train schedule to see when Guy Pagett’s train would pass through Kimberley. I discovered it was due at 5.40 the next afternoon and would depart at 6. I wanted to meet Pagett as soon as possible, and that seemed like a good opportunity. The situation in the Rand was becoming dire, and another chance might not come soon. The only thing that brightened my day was a message from Johannesburg. An innocent telegram: “Arrived safely. All is well. Eric is here, also Eustace, but not Guy. Stay put for now. Andy.” Eric was our code name for Race. I chose it because I detest that name. There was nothing to be done until I could meet Pagett. Suzanne occupied herself by sending a comforting cable to Clarence in the distance. She became sentimental about him. In her own way, very different from me and Harry, she genuinely cared for Clarence. “I wish he was here, Anne,” she sobbed. “It’s been so long since I saw him.” “Have some face cream,” I offered soothingly. Suzanne dabbed a bit on her nose. “I’ll need more face cream soon,” she noted, “and you can only find this kind in Paris.” She sighed. “Paris!” “Suzanne,” I said, “you’ll soon have your fill of South Africa and adventure.” “I’d love a really nice hat,” Suzanne admitted longingly. “Should I accompany you to meet Guy Pagett tomorrow?” “I’d rather go alone. He’d be more comfortable speaking in front of just one of us.” And so, the next afternoon, I stood at the hotel entrance, struggling with a stubborn parasol that refused to open, while Suzanne relaxed on her bed with a book and a basket of fruit. According to the hotel porter, the train was surprisingly punctual today, though he doubted it would make it through to Johannesburg. The line had been sabotaged, he gravely informed me. It sounded promising! The train arrived just ten minutes behind schedule. Everyone poured out onto the platform, walking back and forth anxiously. I easily spotted Pagett. I approached him eagerly. He jumped at the sight of me, more than usual this time. “My word, Miss Beddingfeld, I thought you had vanished.” “I’ve reappeared,” I informed him solemnly. “How are you, Mr. Pagett?” “Fine, thank you looking forward to resuming my duties with Sir Eustace.” “Mr. Pagett,” I said, “there’s something I need to ask you. I hope you won’t be offended, but it’s crucial. I want to know what you were doing in Marlow on January 8th last year?” He started. “Really, Miss Beddingfeld I indeed” “You were there, weren’t you?” “I had my reasons I was in the vicinity, yes.” “Can you tell me what those reasons were?” “Hasn’t Sir Eustace already informed you?” “Sir Eustace? Does he know?” “I’m fairly certain he does. I hoped he hadn’t recognized me, but from his insinuations and comments, I fear it’s quite likely. In any case, I intended to come clean and offer him my resignation. He’s an unusual man, Miss Beddingfeld, with a strange sense of humor. It amuses him to keep me in suspense. I suspect he knew the truth all along. Perhaps he’s known for years.” I hoped to decipher Pagett’s ramblings eventually. He continued confidently: “It’s hard for a man of Sir Eustace’s stature to understand my position. I admit my mistake, but it seemed harmless. I think he should have confronted me directly instead of making sly jokes at my expense.” A whistle blew, and people started boarding the train. “Yes, Mr. Pagett,” I interjected, “I agree with your views on Sir Eustace. Pagett seemed to realize I had asked a question. His focus shifted from Sir Eustace and himself to me. “I apologize, Miss Beddingfeld,” he said stiffly, “but I don’t see why you’re interested in this.” He was back on the train, leaning down to speak to me. I felt at a loss. What to do with a man like him? “If it’s so dreadful that you can’t tell me” I began snidely. Finally, I struck a nerve. Pagett stiffened and blushed. “Dreadful? Ashamed? I don’t understand.” “Then enlighten me.” In three brief sentences, he spilled the beans. At last, Pagett’s secret was out! It was nothing like I had anticipated. I settled into a chair for some serious contemplation.

I explained to Mrs. Flemming that I had witnessed a nasty accident in the Tube and that I was rather upset and would go to my room and lie down. The kind woman insisted on my having a cup of tea. After that I was left to my own devices, and I proceeded to carry out a plan I had formed coming home. I wanted to know what it was that had produced that curious feeling of unreality whilst I was watching the doctor examine the body. First I lay down on the floor in the attitude of the corpse, then I laid a bolster down in my stead, and proceeded to duplicate, so far as I could remember, every motion and gesture of the doctor. When I had finished I had got what I wanted. I sat back on my heels and frowned at the opposite walls. There was a brief notice in the evening papers that a man had been killed in the Tube, and a doubt was expressed whether it was suicide or accident. That seemed to me to make my duty clear, and when Mr. Flemming heard my story he quite agreed with me. “Undoubtedly you will be wanted at the inquest. You say no one else was near enough to see what happened?” “I had the feeling some one was coming up behind me, but I can’t be sure and, anyway, they wouldn’t be as near as I was.” The inquest was held. Mr. Flemming made all the arrangements and took me there with him. He seemed to fear that it would be a great ordeal to me, and I had to conceal from him my complete composure. The deceased had been identified as L. B. Carton. Nothing had been found in his pockets except a house-agent’s order to view a house on the river near Marlow. It was in the name of L. B. Carton, Russell Hotel. The bureau clerk from the hotel identified the man as having arrived the day before and booked a room under that name. He had registered as L. B. Carton, Kimberley, S. Africa. He had evidently come straight off the steamer. I was the only person who had seen anything of the affair. “You think it was an accident?” the coroner asked me. “I am positive of it. Something alarmed him, and he stepped backwards blindly without thinking what he was doing.” “But what could have alarmed him?” “That I don’t know. But there was something. He looked panic-stricken.” A stolid juryman suggested that some men were terrified of cats. The man might have seen a cat. I didn’t think his suggestion a very brilliant one, but it seemed to pass muster with the jury, who were obviously impatient to get home and only too pleased at being able to give a verdict of accident as opposed to suicide. “It is extraordinary to me,” said the coroner, “that the doctor who first examined the body has not come forward. His name and address should have been taken at the time. It was most irregular not to do so.” I smiled to myself. I had my own theory in regard to the doctor. In pursuance of it, I determined to make a call upon Scotland Yard at an early date. But the next morning brought a surprise. The Flemmings took in the Daily Budget, and the Daily Budget was having a day after its own heart. EXTRAORDINARY SEQUEL TO TUBE ACCIDENT. WOMAN FOUND STABBED IN LONELY HOUSE. I read eagerly. “A sensational discovery was made yesterday at the Mill House, Marlow. The Mill House, which is the property of Sir Eustace Pedler, M.P., is to be let unfurnished, and an order to view this property was found in the pocket of the man who was at first thought to have committed suicide by throwing himself on the live rail at Hyde Park Corner Tube Station. In an upper room of the Mill House the body of a beautiful young woman was discovered yesterday, strangled. She is thought to be a foreigner, but so far has not been identified. The police are reported to have a clue. Sir Eustace Pedler, the owner of the Mill House, is wintering on the Riviera.” Nobody came forward to identify the dead woman. The inquest elicited the following facts. Shortly after one o’clock on January 8th, a well-dressed woman with a slight foreign accent had entered the offices of Messrs. She gave the name of Mrs. de Castina and her address as the Ritz, but there proved to be no one of that name staying there, and the hotel people failed to identify the body. Early this morning, they returned to London, and that's when the attempted assassination occurred.” “Hold on, please. Who exactly is this Captain Daniels? Do you have his background?” Lord Estair smiled. “I had a feeling you would ask that. We don't have much information on him. He doesn't come from a notable family. He has served in the British Army, and is a very capable secretary, with an impressive command over seven languages. That's why the Prime Minister chose him to accompany him to France.” “Does he have any family in England?” “Two aunts. A Mrs. Everard, who resides in Hampstead, and a Miss Daniels, who lives close to Ascot.” “Ascot? Isn't that near Windsor?” “That aspect has not been ignored. But it hasn't yielded any results.” “So, you consider Captain Daniels to be beyond suspicion?” A hint of bitterness crept into Lord Estair’s tone as he replied: “No, Monsieur Poirot. In these times, I would think twice before declaring anyone free of suspicion.” "

“Two shots fired, I observe,” he noted, handing it back. “Now, madame, if I might see,” he paused delicately. “The servant shall take you,” she murmured, averting her head. The parlourmaid, summoned, led Poirot upstairs. I remained with the lovely and unfortunate woman. It was hard to know whether to speak or remain silent. I essayed one or two general reflections to which she responded absently, and in a very few minutes Poirot rejoined us. “I thank you for all your courtesy, madame. I do not think you need be troubled any further with this matter. By the way, do you know anything of your husband’s financial position?” She shook her head. “Nothing whatever. I am very stupid over business things.” “I see. Then you can give us no clue as to why he suddenly decided to insure his life? He had not done so previously, I understand.” “Well, we had only been married a little over a year. But, as to why he insured his life, it was because he had absolutely made up his mind that he would not live long. He had a strong premonition of his own death. I gather that he had had one hæmorrhage already, and that he knew that another one would prove fatal. I tried to dispel these gloomy fears of his, but without avail. Alas, he was only too right!” Tears in her eyes, she bade us a dignified farewell. Poirot made a characteristic gesture as we walked down the drive together. “Eh bien, that is that! Back to London, my friend, there appears to be no mouse in this mouse-hole. And yet” “Yet what?” “A slight discrepancy, that is all! You noticed it? You did not? Still, life is full of discrepancies, and assuredly the man cannot have taken his own life there is no poison that would fill his mouth with blood. No, no, I must resign myself to the fact that all here is clear and above-board but who is this?” A tall young man was striding up the drive towards us. He passed us without making any sign, but I noted that he was not ill-looking, with a lean, deeply bronzed face that spoke of life in a tropic clime. A gardener who was sweeping up leaves had paused for a minute in his task, and Poirot ran quickly up to him. “Tell me, I pray you, who is that gentleman? Do you know him?” “I don’t remember his name, sir, though I did hear it. He was staying down here last week for a night. Tuesday, it was.” “Quick, mon ami, let us follow him.” We hastened up the drive after the retreating figure. A glimpse of a black-robed figure on the terrace at the side of the house, and our quarry swerved and we after him, so that we were witnesses of the meeting. Mrs. Maltravers almost staggered where she stood, and her face blanched noticeably. “You,” she gasped. “I thought you were on the sea on your way to East Africa?” “I got some news from my lawyers that detained me,” explained the young man. “My old uncle in Scotland died unexpectedly and left me some money. Under the circumstances I thought it better to cancel my passage. Then I saw this bad news in the paper and I came down to see if there was anything I could do. You’ll want some one to look after things for you a bit perhaps.” At that moment they became aware of our presence. Poirot stepped forward, and with many apologies explained that he had left his stick in the hall. Rather reluctantly, it seemed to me, Mrs. Maltravers made the necessary introduction. “Monsieur Poirot, Captain Black.” A few minutes’ chat ensued, in the course of which Poirot elicited the fact that Captain Black was putting up at the Anchor Inn. The missing stick not having been discovered (which was not surprising), Poirot uttered more apologies and we withdrew. We returned to the village at a great pace, and Poirot made a bee line for the Anchor Inn. “Here we establish ourselves until our friend the Captain returns,” he explained. “You notice that I emphasized the point that we were returning to London by the first train? Possibly you thought I meant it. But no you observed Mrs. Maltravers’ face when she caught sight of this young Black? She was clearly taken aback, and he eh bien, he was very devoted, did you not think so? And he was here on Tuesday night the day before Mr. Maltravers died. We must investigate the doings of Captain Black, Hastings.” In about half an hour we espied our quarry approaching the inn. Poirot went out and accosted him and presently brought him up to the room we had engaged. “I have been telling Captain Black of the mission which brings us here,” he explained. “You can understand, monsieur le capitaine, that I am anxious to arrive at Mr. Maltravers’ state of mind immediately before his death, and that at the same time I do not wish to distress Mrs. Maltravers unduly by asking her painful questions. Now, you were here just before the occurrence, and can give us equally valuable information.” “I’ll do anything I can to help you, I’m sure,” replied the young soldier; “but I’m afraid I didn’t notice anything out of the ordinary. You see, although Maltravers was an old friend of my people’s, I didn’t know him very well myself.” “You came down when?” “Tuesday afternoon. I went up to town early Wednesday morning, as my boat sailed from Tilbury about twelve o’clock. But some news I got made me alter my plans, as I dare say you heard me explain to Mrs. Maltravers.” “You were returning to East Africa, I understand?” “Yes. I’ve been out there ever since the War a great country.” “Exactly. Now what was the talk about at dinner on Tuesday night?” “Oh, I don’t know. The usual odd topics. Maltravers asked after my people, and then we discussed the question of German reparations, and then Mrs. Maltravers asked a lot of questions about East Africa, and I told them one or two yarns, that’s about all, I think.” “Thank you.” Poirot was silent for a moment, then he said gently: “With your permission, I should like to try a little experiment. You have told us all that your conscious self knows, I want now to question your subconscious self.” “Psychoanalysis, what?” said Black, with visible alarm. “Oh, no,” said Poirot reassuringly.

"Mademoiselle, would you mind showing me once more the actions you described earlier? You were here working, correct?" Célestine sat, stood up, went to the next room, picked up an item from the dresser, and came back. Poirot watched her closely, also keeping an eye on his bulky pocket watch. "Could you do it one more time, please?" After the repeat performance, he jotted something down in his notebook and put the watch away. "Thank you, mademoiselle. And to you, sir," he nodded at the inspector, "for your cooperation."

"He scrutinized me intently for a few moments. "Indeed. I understand perfectly. And you are wise. Stick to your story," he said. "That seems to be your constant advice," I replied, somewhat annoyed. "Ah, my friend, trust in Papa Poirot. One day, if you allow me, I will arrange a suitable marriage for you." "Thank you," I chuckled, "but the idea doesn't appeal to me." Poirot sighed and shook his head. "The English!" he muttered. "No method at all. They leave everything up to chance!" He furrowed his brow and adjusted the salt cellar. "You mentioned that Mademoiselle Cinderella is staying at the Hôtel d'Angleterre, did you not?" "No. Hôtel du Phare." "Yes, I had forgotten." A brief moment of doubt crossed my mind. Had I ever told Poirot about the hotel? Glancing at him, I felt reassured. He was meticulously cutting his bread into small squares, completely engrossed in the task. He must have assumed I had revealed the girl's whereabouts to him. We had coffee outside, facing the sea. Poirot smoked one of his tiny cigarettes and then checked his watch. "The train to Paris departs at 2:25," he noted. "I should make my way there." "Paris?" I exclaimed. "That's correct, my friend." "You're going to Paris? But why?" He responded gravely. "To find the killer of Mr. Renauld." "Do you think he's in Paris?" "I'm certain he is not. However, that is where I must search for him. You may not understand now, but I will clarify everything in due time. Trust me, this trip to Paris is essential. I won't be gone long. Most likely, I'll be back tomorrow. I don't think you should join me. Stay here, keep an eye on Giraud, and spend time with Mr. Renauld's son. And if you wish, try to win over Mademoiselle Marthe. But I doubt you'll be successful." I wasn't particularly pleased with his last comment. "That reminds me," I interjected. "I wanted to ask you how you knew about those two?" "My friend, I understand human nature. Put a boy like young Renauld together with a beautiful girl like Mademoiselle Marthe, and the outcome is almost inevitable. And then the quarrel! Money or a woman, and given Léonie's account of the boy's anger, I chose the latter. So I made my assumption, and I was right." "So that's why you warned me about getting involved with the lady? You already suspected she had feelings for young Renauld?" Poirot smiled. "At the very least, I noticed her anxious eyes. That's how I always remember Mademoiselle Daubreuil - the girl with the anxious eyes." His tone was so serious that it unsettled me. "What do you mean by that, Poirot?" "I believe, my friend, that we will find out soon enough. But I must depart." "You have plenty of time." "Perhaps, perhaps. But I prefer to have leisure at the station. I don't want to rush or hurry. At any rate," I said, getting up, "I'll come see you off." "You will do no such thing. I forbid it." He was so firm that I stared at him in astonishment. He nodded decisively. "I mean it, my friend. Goodbye! May I shake your hand? Ah, no, I forgot that's not the English way. A handshake, then." I felt somewhat lost after Poirot had left. I walked along the beach, observing the swimmers, without feeling motivated to join them. I had a hunch that Cinderella might be among them, sporting a striking outfit, but I saw no trace of her. I wandered aimlessly towards the end of town. It struck me that it would be the right thing to do to inquire about the girl. It would also save me trouble in the long run. The issue would be resolved. I wouldn't have to worry about her anymore. But if I didn't go at all, she might come looking for me at the Villa. And that would be inconvenient in every way. Clearly, it would be best to pay a brief visit, during which I could make it clear that I couldn't help her further as a showman. So I left the beach and headed inland. I soon reached the Hôtel du Phare, a modest building. It was frustrating not to know the lady's name, and to save face, I decided to step inside and have a look around. Perhaps I would find her in the lounge. Merlinville was a small town - you left your hotel to go to the beach, and you left the beach to return to the hotel. There were no other attractions. A Casino was under construction, but it wasn't finished yet. Since I had walked the length of the beach without spotting her, she must be in the hotel. I entered. Several people were seated in the small lounge, but she wasn't among them. I peeked into other rooms, but she was nowhere to be seen. After waiting for a while, impatience got the better of me. I pulled the concierge aside and discreetly slipped him five francs. "I need to see a lady who is staying here. A young English lady, petite and dark-haired. I'm not entirely sure of her name." The man shook his head, attempting to stifle a grin. "There is no lady here matching your description." "Perhaps she's American," I suggested. These people can be so dense. But the man continued to shake his head. "No, sir. There are only six or seven English and American ladies here, and they are all older than the lady you're looking for. You won't find her here, sir." He was quite certain, which made me doubt myself. "But she told me she was staying here." "You or the lady must have made a mistake, as another gentleman was here asking for her," he revealed. "What do you mean?" I asked, taken aback. "Yes, sir. A gentleman who described her just as you did." "What did he look like?" "He was a small, well-dressed gentleman, very tidy, with a stiff mustache, a peculiarly shaped head, and green eyes." Poirot! So that's why he didn't want me to see him off at the station."

"The revolver at Ealing was a mistake, a clue that led me on the right track. The criminals wanted the police far from Derbyshire, so they planted it there. It wasn't the one used to shoot Mr. Pace, which Mrs. Havering did slyly. Despite Japp's efforts, they escaped justice. But fate caught up with them later. Bond robberies were on the rise, including the disappearance of a million dollars’ worth of Liberty Bonds on the Olympia. Miss Farquhar sought Poirot's help, as her fiancé was blamed for the theft. The bonds were entrusted to him by his uncle, Mr. Vavasour, and disappeared during the voyage."

Upon the recent publication of the great man's daily schedule, I had pinpointed his whereabouts. He was engrossed in dictating to his secretary in his residence. Knowing that a direct approach would be futile, I devised a clever strategy. By utilizing the Marquis of Loamsley's card, I gained access to Lord Nasby. Despite his initial outburst, I managed to present the details of the Mill House Mystery. Lord Nasby's interest was piqued, and he inquired about brachycephalic heads. Although my findings were deemed thin, I boldly requested a position on his paper to further investigate.

"The crime scene was meticulously staged to mislead investigators about the time of death. Madame Renauld, the examining magistrate, and everyone else accepted the initial timeline without question. However, Hercule Poirot, with his keen eye for detail, knew that the truth was being concealed. The doctors' examination of the body revealed that death had actually occurred much earlier than indicated at the crime scene. There was a deliberate effort to create a false narrative, but Poirot was determined to uncover the real timeline of events."

"Blue eyes and a very nice complexion and well, that’s all, I think,” I concluded lamely. “And her husband?” “Oh, he’s quite a nice fellow nothing startling.” “Dark or fair?” “I don’t know betwixt and between, and just an ordinary sort of face.” Poirot nodded. “Yes, there are hundreds of these average men and, anyway, you bring more sympathy and appreciation to your description of women. Do you know anything about these people? Does Parker know them well.” “They are just recent acquaintances, I believe. But surely, Poirot, you don’t think for an instant” Poirot raised his hand. “Tout doucement, mon ami. Have I said that I think anything? All I say is it is a curious story. And there is nothing to throw light upon it; except perhaps the lady’s name, eh, Hastings?” “Her name is Stella,” I said stiffly, “but I don’t see” Poirot interrupted me with a tremendous chuckle. Something seemed to be amusing him vastly. “And Stella means a star, does it not? Famous!” “What on earth” “And stars give light! Voilà! Calm yourself, Hastings. Do not put on that air of injured dignity. Come, we will go to Montagu Mansions and make a few inquiries.” I accompanied him, nothing loath. The Mansions were a handsome block of buildings in excellent repair. A uniformed porter was sunning himself on the threshold, and it was to him that Poirot addressed himself: “Pardon, but could you tell me if a Mr. and Mrs. Robinson reside here?” The porter was a man of few words and apparently of a sour or suspicious disposition. He hardly looked at us and grunted out: “No. 4. Second floor.” “I thank you. Can you tell me how long they have been here?” “Six months.” I started forward in amazement, conscious as I did so of Poirot’s malicious grin. “Impossible,” I cried. “You must be making a mistake.” “Six months.” “Are you sure? The lady I mean is tall and fair with reddish gold hair and” “That’s ’er,” said the porter. “Come in the Michaelmas quarter, they did. Just six months ago.” He appeared to lose interest in us and retreated slowly up the hall. I followed Poirot outside. “Eh bien, Hastings?” my friend demanded slyly. “Are you so sure now that delightful women always speak the truth?” I did not reply. Poirot had steered his way into Brompton Road before I asked him what he was going to do and where we were going. “To the house agents, Hastings. I have a great desire to have a flat in Montagu Mansions. If I am not mistaken, several interesting things will take place there before long.” We were fortunate in our quest. No. 8, on the fourth floor, was to be let furnished at ten guineas a week. Poirot promptly took it for a month. Outside in the street again, he silenced my protests: “But I make money nowadays! Why should I not indulge a whim? By the way, Hastings, have you a revolver?” “Yes somewhere,” I answered, slightly thrilled. “Do you think” “That you will need it? It is quite possible. The idea pleases you, I see. Always the spectacular and romantic appeals to you.” The following day saw us installed in our temporary home. The flat was pleasantly furnished. It occupied the same position in the building as that of the Robinsons, but was two floors higher. The day after our installation was a Sunday. In the afternoon, Poirot left the front door ajar, and summoned me hastily as a bang reverberated from somewhere below. “Look over the banisters. Are those your friends. Do not let them see you.” I craned my neck over the staircase. “That’s them,” I declared in an ungrammatical whisper. “Good. Wait awhile.” About half an hour later, a young woman emerged in brilliant and varied clothing. With a sigh of satisfaction, Poirot tiptoed back into the flat. “C’est ça. After the master and mistress, the maid. The flat should now be empty.” “What are we going to do?” I asked uneasily. Poirot had trotted briskly into the scullery and was hauling at the rope of the coal-lift. “We are about to descend after the method of the dustbins,” he explained cheerfully. “No one will observe us. The Sunday concert, the Sunday ‘afternoon out,’ and finally the Sunday nap after the Sunday dinner of England le rosbif all these will distract attention from the doings of Hercule Poirot. Come, my friend.” He stepped into the rough wooden contrivance and I followed him gingerly. “Are we going to break into the flat?” I asked dubiously. Poirot’s answer was not too reassuring: “Not precisely to-day,” he replied. Pulling on the rope, we descended slowly till we reached the second floor. Poirot uttered an exclamation of satisfaction as he perceived that the wooden door into the scullery was open. “You observe? Never do they bolt these doors in the daytime. And yet anyone could mount or descend as we have done. At night yes though not always then and it is against that that we are going to make provision.” He had drawn some tools from his pocket as he spoke, and at once set deftly to work, his object being to arrange the bolt so that it could be pulled back from the lift. The operation only occupied about three minutes. Then Poirot returned the tools to his pocket, and we reascended once more to our own domain. On Monday Poirot was out all day, but when he returned in the evening he flung himself into his chair with a sigh of satisfaction. “Hastings, shall I recount to you a little history? A story after your own heart and which will remind you of your favourite cinema?” “Go ahead,” I laughed. “I presume that it is a true story, not one of your efforts of fancy.” “It is true enough. Inspector Japp of Scotland Yard will vouch for its accuracy, since it was through his kind offices that it came to my ears. Listen, Hastings. A little over six months ago some important Naval plans were stolen from an American Government department. They showed the position of some of the most important Harbour defences, and would be worth a considerable sum to any foreign Government that of Japan, for example.

I had my suspicions about him, particularly his unwavering insistence on Cabin 17. Maybe it was just his stubborn nature shining through. Stubbornness can be quite the trait. It wouldn't hurt to have a chat with Mr. Chichester, I thought to myself. After a quick fix to my unruly hair, I made my way back up to the deck, determined. Luck was on my side. I spotted my target by the rail, sipping on beef tea. Stepping closer, I addressed him. "I trust you've let go of the Cabin 17 issue," I ventured, flashing a smile. "I believe holding grudges goes against the grain of true forgiveness," Mr. Chichester replied, his tone chilly.

My dear Anne Beddingfeld, I am compelled to reach out to you, not solely for the joy of writing, but for the certain delight it will bring you to receive my message. Our mutual acquaintance Race's intellect may not be as sharp as he believes. I am considering naming you as the executor of my literary works. Enclosed is my personal journal. While it holds no appeal for Race and his associates, I believe you may find some passages entertaining. Feel free to utilize it as you wish. Perhaps a piece for the Daily Budget titled "Encounters with Criminals." I do insist, however, that I remain the focal point.

As he spoke, he flung the door wide and we stepped inside. The chamber M. Renauld had designated as his personal sanctuary was compact, yet adorned with exquisite elegance. A practical writing desk, complete with numerous compartments, occupied the corner by the window. Across from the fireplace, two expansive armchairs clad in leather beckoned, encircling a circular table adorned with the newest publications. Rows of books adorned the walls, while a splendid oak sideboard with a tantalus graced the far end of the room.

A large chintz-covered sofa was placed against the wall, while the window seats were adorned with the same faded chintz fabric. Poirot, with his customary cigarette in hand, proposed a plan to search for a clue in the room. I yanked the cabin trunk closer, my voice sharp as I commanded: "Show yourself now." Silence greeted me. Leaning down, I spotted my unexpected guest motionless beneath the bunk. Was he asleep? I shook his shoulder, but he remained still. "Passed out," I muttered in frustration. Panic set in as I noticed a crimson stain on the floor. With great effort, I pulled the man into the center of the cabin. His pallid face revealed unconsciousness. It didn't take long to locate the source - a brutal wound beneath his left shoulder. Stripping off his jacket, I focused on addressing the injury.
